webTitle: Warm-up game leaves Pakistan frozen out

fields.headline: Warm-up game leaves Pakistan frozen out
fields.standfirst: Connell 44, Bhutia 60, Preece 90
fields.trailText: The surroundings may have bordered on the surreal, with snow swirling down from the Pennines on a freezing wind, but history was made here last night as Pakistan's national team played their first ever game in this country.
fields.body:
The surroundings may have bordered on the surreal, with snow swirling down from the Pennines on a freezing wind, but history was made here last night as Pakistan's national team played their first ever game in this country.

The tourists are more accustomed to the oppressive heat of their training camp in Islamabad, a city basking in 30C temperatures and 43% humidity today. Once recovered from this dose of winter chill, they will play Coventry City on Sunday before their English coach John Layton attempts to negotiate safe passage through a World Cup qualifying group which includes Thailand, Sri Lanka and Lebanon.

Qualification remains unlikely yet the enthusiasm is there to be tapped; last night's match, played as part of Bury's Kick Racism Out of Football campaign, was televised live in Pakistan to an estimated audience of 5m.

In anticipation of the fixture, the Second Division club distributed leaflets throughout Asian communities from Oldham to Bradford. The traditional hamburger joints were replaced with takeaway curry stalls while the Pakistani crescent moon and star fluttered in the stands.

"We are hoping that the Asian people who came to see their national team will see what a safe, friendly environment there is here at Bury and will come again," said the Shakers' chairman Terry Robinson. Bury took their first step along that road last season when they became the first British club to sign an Asian player - the Indian international Baichung Bhutia. The striker, a star to rival David Beckham in his homeland, was a whirl of clever spins and neat passes on the Gigg Lane quagmire.

"It will be a slow process attracting Asian support because they do not have a strong affinity with football," added Robinson, "but we feel this is a worthwhile exercise."

Quite what the millions watching back in Pakistan made of the defeat remains a mystery. Pakistan are currently ranked 191st out of 203 in the world. From such minnow status they look up to the footballing giants of Djibouti and the Seychelles while hardly scoffing at the impudence of lowly Nicaragua and Guam.

Last night they were made to look as ordinary as that sounds by a Shakers XI of barely reserve-team strength. With cricket Pakistan's main sport, the tourists have a smaller pool of talent to draw on than the Second Division club.

Yet their style showed flashes of class while they struggled to come to terms with the conditions. Zafar Majeed and Gohar Zaman were nimble down either flank and Mohammad Riaz, marauding forward from midfield, missed the best chance of a bad-tempered first half before Lee Connell speared Bury ahead.

Bhutia bundled home Bury's second and, by the time the player-manager Andy Preece curled an injury-time third, Pakistan were betraying heavy legs as the 741 "away" fans in the 1,292 crowd continued their boisterous party.

"Football is only played in four or five centres, but every one has heard of the likes of Beckham and Michael Owen," said the tourists' assistant coach Akhtar Mohy-ud-Din.

"What we need is a more competitive structure because at the moment we only have two competitions - the President's Cup and the National Championship. There are 24 teams in each tournament, but the events are only held over a period of 20 days."

At least the grassroots appear to be quietly taking hold; Pakistan's Under-19s recently beat India for the first time in over 40 years. There were enough glimpses here to suggest a footballing future.

fields.headline: Hague censured by parliamentary watchdog
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader, William Hague, was today censured by the Commons standards commissioner Elizabeth Filkin for misleading entries in the register of members interests.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader, William Hague, was today censured by the Commons standards commissioner Elizabeth Filkin for misleading entries in the register of members interests.

She found that for two years the Tory leader had been incorrectly claiming that all speaking fees he earned were directed through the "William Hague charitable trust" to deserving causes in his Richmond constituency. In fact, the trust had never been set up.

However, Ms Filkin recommended no action be take against Mr Hague as the entries were recorded "in good faith" and entries were not intended to be misleading.

There was no evidence of "irregularity or impropriety" in the uses the fees were put to, she added.

But she said: "Mr Hague failed to respond correctly on eight separate occasions when required to check his entry, with the result that it continued in a materially inaccurate form for a considerable period - at least six months and arguably longer."

The Labour MP, Fraser Kemp - who made the complaint to the standards and privileges committee after the oversight was exposed on the Mark Thomas Product, a Channel 4 comedy show - demanded that the Conservative leader make an apology to the Commons at today's prime minister's questions.

He said: "William Hague must now apologise to the house. This is the second time he has been censured by the committee on standards and privileges.

"This report shows that William Hague received money from speaking engagements and told parliament this money was going to charity for over a year when in reality the cheques were gathering dust in his office drawer."

A spokesman for Mr Hague said: "We have nothing to add to the contents of the report."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Gay and Jeremy
fields.trailText: How are you enjoying Cairns? Just wanted to say that, like you, I don't like putting my head under the water, but, with the excellent instruction and advice from our guide on our trip to the reef I gave it a try.
fields.body:
Hi Sue

How are you enjoying Cairns? Just wanted to say that, like you, I don't like putting my head under the water, but, with the excellent instruction and advice from our guide on our trip to the reef I gave it a try. First time for me (four years ago) and I wished that I had tried it before. I felt quite safe even going "over the shelf", although a yard or two was enough to remind me that the sea bed was a long way down! Around the corals it was quite beautiful. We saw some beautiful fish, sea anemones and so on.

Continue to enjoy your adventure.

fields.headline: Rebels offer ceasefire in Macedonia
fields.standfirst: Special report
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanian rebels have tonight offered a unilateral ceasefire in their battle against the army and police in Macedonia, just hours before the expiration of a government ultimatum demanding they lay down their arms.     The concession was offered by Ali Ahmeti, the political head of the National Liberation Army, in a television broadcast in neighbouring Kosovo.
fields.body:
Ethnic Albanian rebels have tonight offered a unilateral ceasefire in their battle against the army and police in Macedonia, just hours before the expiration of a government ultimatum demanding they lay down their arms. The concession was offered by Ali Ahmeti, the political head of the National Liberation Army, in a television broadcast in neighbouring Kosovo.

"We, the general staff of the National Liberation Army, announce a unilateral ceasefire and we open the road for dialogue so heads can cool down and to find the best solution," he said.

He said the ceasefire was open ended, but warned that in case of attack the four-week-old struggle would continue.

"In case our positions are threatened by our opponents, then all our forces will be on the move and the conflict would widen," he said, in the taped broadcast.

"We have repeated constantly and will repeat again that we are for dialogue," he said. "We are not for a war that would create rivers of blood between two nations, because the reason for dialogue would be lost in that case."

There was no immediate government reaction to the offer, made public less than five hours before the expiry of a government deadline to the rebels to lay down their arms and disperse or face a full counterattack.

Earlier today, a rebel commander who gave his name only as Sokoli told local media in Kosovo that the insurgents had no intention of surrendering.

The government issued the ultimatum beginning at midnight Tuesday and telling the rebels they had 24 hours to lay down their weapons and surrender or leave Macedonia. After that, said the government, the army and police would launch an offensive to push the insurgents northward toward Kosovo, and out of Macedonia.

Macedonian army sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, later said that the military had spotted a "huge group" of Albanian insurgents on the Kosovo border apparently preparing to cross into Macedonia.

Several hours before the ultimatum was issued, army cannon targeting rebels on hillsides just north of Tetovo fell silent and the calm near Macedonia's second-largest city held into this afternoon. But in a sign that the conflict could spill over to the Macedonian capital, a police officer was shot and killed when a group of policemen were attacked in the Albanian quarter of Skopje.

fields.headline: Goram signs for Manchester United
fields.trailText: Manchester United have solved their goalkeeping crisis by signing Andy Goram on loan. The Premiership leaders have agreed to pay Motherwell £100,000 to borrow the 36-year-old former Rangers and Scotland goalkeeper.
fields.body:
Manchester United have solved their goalkeeping crisis by signing Andy Goram on loan. The Premiership leaders have agreed to pay Motherwell £100,000 to borrow the 36-year-old former Rangers and Scotland goalkeeper.

United had received Uefa's permission to sign a goalkeeper on loan with the injured Fabien Barthez and Raimond van der Gouw doubtful for the Champions League quarter-finals against Bayern Munich.

Goram's Motherwell contract expires in the summer but the United deal is for three months only.

Motherwell's director of football Pat Nevin, who had initially rejected such a move, said: "The deal is agreed. Now it is a question of getting the paperwork done."

He added: "We came to an agreement. It's a perfectly sensible. It's a clever piece of lateral thinking by United. They needed a goalkeeper short-term and someone who will be able to cope with the big atmosphere.

"They have got the right man and it is fantastic move for him as well. There was no way we could stand in his way and all three parties are happy now."

webTitle: Health workers to benefit most from housing fund

fields.headline: Health workers to benefit most from housing fund
fields.trailText: Health workers look set to be the main beneficiaries of a £250m fund set up to help solve the housing crisis for public sector key workers.
fields.body:
Health workers look set to be the main beneficiaries of a £250m fund set up to help solve the housing crisis for public sector key workers.

The government has shortlisted 175 from 200 initial bids for its starter home initiative, which aims to help 10,000 nurses, teachers, police officers and other key workers over the next three years. The Department for the Environment, Transport and the Region has revealed that bids were mostly led by housing associations, but NHS trusts, police constabularies and education authorities also made bids.

Half of the bids were targeted at London, where the high price of housing is the main source of a growing recruiting crisis for key workers. Of the London bids it has emerged that 18.7% were for nurses, 17.6% were for other health workers, 31.6% were for police officers, 24.8% were for teachers, and 7.1% were for other key workers.

The initiative has been heavily oversubscribed: the value of the first wave of bids amounted to £830m. That has now been whittled down to £580m, but the government must narrow this list further, down to a total of £250m. An announcement on the successful schemes is expected in June.

Announcing the shortlist, junior housing minister Bob Ainsworth said: "There is significant competition for funding, with the value of bids going through to stage two more than double the available budget."

He added: "Bidders predominantly propose using interest free equity loans or shared ownership to assist purchasing existing or newly built properties."

Dino Patel, policy officer at the London Housing Federation, said: "We welcome the starter homes initiative. It is desperately needed, especially in London where we are losing a lot of key workers. Businesses are increasingly recognising that housing is a key determinant in people taking up jobs. More than a third of business are concerned about the lack of affordable housing."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Kelly
fields.trailText: Lake Taupo is beautiful, as is Napier if you like art deco (and very well restored). You can visit vineyards in Hawkes Bay, and I'd recommend the views from Te Mata Peak just inland from Napier. I have relatives there and enjoyed many summers in my childhood on the beaches on the east coast, and also in the Bay of Islands.
fields.body:
Hi Sue!

Just to echo what Andrea said about New Zealand and to add a few more suggestions. Lake Taupo is beautiful, as is Napier if you like art deco (and very well restored). You can visit vineyards in Hawkes Bay, and I'd recommend the views from Te Mata Peak just inland from Napier. I have relatives there and enjoyed many summers in my childhood on the beaches on the east coast, and also in the Bay of Islands. Rotorua on the other hand is very touristy (the town itself is not up to much) but I'd still go, as the Thermal Wonderland pools are amazing and well worth the visit.

As for the South Island, the Abel Tasman (even just for a day walk) Milford Sound and Queenstown are compulsory viewing! Really in NZ the list of 'must sees' is endless Have a great time! And keep taking lots of lovely pictures.

fields.headline: NUJ slams Desmond interference
fields.trailText:
Wednesday 6.15pm: The NUJ has issued a plea to the independent editorial board of Express Newspapers, writes Julia Day
Mar 19: NUJ calls for Express action
Mar 21: Fraser gave up £1.2m company for Desmond
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The NUJ has issued a plea to the independent editorial board of Express Newspapers to address allegations of Richard Desmond's interference in editorial decision-making.

Jeremy Dear, the NUJ's national newspaper organiser, sent a letter to the members of the board on March 16 urging them to convene a meeting with the editors of the papers to address the issue.

The letter says: "A recent article in the New Statesman alleges instances of interference of the sort that we understood the board has been appointed to ensure did not happen."

Mr Dear also sets out concerns that Mr Desmond's role in editorial decision-making is undermining the credibility of the paper.

The union also wants the board to intervene in the row over Mr Desmond's plans to make 145 redundancies across the Express titles.

The letter continues: "In addition we are also most concerned that the editorial content and quality of the newspapers in this group will be damaged as a consequence of the latest round of redundancies."

Mr Desmond set up the editorial board after taking over the newspapers to maintain and uphold the editorial integrity of the titles.

The move was also seen as an attempt to fend off criticism that editorial quality would suffer under his stewardship.

The board includes Arthur Davidson QC, a former Labour MP, Barbara Thomas, a former News International director, and Jonathan Holborow , former editor of the Mail on Sunday.

A spokeswoman for the company said the NUJ was misguided about the purpose of the editorial board.

And she dismissed claims that there was any inappropriate "interference" by Mr Desmond.

"The editorial board was set up for the editors and the editors only. It will formally convene should any issues arise regarding undue interference.

"They have met informally on several occasions but they have not met formally because the need hasn't arisen," she said.

In the meantime, it emerged that celebrity photographer Jason Fraser, is taking on wider responsibilities at the paper.

In addition to his picture desk role, he will become involved in newsdesk activities, helping establish the news agenda for the day.

Under the deal he will also become involved in the commercial activities of the paper making presentations to investors and advertisers.

webTitle: Spurs say £18,700 in drawer was for charity

fields.headline: Spurs say £18,700 in drawer was for charity
fields.trailText: Tottenham's money-in-a-drawer mystery appeared to be solved tonight when the club issued a statement saying it had been their regular practice to impose cash fines on players and donate the proceeds to charity.
fields.body:
Tottenham's money-in-a-drawer mystery appeared to be solved tonight when the club issued a statement saying it had been their regular practice to impose cash fines on players and donate the proceeds to charity.

The statement responded to a story by the Daily Mirror which said that the club's new owner, ENIC, had launched an internal inquiry after a tin stuffed with £18,700 in cash had been found in a drawer in the office of the club secretary four days after George Graham had been sacked as manager.

Graham, who departed White Hart Lane last Friday, had reacted by accusing ENIC of trying to smear him through leaks to the press.

The Spurs statement said: "The cash in question is as a result of fining players in cash for misdemeanours, this has been a practice at the club for a number of years. At the end of each season all monies are donated to charity.

"The cash was not suddenly found in a drawer, as the Mirror claims. It was kept in a strong box in the club secretary's office and obviously its purpose, existence and whereabouts were known.

"We were not asked to comment in advance, nor is the club aware of the source of this information. We are actively conducting our own investigation on that point."

Earlier Graham's solicitors had issued a statement which said the cash, collected by the club secretary John Alexander, was destined for the Richard House Trust Children's Hospice, after Great Ormond Street Hospital had benefited last year.

It added that: "Mr Graham is disappointed that the club should now be feigning concern and using this scheme as a pretext to try and denigrate his character in the newspapers.

"Having supposedly sacked him for revealing confidential information it is surprising that once again the club is prepared to run its affairs through the leak of internal club information to the press."

The Mirror report had alleged that on one occasion the England Under-21 Ben Thatcher was fined £9,500 and told by Graham to go to his bank and return with the money.

Premiership clubs normally deduct fines from a player's wages. Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association, said: "If such large sums have been demanded from players and paid in cash it is an extraordinary occurrence and I've never heard of it before."

The statement responded to a story by the Daily Mirror which said that the club's new owner, ENIC, had launched an internal inquiry after a tin stuffed with £18,700 in cash had been found in a drawer in the office of the club secretary four days after George Graham had been sacked as manager. Graham, who departed White Hart Lane last Friday, had reacted by accusing ENIC of trying to smear him through leaks to the press. The Spurs statement said: "The cash in question is as a result of fining players in cash for misdemeanours, this has been a practice at the club for a number of years. At the end of each season all monies are donated to charity. "The cash was not suddenly found in a drawer, as the Mirror claims. It was kept in a strong box in the club secretary's office and obviously its purpose, existence and whereabouts were known. "We were not asked to comment in advance, nor is the club aware of the source of this information. We are actively conducting our own investigation on that point." Earlier Graham's solicitors had issued a statement which said the cash, collected by the club secretary John Alexander, was destined for the Richard House Trust Children's Hospice, after Great Ormond Street Hospital had benefited last year. It added that: "Mr Graham is disappointed that the club should now be feigning concern and using this scheme as a pretext to try and denigrate his character in the newspapers. "Having supposedly sacked him for revealing confidential information it is surprising that once again the club is prepared to run its affairs through the leak of internal club information to the press." The Mirror report had alleged that on one occasion the England Under-21 Ben Thatcher was fined £9,500 and told by Graham to go to his bank and return with the money. Premiership clubs normally deduct fines from a player's wages. Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association, said: "If such large sums have been demanded from players and paid in cash it is an extraordinary occurrence and I've never heard of it before."

fields.headline: Scottish minister speaks out
fields.standfirst: The minister for finance and local government talks to Simon Parker about the future of Scotland's local authorities
fields.trailText: The minister for finance and local government talks to Simon Parker about the future of Scotland's local authorities.
fields.body:
It's said that many of the policies you've implemented since becoming finance and local government minister are based on those of your predecessors Frank McAveety and Jack McConnell. When do we start to see your policies coming through, and what will they be? What's your vision for Scottish local government?

Ministers don't have individual policies. We are delivering the Scottish executive's policies as an administration. Our objective for local government is that it should be highly valued by the consumers of its services and that these services should provide value for money and be competitive with services provided in any other sector. In terms of the delivery of these services, I think a mixed economy can have benefits - but my very clear preference is for public sector delivery.

The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) has been badly shaken by the string of councils that have recently pulled out or threatened to do so. Does the executive still think Cosla is a representative and important voice for local government? How will you deal with Glasgow now it has pulled out? Do you give any credence to the suggestion that the convention's recent troubles are partly due to an SNP conspiracy?

No, because for many local authorities Cosla is a representative and important voice for local government. All authorities will be dealt with in the same way as before. In matters of collective importance to councils we will deal with Cosla, in matters of clearly local significance we will talk to individual authorities, as we have in the past. It's business as usual with a level playing field for all authorities and no special favours.

The issue of local government proportional representation (PR) in Scotland has been off the agenda recently, despite being in your partnership agreement with the Lib Dems. The coalition is already coming under strain over the fishing industry - can it survive what seems like an inevitable confrontation over PR? Are you a supporter of PR?

We recently published Working Together for Scotland, a document that committed us to continuing to make progress on electoral reform. We have a ministerial working group that is looking at a range of issues relating to local government. So, no policy area is being ignored - I don't think the Liberal Democrats would agree that PR has been off the agenda recently. In recent weeks we have seen some of the more serious stresses and strains that can come with systems that are not first past the post. What is critically important at this stage, is that the Scottish parliament demonstrates that an alternative system can be made to work well.

It's widely accepted that local government finance in England and Scotland is in need of reform. But you've been accused of fudging this issue, and you've got a Scottish parliamentary committee producing its own reform proposals. Is the three-year settlement and the abolition of spending guidelines as far as it goes - or have you got something else up your sleeve? If so, when might we see it?

First, I'm not sure it is widely accepted that council finance is in need of reform. I know it's discussed in fairly specific places - not usually in general conversation though! I'm also not aware of having been particularly, or widely, accused of having fudged the issue. I welcome the parliament's local government committee carrying out an inquiry and I'm looking forward to cooperating with it. We have still got issues to consider - on reducing ring-fencing, the distinction between capital and revenue, on the relationship between economic development and non-domestic rating returns and on council tax collection rates, for example.

You have a reputation for being a local government moderniser and your former council is now operating a cabinet. Do you support the executive's decision not to allow referendums for directly elected mayors (or provosts) in Scottish councils? Shouldn't people have the choice? Or do Scottish authorities not need this kind of reform?

The key thing is to ensure councils have the kind of political structures that enable them to work best. In that context, there might be a place for elected mayors, but I am not aware of significant pressure from anywhere in Scotland to have this option available.

Unison's strikes ended recently. What is the executive doing to make sure this kind of industrial action isn't repeated at the next pay round? It looks as though Unison's action did win them some gains in the end - is this an example of local government employers being held to ransom and giving in?

Pay negotiations in local government are rightly a matter for unions and employees - not the executive. As to the terms of the agreement, I'm afraid you will need to ask the participants to the negotiations and agreement as to their views on the ultimate outcome.

The executive has always had a very close relationship with Scottish local government. As the parliament develops and you have to start taking big decisions on issues such as PR and finance, do you think you can maintain those close ties? If the SNP wins control of more councils at the next election, will you be able to work with them constructively?

Local government has a crucial role to play in post-parliament Scotland. It is the key vehicle for the delivery of so many of our policies and that is why a close and positive relationship must be maintained. We will always seek to work constructively with all of Scotland's councils, irrespective of their political hue. There will be no selective punishment as there was under the Tories. Whether the SNP is willing to work constructively with the executive is a matter for them.

webTitle: Diary of a social services director: overview

fields.headline: Diary of a social services director: overview
fields.trailText: Lisa Christensen's diary aims to give readers a 'warts and all' view of the pressurised environment of a social services department that is being monitored by the social services inspectorate.
fields.body:
Lisa Christensen had been in her post as social services director of Lambeth council for a year when she started writing the diary of a monitored social services authority. The aim of the diary was to give readers a "warts and all" view of what it was like to work in the pressurised environment of a social services department. But not just any old social services department - one that was under the spotlight, criticised in the media and monitored by the Social Services Inspectorate (SSI).

The diary has covered a period characterised - in the words of Ms Christensen - by "trauma and hope".

It began on a high note with a new head of children's services being appointed. This was significant, as the post had not been properly filled following the suspension and dismissal of the previous assistant director. And children's services were not only without a boss but in a terrible state - which was the main reason for the authority being on "special measures" (monitored by the SSI for the previous 10 months).

Ms Christensen has since flagged up signs of hope. Her department has been awarded a "comparatively reasonable" performance in the government's Performance Assessment Framework (PAF) league tables, and she has made considerable progress in rebuilding the children's services management team. The department is also increasingly more able to produce reliable performance information.

She has also highlighted improvements in "joined up" working with health and housing colleagues, a surprisingly positive experience when meeting with the government's adoption taskforce, and weekly meetings with small groups of staff to talk through the vision, values and direction. The picture is of a slow but steady reinvigoration of what has been a dismal and unconfident department.

Alongside this has come the, possibly inevitable, "dark moments of disappointment" for Ms Christensen and her staff. Most serious was the announcement of ministerial instructions (or "directions") under the Local Authority Social Services Act 1970. Ms Christensen also wrote of the "swoop" of the adoption task force, the seemingly endless rounds of action plans and the insatiable appetite of (understandably) anxious external authorities to have yet more evidence of improvement as quickly as possible.

A sense appears in the diary of two strands of concurrent activity - busy activity to ensure service improvements and then scurrying around to ensure that monitoring is undertaken and statistics are produced. On occasions, there is a hint of frustration at wanting to get on with the business of delivering and improving services, and having to constantly produce information for different monitoring bodies. One diary entry described how Ms Christensen spent nearly half her time one week poring over the same set of data with several different audiences.

The overarching hope expressed in the diaries is that confidence will be rebuilt and the emphasis will shift more to the actual doing than to the reporting of what's being done. However, the diary has been very upfront in acknowledging that confidence has to be earned, following the very public shaming of the department's record of past failings.

The diary provokes questions about how many others are in the same boat - and how government and the inspection regime will respond to make sure that the needs of vulnerable children, adults and their families are addressed in a way that is synonymous with a civilised society. It offers a compelling glimpse of life in a modern social services department under pressure in Britain today - where the certainty of safe practice, dealing with recruitment difficulties and tussling with the budget are all routine fodder for the director.

fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague demanded new urgency in dealing with the outbreak yesterday. These are the points he made and agriculture minister, Nick Brown's replies
fields.body:
William Hague demanded new urgency in dealing with the outbreak yesterday. These are the points he made and agriculture minister, Nick Brown's replies

Hague: Allow vets to authorise slaughter on suspicion of disease.

Brown: Already happens in 80% of cases, where there is uncertainty samples are sent to lab.

Hague: Bring in vets from abroad.

Brown: Seventy have already arrived, 10 more yesterday, and 30 in the next few days. Any more welcome.

Hague: Use final year veterinary students

Brown: 120 already working, another 80 recruited.

Hague: Bury more carcasses to remove backlog

Brown: Already doing so where possible but constraints because of water contamination and lack of depth of soil in Cumbria.

Hague: Bring in the army.

Brown: Already using army vets and army logistics experts. Shortage of expertise rather than manpower is the problem.

Hague: More support for stricken farmers and rural businesses.

Brown: Meacher helping small businesses, farm subsidies being brought forward with EU approval

Hague: Put off local elections.

Brown: Never been done except in wartime.

fields.headline: A homosexual Speaker
fields.standfirst:
The raw fear that George Thomas felt is now just a historical curiosity

Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: The raw fear that George Thomas felt is now just a historical curiosity.
fields.body:
The most remarkable thing about the revelation this week that the late George Thomas, the former Speaker of the House of Commons, was a secret homosexual is the almost complete lack of surprise or attention that this "news" has provoked. It has landed upon the public consciousness with all the impact of a blancmange dropped from a great height.

There could not be a more telling contrast between this and the image conjured up of the late Viscount Tonypandy as a man who lived in such trembling terror of disclosure that even the breath of another man's scandal turned him to jelly.

Apart from a few middle-aged investigative journalists with a specific interest in the event, the hidden truth has been of apparent little interest to anyone. It is perhaps scarcely suprising to learn that a man who died a bachelor in his late eighties and whose main interest in women seems to have been centred around his own mother and the Queen's turns out, after all, to have been a homosexual.

It feels inappropriate in this context to use the word "gay". According to the account provided by his lifelong friend Leo Abse, the former Labour MP who introduced the legislation to legalise homosexuality, George Thomas lived his life shrouded by guilt and repression and fear. Mr Abse has tweaked the curtain of history with his account of repeated attempts at blackmail, of one threat so dreadful that Thomas had to borrow £800 to resettle the blackmailer in Australia, of the pitiful shame of venereal disease.

He reminded us of the fear in which so many homosexuals, and particularly those in public life, were obliged to conduct themselves, even after the law had been changed to lift the certainty of prosecution. No, not "gay", not for them. Not for George Thomas the comfortable public acceptance of the acknowledged homosexuality of prominent politicians today: the culture secretary Chris Smith, the junior minister Angela Eagle, even the new mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delanoe.

In Britain, at least, it is a fairly recent development that this should be so and in political terms it is obviously a healthy one. Anything which encourages politicians to be a little more honest must be good for democracy. It is worth remembering that it is less than 10 years since at least one prominent politician very specifically registered an anxiety that the exposure of his private life to public scrutiny might affect his political future.

When Peter Mandelson was first looking for a seat in the House of Commons it is said that one of his friends asked what he would say if a Labour party selection conference questioned him about being gay. "I should deny it," he reportedly said. He may subsequently have been "outed" against his wishes, but it has had little impact. It was not his personal sexual proclivities that has defined the course of his public career.

The one truly strange episode recounted by Mr Abse in a new chapter of his psychological biography of the prime minister (Tony Blair, The Man Behind The Smile), concerns the former Liberal party leader Jeremy Thorpe. Mr Abse was summoned to Speaker's House in 1976 where he found Mr Speaker Thomas "grey-faced and trembling" as a result of inquiries by investigative journalists into the allegations by the notorious Norman Scott about a homosexual conspiracy that stretched like a web through the fabric of British politics.

The journalists were, in reality, on to something. It took all Mr Abse's strategic skills to help the Speaker fob them off and a couple of weeks for Mr Thomas to regain his equanimity. It is a footnote in history now. But history would have been different if we had learned more of the truth at the time.

webTitle: Blair refuses to budge from May 3 election date

fields.headline: Blair refuses to budge from May 3 election date
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday left no doubt in any wavering MP's mind that he is determined to stage the May 3 general election
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday left no doubt in any wavering MP's mind that he is determined to stage the May 3 general election he has planned for so long rather than delay it until the summer or autumn.

Apart from polling day itself only one other date in the coming campaign calendar is certain, Thursday April 5, when parliament must be dissolved, exactly 17 working days before the election.

In fact, there are four weekends and two bank holidays between the two dates - as well as Maundy Thursday which for reasons of arcane electoral law does not count as a working day either.

With Labour fearful of voter apathy and a low turnout that damages its prospects without a single defector to the William Hague-led Tories, it still leaves Mr Blair and his party rivals plenty of scope for tactical maneouvre.

Crucial among those will be the exact date that Mr Blair emerges from No 10 to tell the waiting cameras that he is paying an unscheduled trip to Buckingham Palace - grinning as to what exactly he will ask the Queen to do. That ritual will probably occur on Thursday, March 29, on Friday or, as one Whitehall rumour has it, on Saturday, March 31.

That last option is "very remote", some insiders said, because it would give Labour's diehard enemies in the nihilistic Sunday papers first bite at the campaign story.

It could be as late as Monday, April 2, as the Sun reported yesterday when it announced on its front page "Election Day: Official - May 3" adding "Sun Was Right All Along".

But it is not yet official and the Sun has been no more right than most MPs and media. It would also leave only three days for parliamentary work to tie up the few bills that will have to be pushed through parliament by April 5. Most important is the finance bill which implements Gordon Brown's latest tax cuts.

But, whether Thatcherite or Blairite, the Sun likes to be on the winning side. Its assertion will help to create the public mood of inevitability which Downing Street strategists want to foster, to neutralise disquiet which surfaced in today's Guardian/ICM poll.

Despite the horrors of the foot and mouth outbreak, those at Labour headquarters at Millbank have have always been determined to press ahead with the timetable towards which they will have been working for four years and two days since their 1997 landslide victory.

The reasons are not hard to fathom. Official figures for unemployment have just dipped below 1m for the first time in 25 years. Inflation is below 2.5%, interest rates are low and the economy is buoyant.

This could change if falling stock market prices in the US affect the UK whose trade, overseas profits and wider economic cycle is more aligned with the economy of America than the rest of the EU.

The last time it sought re-election with a three figure Commons majority in 1970 Murphy's Law derailed Harold Wilson in the shape of some Boeing aircraft imports and industrial diamonds which undermined the May monthly balance of payment figures and helped let in Ted Heath.

Easter Sunday intervenes on April 16 creating a problem for party managers seeking to maintain momentum. Last night no one was saying when the three parties would hold their launches. Usually they are coordinated to give each a fair chance of publicity on successive days, possibly April 9, 10 and 11.

"That is a tactical decision," one Downing Street insider said last night. There will be plenty more of those.

webTitle: Kennedy issues challenge on climate change

fields.headline: Kennedy issues challenge on climate change
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy yesterday moved to raise his profile ahead of the coming election by challenging Tony Blair to tell US president George Bush that his new administration's views on climate change were "out of step" with the rest of the world.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy yesterday moved to raise his profile ahead of the coming election by challenging Tony Blair to tell US president George Bush that his new administration's views on climate change were "out of step" with the rest of the world.

Mocking Ronald Reagan's famous disdain for environmental concerns - "a tree's a tree, how many do you need to look at?" he said when told of plans to expand the Redwood national park in California - the Liberal Democrat leader welcomed what he tartly described as Mr Blair's "recent" conversion to the green cause.

Mr Kennedy has been criticised for his low profile since succeeding Paddy Ashdown as party leader 18 months ago and for not being tough enough on Labour.

He blamed European ministers, including John Prescott, for not arranging a deal to ratify the Kyoto agreement on climate change targets at The Hague last year at a time when Bill Clinton was still president. He said: "I was seriously disappointed at their weakness in allowing the US to get away with having killed the deal."

But his harshest words were reserved for the new US administration. "Last week President Bush wrote to four US senators spelling out his opposition to the Kyoto protocol. I challenge the prime minister to make it clear to President Bush that his views are out of step with other world leaders."

This weekend's Stockholm summit gives EU leaders a "perfect opportunity" to speak out, he said. Mr Kennedy singled out the prime minister's speech earlier this month, only his second on the environment since 1997.

"Only time will tell how long this new found interest continues. But we do have evidence now of Labour's record. Before the last general election the prime minister pledged to put the environment at the heart of government," Mr Kennedy said.

"Yet four years later the number of car journeys have risen, fuel duty has just been cut, a massive programme of road building has been announced and the election pledge for a 20% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 has been downgraded to nothing more than an aspiration," he told a meeting of the Green Alliance in London.

Lib Dem policy, he explained, was not just to meet the 2010 target relating to carbon dioxide emissions - but to further reduce it by 1.5% a year up to 2050.

Fishermen. A package of financial assistance for fishermen, laid off as a result of EU stock conservation measures, will be announced "within days", deputy chief whip Lord Carter told peers.

fields.headline: French are Blair's summit target
fields.standfirst:
Attacking protectionism may boost Labour vote

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's hope of using this weekend's European Union economic summit in Stockholm to boost the efficiency of the European economy was dashed yesterday
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and Michael White  in London
fields.body:
Tony Blair's hope of using this weekend's European Union economic summit in Stockholm to boost the efficiency of the European economy was dashed yesterday when France signalled its refusal to open its energy markets as Britain and Germany have done.

The prime minister - whose electricity in Downing Street is supplied by a French firm - flies to the Swedish capital tomorrow night with Robin Cook and Keith Vaz, the embattled minister for Europe.

They want to consolidate a range of liberalisation policies, including such "real people issues" as cheaper phonecalls, electricity and air fares. Also on the list are less expensive cars: Britain's own dealer cartel pushes up the average car price by 10%.

Briefing reporters in Downing Street before the summit, senior officials brushed aside complaints yesterday by the European Round Table of Industrialists that the EU's programme of economic reforms, designed to catch up with US levels of competitiveness, was moving too slowly.

Now that the US economy, so long the motor of world growth, is entering a slow-down or even a recession, EU leaders will show whether they can meet the challenge of global leadership by improving Europe's growth rates.

But even as officials rattled off impressive statistics about falling prices to consumers in Europe - and held out the prospect of EU-wide recognition of qualifications for professionals and plumbers alike - the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was pouring cold water on an important British objective: opening up the energy sector.

Mr Blair's spokesman said that for the first time one-third of France's notoriously protected electricity market was being opened to competition But, speaking in Brussels, Mr Jospin took issue with a 2005 deadline to fully liberalise the gas and electricity sectors, as proposed by the European commission.

"We think that the question cannot be put exclusively in terms of fixing early dates for liberalisation," he insisted after talks with the commission president, Romano Prodi.

France's position puts it at odds with Britain and most other EU member states, which pledged at last year's "dot.com" economic summit in Lisbon to make Europe the "most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the world over the next 10 years".

Tony Blair wants the energy deadline brought forward to 2003. "There will be quite a row about this," a senior diplomat predicted last night.

Mr Blair may not be averse to that: a row in Stockholm might help him show he is standing up for Britain's interests - and its voters' cheaper utility prices - in the run-up to a general election campaign in which William Hague hopes to play the Euro-card.

In Brussels, a British official said: "Energy is a small part of the overall picture but it's something where we can make real progress and show that Europe is capable of delivering tangible value."

Germany and Britain have already fully liberalised their energy markets, but France, where state-controlled firms dominate, has stuck to the EU law's minimum requirement that 30% of the electricity market must be open to supply by a foreign provider. The figure for gas is 20% .

Mr Jospin's protectionism on energy and French support for a welfare-centred social agenda will put a damper on a summit already criticised for lacking a focused theme.

Tony Blair wants to use Stockholm to show that Britain's concern for market reforms and greater flexibility - on which he outperformed the French at Lisbon and again at Nice - is setting the agenda in the EU.

He has launched a series of bilateral initiatives to set a direction that emphasises job creation, competitiveness and social cohesion. There is even a plan for Europe-wide financial prospectuses to make it simpler to raise capital, especially venture funds. Results since Lisbon have been mixed. On the plus side, Europe has created 2.5m new jobs and its economy grew by almost 3.5% last year, its best performance in 10 years.

Its growth this year has, at 3%, been projected to overtake that of the US, but a slowing world economy could prevent that. And many internal barriers remain in the union, where 14m people are still out of work : double the level of the US and Japan.

Officials in Brussels say the single most important outcome of the next two days in Stockholm is likely to be agreement on financial services - crucial for capital markets and cheaper finance.

Britain is pushing for an emphasis on skills and employability, as well as the key question of labour market mobility, allowing EU citizens to take their pensions anywhere in the union.

Cutting red tape is another priority - a task where business organisations consider Brussels less than expert.

France is likely to hit back at Britain by attacking its record on the liberalisation of postal services, another Lisbon target. Mr Blair has argued for the special rural needs for post offices.

Likely diversions during the two-day summit include the crisis in Macedonia, BSE and the foot and mouth crisis for the livestock business, and meetings with an invited guest, the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.

Sweden, the summit host, hopes the session with Mr Putin will be the start of a meaningful dialogue on economic and political issues, including plans to expand the EU to countries that used to be part of the Soviet Union or the Soviet bloc.

fields.headline: Mr Byers bites back
fields.standfirst:
Yet another twist to the Robinson affair

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Zinoviev letter it is not. The Daily Mail's serialisation of Tom Bower's book about Geoffrey Robinson MP is tendentious and partisan and clearly aimed at destabilising the government.
fields.body:
The Zinoviev letter it is not. The Daily Mail's serialisation of Tom Bower's book about Geoffrey Robinson MP is tendentious and partisan and clearly aimed at destabilising the government - in the hope, perhaps, of knocking a few points off its polling lead.

But the Rothermere family's previous discovery of smoking-gun correspondence in the 1920s had some public point to it, fictional though the Soviet connection turned out to be. This one is strictly ad hominem, even if the Robinson saga does raise points of public order. Did a discredited ex-minister receive a payment for services rendered from a deceased media magnate 11 years ago? The fate of Robert Maxwell's Hollis engineering company is historically trivial. What Geoffrey Robinson subsequently said or did is pretty small beer, too, since he is out of power and certain not to return.

The issue that is, potentially, significant is whether, at Mr Robinson's behest, the chancellor and the trade secretary acted in a way that affronts the common sense of appropriate conduct by ministers. "Common sense" does not, these days, set the bar high. The public seems not to care much about the recent sequence of charges against Labour ministers; that is either because its confidence in the probity of politicians is already low or because it is ready to trade off a healthy dislike of pelf against its still robust sense of Labour's competence.

On the Bower charge sheet, ministers' offences include the "browbeating" of the former permanent secretary at the Treasury. But Lord Burns is a big boy who, ideologically sympatico or not, had taken his knocks at the hands of Margaret Thatcher and also survived Black Wednesday. So what if he had some heated exchanges with either Gordon Brown or Mr Robinson?

More important by far is the allegation that the minister with statutory responsibility for policing the companies acts buried findings of fact by inspectors that told against Mr Robinson's tale. In a capitalist society unreliable rule-makers potentially damage all private traders, for directors, shareholders and customers all depend on the fair adjudication of corporate conduct. Of course Stephen Byers is also a politician who has no business being in the game if he cannot field the brickbats without running for cover under the libel laws. But good government depends on clean hands. Mr Byers does not just have his own reputation but the good name of the Department of Trade and Industry to protect; he must show that established procedure was followed to the letter and officials were not nudged into saving their minister's blushes.

Geoffrey Robinson may now face further inquiry into his chequered financial affairs by the Commons. Eternal investigation may be his fate, perhaps proving that business practice (of his kind) and elective politics are incompatible. Gordon Brown stands charged of little more than the heinous offence of writing a press release. He would be better advised to concentrate on that blip in the inflation figures registered yesterday. But Stephen Byers represents the entire Blair government in this matter, which is why Number 10 has implicitly associated itself with his threat to sue the Daily Mail, if an apology is not forthcoming.

Having made the threat, he will doubtless feel bound to go through with it, since to retract would suggest either some acceptance of charges against him or fear of the Mail. If Mr Bower or the paper has the goods they will fight, win and deservedly damage the government. If they do not, some fortunate charity could be in line to pocket a tidy donation.

fields.headline: Their lips are sealed
fields.standfirst:
What peers do not want us to know

Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: For centuries the connection between the giving of money and receiving of honours has been a murky one.
fields.body:
For centuries the connection between the giving of money and receiving of honours has been a murky one. This government has moved further than most in the direction of limited transparency, but the suspicion still lingers that a generous donation to a political party may subsequently be rewarded by some sort of embellishment to one's name. If true, this would, of course, be a scandal. Not even in Zimbabwe can one - yet - buy a seat in the legislature.

Since political parties are notoriously ungenerous in allowing access to information on this subject, it struck us as a good idea to do a little original research of our own. We wrote to all peers created since 1995 asking two simple questions: had they ever given money to a political party, and, if so, how much?

We might have saved on effort and postage stamps. Out of a total of 250 life peers, 92 failed to respond at all, while another 34 refused to take part. One comservative peer, Baroness Fookes, de clined to answer unless a payment was made to the charity of her choice. The Labour whips office, meanwhile, advised all its own peers to refuse to take part. Even Lord Ashcroft, the outstandingly generous Conservative party treasurer, was more open.

There is something both dismal and arrogant about this collective response. Peers make laws. They are - or should be - in some sense accountable. The fact that they are unelected should make them doubly conscious of this fact. To have them blithely thumbing their noses at newspapers asking perfectly legitimate questions is not an attractive sight.

At some point in the next parliament the prime minister will have to decide about the future composition and role of the upper house. Questions of legitimacy and accountability are fundamental to any consideration of what should come next. Behaviour of this sort by unelected peers may simply hasten the day when they should be replaced by elected ones.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Lambs reared for mint sauce are now cuddled on the news

fields.headline: Lambs reared for mint sauce are now cuddled on the news
fields.standfirst:
It is instructive to look closely at the non-existent plight of farmers

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: It is instructive to look closely at the non-existent plight of farmers
fields.body:
Has the country ground to a halt, lights out, closed for business, a nation in deadly quarantine? Watching the nightly news, that is what townies and the world outside think, as reporters stand by burning pyres, intoning purple prose that would better suit the floods, fever and famine found aplenty among humans elsewhere. Mad reporter disease has seized the BBC as they stand in the few crisis areas wringing their hands in the flickering flames, stricken with a verbal dose of the Fergal Keanes.

How bad is it out there? For the farmers waiting for slaughter or left with bloated dead cows for days before incineration, it is a disgusting disaster to live near. But this is not the plague. People are not dead. (The 79-year-old Devon farmer who drank near-lethal disinfectant out of fear his cattle might catch it, is in a stable condition. His family says he's been depressed since Christmas.)

Is the countryside paralysed? Not really. No schools are closed, no country pubs shut, mail and milk is delivered everywhere. Smoke is not billowing from coast to coast. Pyres are hard to find, even in Cumbria where the tourist board and county council are outraged at the impression given that it is closed for business: it is not.

Maff says fell-walking continues so long as rules are obeyed, lakes are open: travel from Carlisle to Keswick and you pass no smoke. Parts of south Dumfries, north Cumbria and a bit of Devon are badly affected, but elsewhere, Maff insists, life goes on, apart from small patches around an outbreak. Only 1% of the nation's livestock is affected - still minor compared with the same stage in the 1967 outbreak: 12 new cases a day now, 77 then. As for the reported £9bn cost of this - it is the kind of nonsense figure thrown up in every crisis.

All proportion and perspective has been lost. Everyone sympathises with farmers who lose precious blood-lines and have to start again in the midst of an agricultural recession. But they get full compensation. The tragedy is not on the scale of the 6,000 steel workers or the swaths of textile and car workers who have lost their livelihoods in the past year, for much the same reasons as the agricultural depression - high sterling and failing to join the euro. Those were one-day news stories, with no camera- grabbing fires to mark the moment. Unpaid mortgages and the silent drop from decent pay to a minimum wage is not telegenic.

The latest annual agricultural figures have just been posted on the Maff website. They make interesting reading. Agriculture now accounts for just 0.8% of GDP. The total workforce is 2% and falling. As farmers cut costs, they shed 11% of paid farm workers last year, but in England and Wales land values have shot up 10.7% per hectare. In real terms, assets rose, while debts fell. Since 1995 farming has been in sharp recession - but that came after a rapid boom: it averages out at a 40% increase since 1990, not too bad. Meanwhile, the total subsidy farmers received last year was £3.1bn - which is more than all subsidy for all other industries put together. Averages are unfair and there are some very poor struggling farmers, just as there are poor corner shopkeepers alongside rich supermarkets: while life is tough for marginal tenant farmers, the rich owner- farmers - who get most of the subsidy - saw their capital wealth grow hugely, again.

Turn to the National Farmers Union website and there is today's impassioned plea from their leader: "the prime minister is urged to give a glimmer of hope through the gloom" in this "soul-devouring crisis" where many are "suffering the torture of worrying where the disease will strike next". "Dark days are stretching ahead of farmers and many are at their wits end, not knowing how they are going to make ends meet." They demand more from the government: what is euphemistically called an "adjustment" to the sheep annual premium, "a recovery package would at least to give farmers hope to carry on", begging for a "scheme to help farmers retire". Retire? What of the other one third of pensioners who retire with no savings? Down on the farm they live by other rules, in which ordinary state benefits levels are not enough.

Why, on top of compensation, do they expect more than anyone else? Why - even odder - does the government keep on doling it out? Since 1997 Labour has has shelled out £1.2bn on top of the common agricultural policy (CAP), with another £1.6bn promised from last October. If ever there was a prime example of the Tory view that subsidies corrupt and distort, it is in farming. Farmers do not insure against disasters like any other business because the state always compensates them for bad luck or bad farming. Maff itself admits there is considerable incentive to fraud in the subsidies - and it happens.

CAP pays out for production, needed or not, so most goes to the big barley barons. But 20% could be diverted to environmental purposes instead - guarding hedgerows, coppices, forests and heathland, creating field margins for wild flowers, building dry stone walls and a countryside fit for townie tourists. Poor farmers should get more subsidy to do this work. But, frightened of the big boys, Labour only dares divert 2.5% away from unwanted production into environmental subsidies, though even France diverts its full 20% from production.

Perhaps it is because farmers own three quarters of Britain's land mass that they mesmerise the nation. Whether it is the Countryside Alliance on the hoof, fuel protesters in tractors, new demands for extra compen sation, or slow-hand claps for the chief vet, they lack any idea of how they look to the rest of the nation. Nightly watching them weep over animals destined to be eaten, cuddling lambs reared for mint sauce is bizarre.

William Hague says: "The rural way of life is under threat from urban values, Islington pressure groups and a metropolitan elite who know nothing of the countryside." Well, the view from Lambeth (in my case) is that we are learning a great deal more about the countryside than we did. The louder they shout for more, the closer we examine what they get already - and how they farm.

On average country-dwellers are healthier, happier, safer, better educated and richer than urban-dwellers. More than half British people wish they lived in the country, but can't afford to join this genuine elite. Disappearing post offices and shops, or outbreaks of animal disease are sad - but on the scale of human pain or national emergency, rural discomfort is a small tear in the chintz of the nation's social fabric.

As the Guardian's campaign on bare, ruined public services shows, everywhere there is a desperate need to repair the damage of a 20-year stand-still. Uneducated youth, badly cared for old age, 2,000 wasteland urban estates, transport in meltdown, prisons with reoffending designed in, squalid urban space and low national ambition and expectation. But dead cows on pyres grip the news night after night.

fields.headline: Precious little giving
fields.standfirst: While pensioners and children donate generously to charities, our millionaires hoard their money
fields.trailText: While pensioners and children donate generously to charities, our millionaires hoard their money
fields.body:
Like millions of others, I watched a good chunk of Comic Relief the other day. Like, I suspect, very few others, I watched it with a rising sense of disgust.

No, it wasn't flagging celebrities using the good name of "charidee" to resuscitate their careers which had me shouting at the TV. Nor was it the tasteless jumps from pictures of African deprivation to clips of "the best in British comedy" which made me shudder.

No, what truly enraged me was the money. For the TV telethon raised a pathetically small amount -£25m so far - and most of it from the wrong people.

Every arm-twisting appeal from Ant and Dec was calculated to persuade another child to give up his pocket money, just as each guilt-trip from Graham Norton pressured a pensioner to pledge a couple of quid she couldn't spare. Like the lottery, disproportionately played by those who are most hard-up, Comic Relief is one of those national whip-rounds where the poorest end up paying the most.

And, as the hard-earned donations came in, the same question nagged: where are the rich?

Of course, there were individuals who did their bit: JK Rowling and Helen Fielding had nobly written new mini-books, especially for Comic Relief. But where were the big battalions, the corporate giants with mega-money? Where were they?

Persil made a brief appearance, their logo emblazoned atop a terrifyingly large pair of pants. For that free advertisement on the BBC, the company had given the princely sum of £300,000: how tiny the stain that gift would have left on Unilever's annual profits of £1.73bn. British Telecom made nearly £3bn last year, but they stumped up just £350,000 - slightly more than the money they had made from viewers' calls to Comic Relief. BT insists the law forced them to charge 10p for each one of those calls. But they could have at least doubled the public's money, matching it penny for penny.

Perhaps we shouldn't single out these companies. After all, most of Britain's top brand names are just as stingy. BP posted profits this year of a staggering £7.88bn. Yet how much did they give away? A measly £47.5m, around half of 1%, with just £3.7m spent in the UK.

This, it seems, is the British corporate habit: to give the bare minimum you can possibly get away with. I remember meeting a fundraiser who works with Britain's homeless. She told me proudly that ICI had given "five hundred". I asked if this was £500,000 a year or in total. "Oh, no," she laughed. "Five hundred pounds." That was the sum of their generosity.

Our richest individuals, with a few admirable exceptions, are no better. Anita Roddick wins plaudits for her Body Shop Foundation, Elton John has done his bit for Aids research while Paul Hamlyn, Cameron Mackintosh and computer tycoon Peter Ogden have all reached into their pockets. But the more common picture is of a fat, tight fist.

Witness the hosannas offered in thanks to the Duke of Westminster last week for tossing £500,000 to farmers in distress over foot and mouth. For a man estimated to be worth £3.75bn, that amounted to finding a 2p piece in the sofa. Prince Charles gave farmers the same amount - or rather "gave". In fact that non-princely sum did not come from HRH's own pocket at all, but from charities he heads. For the media bounce he got out of it, it was other people's money well spent.

Yet the dukes are no worse than the commoners. The last time a biggest givers' list was compiled was 1994: the rich did not like their miserliness exposed and refused to cooperate after that. But the list still makes revealing reading. Way out in front was George Soros, who gave a whopping £100m. All the other donors combined could not match him. Together they gave a paltry £75m.

For once it may be centrally relevant that Soros was not born in this country. For the billionaire financier has a distinctly non-British attitude to philanthropy. He gives like an American. There, the wealthy are much less shy about their generosity. On the contrary, they positively revel in it. That's why the Chronicle of Philanthropy can publish its annual "Most Generous" list, in which America's billionaires jostle for top spot by giving ever vaster sums to charity.

Number one this year, as always, is Bill Gates and wife Melinda, whose personal foundation is now worth $21bn. Gates says he wants to give almost all his eye-popping fortune away in his lifetime, and to that end he has hired his father to spend his billions on good works - chiefly on world health, from Aids to malaria. His best-known rival is CNN founder Ted Turner who also likes the grand gesture, including one $1bn gift to the United Nations.

This is just the way Americans do things - and always have. Turner and Gates are the heirs of the Mellons, Carnegies and Rockefellers: super-rich families who dedicated as much energy to giving away their wealth as to earning it. It's telling that one of Britain's most reliable benefactors is John Paul Getty: an American.

The US charitable habit is partly rooted in religious tradition but also in the country's approach to government. An unspoken contract exists: the rich are taxed lightly and, in return, they make a hefty contribution through philanthropy. Proof that the attitude lives on has come recently with the billionaires' rebellion against George W Bush and his $1.6 trillion tax cut. They don't like the president's proposal to abolish inheritance duty. Gates Snr, Warren Buffett and the rest of the Croesus club reckon such a move would create a new, unAmerican aristocracy of wealthy kids who haven't earned their fortunes for themselves. But the billionaires also insist that any tax cuts should be aimed at the poor, not them; and that abolishing estate duty will remove the current, tax-avoiding incentive for the rich to give their fortunes away to charity before they die.

This is not the ethos of our rich. And yet it should be. For thanks to Thatcherism and its successors, Britain's rich are not taxed heavily either. Like Americans, and unlike Europeans, they are allowed to keep much more of their own money. But while they grab this side of the American bargain -low taxes - they don't seem too keen on the other. They take the tax break but won't give the charity.

Now might be a good time to start asking the rich to cough up. For one thing, there are more of them - with 200,000 millionaires in Britain now, twice the 1996 number. Add to that this week's Guardian exposé of the rundown state of our national infrastructure - including universities, which could do with a dash of US-style generosity from their most affluent alumni. And tomorrow the prime minister will report on the state of social exclusion in Britain - the teen parents, school truants and homeless youngsters. Across the ocean, society's most blessed would see those problems as a personal responsibility they should meet. Here they sit back and count their money - leaving a few comedians to squeeze pennies from the poor.

fields.headline: Ticket to slide
fields.trailText: With railways run by men who think a super saver is the person who cuts passengers out of the wreckage, the profit motive has not enjoyed a run of good publicity lately.
fields.body:
It is heartening but not surprising to read that the bulk of British people have had enough of privatisation. With railways run by men who think a super saver is the person who cuts passengers out of the wreckage, the profit motive has not enjoyed a run of good publicity lately.

I suspect that many rail passengers would also prefer the old surly and drably clad guard of yesteryear to what is now called the "Customer Operations Leader". That's not a job; it's just three random words strung together. He might as well announce himself as the Drummer Crisps Sandal. We want someone who gives the impression that he might know something about trains, not a man who looks and sounds like a holiday rep. The creative use of mauve does nothing for our confidence in our short-term future.

Londoners clearly want the underground to be run by the state. They will be highly bemused by John Prescott hiring as a spin-doctor a mate who has been lobbying him on behalf of consortia bidding to run the tube and air traffic control. Companies pay a man to advise a friend in government to consider their bids, and then the man gets a job advising his friend. Not what you might call an uphill struggle his career, is it?

The soundings put out by Prescott to bring private companies into the tube have been highly secret. However, I can exclusively reveal that some of the responses might have been as follows:

"Yes, sure. What's the tube?"

"How about turning it into luxury basement flats?"

"What's in it for us?"

"When you say safe, how safe does it have to be?"

Of course, the railways, schools and hospitals do need money, and private business has it. The question is how we get hold of it. We'd save an awful lot of bother if we just took it. After all, businessmen rely on the state to educate, nurse and transport the workforce. If companies want their staff delivered promptly and in one piece every morning, they should pay up. I'm not saying London Underground should threaten to act like a private company and start killing the passengers; I just mean the private sector needs the public sector more than the other way around.

Partnerships and the private finance initiative have done no more for the profit motive's reputation than has wholesale privatisation. They are so clearly schemes for handing public money to building firms that there is no question about the government's ideological position. It believes in transferring risk on to private contractors, who in turn transfer it on to train passengers.

The government is hostile to public ownership and holds private business in utter reverence. Capitalists receive so many state benefits that the rest of us are entitled to demand that they be humiliated by Department of Social Security officers from time to time. Balfour Beatty shareholders should be made to attend Restart interviews. Actually, what with export credit guarantees, businessmen are probably entitled to more state handouts than they are aware of. Perhaps they lose more in unclaimed benefits than they gain in tax breaks.

Apparently, the polls show that some privatisation is to our liking, notably that of BT. This, I don't understand. Why should hundreds of young Glaswegians go through the humiliation of having to ring customers at all hours to ask if we want any more friends or family? Is this the rationale behind teenage chat-lines - to train a whole generation of young people for a future making needless phone calls? Is this what we want for our children?

And frankly, the time one spends fielding calls from people telling us how we can save money more than outweighs the benefits of any possible saving. Let us seize back the utilities that once were our birthright, and no longer be pestered by desperate youngsters asking us of we want our gas supplied by the water board or our electricity delivered by Pizza Hut. I imagine that, after Prescott's chum has finished lobbying for the air traffic sell-off, Nats will be replaced by a call centre, and pilots will receive random radio transmissions advising them on how they could save lives by crashing in the sea.

Mind you, while Ken Livingstone is battling with Prescott over the tube, he is himself privatising policing. Private security is visible all over London, though why Trafalgar Square needs bouncers I don't know. Too many jeans and trainer, perhaps. But shouldn't the public own the means of repression? At least the real cops throw us down the stairs; private ones will probably drop us.

comment@theguardian.com
fields.bodyText: It is heartening but not surprising to read that the bulk of British people have had enough of privatisation. With railways run by men who think a super saver is the person who cuts passengers out of the wreckage, the profit motive has not enjoyed a run of good publicity lately. I suspect that many rail passengers would also prefer the old surly and drably clad guard of yesteryear to what is now called the "Customer Operations Leader". That's not a job; it's just three random words strung together. He might as well announce himself as the Drummer Crisps Sandal. We want someone who gives the impression that he might know something about trains, not a man who looks and sounds like a holiday rep. The creative use of mauve does nothing for our confidence in our short-term future. Londoners clearly want the underground to be run by the state. They will be highly bemused by John Prescott hiring as a spin-doctor a mate who has been lobbying him on behalf of consortia bidding to run the tube and air traffic control. Companies pay a man to advise a friend in government to consider their bids, and then the man gets a job advising his friend. Not what you might call an uphill struggle his career, is it? The soundings put out by Prescott to bring private companies into the tube have been highly secret. However, I can exclusively reveal that some of the responses might have been as follows: "Yes, sure. What's the tube?" "How about turning it into luxury basement flats?" "What's in it for us?" "When you say safe, how safe does it have to be?" Of course, the railways, schools and hospitals do need money, and private business has it. The question is how we get hold of it.
