webTitle: Why Tony turns to God at election time

fields.headline: Why Tony turns to God at election time
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair starts talking about God, you can guess that a general election is imminent. In 1996, as Labour prepared for the last campaign, he discussed his Christian faith in a lengthy interview with the Sunday Telegraph. His advisers were said to be appalled. Yet now he has made another divine intervention, in an even longer interview with the same paper.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair starts talking about God, you can guess that a general election is imminent. In 1996, as Labour prepared for the last campaign, he discussed his Christian faith in a lengthy interview with the Sunday Telegraph. His advisers were said to be appalled. Yet now he has made another divine intervention, in an even longer interview with the same paper.

One effect of his 1996 remarks was to emphasise the contrast between "the Revd ARP Blair, MA Oxon" - a man who can quote Nietzsche and Meacher with equal fluency - and John Major. That was certainly how they were interpreted by Major. "I don't pretend to understand all of the complex parts of Christian theology," he retaliated rather huffily, "but I accept it."

One can't help suspecting a similar purpose now. William Hague may be a wiz on the judo mat, but it's hard to imagine him ever saying this: "There is a very interesting debate which I used to study at university - I was not interested in it then but I'm interested now - between the concept of natural law and utilitarianism. I've shifted far more towards the first, having been for a long time the second. I'm far more of a believer in the power and the necessity to make judgments about the human condition, as opposed to simply saying, 'Well, look, what's good for the greatest number is fine.' "

Although the Sunday Telegraph suggests that Blair's philosophical conversion from utilitarianism to natural law is recent, it certainly predates his election as Labour leader. In the preface to Reclaiming the Ground, a book of essays published in 1993, he wrote that "Christianity is a tough religion, even though it may not always be practised as such. It places a duty, an imperative on us . . . It is not utilitarian - though socialism can be explained in those terms. It is judgmental. There is right and wrong." And it upheld "principles of living that are timeless".

Medieval natural law, promulgated by Thomas Aquinas, was essentially a way of disguising individual prejudice with mystical mumbo-jumbo so that it could be passed off as an eternal verity. As Aquinas explained, law is natural because it is "a purpose implanted by the Divine art". Citizens had no rights, merely duties. It was not until the Enlightenment that a more positive and secular version of natural law emerged, giving rise to such revolutionary concepts as human rights. After a long hiatus, these theories are now being revived and embellished: more than two dozen books on natural law have been published in the US over the past few years. Feminists, animal lovers and crusaders against oppression use their own interpretation of natural law to demand certain universal standards of conduct.

Fair enough - even if codified "natural rights" are not necessarily progressive, still less immutable. (Think of the pre-eminence granted to property rights in America; or of the famous 1905 decision by the US supreme court to strike down a statute limiting bakers' working week to 60 hours, on the grounds that it infringed the right to "freedom of contract".) But is this what Blair means?

I think not: he started talking about "the necessity to make judgments about the human condition" in reply to a question about his religion. Just as Blair's crude summary of utilitarianism appears to be based on the old Benthamite recipe - with a spoonful of John Stuart Mill for seasoning - so his natural law harks back to Aquinas. These, too, have enjoyed something of a revival lately - almost exclusively among rightwing Catholic theologians and pundits who wish to justify intolerance of "deviations" such as homosexuality and impose an unquestionable moral authority.

Cherie Booth and her children are RCs, and the prime minister himself has attended Catholic mass. Although Blair insists elsewhere in the Sunday Telegraph interview that he's "very normal", he is manifestly not: few if any British politicians hold forth about stern theological imperatives. On mainland Europe, however, there are plenty who do. They are called Christian Democrats. Can another name change for the Labour Party be far behind?

Forsyth's best fiction yet

As Libby Brooks pointed out in Monday's paper, Frederick Forsyth is remarkably generous with his opinions. Since he gave up writing thrillers, soon after Labour's victory, he has been as prolific as Dr Raj Persaud and Keith Flett put together, writing scores of newspaper polemics, letters to editors and lectures for the Today programme. He has also acquired a taste for public speaking: two weeks ago he warned an audience at a golf club in Essex that if Labour won the next election, Tony Blair would introduce "neo-communism" in Britain.

Fans of Forsyth may feel they have heard this before. In his novel The Fourth Protocol, the KGB smuggles an agent into Britain shortly before the 1987 election. His task is to detonate a nuclear device in Suffolk, which will somehow scare millions into voting Labour. After the victory, Neil Kinnock will be deposed and replaced by "Britain's first Marxist-Leninist premier" - Ken Livingstone.

Like many "political thrillers", The Fourth Protocol is deeply unthrilling and politically absurd. Nevertheless, Forsyth tried to give his fiction an air of verisimilitude by using real people - most famously De Gaulle - and boring us rigid with his research into the specifications of Heckler and Koch sub-machine guns. Details such as this allowed publishers to hint that Forsyth's novels expressed a truth so explosive it could only be told as fiction.

His non-fiction, paradoxically, becomes increasingly unreal. Soon after the foot and mouth epidemic began, he wrote to the Mail asking why Labour had refused to ban meat imports from South Africa until last December, even though the disease had been rife there since September. "Was not Nelson Mandela destined to grace the Labour conference in October? It is perfectly feasible that an infected, packaged product was imported here before Christmas and released into the environment last week." So much for the method; what about motive? Simple: the Countryside March, which was "known to have terrified this government", would have to be called off.

If the pig-poisoning, neo- communist Blair does win a second term, perhaps Forsyth will return to penning quasi-plausible thrillers - instead of producing fiction so preposterous it can only be written as journalism.

Poll vault

The News of the World calls its latest ICM poll "a devastating blow to William Hague". The survey discovers that "just 31% of voters have heard of shadow health secretary Liam Fox. Shadow education secretary Theresa May and shadow defence secretary Iain Duncan-Smith are recognised by only 36%."

Amazing indeed: but what are those words "just" and "only" doing there? Not long ago, when the London Evening Standard showed photos of the shadow cabinet to 30 people in the street, the only one who recognised Fox was a Lib Dem activist. The public's sudden awareness of these figures fully explains the poll's other finding: that Labour will win the election with a majority of 179.

fields.headline: 'Blank cheque' aid to rural communities
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The government yesterday took the extraordinary step of offering what amounted to a blank cheque to struggling rural communities when it promised to match every pound donated by the public to ease the plight of farmers and their neighbours.
fields.body:
The government yesterday took the extraordinary step of offering what amounted to a blank cheque to struggling rural communities when it promised to match every pound donated by the public to ease the plight of farmers and their neighbours.

Michael Meacher, environment minister, made the pledge as part of a multi-million pound package designed to restore tourism in stricken areas - and some unaffected ones which have overreacted - as well as easing the cashflow problems of small rural businesses hurt by the foot and mouth outbreak.

In his Commons statement the minister did not put a total cost on the package, nor say specifically what charities and voluntary bodies would benefit from the matching funds. He did say the Prince of Wales's £500,000 gift, matched already by the Duke of Westminster, would be counted.

The Rural Stress Network, under pressure since the outbreak, the Samaritans and Action for Communities in Rural England, are among those to benefit. Privately officials later included even the £2.1m so far raised by readers of the Daily Mail, possibly a shrewd move which might neutralise the anti-Labour propaganda use which the flagship Tory tabloid has made of the crisis.

Tens of thousands of small businesses will benefit from the government's package and rate relief, initially a Tory suggestion, will run into tens of millions of pounds, officials conceded. "It is going to be demand-led on a case by case basis," officials said. A telephone helpline, with "significant manpower", is to be set up this week to advise tourists where they can safely go. An advertising campaign, starting tomorrow, will hammer home the message - telling people not to go near livestock, but to go anywhere safe.

 The foot and mouth outbreak will not stop the census being conducted on schedule throughout England and Wales next month, the chief national statistician said yesterday.

About 63,000 volunteers had been due to hand deliver census forms to every home on April 29 as part of the national statistical stocktaking con-ducted every 10 years.

Len Cook, the national statistician, said the £225m project would go ahead with special arrangements for the handover of forms at farm boundaries, or by post. He added: "Census takers working in the countryside will respect all foot and mouth restrictions, whether statutory or otherwise imposed."

webTitle: Blair defies voters' no to May poll

fields.headline: Blair defies voters' no to May poll
fields.standfirst:
Blair defies voters' no to May poll

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is poised to defy growing public concern over the foot and mouth crisis by pressing ahead with his planned May 3 general election despite mounting Tory attacks and a new Guardian poll indicating that a majority of voters now believe the campaign should be postponed.
fields.byline: Alan Travis, Lucy Ward  and Paul Brown
fields.body:
Tony Blair is poised to defy growing public concern over the foot and mouth crisis by pressing ahead with his planned May 3 general election despite mounting Tory attacks and a new Guardian poll indicating that a majority of voters now believe the campaign should be postponed.

The ICM poll confirms a hardening of the sudden swing in opinion against a May election in the last 10 days, with 52% of voters saying the election should be postponed and only 40% saying it should go ahead.

A hint that Labour may pay a price for Mr Blair's determination to stick to his original election timetable also emerges from the poll. Labour is three points down on last month at 44% while the Tories are up by the same amount to 35%, narrowing Labour's lead from 15 to nine points.

The number of foot and mouth outbreaks rose dramatically yesterday with 46 confirmed new cases, topping the previous daily record of 28 and bringing the total number of cases to 395. Four suspected cases were also identified in the Netherlands, which has so far been free of the disease.

The poll findings came as the Conservative leader, William Hague, moved on to the offensive over the crisis for the first time. Without directly calling for the postponement which Tory strategists would love to see, he argued that an election would be inappropriate unless the epidemic was brought under control.

Mr Hague explicitly called for emergency legislation this week to permit the delay of county council elections in worst-hit areas, such as Devon and Cumbria. "We are not going down that road," No 10 said later. Delay would send "the worst possible signal" of panic in Britain to the outside world, Mr Blair's aides said.

As the Tories called for more widespread deployment of troops to help bury animal carcasses, the government fought back. A multimillion pound aid package for businesses affected by the outbreak, drawn up by the Rural Task Force, included a government pledge to match public donations made to ease "rural distress".

Officials confirmed that the sum involved - effectively a blank cheque - would run into millions, including match funding for the Prince of Wales and Duke of Westminster's donations of £500,000 apiece, and the £2.1m raised by the Daily Mail.

There will also be rate relief for small businesses in local authorities in areas worst hit by the crisis, which will total tens of millions of pounds, as well as permission for councils to defer payment of business rates.

The government is planning a national advertising campaign explaining which areas are safe to visit and stressing the benefits tourists can bring to the countryside.

English Heritage and the National Trust are to reopen 350 properties between now and April 1, British Waterways will begin opening canals next week, and local councils and the national parks will consider which footpaths should now be opened.

Downing Street also announced plans to recruit more vets, license five more rendering plants to deal with carcasses, reduce the time vets have to be quarantined between farm visits and hold discussions centred on a central tariff for animal valuations to speed up slaughter.

While the Guardian poll showed opposition to a May election edging over 50%, opinion does split along predictable party lines with a majority of Labour voters urging Mr Blair to go ahead now and Conservative and Liberal Democrat supporters urging postponement.

If there were a general election tomorrow on the voting intentions shown in the poll, Mr Blair would be back in Downing Street with a majority of around 145.

ICM's "variometer", which takes account of regional differences in swing, estimates that Labour would return 402 MPs, the Conservatives 201, the Liberal Democrats 27, and the nationalist parties 10. William Hague's survival would be in doubt.

Further evidence that foot and mouth crisis has not yet proved politically disastrous for the government is also shown by the response of voters when they were asked whether they approved or disapproved of the way the government had handled the outbreak.

The replies were fairly evenly split with 46% of voters saying they disapproved and 39% saying they approved. Although the verdict does tend to split along the party political preferences of voters, there is still a significant minority of Labour voters (31%) who are unhappy with the government's handling of the crisis.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between March 16 and 18, 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

As the Tories called for more widespread deployment of troops to help bury animal carcasses, the government fought back. A multimillion pound aid package for businesses affected by the outbreak, drawn up by the Rural Task Force, included a government pledge to match public donations made to ease "rural distress". Officials confirmed that the sum involved - effectively a blank cheque - would run into millions, including match funding for the Prince of Wales and Duke of Westminster's donations of £500,000 apiece, and the £2.1m raised by the Daily Mail. There will also be rate relief for small businesses in local authorities in areas worst hit by the crisis, which will total tens of millions of pounds, as well as permission for councils to defer payment of business rates. The government is planning a national advertising campaign explaining which areas are safe to visit and stressing the benefits tourists can bring to the countryside. English Heritage and the National Trust are to reopen 350 properties between now and April 1, British Waterways will begin opening canals next week, and local councils and the national parks will consider which footpaths should now be opened. Downing Street also announced plans to recruit more vets, license five more rendering plants to deal with carcasses, reduce the time vets have to be quarantined between farm visits and hold discussions centred on a central tariff for animal valuations to speed up slaughter. While the Guardian poll showed opposition to a May election edging over 50%, opinion does split along predictable party lines with a majority of Labour voters urging Mr Blair to go ahead now and Conservative and Liberal Democrat supporters urging postponement. If there were a general election tomorrow on the voting intentions shown in the poll, Mr Blair would be back in Downing Street with a majority of around 145. ICM's "variometer", which takes account of regional differences in swing, estimates that Labour would return 402 MPs, the Conservatives 201, the Liberal Democrats 27, and the nationalist parties 10. William Hague's survival would be in doubt. Further evidence that foot and mouth crisis has not yet proved politically disastrous for the government is also shown by the response of voters when they were asked whether they approved or disapproved of the way the government had handled the outbreak. The replies were fairly evenly split with 46% of voters saying they disapproved and 39% saying they approved. Although the verdict does tend to split along the party political preferences of voters, there is still a significant minority of Labour voters (31%) who are unhappy with the government's handling of the crisis.  ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between March 16 and 18, 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults. What's going on? webTitle: Census takers allow for farm restrictions

fields.headline: Census takers allow for farm restrictions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth outbreak will not stop the census being conducted on schedule throughout England and Wales next month, the chief national statistician said yesterday.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth outbreak will not stop the census being conducted on schedule throughout England and Wales next month, the chief national statistician said yesterday.

About 63,000 volunteers had been due to hand deliver census forms to every home on April 29 as part of the national statistical stocktaking conducted every 10 years.

There were fears that this could not be done without breaking restrictions on movement in the infected areas or reducing the validity of the census by exempting hard hit parts of the country.

Len Cook, the national statistician, said the £225m project would go ahead with special arrangements for the handover of forms at farm boundaries, or by post.

Census day will come four days before May 3, widely assumed to be Tony Blair's favourite date for a general election, disease restrictions permitting.

Mr Cook said: "Census takers working in the countryside will respect all foot and mouth restrictions, whether statutory or otherwise imposed.

"I am conscious of the distress and difficulty the disease is causing, and we shall do nothing that might contribute to its spread.

"Census enumerators are local people, working in local communities, in local conditions".

He said that new arrangements were being put in place so that census forms could be delivered by post or at farm boundaries.

"Census takers are being instructed to be flexible in arranging the delivery of forms. On no account will they use taped-off thoroughfares or pass warning signs. They will comply at all times with local disinfecting requirements," he said.

"People in rural England and Wales have responded particularly well in past censuses and this makes it possible to introduce a much more flexible approach to counting people in these parts of the country, in response to the outbreak."

Barney Holbeche, head of parliamentary affairs at the National Farmers' Union of England and Wales, welcomed the plans.

He said: "We are grateful to the census organisers for recognising the need to minimise any risk of further spreading infection.

"It is important that this exercise is conducted in a sensitive manner at this time of great stress for farmers, and we will be working with the census takers to facilitate this process."

webTitle: Hague raises the stakes on poll issue

fields.headline: Hague raises the stakes on poll issue
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday raised the stakes in the political manoeuvring behind the foot and mouth crisis when he insisted a general election could not be held when the disease remained "out of control".
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday raised the stakes in the political manoeuvring behind the foot and mouth crisis when he insisted a general election could not be held when the disease remained "out of control".

The Conservative leader's direct challenge to the government, backed up with calls for plans for the delay of county council elections in worst hit areas, marks a calculated but risky shift to the offensive for the Tories after several weeks maintaining a political consensus over the handling of the outbreak.

Party strategists believe that, while Labour shows every sign of pressing ahead with a May 3 general election, public feeling that the contest should be postponed is growing.

The mounting seriousness of the crisis, in the face of unpopular efforts at containment, now offers scope for an assault on government handling of the epidemic, even at the risk of being accused of making political capital out of the problem, Mr Hague's aides have concluded.

The Tories have been, and remain, wary of making any direct suggestion that the election should be postponed amid fears of being perceived to be running scared of a battle polls indicate they will lose badly.

Mr Hague yesterday stopped short of calling for postponement - or even demanding the delay of county council elections - but he attempted to set down a marker that, without a clear easing of the crisis, calling an election campaign would be irresponsible.

Avoiding giving a definition of what would constitute the disease being "under control", he insisted his party would not be frightened to speak out if it felt the government was calling an election in inappropriate circumstances.

Yesterday's statement marks the culmination of a gradual Tory move towards risking a direct attack on the government election plans. Initially, the party steered clear of any such suggestions, while simul taneously allowing other sympathetic voices - the National Farmer's Union, the Countryside Alliance and Conservative supporting newspapers - to make the case instead.

Last week, shadow agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, stressed that the party was ready for an election fight whenever the government chose to call one, but suggested that voters would question the appropriateness of a poll amid a crisis affecting not only farmers but a swath of rural and tourist industries.

Addressing Cumbrian farmers last Thursday, Mr Hague argued that it would be "very difficult" to hold an election if the foot and mouth situation remained as it was - a warning strengthened yesterday to a clear statement that, without an easing of the crisis, it would not be right to call an election.

Conservative strategists insist they are not reducing the party's room for manoeuvre by opposing a poll. A Hague aide said: "We are not boxed in at all. On the day Blair announces the election we could say we agree the outbreak has been contained, or we could say we completely deplore this decision, the outbreak is not under control. All those options are still open to us."

Labour yesterday swung into action to counter Mr Hague's offensive, as the Commons leader, Margaret Beckett, accused him of trying to make political capital out of the crisis, despite the Tories' officially bipartisan policy.

She said: "In situations like this, there are ways of making constructive criticism without so obviously trying to turn it into a political issue. Many of the points he makes are already being addressed."

Trades union leaders were also mobilised to send out a coordinated message that postponing local elections -used as Labour code for the unannounced general election - would send out a panic message and further damage the rural economy and jobs.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB which has over 20,000 members in the tourism sector, said: "Cancelling the local elections would be the worst possible move.

"We are trying to restore confidence in the UK as a tourist destination and effec tively suspending democracy would send a signal to the world that we are a nation in crisis."

Conservative county councillors and some election officials in worst hit areas raised concerns over council elections, however.

Cattle and sheep farmer Steele Addison, a Tory councillor representing Lowther and Shap, near Penrith, Cumbria, said yesterday: "I think at the present time most certainly as we see this thing expanding so rapidly across the Cumbria countryside, it would be silly to think in terms of elections.

"We cannot go electioneering at a time like this. It is inappropriate."

The West Devon borough council chief executive, David Incoll, said it seemed likely that many of the village halls normally used as polling stations in elections would not be available on May 3.

"We will do whatever we have to do, but I think there would be concern as to holding the election in certain village halls in the most affected areas," he told BBC Radio 4.

fields.headline: British most hostile to asylum
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The British are the most hostile to political refugees of all EC people, according to a report from the European monitoring centre on racism and xenophobia.
fields.body:
The British are the most hostile to political refugees of all EC people, according to a report from the European monitoring centre on racism and xenophobia.

Belgium and Greece are the EU's most xenophobic countries, and more hostile towards the idea of a multicultural Europe than anyone else.

In the UK 23% of those questioned in the survey of more than 16,000 Europeans commissioned by the centre a year ago said political asylum seekers who had suffered human rights violations in their own countries of not be accepted.

The survey found that 39% of those questioned thought legal immigrants who became unemployed should be forcibly repatriated, and 51% believed that ethnic minorities increased unemployment.

Although the report shows an increased in tolerance since the previous survey in 1997, it reveals that many Europeans are seriously concerned about the implications of mass immigration.

It classes 27% of Greeks and 25%of Belgians as intolerant, compared to 4% of Spaniards.

"People are more and more looking for scapegoats ... and are worried about the effects of migration," Beate Winkler, the centre's director, said.

She added that Greek social security, jobs and schooling had been particularly affected by the wars in the Balkans.

More than half the Greeks disagreed that it was a good thing for a society to be made up of different races, religions and cultures, as did 35% of Belgians.

"The statistics show that Europe needs immigrants and we have to prepare our populations for that," Ms Winkler said, adding that politicians were failing to promote the benefits of immigration.

webTitle: Ministers step up support for 2002 games

fields.headline: Ministers step up support for 2002 games
fields.standfirst: As concern over financing grows, Blair warns Manchester's Commonwealth Games must show Britain as leader in staging prestige events
fields.trailText: As concern over financing grows, Blair warns Manchester's Commonwealth Games must show Britain as leader in staging prestige events
fields.body:
Ministers are at the point of underwriting next year's Commonwealth Games in Manchester after a warning from Tony Blair that the event must succeed in portraying Britain as a world leader in staging prestige international gatherings.

Amid growing concern over the financing of the games, which still need £32m to meet sponsorship targets, the prime minister has ordered a far higher level of government commitment - both political and financial - than was ever envisaged when Manchester bid for the games in 1995.

Manchester's council tax payers still remain technically liable for any losses. But yesterday Ian McCartney, the Cabinet Office minister given special responsibility for the games by Mr Blair last year, told the Commons culture select committee meeting in Manchester that there was now "a far more close relationship between central government and those who deliver the games".

With fewer than 500 days to go before the opening ceremony, government spending is now seen as an investment in a showcase rather than a potential bail-out, although no indication has been given of the level of spending that may be required.

Mr Blair has supported the games with a series of breakfast meetings and receptions and has also featured in a promotional video.

But it is a sign of his increasing interest that Granada chief, Charles Allen, who is chairman of Manchester 2002 Ltd, is personally presenting him with regular reports on the finances and organisation.

Ministers were influenced by three factors in their decision to strengthen commitment to the games.

The Sydney Olympics set new standards by which international events will be judged; the Commonwealth Games are a key element in the celebrations of the Queen's golden jubilee ("They are the jewels in the crown," said Mr McCartney); and London is gearing up for a bid for the 2012 Olympics.

A further impetus may have been the political fallout from the shambles over two London projects - the dome and Wembley stadium - which have damaged Britain's international reputation.

"The Commonwealth Games are here and going to happen so we must make them successful," said Mr McCartney after yesterday's hearing. "That success will give us the capacity for the first time in a long time to go to the market place and say: 'We are quite good at this kind of event. We have a track record here'.

"That's what we don't have at the moment - a track record in truly global events. The Commonwealth Games present us with an opportunity to achieve that."

In a clear reference to a possible Olympic bid, he added: "There are other events coming in the next decade or so which we need to bid for. If we want to bid for them, we can only bid on the basis of the strength and quality of our capacity to deliver them."

Both the government and the games organisers stress that they are "light years" removed from the provincial fiasco of the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh in 1986.

"This is now a global event in terms of its size, diversity and the number of nations and sports involved," Mr McCartney added.

Ministers and games organisers are now working on a review to discover gaps in planning and funding shortfalls.

"The review is not taking place on the basis that there is a crisis," said Mr McCartney. "Far from it. This is an organisation that is in control of events but needs to make sure that it remains in control of events, the logistics and the funding, over the last 500 days."

The minister's robust stance was welcomed by games organisers. "This is a national project and we have always believed it was national project," said Howard Bernstein, chief executive of Manchester city council. "This is a legitimate event for a government to spend its money on."

There are even suggestions that spending might rise above previous budgets to meet the expectations set by Sydney.

"We are the Commonwealth Games and not the Olympics but people's view of how we do things is influenced by what they saw at Sydney, where the games had far more impact on the world than any recent Olympics," said Frances Done, chief executive of M2002, the company responsible for the organisation of the Manchester games.

"They got through to people about what you do and how you do it. We are having to decide right now the way we do things because of the influence of Sydney. Sports presentation there was fantastic with modern, upbeat, exciting presentation which involved video screens, sound and lighting.

"We hadn't originally budgeted for that level of input. So there is a question mark now: should we do that? It has certainly become an expectation."

Timed events

1993: Manchester invited to bid for for Comonwealth Games.

April 1995: After defeating Sheffield and London, Manchester submits bid to games federation.

November: Manchester confirmed as host city for XVIIth games.

1999: Work begins on stadium.

July 2000: Aquatic Centre opens - venue for swimming and diving events.

October 2001: Internet sales for 17 the key sports begin, followed two months later by telephone sales.

December: Main stadium due for completion in east Manchester, with full fitting out due by following March. Will eventually become home for Manchester City FC, when running track is removed and 10,000 more seats added, bringing capacity to 48,000.

July 25 2002: Queen opens Games as highlight of her golden jubilee.

August 4: Games close

Autumn: City prepares to make east Manchester - venue for stadium and existing velodrome - Britain's premier sporting complex, and key to the regeneration of one of the city's poorest areas.

"That success will give us the capacity for the first time in a long time to go to the market place and say: 'We are quite good at this kind of event. We have a track record here'. "That's what we don't have at the moment - a track record in truly global events. The Commonwealth Games present us with an opportunity to achieve that." In a clear reference to a possible Olympic bid, he added: "There are other events coming in the next decade or so which we need to bid for. If we want to bid for them, we can only bid on the basis of the strength and quality of our capacity to deliver them." Both the government and the games organisers stress that they are "light years" removed from the provincial fiasco of the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh in 1986. "This is now a global event in terms of its size, diversity and the number of nations and sports involved," Mr McCartney added. Ministers and games organisers are now working on a review to discover gaps in planning and funding shortfalls. "The review is not taking place on the basis that there is a crisis," said Mr McCartney. "Far from it. This is an organisation that is in control of events but needs to make sure that it remains in control of events, the logistics and the funding, over the last 500 days." The minister's robust stance was welcomed by games organisers. "This is a national project and we have always believed it was national project," said Howard Bernstein, chief executive of Manchester city council. "This is a legitimate event for a government to spend its money on." There are even suggestions that spending might rise above previous budgets to meet the expectations set by Sydney. "We are the Commonwealth Games and not the Olympics but people's view of how we do things is influenced by what they saw at Sydney, where the games had far more impact on the world than any recent Olympics," said Frances Done, chief executive of M2002, the company responsible for the organisation of the Manchester games. "They got through to people about what you do and how you do it. We are having to decide right now the way we do things because of the influence of Sydney. Sports presentation there was fantastic with modern, upbeat, exciting presentation which involved video screens, sound and lighting. "We hadn't originally budgeted for that level of input. So there is a question mark now: should we do that? It has certainly become an expectation." Timed events 1993: Manchester invited to bid for for Comonwealth Games. April 1995: After defeating Sheffield and London, Manchester submits bid to games federation. November: Manchester confirmed as host city for XVIIth games. 1999: Work begins on stadium. July 2000: Aquatic Centre opens - venue for swimming and diving events. October 2001: Internet sales for 17 the key sports begin, followed two months later by telephone sales. December: Main stadium due for completion in east Manchester, with full fitting out due by following March. Will eventually become home for Manchester City FC, when running track is removed and 10,000 more seats added, bringing capacity to 48,000. July 25 2002: Queen opens Games as highlight of her golden jubilee. August 4: Games close Autumn: City prepares to make east Manchester - venue for stadium and existing velodrome - Britain's premier sporting complex, and key to the regeneration of one of the city's poorest areas.

webTitle: Railtrack given new target for 'normal service'

fields.headline: Railtrack given new target for 'normal service'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Some rail services will not be back to normal until next February leading to potential new claims against Railtrack from train companies for millions of pounds of compensation, Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Some rail services will not be back to normal until next February leading to potential new claims against Railtrack from train companies for millions of pounds of compensation, Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, revealed yesterday.

In a review of Railtrack's achievements since the Hatfield rail crash last year, Mr Winsor gave Railtrack a May 21 deadline to return most services to normal.

He agreed that fewer than a quarter of the train companies will have services running normally by the original target of Easter. Even after extensive work over the holiday, only 12 of the 28 companies will be running normal services.

Mr Winsor gave Railtrack the new deadline because he thought that Railtrack would never meet its original date. "I think the public has reached a stage when they will only believe normal service has been restored when they see it. The public are right to be sceptical about Railtrack's promises. We are sceptical about Railtrack's promises too."

Mr Winsor has issued an enforcement order against the company, which he thought Railtrack would "take very seriously". He was confident that the May 21 target would be met and he was not holding the threat of a fine over the company. He has also ordered Railtrack to produce a record of its assets and the condition of its infrastructure in order to prevent another crash.

Mr Winsor agreed that if Railtrack failed to meet the deadline, the rail companies could take legal action to obtain more compensation. In the most severe circum stances, the government could remove its licence to operate.

So far, Railtrack has accepted responsibility for up to £900m compensation in the aftermath of the Hatfield crash, but this figure only goes up to the end of March. It will inevitably have to face a larger bill of more than £1bn, much of which is expected to be funded by the taxpayer.

Mr Winsor said: "Railtrack at first promised us the network would be restored by Christmas, then January, the Easter." He added that the level and extent of disruption and uncertainty caused by the repair work "has been unprecedented and remains unacceptable".

The two rail companies which might not be back to normal until next year are Anglia and WAGN. In both cases Mr Winsor is concerned about work pending at Liverpool Street in London. He said that one route between Finsbury and Moorgate would berestricted until next February.

The six companies running normally by Easter include Island Line (Isle of Wight), Eurostar, Heathrow Express and Merseyrail. Companies running normally again immediately after Easter include Gatwick Express, South West Trains and Thameslink.

Connex South Central's Rugby to Clapham Junction services and Silverlink's London to Birmingham service will not be back to normal until June 30. Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, said: "There has been much progress to restore the network to pre-Hatfield levels as quickly as possible. The regulator states he is only asking us to meet the plans to which he is already committed."

Anthony Smith, national director of the rail passengers' council, said: "The setting of successive dates for the end of this work, which are then broken, is leading to disillusionment. Railtrack and train companies must tell [passengers] the truth."

webTitle: Hague appoints Muslim adviser on ethnic issues

fields.headline: Hague appoints Muslim adviser on ethnic issues
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague attempted to mend fences with Britain's ethnic minorities yesterday when he lavished praise on Muslims for leading the fight against racism.
fields.body:
William Hague attempted to mend fences with Britain's ethnic minorities yesterday when he lavished praise on Muslims for leading the fight against racism.

Speaking in the wake of the row over his "foreign land" speech, the Tory leader said that Muslims had promoted values of faith and responsibility since they first settled in Britain in the 16th century.

Opening his speech to the Muslim Council of Britain with the Islamic saying "peace be with you", Mr Hague said that Tories and Muslims shared the values of hard work and support for the family.

"Your values of strong faith, education, responsibility to others, of hard work and tolerance are values which resonate with all our citizens in every part of this country," Mr Hague said.

He announced that he had appointed Mohammed Riaz, who is standing for the Tories in Bradford West, as an adviser to the shadow cabinet on ethnic and cultural issues.

Tory sources denied that Mr Hague's remarks were designed to mend fences after his warning earlier this month that a Labour election victory would turn Britain into a "foreign land".

They said his remarks at the party's spring conference in Harrogate were about the threat posed by the EU and were not about race.

webTitle: Kennedy issues challenge on climate change

fields.headline: Kennedy issues challenge on climate change
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy yesterday moved to raise his profile ahead of the coming election by challenging Tony Blair to tell US president George Bush that his new administration's views on climate change were "out of step" with the rest of the world.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy yesterday moved to raise his profile ahead of the coming election by challenging Tony Blair to tell US president George Bush that his new administration's views on climate change were "out of step" with the rest of the world.

Mocking Ronald Reagan's famous disdain for environmental concerns - "a tree's a tree, how many do you need to look at?" he said when told of plans to expand the Redwood national park in California - the Liberal Democrat leader welcomed what he tartly described as Mr Blair's "recent" conversion to the green cause.

Mr Kennedy has been criticised for his low profile since succeeding Paddy Ashdown as party leader 18 months ago and for not being tough enough on Labour.

He blamed European ministers, including John Prescott, for not arranging a deal to ratify the Kyoto agreement on climate change targets at The Hague last year at a time when Bill Clinton was still president. He said: "I was seriously disappointed at their weakness in allowing the US to get away with having killed the deal."

But his harshest words were reserved for the new US administration. "Last week President Bush wrote to four US senators spelling out his opposition to the Kyoto protocol. I challenge the prime minister to make it clear to President Bush that his views are out of step with other world leaders."

This weekend's Stockholm summit gives EU leaders a "perfect opportunity" to speak out, he said. Mr Kennedy singled out the prime minister's speech earlier this month, only his second on the environment since 1997.

"Only time will tell how long this new found interest continues. But we do have evidence now of Labour's record. Before the last general election the prime minister pledged to put the environment at the heart of government," Mr Kennedy said.

"Yet four years later the number of car journeys have risen, fuel duty has just been cut, a massive programme of road building has been announced and the election pledge for a 20% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 has been downgraded to nothing more than an aspiration," he told a meeting of the Green Alliance in London.

Lib Dem policy, he explained, was not just to meet the 2010 target relating to carbon dioxide emissions - but to further reduce it by 1.5% a year up to 2050.

webTitle: Universities welcome cut in teaching assessments

fields.headline: Universities welcome cut in teaching assessments
fields.standfirst: Special report: University teaching inspections
fields.trailText: David Blunkett today proposed a 40% reduction in the assessment of higher education teaching by exempting high-scoring institutions from the next round of external reviews.
fields.body:
David Blunkett today proposed a 40% reduction in the assessment of higher education teaching by exempting high-scoring institutions from the next round of external reviews.

Making his announcement, Mr Blunkett said: "We are committed to lighter touch arrangements for the new method of academic review. In broad terms, university departments which have achieved good scores in the current round will be exempt from external review in the next round. The aim is to secure a reduction of 40% or more in the volume of review activity compared with the existing arrangements."

Universities have enthusiastically welcomed today's decision.

In the past, many academics have protested against the Quality Assurance Agency's assessments, arguing it is bureaucratic and wasteful. Andrew Oswald, economics professor at Warwick University, calculated that preparing for an assessment of his course cost 50 people, including himself, a total of 8,000 man/hours.

"It's just enormous amount of time. If today's announcement actually happens, then it's very good news. It will save us a huge amount of wasteful paperwork. It's about time that people listened to common sense," Professor Oswald said.

Universities UK chief executive, Diana Warwick also welcomed Mr Blunkett's announcement, saying: "Vice-chancellors will be pleased to see this new commitment to reduce the burden of assessment which is costly - time which could be more usefully spent on teaching students."

Mr Blunkett's proposal will now be discussed by representatives of involved bodies including Universities UK, the Higher Education Funding Council for England and the Quality Assurance Agency - leading to worries amongst some that the proposals may be diluted in the consultation

But Universities UK's parliamentary and government relations manager, Chris Felton believes they can keep the proposals on track: "We've campaigned for this and will keep up the pressure on government to ensure cost savings."

fields.headline: Maitland Emmet
fields.standfirst: His passion for natural history led to an unrivalled knowledge of small moths
fields.trailText: His passion for natural history led to an unrivalled knowledge of small moths
fields.body:
Maitland Emmet, who has died aged 92, turned a childhood passion for natural history into a lifelong study of moths and butterflies. In his 46 years of retirement, he became one of Britain's foremost authorities on microlepidoptera, or small moths.

His achievements included adding 20 species of moths to the list of those known to inhabit Britain, discovering the life cycles of many species and creating the most important collection of nepticulid moths (the very smallest) in Britain, together with a herbarium of leaves mined by their larvae. During his final weeks of life, he took pride in supervising the transfer of this part of his collection to the Natural History Museum.

Born in the vicarage at West Hendred, Oxfordshire, Emmet was the son of a clergyman. On his 13th birthday, he was given his first butterfly net, and promptly searched the grounds of his Dorset preparatory school for butterflies. His first catch was a comma, a species not seen in the county since the 19th century.

A lively interest in natural history continued at Sherborne school, where Emmet was allowed to keep a pet jackdaw he had reared from a nestling. While reading greats at University College, Oxford, his dominant interest became rowing; he also learned to fly, and bought a government surplus biplane which, as a master at St Edward's school, Oxford, he would sometimes land on the playing field. Apart from war service, teaching classics and English at St Edward's occupied the major part of his working life, and being asked to resuscitate its field club reignited his own interest in British lepidoptera.

During the second world war, Emmet served with the 6th Oxford and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry. Training on the Isle of Wight, then the only British haunt of the Glanville fritillary, was followed by active service in Burma, with its opportunities for observing tropical butterflies and birds. He became a lieutenant-colonel, received an MBE and wrote his first book, The Arakan Campaign Of The 25th Land Division.

In 1956, he retired early from teaching, and later moved to Saffron Walden, Essex, to care for his elderly mother and aunt. He learnt much from other enthusiasts at field meetings; his repayment was an enthusiasm for helping a younger generation of entomologists, and a willingness to play an active part in the administration of societies to which he belonged. He served terms as president of the Amateur Entomologists' Society and the British Entomological and Natural History Society, and as a vice-president of the Royal Entomological Society. The Zoological Society of London awarded him its Stamford Raffles Award for contributions to zoological knowledge by amateur naturalists.

Emmet had become increasingly interested in the so-called micro-moths, about which little was known. By the early 1960s, he took up the ultimate challenge - the nepticulidae , only a few millimetres in wingspan. Less than 10 years later, he knew more about these moths than anyone else in Britain, and was breeding out many species from their caterpillar forms, found by collecting their characteristic leaf-mines.

In addition to more than 100 published papers, he wrote three books. A Field Guide To The Smaller British Lepidoptera has been the bible of British microlepidopterists since 1979; The Scientific Names Of The British Lepidoptera: Their History And Meaning (1991) explains the names of more than 2000 moths and butterflies of Britain; and his most enduring legacy came about through editing The Moths And Butterflies Of Great Britain And Ireland. Seven parts of this multi-volume treatise appeared between 1976 and his death.

From the outset, Emmet was on the editorial panel, becoming senior editor in 1987. He wrote major sections of the text for the microlepidoptera sections himself, always refusing to copy previous descrip tions without first checking them against the moth and its larval stages. He had prepared the next double-volume for publication, working hard until close to his death; its publication will be a fine memorial.

A bachelor until his 60s, Emmet married Katie (the widow of his close friend Chris Tinne) in 1972. She loved plants, and had soon created a beautiful garden, in which Emmet identified more than 990 species of butterfly and moth - a total he believed to be the highest for any garden in Britain. Katie was also enrolled to search the Essex countryside for the wild plants that were host to rare moths.

During the research for The Smaller Moths Of Essex (1981) and The Larger Moths And Butterflies of Essex (1985), the couple visited all 53 of the 10km map squares in the county, searching plants for leaf mines, and using the light-trap which Maitland's elder sister, the late Professor Dorothy Emmet (Obituary, September 25 2000) had given him for his 75th birthday. They would simply knock on the door of a farmhouse or other building with a large garden, and ask permission to set up their trap. Thus, they made a huge number of friends, some of whom became moth enthusiasts.

A courteous and charming man, with a keen sense of humour, Emmet described the 23 years with Katie (she died in 1995) as the happiest of his life. He is survived by his sister, Margery Wilson.

Arthur Maitland Emmet, entomologist, born July 15 1908; died March 3 2001

fields.headline: Durham students face rent hike
fields.trailText: Students at Durham University face rent increases of over £200 a year for the next five years following a decision yesterday by the university council.
fields.body:
Students at Durham University face rent increases of over £200 a year for the next five years following a decision yesterday by the university council.

Last Thursday, 800 students marched in protest against the universityÕs plans, after negotiations broke down between the university and the DurhamÕs student union.

A petition of 6000 signatures, representing over half of Durham's student population, was handed to the Vice-chancellor Professor Sir Kenneth Calman at Old Shire Hall, the university's administrative building.

fields.headline: Brigid Beattie-Moriarty
fields.standfirst: Dynamic headteacher who created a model of good education for women
fields.trailText: Dynamic headteacher who created a model of good education for women
fields.body:
As principal of one of the largest girls' state secondary schools in the country, Brigid Beattie-Moriarty, who has died aged 62 following a brain haemorrhage, created an outstanding centre of multi-cultural education at Burntwood, in Wandsworth, south London.

Her strong and independent voice, often ahead of national policy, was listened to by politicians, government advisers, chief inspectors, educationalists, other headteachers and staff. While she preferred sustained debate, her television soundbites were effective, most recently on last month's green paper on school education, Building On Success, and on teacher shortages. She spoke with authority of her successful experience, rooted in strong leadership, vision and insight.

Before Brigid's arrival, Burntwood had been named by her majesty's inspectors as one of "10 good schools", and would be recognised for its "success against the odds". Her beliefs and philosophies - and her understanding of the importance of structure, clear systems and policies - led the school, where she was known as Brigid Beattie, to be recognised again in 1997 by the chief inspector; last year, it became a beacon school. Its chamber choir has twice won the Sainsbury's choir-of-the-year competition.

The eldest of four girls, Brigid was named after her Irish maternal grandmother, who became the landlady of the Three Horseshoes at Henley-on-Thames. Her Catholic mother trained as a teacher and was a keen theatregoer, taking Brigid and her sisters to Stratford-upon-Avon from an early age; her Anglican father was a successful farmer and a member of the Church of England.

At the age of six, she was sent to a weekly boarding school in Reading, and at 12 to the Convent of the Holy Family, a mixed Catholic-Protestant boarding school in Littlehampton. She read history at the London School of Economics, where she met her first husband Alan, and became vice-president of the students' union.

She drew lessons from very varied classroom experiences - there was history teaching at Parliament Hill school for girls; academic, selective sixth-form teaching at Henley grammar school; the inner-city demands of William Forster school, Haringey; and the deputy headship of Holland Park comprehensive.

Brigid wanted inner-city children to achieve the highest standards within the state sector, and to benefit from the best of the cultural and class values she had enjoyed, such as Shakespeare, and an appreciation of beauty and good behaviour. She believed headteachers had a duty to pass on the core of our heritage, as well as learning the lessons of history.

Following a sabbatical in Oxford, and a period as an advisory teacher in equal opportunities, she applied in 1986 for the headship of Burntwood, an amalgamation of two south London schools, Mayfield and Garratt Green. She was appointed at the second time of applying the same year.

London boroughs, including Margaret Thatcher's favourite council, Wandsworth, were due to take over education following the abolition of the Inner London Education Authority. Brigid was one of the first to understand the likely effects of the 1988 Education Act, not least of open enrolment, city technology colleges, league tables, local management and possible grant-maintained status.

Schools should take responsibility for their destiny. Greatly improved results and growing popularity could be achieved. Limited selection by testing, sometimes controversial, would be part of the strategy for Burntwood, Graveney and Ernest Bevin schools in Wandsworth.

Brigid believed that her recreations in Who's Who - biography, art, architecture, theatre, opera, interiors, landscape, the aesthetic in general - made at least as great a contribution to her success as a headteacher as did her training. She touched and influenced many people's lives personally and professionally. When the school's first black student was due to go up to Oxford, Brigid drove her there herself to help ensure a successful induction.

She could overawe others, and was prepared to fight important battles, whether supporting the development of strong sixth forms in inner-city schools, defending an exclusion case at the high court, resulting in a new interpret-ation of education law, or speaking up for a beleaguered chief inspector of schools.

Brigid contributed effectively as a member of the BBC Education Broadcasting Council, as non-executive director of a health trust, on an education department anti-bullying project and as a college governor. She would drive forward both thinking and practice, progressive but not trendy. Within a clear framework of values, she embraced the reality of what can be barriers in society - social class, state and independent education, and religious divisions.

She demanded quality and style, but friendship, humour and laughter were never far away. She rewarded her staff achievements with "tiger stickers", which even the hardest-bitten proudly displayed. She would have appreciated the spontaneous tribute of the Burntwood girls who, at the news of her death, gathered around the school flagpole, sang Amazing Grace, said a prayer and called for three cheers for Mrs Beattie. One of her pupils wrote: "I didn't know you, but I knew you were on my side."

Brigid achieved her school's aim of giving "the best education today for the woman of tomorrow". She was made a CBE in 1998, and is survived by her husband, Denis, a son from her first marriage, and a son, stepson and stepdaughter from her second marriage.

fields.headline: School rebuked over drowning
fields.standfirst:
Teacher did not notice that girl was missing

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A nine-year-old girl on a school sailing trip drowned beneath a capsized boat after her teacher failed to realise she was missing, according to an official accident report yesterday.
fields.body:
A nine-year-old girl on a school sailing trip drowned beneath a capsized boat after her teacher failed to realise she was missing, according to an official accident report yesterday.

Elizabeth Bee was one of nine pupils from Boundary Oak independent school in Fareham, Hampshire, thrown from their craft along with their teacher, Paul Dove, into Portsmouth harbour amid strong winds in September 1999.

Mr Dove, 64, failed to count his pupils after the incident and it was at least nine minutes later that Elizabeth's twin sister, Victoria, noticed her absence, the report by the marine accident investigation branch found.

Investigators criticised the school for failing to carry out professional safety checks on the "grossly overloaded" 14ft dory, which was not watertight and overturned when foam in its floor became waterlogged.

There was no emergency radio equipment and Mr Dove's supervision had been "at best lax, at worst non-existent", they said. Although an experienced sailor, he had not been qualified to the standards expected by the adventure activities licensing authority.

The outing began when the group - several of whom had never sailed before - set out from HMS Excellent's sailing centre on Whale Island, Portsmouth. A series of minor incidents followed - the engine stalled, one pupil fell into the water, but was rescued, and another was stung by a jellyfish - and water entered the boat's leaky hull and soaking into foam on its floor.

By the time the engine stalled a second time and could not be restarted, the boat was "in a grossly overloaded and unstable condition" but Mr Dove "did not appear to have been aware of the very dangerous situation that had developed", investigators found. He instructed four children to start paddling, but the craft overturned, leaving him and the pupils, who were all wearing lifejackets, clinging to or standing on the hull.

A harbour vessel arrived after four minutes and recovered the children after another five. But the teacher did not inform the rescue boat crew that there were nine pupils in his charge, and Elizabeth's absence was only noticed when her sister said she could not see her. She was found beneath the boat and first aid was administered, but she died in hospital.

The crown prosecution service decided last year not to act against Boundary Oak or Mr Dove, but Elizabeth's mother, Lesley Bee, yesterday said she planned to take legal action against the school. "All I have ever wanted is for every one to know the truth ... because of the school's incompetence and lack of management Elizabeth lost her life," she said.

"The girls should never have gone out in that weather and certainly not in a blatantly dangerous boat. What has made losing Elizabeth even worse ... is the refusal of anyone to take the blame, but now the school and Mr Dove cannot hide from that responsibility."

The school said it would take careful note of the investigators' findings but that in any case all sailing activities had been suspended after the accident and permanently discontinued last year.

"Our thoughts are very much with the family as they are put through the agonies of thinking about the death of their daughter," said headteacher Roger Bliss. But he insisted the school had "done everything it could have done to put the necessary safeguards in place with respect to the type of craft and pupil welfare". The craft had been donated by a parent, he said, "who knew the school's requirements and gave us the boat in good faith."

Hampshire county council had produced guidelines for school sailing trips but Boundary Oak had not received a copy, the report found.

"We do not have any obligation to forward any guidance that we produce [to independent schools], but if it is requested we are quite happy to share it with them," a council spokeswoman said.

webTitle: Offer of talks on workload may end teaching dispute

fields.headline: Offer of talks on workload may end teaching dispute
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: An end to the bitter dispute over staff shortages in schools was in sight last night, after the government and local authority employers said they were willing to start negotiations with the teaching unions provided they called off the action.
fields.body:
An end to the bitter dispute over staff shortages in schools was in sight last night, after the government and local authority employers said they were willing to start negotiations with the teaching unions provided they called off the action.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, intervened by offering an independent review of teachers' workload, while in another significant concession, the Local Government Association said teachers could for the first time be paid overtime of up to £20 an hour if they covered for colleagues.

Leaders of the two unions involved, the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said they would consider both proposals at executive meetings today and tomorrow. They welcomed the offers as a breakthrough which could represent the first steps towards "an improved contract" for teachers.

Pupils have faced being sent home from school when their teachers have refused to cover for staff illness of longer than three days or long term vacancies. So far teachers in 10 areas in England have voted to take so-called "no cover action".Ballots are being held in eight other areas. The results of ballots in Derbyshire and Birmingham are due next month.

Only two schools in England say they have been forced to send children home in the last two weeks, although more would be affected if the action continued.

The schoolteachers' review body recommended in its report on teachers' pay and conditions last month that there should be an independent evaluation of teachers' workload, but the government ignored the recommendation until yesterday.

A spokeswoman for the Department for Education said: "If no action were taking place, we would of course be willing to respond positively to the STRB's recommendation that there be an independent evaluation of teachers' workload ... The secretary of state will only take part in such discussions with the unions on this issue once the action is called off."

Earlier, Graham Lane, the education chairman of the Local Government Association, which represents local education authority employers, wrote to union leaders asking them to suspend the industrial action so that talks could start.

He said the overtime payments could be introduced immediately. The assocation believed an independent inquiry would be unnecessarily time-consuming, and instead proposed talks with ministers after the election for "a comprehensive agenda" covering teachers' working arrangements.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "At long last the government has admitted there is a crisis. We will look positively at the substance of both proposals from the employers and government."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, said: "The unions have waited for 15 years for talks on teachers' contracts so obviously we take the government's offer very seriously."

webTitle: Watch children on net, parents told

fields.headline: Watch children on net, parents told
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Schools are to be advised not to place individual photographs of pupils on their websites under new government guidance, writes Alan Travis..
fields.body:
Schools are to be advised not to place individual photographs of pupils on their websites and to take measures to "anonymise" children's email addresses, under new government guidance to be published today.

Teachers will be asked to ensure that all pupils using the net at school are protected by filtering systems which ensure they do not visit inappropriate websites.

A police officer also warned parents yesterday to move the home computer out of their children's bedroom and into the family living room and not to leave them surfing alone to protect them from potential child abusers.

The details of the Department for Education's new "safer surfing" guidance are to be disclosed as the home secretary, Jack Straw, announced there will be a meeting next week of internet companies, child welfare charities and the police to tackle sex offenders who exploit the 100,000 internet chat rooms available to British children.

A report by the Internet Crime Forum published yesterday urged internet service providers to promote chat services specifically targeted at children and ensure they are supervised with a simple way of reporting any incident in a chat room for investigation.

The forum's chairman, Detective Chief Superintendent Keith Ackerman, said that more than 5m children were now online in Britain and girls aged 13 to 17 were the most likely targets of predatory adult sex offenders who exploited the anonymity of chat rooms. "Too many parents are technophobes," said Mr Ackerman. "The computer is nearly always put in the wrong place - in the kiddies' bedroom. It is then not a family pursuit. The child is to a degree abandoned to look at the internet themselves. Proper supervision in a more public area like the lounge or dining room is required so the parents can learn from the child and vice versa."

The advice to parents will be supplemented today by official guidance to schools working to meet the government's pledge to provide every child with access to the internet and their own email address. The Department for Education guidance will stress the need not to publish individual photographs of named children on school websites and to "anonymise" children's email addresses so that they cannot be individually messaged by strangers outside the school.

This might involve giving each child a numerical email address for use outside the school which translates into an address using their own name when used on a school computer. So somebody who is known to the outside world as "pupil20.4thyear@bashstreet.sch.uk" would be on the school system as "joannasmith.4thyear@bashstreet.sch.uk".

The Internet Crime Forum's report, Chat Wise, Street Wise, published yesterday, said parents need to be educated about the risks of their children using chat room services and it suggests that a kitemarking scheme be introduced to identify sites which are safe for children.

webTitle: In brief: Oscar ceremony safe from power cuts

fields.headline: Oscar ceremony safe from power cuts
fields.standfirst: Plus: Full Monty writer out of sorts; Rambo 4 in the works; Joy Division biopic on the way; Britney Spears out of cash
fields.trailText: Plus: Full Monty writer out of sorts; Rambo 4 in the works; Joy Division biopic on the way; Britney Spears out of cash
fields.body:
 Organisers of Sunday night's Oscar ceremony have been reassured by California state officials that the star-studded event will not be hit by the power blackouts that have been hitting the area recently. The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power has said it has enough power in its reserves to make sure Hollywood's biggest night of the year will go ahead without a hitch. The power cuts, which have been plaguing the state since January, appeared to have stopped but started again earlier this week. A spokesman for the Shrine Auditorium, where the Oscars will be held, told the New York Post: "It's our belief there will be no problems on Sunday. We are not subject to rolling blackouts."

 The Full Monty writer Simon Beaufoy is battling to distance himself from his latest movie Blow Dry. The film about the hairdressing trade, which stars Alan Rickman and Josh Hartnett, is proudly advertised across posters in America as, "A new comedy from the creator of The Full Monty". However, Beaufoy is embarrassed by his connection to the film which has received a battering from critics. According to the London Evening Standard, he has now resorted to legal action to have his name taken off the movie. According to an unnamed source: "He's now gagged by lawyers but it seems he withdrew completely from the creative process early on."

 Miramax film supremo, Bob Weinstein, has confirmed that a script for Rambo 4 has been given the green light. According the fan site Stallone World, Jackie Chan, Richard Crenna, Brian Dennehy and Sylvester Stallone himself have agreed to appear in the latest instalment in the story of the mumbling Vietnam vet which reportedly involves Rambo tackling drug dealers in a US government building. Weinstein told the site: "We'd love nothing more than for Stallone to be involved. We think it's a billion-dollar property."
