webTitle: 'My dad is a living deterrant to becoming a teacher'

fields.headline: 'My dad is a living deterrant to becoming a teacher'
fields.standfirst: Oliver Burkeman discovers that the school generation doesn't really want to join in
fields.trailText: Oliver Burkeman discovers that the school generation doesn't really want to join in.
fields.body:
Melanie Zaalof was in a police station in central Birmingham when it hit her. "I was doing a work placement there when a call came in to rescue a five-year-old girl who was at risk in a house nearby," the 18-year-old A-level student recalls. "It took exactly two hours and fifteen minutes of filling out forms and filing papers before the officers could go and rescue that girl. And I just thought - that's not right. It can't be."

But drowning in paperwork is only one of many reasons why Zaalof and her fellow students at Bournville secondary school in Birmingham baulk at the prospect of life in the public services. For Douglas Brown, the 17-year-old son of two teachers, it was the dawning realisation that working in the classroom was much like being a nightclub bouncer that did it. "Three-quarters of the time it's just crowd control," he says. "No wonder so many people get so disillusioned with it."

At least nightclub bouncers get free drinks. There is nothing scientifically representative about Bournville, of course, but it is as good a snapshot of late-teenage Britain as any: an ethnically diverse urban comprehensive with a larger than average intake of below average pupils - popular with parents, rated good and improving when the Ofsted inspectors last called.

Here, if anywhere, is where the next generation of doctors and nurses, teachers and police officers, civil servants and air traffic controllers must be found. But if they are thin on the ground - and they are - it is not for the reason that might be expected. Money, in fact, is almost never mentioned.

It may be a timeless commonplace that each generation is more selfish than the last, bored by the pride in serving the community that supposedly quickened their parents' hearts - but it isn't true. When Bournville's 16- to 18-year-olds shun public-sector careers, they are not rebelling: they are following the advice of parents who took those jobs themselves and now dread their children doing the same.

"My dad is living proof for me, a living deterrent never to become a teacher," says one 16-year-old, an aspiring actor, echoing a widespread view. "He thought he could do it for five years, then quit, but by then he'd got a mortgage. He comes home every day regretting his decision, and now he's stuck with it until he retires. He doesn't want me to get trapped like that."

Hillcrest School, down the road from Bournville, has an arguably even more important role to play in the current recruitment crisis in the public services: it is an all-girls state school, and 80% of workers in the sector are women. There are some old-fashioned gripes among older students here - bureaucracy, lack of appreciation, too much routine - but one prevalent objection is of much more recent origin.

"You're constantly in the public eye and at risk of ending up in the papers - this doctor's done that, this teacher's done this, this nurse has done that," says Hayley-Jayne Kellerman, 16, who - despite everything, and seemingly uniquely - wants to teach maths (her academic father, needless to say, would rather she entered the world of finance).

"My stepmother's a pathologist, and after the organ scandals they came in, opened all the morgues, looked through all the files - it was just too much stress for her. The majority is judged by the minority."

But even the traditional benefits of public sector work, such as relative job security, seem unattractive now. The anchorless insecurity of the new economy may have its losers - thousands of late-shift call-centre workers for every internet millionaire - but seeking the stability of a public service job seems like a kind of defeatism: an admission that one didn't even try to be a winner.

"Our generation is predicted to change career four times during our lives," says 18-year-old Seema Parmar. "I don't want to look back on my life and see that I went into a job because it was safe and stayed there forever."

"You're going to spend most of your life doing it, so it might as well be meaningful," says Tom Willshire at Bournville. "I'm told that the job I want will mean forget having girlfriends, forget having a regular place to live or anything like that, for years, but I'm happy to make that sacrifice."

There are pockets of enthusiasm for public service, mostly among those who say they would be teachers or hospital staff for almost any money, because they can never remember having wanted to do anything else. But even they have a more fundamental objection: that it is not rewarding to work in those services to which people are entitled - precisely because they act like they're entitled. "People think they have a right, and they do," says Gina Hinsley, 17, who is more interested in marketing or advertising.

"So they think - well, you better be a good teacher because it's my money, and I'm paying taxes. You don't get credit for being good."

This doesn't seem like selfishness - more like a refusal to accept that ambition and service need be antithetical. But Bournville's and Hillcrest's future young professionals know that, at the moment, they seem to be: they have, after all, spent the last 14 years watching their teachers find that out. "And let's face it," says Lauren Adkins, 18, who wants to work at the Home Office. "Some pupils are nightmares."

When Bournville and Hillcrest students go to the movies, as often as not they end up at Warner StarCity, the sprawling megaplex on the outskirts of Birmingham that is Britain's largest cinema complex. There is something for every taste - 30 screens showing Hollywood, Bollywood and European films - but the teacher training adverts they see before the films these days seem baffling, ridiculous. What kind of propaganda campaign could ever hope to counteract everything a sixth-former already knows about schooling?

"They've got Nick Hancock and Dawn French talking about how they taught for a year, how rewarding it was, and how they went on to be superstars," says Tom Willshire. "Well, if most teachers taught for a year and then went off to be Nick Hancock, they'd probably find it rewarding too."

Similar recruitment drives elsewhere in the sector meet with equally withering responses. "You read Black Woman magazine or something, and it's full of adverts for police recruitment," says Lauren Adkins. "For me, that's patronising, the idea that you have to be of a certain colour for them to really want you. But the police are just seen as going about nitpicking - I've got a friend who was fined for putting his seatbelt on as he drove off instead of before he started the car - so do they really think we're going to apply because of a magazine ad?"

But it is Caleb Opuku, an 18-year-old at Bournville, who puts it most succinctly. "With all these jobs, you can't just keep telling someone that something's not the way it is, over and over again," he says. "It's just not going to work."

webTitle: PR to improve the freemason's image

fields.headline: Secrets and ties
fields.standfirst: Tired of being 'mugged' by the media, the United Grand Lodge of England has appointed a PR agency to improve the image of freemasonry. But can the spin doctors allay suspicions that the secretive organisation is pulling strings in the police and judiciary? Stephen Moss reports
fields.trailText: Tired of being 'mugged' by the media, the United Grand Lodge of England has appointed a PR agency to improve the image of freemasonry. But can the spin doctors allay suspicions that the secretive organisation is pulling strings in the police and judiciary? Stephen Moss reports
fields.body:
You're not going to mug us, are you?" asks Chris Connop, spokesman for the United Grand Lodge of England. He is evidently worried on this point, as he asks the question half a dozen times. He also looks suspicious when the photographer starts grovelling around on the floor of the grand temple at Freemasons Hall, an art deco masterpiece in central London and the masons' HQ. "I don't like being photographed from below," he explains. "It makes me look sinister." The photographer becomes agitated and utters an expletive, which may be the first swearword ever uttered in freemasonry's most hallowed hall.

Connop is paranoid because mugging has become an occupational hazard for freemasons. He is fuming over Monday's Newsnight, which made great play of the bizarre initiation rites undertaken by aspiring masons, and by an article by the son of a mason in the Independent portraying freemasonry as "the perfect hobby for bored middle-aged men engaged in undemanding jobs who hanker for a faintly exotic social life".

The freemasons hope this is the dark media hour just before a golden dawn. They are tired of being traduced, and have appointed a PR agency called MDA to re-present them to a doubting public. The doubts have been put most forcibly by Martin Short, author of The Brotherhood, who argues that the heavy concentration of masons in the law and the police force perverts justice. "Can all the rituals be merely symbolic?" asks Short. "One must presume that people join lodges predominantly to feather their own nests, and to form a loose combination against the interests of everybody who is not a mason."

Short did battle on Newsnight with Mike Dewar, head of MDA and a former colonel whose 30 years in the army has left its mark in the way he describes everything in military terms. He is preparing a campaign on behalf of freemasonry; it will be a battle, and initially the masons may have to take some flak, but a couple of years on he reckons our ideas of freemasonry - and our presumption that it is secretive, sinister and self-interested - will have been changed.

"The freemasons feel defensive at the moment," says the brisk, pinstripe-suited Dewar. "They feel they've been pressured. They've been attacked and vilified for so long that every reaction is a defensive reaction - 'No, we're not going to do that; as a matter of principle we won't publish lists of members.' I hope that in two years' time, when this campaign starts to be successful, they'll be a lot less sensitive about that sort of thing. They're not per se secretive about being a mason; in fact they're happy to sing about it, and that's what I'm encouraging them to do."

Dewar is not a mason and says he prefers not to know what goes on at initiation ceremonies (sharp instruments placed against bared breasts, silken nooses placed around the heads of initiates). "I couldn't care a damn what the ceremony is," he says. "That's not what's important. What is important is that these people are extremely good people; well-meaning, upright people with high moral standards. They are a fraternal society whose aim is to make good men better, and their achievements speak for themselves. They collect massive sums of money for charity - £17m last year - and most of the money goes to non-masonic charities."

Others have been less willing to ignore the rituals that are an integral part of freemasonry. In 1996, in an article in this paper, Short attacked the penalties which he said initiates agreed to accept if they transgressed against a brother mason: "having my throat cut across, my tongue torn out by the root and buried in the sand of the sea at low water mark". And that, said Short, was only the penalty for "first-degree" masons, the so-called entered apprentices in their Persil-white aprons. Second-degree (or fellowcraft) transgressors faced having their hearts "torn from their breasts and fed to ravenous birds", while third-degree (or master mason) miscreants faced the ultimate penalty, being severed in two, their bowels burned to ashes, and those ashes "scattered over the face of the earth and wafted by the four winds of heaven."

Short, however, had not been reading the extremely useful Freemasons' Diary, which explains that these hideous penalties have fallen into disuse. "When masonic ritual was developing in the late 1600s and 1700s," it explains soothingly, "it was quite common for legal and civil oaths to include physical penalties, and freemasonry simply followed the practice of the times. After long discussion, they were removed from the promises in 1986."

I asked for clarification from Jim Daniel, grand secretary of the United Grand Lodge. "The physical penalties, which were always only symbolic, were removed from the obligations in 1986," he says. "They were not replaced, so that a candidate still makes his obligation in the certain knowledge that he will be 'branded as a wilfully perjured individual void of all moral worth and totally unfit to be received into this worshipful lodge or any other warranted lodge or society of men who prize honour and virtue above the external advantages of rank and fortune' if he violates his obligation." So no ravenous birds or ritual disembowelling, but you certainly won't be welcome at lodge suppers.

The rest of the ritual remains intact, and the masonic diary defends it as a "shared experience which binds the members together", posing a crucial question to itself in its Q&A explanation of freemasonry - "Why do grown men run around with their trousers rolled up." Its answer is unembarrassed: "It is true that candidates have to roll up their trouser legs during the three ceremonies when they are being admitted to membership. Taken out of context this can seem amusing, but like other aspects of freemasonry, it has a symbolic meaning." (Irritatingly, it doesn't explain what it symbolises.)

Masons are sensitive to the charge that they owe their primary allegiance to their "craft". "Freemasons do not swear allegiances to each other or to freemasonry," says my masonic diary. "Freemasons promise to support others in times of need, but only if that support does not conflict with their duties to God, the law, their family or with their responsibilities as a citizen."

Connop becomes agitated at the suggestion that masons would put their masonic commitments before their worldly duties. "We are not allowed to go around giving masonic signals [there are secret handshakes, passwords and signs] outside a masonic context, because if we did we could be thrown out," he insists. "I'm a magistrate and if I were sitting as a magistrate and somebody tried to give me one of the degree signs, I would say immediately what was going on if I was in the chair. If not, I would say to the chairman, 'I'm sorry but this defendant is trying to gain advantage by his membership of freemasonry,' and I would retire from the bench and not hear that case. That is outrageous. That is not what we stand for."

The hardest thing for an outsider to grasp is what freemasonry is actually for. Connop, who is a member of no fewer than 13 lodges, supplies a one-word answer: "fun". He enjoys the ritual, and opens his mason's case to show us his numerous medals, aprons and masonic ties. He is heading off that evening to the lodge of which he is master to "make a mason" - induct an apprentice into the craft - and is palpably looking forward to it, rehearsing the lines which form part of ceremony. He values the moral compass that freemasonry provides in his life and is moved when he shows us the masonic artefacts that soldiers carried with them in the first world war, but above all he wants to stress the enjoyment and sense of fellowship he derives from being part of the organisation.

The Real Secrets of Freemasonry, a guide to the craft prepared by Worshipful Brother George Gibson in 1945 and much reprinted since, takes a more moralistic stance. "Freemasonry is an organised system of morality . . . derived from divine wisdom and age-long experience, which for preservation from outer assault and inner decay is veiled in allegory and illustrated by symbols. It preaches the Fatherhood of God and the Brotherhood of Man. The influence of divine inspiration is with it throughout. Each Candidate for membership declares his belief in the Supreme Being: keeping strictly aloof from political divisions, it demands from its members a recognition of the eternal and of the light which comes from above."

So what is the essence of freemasonry? Material self-advancement and sinister secrecy, say its critics. Fun, fellowship and a moral code, masons counter. Dewar, who hopes to reverse the decline that has seen membership in England and Wales fall to 320,000, intends to present them as "good, solid citizens with the right moral values who support all that is good in society". But there are two other factors which must surely be considered - food and stamp collecting.

The editor of The Square, "the independent magazine for freemasons", devotes his editorial in this month's issue to the important question: "To eat or not to eat". "Any masonic group which sought to eliminate my choice of whether I dine or not can do without my presence," he thunders in a vigorous defence of the "festive board" against the "Nazis of the masonic world" who want it reduced or eliminated. It is, he explains, "one of the big topics of conversation in masonic circles". What does Martin Short think of that?

I also scanned the small ads in The Square for sinister cabals looking for masons to join their ranks. The Logic Ritual Association, the Goose and Gridiron Society, the London Lunchtimers, the International Masonic Poetry Society . . . bodies to make the flesh creep. And, scariest of all, the Masonic Philatelic Club, based in Cleveland, "open only to masons in good standing of the English Constitution and recognised Grand Lodges". There is an article in The Square about the stamps of Belgium (remarkably, it is part four in a series on Belgian stamps). I assume that encoded within these apparently innocent words on Belgian politician-freemasons is a sinister message to the philatelists of Cleveland. You have been warned.
fields.bodyText: You're not going to mug us, are you?" asks Chris Connop, spokesman for the United Grand Lodge of England. He is evidently worried on this point, as he asks the question half a dozen times. He also looks suspicious when the photographer starts grovelling around on the floor of the grand temple at Freemasons Hall, an art deco masterpiece in central London and the masons' HQ. "I don't like being photographed from below," he explains. "It makes me look sinister." The photographer becomes agitated and utters an expletive, which may be the first swearword ever uttered in freemasonry's most hallowed hall. Connop is paranoid because mugging has become an occupational hazard for freemasons. He is fuming over Monday's Newsnight, which made great play of the bizarre initiation rites undertaken by aspiring masons, and by an article by the son of a mason in the Independent portraying freemasonry as "the perfect hobby for bored middle-aged men engaged in undemanding jobs who hanker for a faintly exotic social life". The freemasons hope this is the dark media hour just before a golden dawn. They are tired of being traduced, and have appointed a PR agency called MDA to re-present them to a doubting public. The doubts have been put most forcibly by Martin Short, author of The Brotherhood, who argues that the heavy concentration of masons in the law and the police force perverts justice. "Can all the rituals be merely symbolic?" asks Short. "One must presume that people join lodges predominantly to feather their own nests, and to form a loose combination against the interests of everybody who is not a mason." Short did battle on Newsnight with Mike Dewar, head of MDA and a former colonel whose 30 years in the army has left its mark in the way he describes everything in military terms. He is preparing a campaign on behalf of freemasonry; it will be a battle, and initially the masons may have to take some flak, but a couple of years on he reckons our ideas of freemasonry - and our presumption that it is secretive, sinister and self-interested - will have been changed. "The freemasons feel defensive at the moment," says the brisk, pinstripe-suited Dewar. "They feel they've been pressured. They've been attacked and vilified for so long that every reaction is a defensive reaction - 'No, we're not going to do that; as a matter of principle we won't publish lists of members.' I hope that in two years' time, when this campaign starts to be successful, they'll be a lot less sensitive about that sort of thing. They're not per se secretive about being a mason; in fact they're happy to sing about it, and that's what I'm encouraging them to do." Dewar is not a mason and says he prefers not to know what goes on at initiation ceremonies (sharp instruments placed against bared breasts, silken nooses placed around the heads of initiates). "I couldn't care a damn what the ceremony is," he says. "That's not what's important. What is important is that these people are extremely good people; well-meaning, upright people with high moral standards. They are a fraternal society whose aim is to make good men better, and their achievements speak for themselves. They collect massive sums of money for charity - £17m last year - and most of the money goes to non-masonic charities." Others have been less willing to ignore the rituals that are an integral part of freemasonry. In 1996, in an article in this paper, Short attacked the penalties which he said initiates agreed to accept if they transgressed against a brother mason: "having my throat cut across, my tongue torn out by the root and buried in the sand of the sea at low water mark". And that, said Short, was only the penalty for "first-degree" masons, the so-called entered apprentices in their Persil-white aprons. Second-degree (or fellowcraft) transgressors faced having their hearts "torn from their breasts and fed to ravenous birds", while third-degree (or master mason) miscreants faced the ultimate penalty, being severed in two, their bowels burned to ashes, and those ashes "scattered over the face of the earth and wafted by the four winds of heaven." Short, however, had not been reading the extremely useful Freemasons' Diary, which explains that these hideous penalties have fallen into disuse. "When masonic ritual was developing in the late 1600s and 1700s," it explains soothingly, "it was quite common for legal and civil oaths to include physical penalties, and freemasonry simply followed the practice of the times. After long discussion, they were removed from the promises in 1986." I asked for clarification from Jim Daniel, grand secretary of the United Grand Lodge. "The physical penalties, which were always only symbolic, were removed from the obligations in 1986," he says. "They were not replaced, so that a candidate still makes his obligation in the certain knowledge that he will be 'branded as a wilfully perjured individual void of all moral worth and totally unfit to be received into this worshipful lodge or any other warranted lodge or society of men who prize honour and virtue above the external advantages of rank and fortune' if he violates his obligation." So no ravenous birds or ritual disembowelling, but you certainly won't be welcome at lodge suppers. The rest of the ritual remains intact, and the masonic diary defends it as a "shared experience which binds the members together", posing a crucial question to itself in its Q&A explanation of freemasonry - "Why do grown men run around with their trousers rolled up." Its answer is unembarrassed: "It is true that candidates have to roll up their trouser legs during the three ceremonies when they are being admitted to membership. Taken out of context this can seem amusing, but like other aspects of freemasonry, it has a symbolic meaning." (Irritatingly, it doesn't explain what it symbolises.) Masons are sensitive to the charge that they owe their primary allegiance to their "craft". "Freemasons do not swear allegiances to each other or to freemasonry," says my masonic diary. "Freemasons promise to support others in times of need, but only if that support does not conflict with their duties to God, the law, their family or with their responsibilities as a citizen." Connop becomes agitated at the suggestion that masons would put their masonic commitments before their worldly duties. "We are not allowed to go around giving masonic signals [there are secret handshakes, passwords and signs] outside a masonic context, because if we did we could be thrown out," he insists. "I'm a magistrate and if I were sitting as a magistrate and somebody tried to give me one of the degree signs, I would say immediately what was going on if I was in the chair. If not, I would say to the chairman, 'I'm sorry but this defendant is trying to gain advantage by his membership of freemasonry,' and I would retire from the bench and not hear that case. That is outrageous. That is not what we stand for." The hardest thing for an outsider to grasp is what freemasonry is actually for. Connop, who is a member of no fewer than 13 lodges, supplies a one-word answer: "fun". He enjoys the ritual, and opens his mason's case to show us his numerous medals, aprons and masonic ties. He is heading off that evening to the lodge of which he is master to "make a mason" - induct an apprentice into the craft - and is palpably looking forward to it, rehearsing the lines which form part of ceremony. He values the moral compass that freemasonry provides in his life and is moved when he shows us the masonic artefacts that soldiers carried with them in the first world war, but above all he wants to stress the enjoyment and sense of fellowship he derives from being part of the organisation. The Real Secrets of Freemasonry, a guide to the craft prepared by Worshipful Brother George Gibson in 1945 and much reprinted since, takes a more moralistic stance. "Freemasonry is an organised system of morality . . . derived from divine wisdom and age-long experience, which for preservation from outer assault and inner decay is veiled in allegory and illustrated by symbols. It preaches the Fatherhood of God and the Brotherhood of Man. The influence of divine inspiration is with it throughout. Each Candidate for membership declares his belief in the Supreme Being: keeping strictly aloof from political divisions, it demands from its members a recognition of the eternal and of the light which comes from above." So what is the essence of freemasonry? Material self-advancement and sinister secrecy, say its critics. Fun, fellowship and a moral code, masons counter. Dewar, who hopes to reverse the decline that has seen membership in England and Wales fall to 320,000, intends to present them as "good, solid citizens with the right moral values who support all that is good in society". But there are two other factors which must surely be considered - food and stamp collecting. The editor of The Square, "the independent magazine for freemasons", devotes his editorial in this month's issue to the important question: "To eat or not to eat". "Any masonic group which sought to eliminate my choice of whether I dine or not can do without my presence," he thunders in a vigorous defence of the "festive board" against the "Nazis of the masonic world" who want it reduced or eliminated. It is, he explains, "one of the big topics of conversation in masonic circles". What does Martin Short think of that? I also scanned the small ads in The Square for sinister cabals looking for masons to join their ranks. The Logic Ritual Association, the Goose and Gridiron Society, the London Lunchtimers, the International Masonic Poetry Society . . . bodies to make the flesh creep. And, scariest of all, the Masonic Philatelic Club, based in Cleveland, "open only to masons in good standing of the English Constitution and recognised Grand Lodges". There is an article in The Square about the stamps of Belgium (remarkably, it is part four in a series on Belgian stamps). I assume that encoded within these apparently innocent words on Belgian politician-freemasons is a sinister message to the philatelists of Cleveland. You have been warned.

fields.headline: Johnston Press posts 21% profit rise
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Johnston Press has brushed off rising costs and an advertising slump by reporting a 21% rise in profits, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Newspaper publisher Johnston Press has brushed off concerns over rising newsprint costs and a slump in the advertising market by predicting a trouble-free year ahead.

The regional newspaper group made the bold statement after reporting pre-tax profits of £66.5m for last year, a rise of 21% from 1999.

Chairman Fred Johnston said the company's prospects for 2001 were good, with falling unemployment in the south boosting job advertising.

"The current year for Johnston Press has begun well, despite a transatlantic economic slowdown and problems in parts of the technology sector," he said.

The Edinburgh-based group reported revenues of £292m from its 200 titles, a rise of more than 20% on 1999.

Johnston Press joined forces with rivals Gannett and Guardian Media Group late last year to bid for Yorkshire Post owner Regional Independent Media, but today the company said RIM was considering "alternative options".

webTitle: Vaz faces new inquiry into alleged Hinduja links

fields.headline: Vaz faces new inquiry into alleged Hinduja links
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, is to face a fresh inquiry into his alleged links with the Hinduja Foundation.
fields.body:
The minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, is to face a fresh inquiry into his alleged links with the Hinduja Foundation.

A complaint was sent to the Commons standards and privileges committee after newspaper reports that the billionaire buisnessmen gave money through their foundation to a company whose directors include Mr Vaz's wife and mother.

Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, today wrote to the Tory shadow cabinet office minister, Andrew Lansley, to tell him that he would investigate his complaint.

The Sunday Times disclosed last weekend that in 1995 the foundation had paid nearly £1,200 to Mapesbury Communications, a company set up by Mr Vaz. The money helped to pay for an Indian spiritual leader's visit to the Commons.

Mr Lansley referred the matter to Ms Filkin because Mr Vaz had previously told her he had never received any financial support from the Hindujas.

A report on an earlier investigation by Ms Filkin into Mr Vaz's conduct as an MP last week cleared the Leicester East MP of all but one of the charges against him.

The Commons standards and privileges committee recommended no action against Mr Vaz, but criticised him for failing to cooperate fully with the commissioner.

Mapesbury was initially set up to handle income from Mr Vaz's extra-parliamentary activities, but its purpose has since changed and he now has no formal link with it.

Mr Vaz is due to accompany the prime minister, Tony Blair, to a European summit in Stockholm on Friday.

webTitle: Hague appoints Muslim adviser on ethnic issues

fields.headline: Hague appoints Muslim adviser on ethnic issues
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague attempted to mend fences with Britain's ethnic minorities yesterday when he lavished praise on Muslims for leading the fight against racism.
fields.body:
William Hague attempted to mend fences with Britain's ethnic minorities yesterday when he lavished praise on Muslims for leading the fight against racism.

Speaking in the wake of the row over his "foreign land" speech, the Tory leader said that Muslims had promoted values of faith and responsibility since they first settled in Britain in the 16th century.

Opening his speech to the Muslim Council of Britain with the Islamic saying "peace be with you", Mr Hague said that Tories and Muslims shared the values of hard work and support for the family.

"Your values of strong faith, education, responsibility to others, of hard work and tolerance are values which resonate with all our citizens in every part of this country," Mr Hague said.

He announced that he had appointed Mohammed Riaz, who is standing for the Tories in Bradford West, as an adviser to the shadow cabinet on ethnic and cultural issues.

Tory sources denied that Mr Hague's remarks were designed to mend fences after his warning earlier this month that a Labour election victory would turn Britain into a "foreign land".

They said his remarks at the party's spring conference in Harrogate were about the threat posed by the EU and were not about race.

fields.headline: RTL warns Hollick on C5 investment
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: RTL has warned Lord Hollick's United Business Media that it will have to continue investing in C5. By Dan Milmo.
Mar 21: C5 results boost RTL fortunes
Mar 21: RTL profits halved as expansion bites
fields.body:
Channel 5 owner RTL has warned Lord Hollick's United Business Media it will have to continue investing in the station.

Bruno Chauvat, managing director of RTL, said today he was determined to avoid a repetition of the budgeting dispute that saw both parties clash in court late last year.

The row broke out when United went to the courts to in an effort to have a £10m film deal blocked.

"I think the only way to improve audience share is by spending on programming. It is in all our interests to invest... It would be great to arrive at a consensus," said Mr Chauvat.

The Luxembourg-based group also admitted it had attempted to buy United's 35% stake in the company, but negotiations fell down over price.

Didier Bellens, chief executive of RTL, said the group had lodged a bid of £220m for the holding.

He said RTL was astounded by United's own valuation of the stake, which came to £500m.

"There was a huge difference of price, but now we are at £350m, so there has been some progress. You should know about the forecast for the UK market and you should do your homework," he said.

Mr Bellens added that the disputed £10m film deal was a "very reasonable package for programming".

United failed in its efforts to prevent RTL from going ahead with the deal.

Mr Bellens said that the advertising outlook for its German businesses is much worse than expected, and the group will cut programming costs.

Advertising spend on German television was expected to rise by 6% this year, but RTL has been forced to rein in its budget after its own forecasts found advertising revenue would improve by between 2% and 3%.

Mr Chauvat added that programming at Channel 5 would not be affected by the cutback.

"We believe that we can reduce programming costs. It will be relatively marginal, and will just mean more repeats in the summer. The viewers will not notice it," said Mr Chauvat.

Lord Hollick, chief executive of United, said recently he did not intend to sell Channel 5 for at least two years.

fields.headline: Fraser gave up £1.2m company for Express job
fields.trailText:
1pm update: Jason Fraser, the top paparazzo who yesterday joined Express Newspapers, gave up a £1.2m turnover company to work for Richard Desmond. By Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 21: New boy Fraser makes a splash
Mar 20: Express rivals angry at new signing
Celebrity stalker: Jason Fraser profile
Mar 20: Express snaps up top photographer
fields.body:
Jason Fraser, the top paparazzo who yesterday was given a place on the board of Express Newspapers, has given up a £1.2m turnover company to work for Richard Desmond.

Accounts from the photographer's company, Fraser Woodward Limited, reveal he paid himself and his ex-wife Morven Fraser £662,547 during 2000.

The accounts, which confirm Mr Fraser as one of the highest paid photographers on the circuit, give credence to reports that Mr Desmond is to pay him a package in excess of £1m.

The photographer's company last year made a profit of £15,000.

The appointment of Mr Fraser, a formerly successful freelance operator, as an executive director on Express Newspapers is unprecedented in the relations between newspapers and paparazzo.

fields.headline: Where's the bar?
fields.standfirst: Amanda Holden's dress; Richard Eyre's audacity; Graham Norton's D&G suit; and Penny Smith's bad jokes - Monkey reports from last night's Royal Television Society awards
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Forget Amanda Holden's dress, it was Richard Eyre who turned heads at the RTS awards, reports Media Monkey.
10.45am: BBC drama triumph
Full list of winners: RTS website
fields.body:
Forget Amanda Holden and that dress - the biggest head-turner at last night's RTS programming awards bash was the sight of Richard Eyre, boldly stepping out in public just the day after news broke of his shock resignation from Pearson TV owner RTL. After many years stuck within the confines of a media industry suit, Eyre is planning three months off in order to, among other things, knock out a novel. He has a deal with none other than Penguin, the book publishing arm of his former employer, Pearson. "Marjorie [Scardino] calls it guilty publishing," Eyre quipped.

It may be La Holden who hogs the RTS picture captions in the tabloids with her little purple silk number, but it was the impish Graham Norton who got to name-check Dolce & Gabbana in his without whoms... after accepting the best presenter gong. The man who put the "erve" into effervescent was deeply grateful for his eye-catching gold brocade D&G suit... worth a cool £35,000.

In another acceptance speech Stephen Jardine, who picked up the best regional presenter award for his Scottish TV work, let slip that he learnt all he knows on that renowned presenting school of hard knocks, the GMTV couch. Apparently the toughest test was trying to keep a straight face during sensitive stories, with co-presenter Penny Smith running her hand up and down his thigh. Smith would have been horrified enough to learn that such unprofessional behaviour had been outed in front of the TV industry's great and good. Unfortunately, in her role as RTS awards host, she was standing on the stage beside Jardine as he let the cat out of the bag.

If our Penny was planning to use last night's RTS platform to launch a move into comedy, Monkey advises her to think again. Unfortunately her gags between awards presentations fell on painfully stony ground in the vastness of the Grosvenor House ballroom. Stick to the couch, Pen. That or shoot the scriptwriter.

Has the RTS joined the Temperance Union and not told its top banana Will Wyatt? Monkey only asks because, after el presidente Wyatt had closed proceedings with the cheery call "the bar is now open...", a fruitless search proved that there was in fact no bar open, anywhere in the hotel's ballroom or its environs. Monkey was forced to join other RTS malingerers in the time honoured awards do pastime of slurping leftover plonk from vacated tables. The shame, the shame...

No sooner had the ceremony itself finished than another TV awards night tradition, that of losers moaning into their unfilled champagne glasses about the iniquity of it all, duly began. But in this case it was hard not to feel sympathy for the ITV people complaining of a BBC stitch-up; given that the commercial broadcaster spent most of 2000 stomping the BBC1 peaktime schedule into tiny little pieces in ratings terms. ITV types were particularly mystified by the award of the best arts show prize to a BBC2 documentary several claimed never to have heard of, entitled Wisconsin Death Trip. Rumours that the programme was in fact BBC2 controller Jane Root's video diary of her recent sojourn in the US on a management training course could not be confirmed.

fields.headline: Freemasons
fields.standfirst: The United Grand Lodge of England has appointed a PR agency to improve the image of freemasonry. Here's our guide to the secretive society on the web
fields.trailText: The United Grand Lodge of England has appointed a PR agency to improve the image of freemasonry. Here's our guide to the secretive society on the web
fields.body:
1. Boaz! No, not another Ali G skit. It's the name of the secret handshake an apprentice needs in order to enter the Freemasons.

2. Not so secret now. The masons are trying to improve their image, and have shown the Guardian round their stylish Grand Lodge, in London's fashionable Covent Garden.

3. They say (through their new PR man) that it's time all this conspiracy nonsense about secret handshakes was put to bed. But do they have secret handshakes? Er, yes.

4. What's odd is that the origin of the conspiracy theory is almost as veiled as the origin of the masons themselves.

5. It seems to have started in 1798 with a book by John Robison, Proofs of a Conspiracy Against All the Religions and Governments of Europe, carried on in the secret meetings of Free Masons, Illuminati, and Reading Societies, collected from good authorities.

6. He accused them of being Godless adherents of "Cosmo-politism" (take that, Bridget Jones), supporters of the French Revolution, and friends of the Illuminati.

7. Republican, cosmopolitan, egalitarian, and elitist? Count me in! It's the good old liberal elite.

8. Disappointingly, though, most notable Freemasons in the past few centuries have been upstanding pillars of the community. Like Mozart (drunk), Substitute Nelson (adulterer) and Churchill (journalist).

9. Sorry, but it says here that even that old chestnut about masonic symbols on the dollar bill may not be true. That's according to the US state department (probably masons to a man).

10. If you're looking for an immensely powerful association of like-minded citizens, occupying important posts in politics and the judiciary, with strange, outlandish symbols and harsh penalties for disloyalty, try this one.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: Mick Jagger is allowing the boyfriend of his 17-year-old daughter Elizabeth to move in to the family home. Would you?
fields.trailText: The question: Mick Jagger is allowing the boyfriend of his 17-year-old daughter Elizabeth to move in to the family home. Would you?
fields.body:
Stephanie Taylor: Administration manager and mother

There is no way I would allow my daughter to be disrespectful to me or her father by allowing her boyfriend to live under our roof. I would be extremely uncomfortable with having a stranger in our home who would be a distraction for my daughter. I am unable to understand why some parents allow their teenagers to rule them. When I was growing up, we were taught that, as well as respecting our parents, we must respect ourselves; a boy who wished to move in with his teenage girlfriend would lead me to question his upbringing.
Verdict: No

Deborah Alexander: Handywoman and mother

I think that, in this situation, parents can't win. Parents may think their child isn't old enough to take this step but, if she's determined to do it, she'll do it anyway. I think that the most important thing is to protect your child. When my oldest daughter was 17, her boyfriend more or less moved in with us. I wanted to know what was going on in her home life, and if it's in your home then you do know. The main difference between Mick Jagger and me is that I imagine he's got a bit more space to accommodate a boyfriend in his house than I have.
Verdict: Yes

Keith Toms: Labour councillor and father

I think the most important thing to do in a situation like this is to talk things through with your teenager and her boyfriend because moving someone else in would lead to a certain amount of upheaval. If I felt my child was confident in the relationship and mature enough to cope with the situation, then I would let them go ahead. If my child was going to take this step anyway, I would want to make them feel as comfortable and protected as possible. As long as they had both thought the whole thing through, and were not entering into the arrangement lightly, they would get my support.
Verdict: Yes

Dorit Braun: Director of Parentline Plus and mother

It depends on a parent's own attitudes towards sex and sexual relationships, and how you have discussed sex with your child and whether there are younger siblings in the family. How big your house is and how many bathrooms you have is also a factor. Parents of teenage children are perpetually struggling to get access to their own bathroom as it is. If a child is going to enter a relationship, many parents would prefer them to do so in a safe and comfortable environment rather than sneaking away. I would feel comfortable with this arrangement.
Verdict: Yes

Navin Shah: Architect and father

I wouldn't reject the proposal. First of all, I would like to sit down with both of them and ask why they wanted to do this. It's a big decision and I would want to point out all the pros and cons to them. I think it is important that the whole family gets involved in discussing an issue like this. If I felt that they were both committed to each other and had good reasons for wanting to live together, I would support them. The advantage of having them live with us would be that, if problems arose, they may accept parental help and. If they were hell-bent on doing this, to resist would be counter-productive.
Verdict: Yes

Lyndon Bowring: Chair of Christian Action, Research & Education

Mick Jagger's concern for protection, and expressions of love towards his children are admirable. However, allowing or encouraging these two young people to move in together in a family home is neither a protective nor, ultimately, a loving thing to do. I am sure that his motives are good, but I fear that this is a decision he will live to regret. My own teenage children have chosen to imbibe my values that sex is a special gift and worth waiting for when you meet the person you want to spend the rest of your life with. We ought to give teenagers more support to resist the pressure to have sex so young.
Verdict: No

webTitle: Shouting at your kids can damage their brains

fields.headline: Loud but not proud
fields.standfirst: Shouting at your kids can damage their brains, as well as hurting their ears, according to US child psychiatrists. Ouch, says Anne Karpf
fields.trailText: Shouting at your kids can damage their brains, as well as hurting their ears, according to US child psychiatrists. Ouch, says Anne Karpf
fields.body:
I thought I was impervious to those "research shows . . ." scare stories, but this one got to me. Shouting at children, according to a recent study by psychiatrists at a hospital affiliated to Harvard Medical School, can significantly and permanently alter the structure of their brains. It was only inordinate self-restraint - of the kind I never display towards my kids - that stopped me marching them straight off for a brain scan.

Ours is a Sturm und Drang household, with shouting matches, screaming fits, and temper tantrums - and that's just the parents. The neighbours have been warned, even the kids have been warned. At two, my first-born could do a passable imitation of me yelling (and she did, to all-comers). And one of her sibling's early sentences was: "You're a lovely Mummy, but a shouty one."

The Harvard study comes in the wake of the revelation that Jennifer Aniston, the Friends star, is not on speaking terms with her mother, partly because she shouted at the actor when she was a child. "Yes, I shouted," admitted Mom, "but a lot of my friends yell at their kids." Please God my girls never make it to Hollywood.

Is shouting at one's children the ultimate parental taboo? Certainly, it contravenes all the good parenting slogans. Shouting at children shows them that you're out of control - and I am. The reassuring thing is that almost everyone seems to do it: rarely before in my writing life have I found such an eager queue of volunteer interviewees. And almost everyone admits that it doesn't work.

There's an American saying that shouting at your children to obey is like using the horn to steer your car - and it produces the same results. But this misses the point: you don't yell at your kids because, after careful consideration, you deem it the most effective strategy; you yell at them because you've lost your rag.

The triggers are many and various, but maternal isolation and exhaustion come high on the list. Cathy Brewer, mother of two-and-a-half-year-old Gemma and five-year-old Jack, confesses: "When Jack was little, I was on my own with him a lot and shouted at him a lot. With Gemma, I've had more help and so I shout less."

Pippa Fox shouts when her children want her attention and she's trying to make their tea. Alice Goldman finds she shouts most "at the end of a day you feel should have ended but hasn't".

"I shout when I'm tired," she explains, "but also when my expectations are highest - on holiday or the weekend. And I often shout at my daughter when I'm angry with myself."

As for me, like most mothers, I rant when I've an unconscionable number of things to squeeze into an unfeasibly small amount of time (which happens most days). I also thunder when my kids encroach on the last vestiges of my personal time and space: I have this peculiar belief that, after more than 11 years of parenting, I should be allowed to pee in peace.

Almost all shouters feel guilty. Pippa Fox says she's so ashamed she shouts at her sons, aged five and nearly two, every day that "I'm trying to cut down" - as if it were like smoking. When Alice Goldman first shouted at her two-year-old, she was so horrified that she went straight round to the health visitor to confess. "The health visitor just laughed and said: 'You'd better get used to it.'"

Is it so inevitable? I've concluded that there are shouty families, and non-shouty ones. DW Winnicott, the psychoanalyst, argued that all mothers feel dominated, exploited, humiliated, drained and criticised by their babies, and that "the mother hates her infant from the word go." Fay Weldon once said: "The greatest advantage of not having children must be that you can go on believing that you are a nice person: once you have children, you realise how wars start."

Sebastian Kraemer, consultant child and adult psychiatrist at the Tavistock Clinic, London, takes a robust view: "I can't imagine how parents can't shout at their children. Family life is such a cauldron of emotions. A happy family has to have some conflict in it: in intimate relationships people have to row and make up. A 15-year-old makes you shout at him sooner or later."

Shouting at kids is often bracketed with smacking them, but for many of us it's an alternative. But when does shouting turn into bullying or verbal abuse? It's partly a matter of degree and ratio. According to Kraemer, "If there's no remission in shouting and there's no loving as well, it's destructive." The age of the child and what you actually say is also important.

"A toddler doesn't understand the difference between you shouting at them and hating them," he elaborates. "With a teenager, that's not the case. There is also a difference between honest self-disclosure ('You've made me very angry') and abuse ('You're a horrible little brat')."

Though many of us worry that shouting at our children will damage not just their brains but their wellbeing, most children quickly become desensitised to loud parents and tune out. "I think I suffer more from my shouting than they do," Pippa Fox says. "I feel absolutely awful afterwards, whereas they're fine five minutes later."

According to Jenny Riley, whose sons are 12 and 14, "The more you shout, the less they listen, and so the louder you have to shout as the years go by - depressing, isn't it ?" Another result of shouting at children is that they become pretty adept shouters themselves.

On the other hand, children who've never been yelled at can be quite fragile flowers (or so I like to think). And almost all shouters agree that a good yell can clear the air and be liberating. Jenny Riley is that rare thing, an unrepentant shouter - not only that, but a qualified counsellor.

"I grew up in a don't-express-yourself household," she says, "but I'm a volatile person, and I've got volatile children, and on balance I don't think that our shouting hurts any of us. If I overdo it I say sorry.

"I've studied all the skills. I'm just not good at practising them in the four walls of my own home."

One way of shouting less, according to Doro Marden of Parentline Plus, the parenting support organisation, is to record your evening meal on cassette and hear it back afterwards: "It can be quite instructive." Marden also suggests that thinking about the trigger situations can help. "Is it when your blood sugar level is low, or theirs is? Is it always when you pick them up from school? You can also try not to get caught up in their anger."

Most crucially, as psychotherapist Roziska Parker puts it in her book Torn in Two: The Experience of Maternal Ambivalence (Virago), mothers vary in the extent to which they can tolerate and manage the conflict provoked by loving and hating the same child.

So the guilt and anxiety we feel about shouting at our kids comes partly from our discomfort with the realities of parenting, and disappointment at failing to become the idealised parents we hoped we'd be.

No one would advocate shouting as desirable parental behaviour, but perhaps a more realistic aim is not so much to try to staunch it as to acknowledge it. No easy feat: every parent I interviewed for this article asked for their name to be changed. (I obliged.) Shouters, it seems, still put themselves on a par with convicted criminals.

fields.headline: Which mother knows best?
fields.standfirst: When your mum tells you it's wrong to breastfeed, do you take her advice, or go with your own instincts as a mother? By Caroline Luce
fields.trailText: When your mum tells you it's wrong to breastfeed, do you take her advice, or go with your own instincts as a mother? By Caroline Luce
fields.body:
When my baby was about two weeks old, my mother and her sister came to lunch. I showed them round our new house and the garden and we sat down to eat the soup and salad my mother had brought. When I started breastfeeding Sam after lunch, they both got up without a word and left the room. Soon I could hear them in the room above, discussing the paintwork and colour scheme. They had taken themselves on another lengthy tour of the house, acting as though they had not seen it all less than an hour before.

I asked my aunt, who has four children, if any of them had been breastfed. She had tried with the first, she said, but gave up after a few days. "It doesn't seem to have done any of them any harm," she added briskly.

A week or so later, I was alone with my mother at her house, and settled down on the sofa after lunch to feed the baby. As the cups of coffee grew cold in front of me, I wondered where my mother was. Eventually, I found her out in the garden, weeding the roses and waiting for me to finish.

Occasionally, her disapproval was even more explicit. When the baby was six weeks old and I rang her feverish with mastitis, she retorted: "Get him on the bottle!" One day when his face was covered in spots, she said spitefully: "It's his diet."

I used to wonder at the intense activity of the breastfeeding lobby. Best for baby, the literature insisted, best for you. Leaflets, lectures, classes, support groups, all hammering home the message that if you don't breastfeed your baby, you are a bad mother, your child's immune system will be rubbish, and you'll never get your figure back. Then I found out what the "breast is best" campaigners were up against. Once my baby was born, I encountered the full force of the anti-breastfeeding camp, in all its disgusted, put-it-away squeamishness - in the person of my mother.

When such powerful disapproval comes from the one person you rely on to give you child-rearing advice, it's a severe blow. Whatever your rapport with your mother has been, when you have a child, the relationship is suddenly polarised in an intense new way: you do need her help and support and you do want her to think you're a good mother.

She, meanwhile, has a chance, especially if she is a housewife and her daughter has a career, to prove that she knows a thing or two. The "we didn't do it like that in my day" attitude reveals far more than a change in childcare fashions. It usually lays bare a seam in your relationship with your mother that, if it isn't to undermine your confidence, needs to be laid bare, however painfully, and examined.

Janet Reibstein, a psychologist, says: "What happens to mothers when you have a baby is a reproduction of your own mothering. As you nurture and breastfeed your own child, the mirror image happens to your mother: it's such a powerful moment, it ensnares everyone, and you become a baby for her again. This shared experience can be a bond, but if it's a tender spot, it can feel like an attack. She might feel, 'I can be a mother again, I can teach you how to do it,' and if you don't take her advice, you're invalidating her."

My mother says she started off breastfeeding her first baby for a few weeks, but found it "too limiting": "Just after I'd had Emily, I went to a party: I seem to remember I nipped home to feed her and then went back to the party."

She belonged to a social world in which nothing is fun without a martini in one hand and a cigarette in the other, and anyone who gave up either during pregnancy was just being a bore. Evidently, she succumbed to the social pressure to pretend that having children shouldn't spoil your fun.

She took great pride in the fact that, for most of her pregnancy, she didn't look pregnant. In her photograph album, there is a picture of her and my father on holiday in the south of France, taken just over a month after my birth. My sisters and I were left at home with a nanny. It's not that my mother hadn't wanted children, it's just that we were not supposed to change her lifestyle.

And now she expects the same of me. While my partner and I were ensconced in our blissed-out, totally domestic existence during the baby's first month of life, our friends joked about daytime TV, while my mother kept asking whether we had seen anything good at the theatre.

This generation of mothers appals her, and it's not just our tendency to breastfeed, willy nilly. In her day, she tells me, babies were put in their prams and left in the garden. They might cry, but they would stop eventually, and anyway they were out of earshot.

"He'll get the upper hand!" she scolded, when Sam was no more than a week old, and I scooped him up, bleating and red-faced, from his basket. "He's got you wrapped around his little finger!"

A friend of my mother's, a woman at least 10 years her senior, shed some light on this rather harsh attitude to parenting. I was sitting with Sam slumped asleep on my shoulder while we drank tea and chatted. The old lady said: "It's so nice that you have him with you so much of the time. We used to be told to put them down in the next room as soon as we'd fed them, and not to go near them again for four hours. Isn't that sad?"

"The childcare bible after the war said you had to feed your baby every four hours and you were not to pick it up if it cried," says Reibstein, author of The Family Through Divorce. "That was the rule. It made a lot of people uncomfortable. Your mother had feelings about you that you have about your son. But she was told, 'No: children have to be subdued, they have a strong will.' She learned things that countered her mothering instincts. If your mother was tyrannised by the four-hour regime and sees her own daughter doing the complete opposite, she feels she's being attacked."

Now the fashion in childcare has changed, it pains some women of my mother's generation to see younger mothers relishing the physical comfort of a wriggly, sweet-smelling new baby, whenever they want to.

My mother frequently expresses the view that there is something wrong with women who cuddle their babies excessively and, worse, that it is bad for the child. "If you're beastly to your child in the early years," she always said, "it will turn out very well behaved."

When my eldest sister had children, I saw how strict my mother was with them and realised that what I thought had been said in jest, was actually in earnest. My sister's children, who were boisterous and outspoken and, if they wanted something, expected to get it, were considered outrageously spoilt.

Eva Figes, a grandmother at 68, remembers when she had her children, she was kept in hospital for days - as all new mothers were - told to feed the babies every four hours and not to pick them up. "I never obeyed the rules; I couldn't bear it. When I got home from hospital, I was in very limited accommodation and I couldn't get out of earshot, so there was no question of leaving them to cry.

"My father told me I was spoiling them, that I gave in to my son too much. And I did. I was taught to be terribly respectful to my parents, but I let my children say what they felt.

"As a grandmother it's a gift, it's your last chance. You're thinking, 'My life's closed off, my children are middle aged,' then there's this new life. I don't mind the children being spoiled - it's not my problem. As a grandparent the one thing you must not do is interfere in the way your children bring up their children. I would never, never say, 'You shouldn't do that,' unless they ask."

If she can respect you for the way you bring up your baby, it's a decisive moment. It can produce a sort of healing, can make a connection with your own mother, and create empathy between you."

They had taken themselves on another lengthy tour of the house, acting as though they had not seen it all less than an hour before. "It doesn't seem to have done any of them any harm," she added briskly. A week or so later, I was alone with my mother at her house, and settled down on the sofa after lunch to feed the baby. While my partner and I were ensconced in our blissed-out, totally domestic existence during the baby's first month of life, our friends joked about daytime TV, while my mother kept asking whether we had seen anything good at the theatre. This generation of mothers appals her, and it's not just our tendency to breastfeed, willy nilly. In her day, she tells me, babies were put in their prams and left in the garden. fields.headline: Wanna be in my gang?
fields.standfirst: Julie Myerson is a grown-up mum, but in the playground, she still feels like a child
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson is a grown-up mum, but in the playground, she still feels like a child
fields.body:
The school playground, a grey Monday morning in March. I discover that our usual partners - the ones we always team up with - are going on holiday.

I go straight over and ask B if we can join up with her. She says sorry, but they've already got their table organised. (And, though she'd never say it, I know that one of the people on her table really doesn't like me.)

So I get up courage to go and ask F. I don't know her all that well but really like her - I'd like to be her friend.

But, oh dear, F says that they'd have loved to team up with us, but they've already got someone else. Do I know them, R and T? I don't think so, I say - making a point of smiling brightly, so it doesn't look like I mind.

"Don't worry," chips in V, who is a churchgoer and always keen to help. "I'll ask around and see if there's anybody left without a partner."

I thank her, but secretly think: "Oh God save us, now we'll be stuck with someone awful - someone like S or W or M." I tell V: "Thanks, but it's OK; we'll sort it."

In case you're wondering, this isn't the playground at my junior mixed infants circa 1968, and I'm not eight years old and smelly. No, it's 2001, I'm forty-and-a-half, and I'm flailing around before the morning bell at my children's school, trying to find another couple for the quiz night.

But I feel eight, loitering weedily by the sandpit, trying to find someone who'll play. I tell myself things have changed, I'm a big girl now. OK, it's true that I never used to be picked at netball - standing, pink with embarrassment and dread, my back to the crumbly sandstone wall. But these days, I don't generally have any trouble getting picked for the things I want to get picked for.

Still, even though we're all grown up now, even though those ancient horrors (PE kits, blue-veined outdoor thighs, sick-smelling school dinners) are safely in the past, it doesn't take much to bring back the nervy eight-year-old. Our badges of grown-upness - own clothes, funky jobs, man, kids - are but a thin skin.

Plonk us back here on the asphalt, peel away that veneer of adulthood, and you'll see that the crucial dynamic has not really shifted since 1968.

You recognise the types: the shy, overweight one who's learned to be (emphatically!) outgoing; the skinny one who meant to, but never quite pulled it off; the popular one in the extrovert clothes (then, lots of ragged black; now, as many acid colours as possible). Over there is the fearless, sporty one in fleece, chaining up her bicycle. You just know that, 30 years ago, she'd have been the upside-down one, all knickers and navel, on the climbing frame.

And, of course, there's the bully - grimly confident, radar already out, seeking a victim. These days, equipped with fake empathy and superficial social graces, she's an even more sinister figure.

She may not steal your lunch money or put your head down the toilet. But when she tells you, with concern in her eyes, that she thought you might want to know what her child has told her about what yours did, you just know the power game is still being played.

And though we'd all say we're friendly and mature, that we'd talk to anyone, go out of our way to make an effort with the new girls and boys, do we really?

Don't we still all huddle in our various cliques, staying close to the people who make us feel safe and wanted? Standing there chatting and laughing at a quarter to nine, as if life's so gloriously delightful, aren't we all still doing exactly what we did back then: desperately trying to look like we belong, like we know the rules?

On Monday night, I complain to J that I've utterly failed to find us partners for the quiz night.

"Well sod it," he says, "We've booked the babysitter, why don't we just bunk off and go out to dinner?"

I gasp. "But we can't . . ."

"Oh, come on, who'll notice?"

I think about it. It's the big school fundraiser. People have put in Effort. He's a Governor, I'm a Governor's Partner. We can't let them down.

"We haven't been out alone for ages," he adds.

"But we shouldn't . . ."

But I already know we will. Is that it, then - the difference between eight and 40: knowing that no one's going to tell you off? Or is it that - oh joy! - you no longer have to wait, shame-faced, back to a wall, to be picked? If you haven't got a partner, then - what the hell, go eat dinner in town.

webTitle: The bliss of a new baby

fields.headline: Holding the baby
fields.standfirst: They said it would get worse after the birth. But Jennifer Torrance is finding life with baby Joe utterly blissful
fields.trailText: They said it would get worse after the birth. But Jennifer Torrance is finding life with baby Joe utterly blissful
fields.body:
It's six weeks to the day since he was born and I'm sitting here with a glass of wine in my hand while he sleeps in the room next door, unable to believe my luck. Why did no one tell me life with a new baby could be this good?

Throughout my miserably nauseous and bloated pregnancy I scared myself silly reading Kate Mosse et al on how much worse it would get after the birth. Friends with kids felt compelled to reveal the nightmare of their first few months, while a particularly depressing exercise in a National Childbirth Trust class saw the pie chart of our paper-reading, shop-browsing lives chopped into hectic slivers of crying and nappy changing.

But - so far - life with our new baby has been bliss. Yes, he's time-consuming: up to a dozen nappy changes a day, at least six hours' breast-feeding, maybe five hours' sleep if I'm lucky. Certainly, I cried the night my milk came in and I couldn't sit up to feed because of the stitches. As I air-dried my nipples around the house, dressed in disposable knickers and flourishing a muslin square, I did feel like something out of Carry On Morris Dancing. And by three weeks I was so overwrought that Mike had to shoo me down the pub with a good friend for a pint of Guinness. But it's been heaven, all of it, and nothing like the endurance test I'd been bracing myself for.

I know I've been lucky: a five-hour labour, lots of support, everything more than ready at home (by 42 weeks I was embroidering a hand-sewn nappy bag) and a very chilled baby who is taking everything in his stride - a side effect, I like to think, of the intensive acupuncture I had in order to induce his birth. And the osteopath tells me I must be the only birth-kinked new mum she has treated who has said that labour didn't hurt that much .

Mike will be working from home for the foreseeable future, bearing the brunt of the housework and sharing the decisions about how long to let him cry. Crucially, he has also learned not to place a glass of cold water just out of reach when I'm breastfeeding.

At two weeks we found a way to make sense of this new 24-hour, free-form baby universe: child-rearing according to Gina Ford, the bestselling but controversially strict maternity nurse - but more of that another time. Though baby Joe only sticks to Ford's timetable of sleeps and feeds a third of the time, when he does - and we find ourselves sitting down to dinner while he sleeps upstairs - it seems too good to be true.

I want to shout my good fortune from the rooftops. But too many people close to me have been unable to have a child at all, or had the first months of their baby's life blighted by a bad birth and colic, for me to feel able to enthuse openly without seeming boastful. As a result, I feel we've had a miraculous, unwarranted escape - something to apologise for and nowhere to celebrate it. For, unsurprisingly I suppose, the arrival of both our families' first grandchild has failed to melt away family tensions. Some close relations remain puzzlingly distant. One grandfather still refuses to hold the baby; my brother has yet to visit.

When we got home from hospital the day after he was born and asked one set of grandparents, who live 20 minutes away, to come over, they declined, saying they were preparing dinner. It has felt at times as though the idea of grandparenthood is enough for them all, without having to connect with the baby himself.

But the emotional rawness of those first few weeks has pretty much healed, along with the stitches I was so upset about. I spent February in a sort of stoned delirium, terrified that I would throw him off rooftops and into rivers by mistake. Every time the fan came on in the bathroom I was convinced I could hear him crying. I stared at our son so much I could see his afterimage everywhere. In comparison, Mike's head looked like a horse's on the pillow next to me. We've both woken and searched the bed frantically for him in the middle of the night, unable to remember where we'd last put him down.

Somehow, it all seems a long time ago already. He has just woken up now, and I suspect that's a windy cry rather than hunger. This is the steepest learning curve I've ever been on.

fields.headline: FA and Home Office discuss anti-thug adverts
fields.trailText: 3pm: The FA and the Home Office may link up to run a campaign tackling football violence, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Football Association and the Home Office are discussing launching a joint advertising campaign to combat football hooliganism.

The FA today confirmed it is considering a joint campaign with the Home Office.

The campaign is one of a number of recommendations to have come out of a recent Home Office report, which examined ways of broadening the appeal of football and abolishing the stereotype of the racist football hooligan.

"It's something we're considering," said a spokesman for the FA.

"We broadly support the recommendations of the report and we're looking into whether advertising is the most effective way of tackling the problem."

The FA has conducted anti-racism campaigns before under the "Let's kick racism out of football" banner.

However, the campaign under consideration is expected to be wider in scope.

Other recommendations in the report, chaired by Home Office minister Lord Bassam, include relaunching the 30,000-strong England Members' Club as Club England.

A Club England roadshow will tour the country in an attempt to recruit more fans from ethnic minorities.

webTitle: Standards commissioner censures Hague over speaking fees

fields.headline: Standards commissioner censures Hague over speaking fees
fields.standfirst: Full report here
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader, William Hague, was today censured by the Commons standards commissioner Elizabeth Filkin for misleading entries in the register of members interests.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader, William Hague, was today censured by the Commons standards commissioner Elizabeth Filkin for misleading entries in the register of members interests.

She found that for two years the Tory leader had been incorrectly claiming that all speaking fees he earned were directed through the "William Hague charitable trust" to deserving causes in his Richmond constituency.

In fact, the trust had never been set up.

However, Ms Filkin recommended no action be take against Mr Hague as the entries were recorded "in good faith" and entries were not intended to be misleading.

There was no evidence of "irregularity or impropriety" in the uses the fees were put to, she added.

But she said: "Mr Hague failed to respond correctly on eight separate occasions when required to check his entry, with the result that it continued in a materially inaccurate form for a considerable period - at least six months and arguably longer."

In December 1999, Mr Hague was also censured by the commissioner for not declaring the free use of Jeffrey Archer's gym for his daily judo sessions with his aide, Seb Coe.

The Labour MP, Fraser Kemp - who made the complaint to the standards and privileges committee after the oversight was exposed on the Mark Thomas Product, a Channel 4 comedy show, - demanded that the Conservative leader make an apology to the Commons at today's prime minister's questions.

He said: "William Hague must now apologise to the house. This is the second time he has been censured by the committee on standards and privileges.

"This report shows that William Hague received money from speaking engagements and told parliament this money was going to charity for over a year when in reality the cheques were gathering dust in his office drawer."

A spokesman for Mr Hague said: "We have nothing to add to the contents of the report."

However, Ms Filkin recommended no action be take against Mr Hague as the entries were recorded "in good faith" and entries were not intended to be misleading. There was no evidence of "irregularity or impropriety" in the uses the fees were put to, she added. But she said: "Mr Hague failed to respond correctly on eight separate occasions when required to check his entry, with the result that it continued in a materially inaccurate form for a considerable period - at least six months and arguably longer." In December 1999, Mr Hague was also censured by the commissioner for not declaring the free use of Jeffrey Archer's gym for his daily judo sessions with his aide, Seb Coe. The Labour MP, Fraser Kemp - who made the complaint to the standards and privileges committee after the oversight was exposed on the Mark Thomas Product, a Channel 4 comedy show, - demanded that the Conservative leader make an apology to the Commons at today's prime minister's questions. He said: "William Hague must now apologise to the house. This is the second time he has been censured by the committee on standards and privileges. "This report shows that William Hague received money from speaking engagements and told parliament this money was going to charity for over a year when in reality the cheques were gathering dust in his office drawer." A spokesman for Mr Hague said: "We have nothing to add to the contents of the report."
