fields.headline: Hospital killings spark health reform
fields.standfirst: A recent case linking a nurse with the murder of 40 patients has prompted an urgent review of Hungary's health system, says Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: A recent case linking a nurse with the murder of 40 patients has prompted an urgent review of Hungary's health system, says Kate Connolly in Budapest
fields.body:
News of the arrest of a nurse alleged to have murdered up to 40 patients during her nightshift was like a siren going off in Hungary. The public shuddered and the newspapers rolled with stories questioning the state of the health service and calling for a reopening of a national debate into euthanasia.

The quiet 24-year-old nurse, who lived with her parents and whose best friend was the family dog, is hardly a typical mass murderer, or even the kind of person who might normally have triggered such a heated discussion.

"She had been viewed suspiciously on a couple of occasions, once when she administered an enema containing cleaning detergent," said one medical orderly at the hospital.

A doctor colleague added: "It's true she had black hair and always wore black, but we thought it was because she had a fairly full figure and wanted to appear slimmer."

Her confession last month to the "mercy killings" of patients in her care at a Budapest hospital, allegedly carried out over a year, has shocked the country - it is unprecedented in Hungary's history. It has also sparked an intense public discussion about euthanasia and the state of the public health care system.

Known simply as Timea F for legal reasons, the young nurse told police she wanted to "ease her terminally ill patients into death" and admitted administering lethal doses of morphine and potassium to them.

She earned the moniker "the black angel" because of her penchant for black clothes and after the deaths of an unusually high number of people on her ward.

"An experienced, professionally trained nurse," was the phrase used to describe Timea by Gabor Takacs, director of the 800-bed Gyula Nyiroe hospital with an annual budget of £5m, where the nurse worked.

But he said she was also "a psychopath who saw herself as the mistress over life and death".

He has prompted an outcry by suggesting the hospital can accept no responsibility for the killings, blaming a dire shortage of nursing staff due to lack of cash in the post-communist health system.

"In the current situation I don't feel that even a small amount of the responsibility lies with doctors," he said. "The nurse in question cared for 40 patients on her own, while this number requires three to four nurses," he said.

The health minister has reacted angrily to the claim. "I simply can't accept that a 24-year-old nurse administered drugs to patients without control," commented Istvan Mikola, who broke off from an EU health ministers' summit in Strasbourg to attend to the crisis. "This is nothing to do with financing and lack of staff," he added.

But in response to what is being viewed as a public relations disaster for an already beleaguered health service, which is having to shut down and merge hospitals all over the country, Mr Mikola has ordered a nationwide review into ward procedures at the country's 162 hospitals.

Critics of the 109-year-old health service say it is not before time. An overhaul of the system between 1994 and 1998 with 35% austerity measures has had, if anything, a retrograde effect on one of Hungary's most neglected public sectors.

Hungarian nurses currently earn a monthly salary of about 28000 Hungarian forints (£67). Many are therefore leaving, some coming to work in Britain's own beleaguered health service. Relatives of patients report that they have to visit the hospital at mealtimes just in order to ensure that their loved ones get fed.

But one of the most controversial issues - a legacy from communist days - is the generous money gifts patients are obliged to give to doctors. "Feketepenz" (black money); "halapenz" (gratitude money); or "paraszolvencia" (pay on the side) - call it what you will, the system does nothing to instil patient confidence in the carer.

A good bedside manner is said to be the ability to smile the so-called "wallet-opening smile". To make matters worse, nurses who would traditionally share in the spoils are being excluded. But as long as wages are low and the system is poorly equipped, the practice of parazolvencia is likely to continue.

Mr Mikola, who has been in office since January, is the first to admit to the sector's problems. But he says that Hungary's situation is not so different from that of other countries. Hungary's health spending, at £245 per capita, "is in the middle range". Germany spends £3,291 a year, while Romania can only afford £42, and Ethiopia is at the bottom with £1.10 a year.

Some of the reform strategies now being looked at include a review of management practices, privatisation, the involvement of large multinationals in funding, as well as a modern database where patients would "log in" with a chip-card system.

Earmarking £945m for this year's budget, Mr Mikola remains optimistic about the government's ability to turn the service round. "The problem is not that the blanket is too short, but that it is being used in the wrong direction," he has said.

The trouble is that nation's unhappy nurses are the ones expected to make the beds.

fields.headline: Sun denies 'Bin man' link to Blair story
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Sun political editor Trevor Kavanagh has denied Benjamin 'Bin Man' Pell was behind his paper's coverage of the Blair memo, write Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll.

'Benji the Bin man' in line for scoop of the year award
fields.body:
Trevor Kavanagh, the Sun's political editor, has denied Benjamin "Bin Man" Pell was behind his own paper's coverage of a leaked memo about Tony Blair.

Mr Kavanagh last year won an award for his story on the leaked memo from the prime minister's pollster Philip Gould.

He said he believed it was acceptable for newspapers to use information obtained by scavenging, saying: "once something's in the dustbin, it's fair game".

News International stablemate the Sunday Times has been nominated for "scoop of the year" at tonight's British Press Awards, the so-called Oscars of British journalism, but faces accusations its own story was the result not of investigative journalism but Mr Pell's notorious scavenging.

He said he did not believe credit should be taken away from the Sunday Times's Insight team.

"I'm not saying it's savoury but all newspapers use sources or intermediaries," said Mr Kavanagh, who is arguably the most influential of Fleet Street political journalists.

"The only difference between these and Benjamin Pell is he is now a public figure.

"We've got an entire network of people, whether it's politics, sport, showbusiness or whatever."

Mr Kavanagh said scoops were a joint effort on the part of a newspaper and its sources and, ultimately, it was the bylined writer - not the mole - who should receive an award.

However, he conceded: "it does rather detract from the purity of the story".

Meanwhile, Philippa Kennedy, the editor of trade magazine Press Gazette and organiser of tonight's awards, said she was confident the story had nothing to do with Mr Pell.

"I don't think the allegations in today's Guardian affect the awards in any way because the story is a good one.

"I have had [deputy editor] Martin Ivens from the Sunday Times on to me this morning and they have utterly denied it came from Pell," she said.

But Ms Kennedy said even if the story had come from Mr Pell, it would not affect whether the story was worthy of being branded a "scoop".

"Let's say Pell found evidence of the prime minister's wife being a Russian spy; would you refuse to run the story because the information had come from a bin?

"We are not changing the shortlist in any way - firstly, because the Sunday Times has denied the involvement of Pell and, secondly, because the trophy is already inscribed."

She joked the only way Mr Pell would gain an award was if a trophy was dropped and binned.

The antics of Mr Pell, who makes a living by going through the dustbins of politicians and celebrities, have been behind a number of high-profile Fleet Street scoops.

He was the subject of a recent documentary on Channel 4, which followed a protracted legal wrangle.

Invoices seen by the Guardian suggest Mr Pell has received more than £3,375 in a single month from the Sunday Times.

webTitle: Hague raises the stakes on poll issue

fields.headline: Hague raises the stakes on poll issue
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday raised the stakes in the political manoeuvring behind the foot and mouth crisis when he insisted a general election could not be held when the disease remained "out of control".
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday raised the stakes in the political manoeuvring behind the foot and mouth crisis when he insisted a general election could not be held when the disease remained "out of control".

The Conservative leader's direct challenge to the government, backed up with calls for plans for the delay of county council elections in worst hit areas, marks a calculated but risky shift to the offensive for the Tories after several weeks maintaining a political consensus over the handling of the outbreak.

Party strategists believe that, while Labour shows every sign of pressing ahead with a May 3 general election, public feeling that the contest should be postponed is growing.

The mounting seriousness of the crisis, in the face of unpopular efforts at containment, now offers scope for an assault on government handling of the epidemic, even at the risk of being accused of making political capital out of the problem, Mr Hague's aides have concluded.

The Tories have been, and remain, wary of making any direct suggestion that the election should be postponed amid fears of being perceived to be running scared of a battle polls indicate they will lose badly.

Mr Hague yesterday stopped short of calling for postponement - or even demanding the delay of county council elections - but he attempted to set down a marker that, without a clear easing of the crisis, calling an election campaign would be irresponsible.

Avoiding giving a definition of what would constitute the disease being "under control", he insisted his party would not be frightened to speak out if it felt the government was calling an election in inappropriate circumstances.

Yesterday's statement marks the culmination of a gradual Tory move towards risking a direct attack on the government election plans. Initially, the party steered clear of any such suggestions, while simul taneously allowing other sympathetic voices - the National Farmer's Union, the Countryside Alliance and Conservative supporting newspapers - to make the case instead.

Last week, shadow agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, stressed that the party was ready for an election fight whenever the government chose to call one, but suggested that voters would question the appropriateness of a poll amid a crisis affecting not only farmers but a swath of rural and tourist industries.

Addressing Cumbrian farmers last Thursday, Mr Hague argued that it would be "very difficult" to hold an election if the foot and mouth situation remained as it was - a warning strengthened yesterday to a clear statement that, without an easing of the crisis, it would not be right to call an election.

Conservative strategists insist they are not reducing the party's room for manoeuvre by opposing a poll. A Hague aide said: "We are not boxed in at all. On the day Blair announces the election we could say we agree the outbreak has been contained, or we could say we completely deplore this decision, the outbreak is not under control. All those options are still open to us."

Labour yesterday swung into action to counter Mr Hague's offensive, as the Commons leader, Margaret Beckett, accused him of trying to make political capital out of the crisis, despite the Tories' officially bipartisan policy.

She said: "In situations like this, there are ways of making constructive criticism without so obviously trying to turn it into a political issue. Many of the points he makes are already being addressed."

Trades union leaders were also mobilised to send out a coordinated message that postponing local elections -used as Labour code for the unannounced general election - would send out a panic message and further damage the rural economy and jobs.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB which has over 20,000 members in the tourism sector, said: "Cancelling the local elections would be the worst possible move.

"We are trying to restore confidence in the UK as a tourist destination and effec tively suspending democracy would send a signal to the world that we are a nation in crisis."

Conservative county councillors and some election officials in worst hit areas raised concerns over council elections, however.

Cattle and sheep farmer Steele Addison, a Tory councillor representing Lowther and Shap, near Penrith, Cumbria, said yesterday: "I think at the present time most certainly as we see this thing expanding so rapidly across the Cumbria countryside, it would be silly to think in terms of elections.

"We cannot go electioneering at a time like this. It is inappropriate."

The West Devon borough council chief executive, David Incoll, said it seemed likely that many of the village halls normally used as polling stations in elections would not be available on May 3.

"We will do whatever we have to do, but I think there would be concern as to holding the election in certain village halls in the most affected areas," he told BBC Radio 4.

fields.headline: Game over for Freeloader.com
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: A games website that played on office workers' disaffection with their jobs is to close, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A games website that played on office workers' disaffection with their jobs has lost all its lifelines and reached game over.

Freeloader.com, the much-celebrated free games download website, is being shut down by parent company Pure Entertainment Games, despite having 750,000 registered users.

Pure Entertainment said it had decided to close because of the downturn in internet advertising revenues and the failure to find a wealthy merger partner.

It said it was reluctant to close the site, which had expanded into France, USA and Germany, but fundraising was not a realistic option in current market conditions.

Shares in Pure Entertainment plunged 82% to 2.5p this morning after the announcement was made.

Pure Entertainment will now either return surplus funds to shareholders or remain listed as a quoted shell. It will try to sell off its technology and brand name.

"The company has taken the above steps with great reluctance and regret as the website is more successful than ever, with all key traffic and user statistics ahead of projections," said the firm in a statement.

Freeloader was launched in May 2000 and spent £1m on a controversial launch campaign encouraging people to play games instead of working.

fields.headline: Happiness makes cheerful debut
fields.trailText: 2pm TV overnights: Paul Whitehouse's sitcom opened promisingly on BBC2 last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Paul Whitehouse's sitcom debut Happiness, about a man approaching a mid-life crisis, opened promisingly on BBC2 last night.

Happiness, written by Mr Whitehouse and David Cummings and featuring cameos from Fast Show stalwarts Mark Williams and Simon Day, went out from 10pm.

The show attracted 2.2m viewers and a 10% share, according to unofficial overnights.

Channel 4 opposition, the documentary Stalked, pulled in 1.6m and a 9% share.

Ouch, Channel 5's shock doc, drew nearly 1m viewers and gave the station its best audience share yesterday.

The programme, which focused on survivors of horrific accidents, went out in the late-night slot from 10.50-11.50pm, where previous hard-hitting documentary titles have included Murder Detectives.

The show had 0.9m viewers and an 8% audience share.

Women's prison drama Bad Girls returned to ITV last night at 9pm to win a hard-fought ratings tussle with BBC1 opposition Silent Witness.

fields.headline: Traditional methods 'caused vCJD deaths'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: BSE

Summary of Leicestershire CJD investigation (PDF)
fields.trailText: Traditional techniques at local abattoirs linked to small-scale butchers led to the deaths of five people in the Leicestershire village of Queniborough from variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD), the official public health report into the cluster said.
fields.body:
Traditional techniques at local abattoirs linked to small-scale butchers led to the deaths of five people in the Leicestershire village of Queniborough from variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD), the official public health report into the cluster said.

Dr Philip Monk, consultant in public health for Leicestershire health authority, said small slaughterhouses in the area had used a recognised technique involving inserting something into the brain to ensure cows did not kick out during the slaughter process.

However, because it was "plausible" that herds in the area were infected with BSE, this technique led to infected material leaking to other parts of the animal.

Dr Monk said: "These were traditional craft butchering practices carried out by people who were experts in their tradition. None of them were illegal. They were both legal and crafted processes that were going on in the 1980s."

He added: "The people who had vCJD were exposed to the BSE agents through the consumption of beef which had been processed from butchers where there was a risk of cross-contamination of bovine brain material during the boning and cutting process in those butchers premises where the skull was split to remove the brain."

The report into Britain's first cluster of deaths from vCJD revealed that a series of coincidences in the way the meat was prepared was responsible for the disease.

The study looked at farming methods and food supplies in the area between 1980 to 1991, the period of time in which all five victims lived in the area.

The investigation was launched in July last year and a progress report in November indicated that lines of inquiry had been narrowed and were concentrating on the meat supply chain as "the only remaining factor".

At the report's publication in Queniborough, Tim Healey, chairman of Leicestershire health authority, which prepared the report, paid tribute to the victims' families for their help in the "painful experience" of investigating the deaths.

webTitle: vCJD: the tragedy of lessons unlearned

fields.headline: vCJD: the tragedy of lessons unlearned
fields.standfirst: If we fail to reform our food industry, more deaths will follow the five in Leicestershire, writes Hugh Warwick
fields.trailText: If we fail to reform our food industry, more deaths will follow the five in Leicestershire, writes Hugh Warwick.
fields.body:
The tragedy of the cluster of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD) cases in Leicestershire is that we appear to have failed to learn some hard-taught lessons.

In the UK, 90 people have been killed by a disease that, apparently, could never happen. Experts assured us repeatedly that humans could never pick up the disease that has blighted the beef industry. But the food industry continues to become more about industry than food.

The local abattoirs at the centre of this cluster are just the unwitting pawns in a game that the corporations are playing with the lives of consumers. Traditional butchering is not the problem; small abattoirs are not the problem. The problem is the commoditisation of food.

Yet we are faced with an industry that continues to pursue this end. It does not matter that, on the one hand, the industry that creates genetically engineered food claims it is exactly the same as traditional food, to avoid any testing; while, on the other, claiming that they are entirely different to gain a patent.

Consumer pressure has had an impact in the UK. But this is not a real change of heart by the industry. It is just a tactic. The food producers are simply waiting until all the fuss has died down. And they are waiting until the Britain's countryside is so contaminated by GM crops that they can safely say it is impossible to guarantee anything is truly GM-free.

As yet, there is no proof that GM food is bad for us. But there is also no proof to the contrary. So, should we just wait? Or should we look at the chaos an intensive industry has already caused through BSE and start to question their rights to use us as guinea pigs in their latest experiments?

 Hugh Warwick is the editor of Splice, the magazine of The Genetics Forum

webTitle: Nato pleas for more troops in Balkans ignored

fields.headline: Nato pleas for more troops in Balkans ignored
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Not a single Nato government has responded to urgent requests from their hard-pressed military commanders in Kosovo for reinforcements to help deal with ethnic Albanian extremists infiltrating neighbouring Macedonia, Nato sources disclosed last night.
fields.body:
Not a single Nato government has responded to urgent requests from their hard-pressed military commanders in Kosovo for reinforcements to help deal with ethnic Albanian extremists infiltrating neighbouring Macedonia, Nato sources disclosed last night.

As Macedonian tanks for the first time shelled mountain slopes above the north-western city of Tetovo, occupied by ethnic Albanian guerrillas, it seemed increasingly clear that the Nato allies are determined not to make further military commitments to the Balkans, despite the deteriorating security situation.

It emerged yesterday that Lord Robertson, Nato secretary general, asked 10 days ago for two extra battalions - about 1,400 soldiers - in the light of increasing incursions of rebel Albanians across the Kosovo-Macedonia border. His request followed an appeal from Lt Gen Carlos Cabigiosu, Italian commander of the 42,000 K-For troops in the Serbian province of Kosovo. "Military commanders need more troops. Basically, they are overstretched. But we have had no offers," said an alliance official.

The Ministry of Defence said there were "no plans" to add to the 3,300 British troops in Kosovo. Privately, it has emphatically told Nato it will not do so, according to alliance sources.

The ministry is, however, sending a military team of 10 to advise the Macedonians in its fight with Albanian rebels - some of whom are believed to be veterans of the Kosovo Liberation Army. Yesterday, the Albanian guerrillas were described by Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, as terrorists.

An MoD spokesman said the 10-strong team would not assist "in a military sense". Two senior British army officers will also fly to Macedonia to assist the British defence attache in the capital, Skopje.

Frustration at the tactics of US troops, some 5,000 of whom are based in eastern Kosovo, appears to have dissipated after the deployment of some of them along the border with Macedonia. However, there remains a feeling that American troops could have done much more in the past few months to stop Albanian guerrillas from transporting arms across eastern Kosovo.

The Macedonian government is bitter about what it regards as the failure of Nato-led peacekeepers in Kosovo to take tougher action against the rebels. Macedonia has asked for an international force to help drive out the guerrillas. Though K-For commanders have sent more troops to the border area to cut off rebel supply lines from Kosovo, Nato insists there is no question of extending its mandate in the Balkans.

Tetovo, Macedonia's second biggest town, resounded to the firing of tank cannon as houses were blasted on the hills above. The army moved at least 10 Soviet-made tanks, hundreds of troops and artillery to Tetovo on Monday in what security sources said was preparation for a final push against the rebels. But yester day there was no sign yet of troops moving up the hills.

Mr Cook yesterday described Britain's policy as working for a "stable, multi-ethnic Macedonia" helping it "to isolate and defeat the terrorists".

Mr Cook said he had spoken on the telephone to European foreign ministers as well as the US secretary of state, Colin Powell. "We are all agreed", he said, "that we will step up the border patrols both on the ground and in the air".

Washington has said it was considering new "non-military help" to Macedonia.

In a one-page statement, the foreign secretary contrasted what he called a "brutal government ... repressing the people" - a reference to the Milosevic regime's attacks in the past on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo - to the democratic government of Macedonia.

"Representatives of the Albanian people are members of the government of Macedonia," said Mr Cook. About 30% of Macedonia's population is ethnically Albanian.

Macedonia's two main Albanian parties yesterday signed a statement urging ethnic Albanian guerrillas to lay down their arms and return home.

The situation in the Balkans is certain to feature prominently at the EU summit in Stockholm, beginning on Friday and which will be attended by the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.

fields.headline: Army threatening all-out attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian forces have halted their bombardment of guerrilla positions in the   hills around the city of Tetovo, but are threatening an all-out assault   unless the ethnic Albanian rebels withdraw or surrender.
fields.body:
Macedonian forces have halted their bombardment of guerrilla positions in the hills around the city of Tetovo, but are threatening an all-out assault unless the ethnic Albanian rebels withdraw or surrender.

The ultimatum has already been rejected by the rebels. When the deadline expires at midnight tonight, the Macedonian army and police units clustered around Tetovo are expected to move into the hills to flush out the Albanian fighters.

It could be a bloody affair. The government forces are ill equipped and have little training for a ground offensive. There are fears that civilians could be caught up in the fighting. Significant numbers of casualties will inevitably deepen the bitterness of the conflict and raise regional tension.

Nato governments fear that if the confrontation spirals, it could infect other parts of the western Balkans. Russia is also sending strong diplomatic signals that it will stand by the Slavic majority in Macedonia.

The situation is made more perilous by the conflicting demands of the rebel groups. Some say they want a new constitution, in which the former Yugoslav republic's Albanian minority would be guaranteed full civic rights.

Other rebels are talking of a greater Albania, taking in chunks of Macedonia, the notionally Serb province of Kosovo, and of course Albania itself.

The Macedonian government in Skopje - which confusingly includes one of the main Albanian parties - is taking a hardline stance against constitutional reform. It says that it will not negotiate with armed insurgents, and is demanding that Nato forces in Kosovo take action to cut the rebels' supply lines.

So far, Nato governments are backing the Skopje authorities - but stopping well short of pledging military aid.

Western ministers are now in the embarrassing position of condemning the Albanian guerrillas who were their allies in the 1999 Kosovo war.

The Kosovo Liberation Army was supposed to have disbanded in the aftermath of that war, but many of its members are known to be with the rebels in the hills above Tetovo.

The US administration, meanwhile, has pledged that its forces in Kosovo will help to patrol the porous border with Macedonia, and that it will also supply Skopje with military intelligence, including detailed aerial photographs.

There are also 400 American soldiers in Macedonia, but their role will remain confined to providing logistical help to the US forces in Kosovo.

Other Nato governments, including Britain and Norway, have reinforced their contingents in K-For, the polyglot army now running Kosovo.

In a telling contribution to the growing debate about the Balkan imbroglio, retired US general Wesley Clark has sharply criticised political leaders over the interminable delay in determining the final status of Kosovo. In theory, the province remains part of Serbia and the rump federation of Yugoslavia. In practice, it is a Nato fiefdom from which most Serbs have long since fled.

There has been little movement towards self-government, and no serious debate about independence, or an irridentist union with Albania.

webTitle: All set for a battle nobody wants

fields.headline: All set for a battle nobody wants
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Huddled in threes and fours in the village square, the people of Poroj awaited the Macedonian onslaught in afternoon sunshine. The mortar fire had abated but tanks were mobilising in the valley below.
fields.body:
Huddled in threes and fours in the village square, the people of Poroj awaited the Macedonian onslaught in afternoon sunshine. The mortar fire had abated but tanks were mobilising in the valley below.

What came was a grey Mitsubishi Lancer, screeching to a halt, its front bumper smashed. A Macedonian army soldier leaped out brandishing a Kalashnikov.

He was sweating and screaming and the villagers dived for cover. "Don't run, help me, I'm escaping. Is there anybody here to take me into the mountains?"

Having grown up in the nearby village of Pollatica, he had decided he did not want to fire on fellow ethnic Albanians. "The army and police have taken up positions to attack. They are putting Albanians in the frontline," he said.

Villagers swirled around. "Take off that patch," a boy yelled, tugging at the insignia on his sleeve. A pistol at his belt suggested that he was an officer.

Two minutes later he vanished in another car with two young men. The self-styled National Liberation Army had acquired another volunteer.

Six days after its guerrillas dug into Mount Baltete and fired on police in Tetovo, Macedonia's second city, their enemy was preparing to flush them out.

"The Macedonian security forces will soon start a final operation to destroy the terrorists," Antonio Milosovski, a government spokesman in the capital, Skopje, said.

At least eight tanks took up firing positions in a sports stadium and abandoned factory on the northern outskirts, the limit of state authority. Mortars lobbed shells into the oak forests above while police snipers took up positions in top-floor flats.

Radio B52 in Belgrade re ported that Russia had offered helicopter gunships and crews to dislodge the insurgents. Ukraine was also reported to have offered helicopters.

Poroj, population 2,500, received the news with stoicism: here, villagers said, was the cradle of the radical Albanian nationalism seeping across western Macedonia.

On a black marble plinth in he park is a bronze bust of Mujdin Alim, a Kosovo Liberation Army fighter killed in battle by Serbs in 1999. The police have repeatedly tried to tear it down, said Nejad, 51.

"If the Macedonians attack this place will become the second Drenica," he said - referring to the battle which escalated the war in Kosovo.

"If they attack, everything bad will happen, all the worst possible things. Officers may not be able to control their soldiers. Some may be psychos."

So far no atrocities have been reported. One rebel said four comrades had been killed and seven injured.

A plaque on an Islamic cultural centre beside the mosque claimed the credit for creating Tetovo's illegal university, which has educated two generations of militants.

"The army could not be based here, because it would not have the support of the people. Only the fights of freedom can come here," a 37-year-old man said.

Poroj is no man's land. Unless they leave their bunkers three miles to the south, the security forces will not stop the mule trains supplying the rebels.

"We have not moved an inch, although there has been heavy shelling," d a rebel commander called Kusha said.

Yesterday's defector encapsulated Macedonia's dilemma: its poorly trained conscript army is 40% ethnic Albanian.

Deploying police units, which are overwhelmingly Macedonian, threatens to further radicalise the Albanian minority, which wants more rights. But if the insurgency is allowed to continue it may become a full-scale civil war.

A two-hour hike through NLA positions last night showed the challenge they face. Young men with mobile phones - sentries - punctuated the mule-trails every 500 metres. A bunker with sandbags was being prepared on the hill overlooking Poroj. Underground tunnels and mine fields are said to have been prepared.

Four men leading eight mules wound up mud tracks, never flinching as explosions rolled across ridges.

They reached Germo, a village 1,200m above sea-level, just before nightfall. Teenage girls unloaded bandages, iodine and painkillers. They set up a first-aid clinic inside the mosque.

"I am a doctor and I have come to do whatever I can do," one man said. A shell thudded nearby, scattering onlookers.

Latif Latifi, 43, a history teacher, is the village commander - "Kommando" was written on his forage cap.

The war would continue until Albanians were given a constituent state in Macedonia, he said. He blamed the government for not building a road and tackling the erosion which had hindered farmers.

"We are depending on the west for help," he said. Nato was chalked on rocks.

fields.bodyText: Huddled in threes and fours in the village square, the people of Poroj awaited the Macedonian onslaught in afternoon sunshine. The mortar fire had abated but tanks were mobilising in the valley below. What came was a grey Mitsubishi Lancer, screeching to a halt, its front bumper smashed. A Macedonian army soldier leaped out brandishing a Kalashnikov. He was sweating and screaming and the villagers dived for cover. "Don't run, help me, I'm escaping. Is there anybody here to take me into the mountains?" Having grown up in the nearby village of Pollatica, he had decided he did not want to fire on fellow ethnic Albanians. "The army and police have taken up positions to attack. They are putting Albanians in the frontline," he said. Villagers swirled around. "Take off that patch," a boy yelled, tugging at the insignia on his sleeve. A pistol at his belt suggested that he was an officer. Two minutes later he vanished in another car with two young men. The self-styled National Liberation Army had acquired another volunteer. Six days after its guerrillas dug into Mount Baltete and fired on police in Tetovo, Macedonia's second city, their enemy was preparing to flush them out. "The Macedonian security forces will soon start a final operation to destroy the terrorists," Antonio Milosovski, a government spokesman in the capital, Skopje, said. At least eight tanks took up firing positions in a sports stadium and abandoned factory on the northern outskirts, the limit of state authority. Mortars lobbed shells into the oak forests above while police snipers took up positions in top-floor flats. Radio B52 in Belgrade re ported that Russia had offered helicopter gunships and crews to dislodge the insurgents. Ukraine was also reported to have offered helicopters. Poroj, population 2,500, received the news with stoicism: here, villagers said, was the cradle of the radical Albanian nationalism seeping across western Macedonia. On a black marble plinth in he park is a bronze bust of Mujdin Alim, a Kosovo Liberation Army fighter killed in battle by Serbs in 1999. The police have repeatedly tried to tear it down, said Nejad, 51. "If the Macedonians attack this place will become the second Drenica," he said - referring to the battle which escalated the war in Kosovo. "If they attack, everything bad will happen, all the worst possible things. Officers may not be able to control their soldiers. Some may be psychos." So far no atrocities have been reported. One rebel said four comrades had been killed and seven injured. A plaque on an Islamic cultural centre beside the mosque claimed the credit for creating Tetovo's illegal university, which has educated two generations of militants. "The army could not be based here, because it would not have the support of the people. Only the fights of freedom can come here," a 37-year-old man said. Poroj is no man's land. Unless they leave their bunkers three miles to the south, the security forces will not stop the mule trains supplying the rebels. "We have not moved an inch, although there has been heavy shelling," d a rebel commander called Kusha said. Yesterday's defector encapsulated Macedonia's dilemma: its poorly trained conscript army is 40% ethnic Albanian. Deploying police units, which are overwhelmingly Macedonian, threatens to further radicalise the Albanian minority, which wants more rights. But if the insurgency is allowed to continue it may become a full-scale civil war. A two-hour hike through NLA positions last night showed the challenge they face. Young men with mobile phones - sentries - punctuated the mule-trails every 500 metres. A bunker with sandbags was being prepared on the hill overlooking Poroj. Underground tunnels and mine fields are said to have been prepared. Four men leading eight mules wound up mud tracks, never flinching as explosions rolled across ridges. They reached Germo, a village 1,200m above sea-level, just before nightfall. Teenage girls unloaded bandages, iodine and painkillers. They set up a first-aid clinic inside the mosque. "I am a doctor and I have come to do whatever I can do," one man said. A shell thudded nearby, scattering onlookers. Latif Latifi, 43, a history teacher, is the village commander - "Kommando" was written on his forage cap. The war would continue until Albanians were given a constituent state in Macedonia, he said. He blamed the government for not building a road and tackling the erosion which had hindered farmers. "We are depending on the west for help," he said. Nato was chalked on rocks. As darkness fell the stone-built houses drew curtains to deny lighting for the Macedonian gunners. "Nobody here likes war. But now we have it," said Commander Latifi. What's going on? webTitle: Albanian rebels told to flee or die

fields.headline: Albanian rebels told to flee or die
fields.standfirst:
Macedonian army threatens a ground offensive backed by air strikes as reinforcements are ferried into Tetovo, near the Kosovan border

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian tanks joined artillery in blasting ethnic Albanian guerrillas yesterday after the army issued an ultimatum to flee or face an all-out assault.
fields.body:
Macedonian tanks joined artillery in blasting ethnic Albanian guerrillas yesterday after the army issued an ultimatum to flee or face an all-out assault.

An army statement last night gave the rebels 24 hours to retreat from their mountain positions above the Macedonian town of Tetovo and stop firing. Otherwise, a ground offensive and air strikes would start at midnight tonight.

The rebels say they are fighting for more rights for the ethnic Albanian community in Macedonia. But Macedonia says they are separatists seeking to unite with mainly Albanian Kosovo, from where most of their supplies come.

Brush fires ignited by shells sent smoke plumes above Macedonia's second city but the self-styled National Liberation Army appeared to hold its ground, six days after it dug in.

Troop transports ferried reinforcements into the northern outskirts to prepare for the attack, on which the government has staked its credibility. Morale at police checkpoints seemed high but doubts remained over the reliability of the state's poorly trained conscript army. Around 40% of its soldiers are Albanian, each one considered a potential deserter.

Villagers in the arc of territory controlled by the rebels vowed to wage a long war if "invaded" by security forces.

In the capital, Skopje, however, two moderate Albanian parties agreed to enter the government to try to isolate the insurgents.

"We condemn the use of force for political gains - there is no place for something like that in civilised democratic states," read the declaration signed by the Democratic Albanian party and the Democratic Prosperity party.

Violence can be "tragic for us as Macedonian citizens and for the entire region" , it said.

Arben Xhafari, whose Democratic Albanian Party is a member of the Slav-dominated government coalition, denied rumors that his party was leaving the government - but warned it might do so later if violence intensified.

He said the government had not fully involved his party in the decision-making process, and said it was "totally dissatisfied with the amount of [government] force being used" against the rebels.

In the rebel-held village of Germo, a cafe erupted in nervous laughter when TV news reported the deadline. Rebels said it changed nothing.

Mule trains with supplies of food and guns were crossing the Sha mountains until nightfall.

Government tanks moved into the city on Monday, and the spokesman for the government, Antonio Milosovski, had pledged "definite action", saying that field commanders would give the attack order soon. In turn, Nato pledged to "starve" the rebels by cutting supply lines from Kosovo.

As the government barrage started, an armoured personnel carrier parked at a junction joined in, shooting at farmhouses on the hillside north of Tetovo.

Hours earlier, the rebels had published their demands for negotiations. "We are determined to realise our demands, and urge Macedonian authorities and non-government figures to make public as soon as possible if they want this to be resolved peacefully or not," they said in a communique.

"Macedonia's ignorant view and hypocritical disrespect of the demands and the patience of Albanians has surpassed all limits," it said. "We urge the international community to recognize our demands which are for peace, not for war."

The statement, signed "National Liberation Army - Tetovo branch," ended with a warning that if talks were rejected, "we will bear no responsibility for the future chain of events."

Earlier yesterday the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, said there would be "no negotiations" with the rebels. The EU security affairs chief, Javier Solana, said said in Skopje that refusal to negotitate was justified, adding: "The terrorists have to be isolated. All of us have to condemn and isolate them."

webTitle: Communique issued yesterday by ethnic Albanian rebels

fields.headline: 'We don't seek killings and war ...'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Translation of a communique issued yesterday by ethnic Albanian rebels fighting for greater rights in Macedonia:
fields.body:
Translation of a communique issued yesterday by ethnic Albanian rebels fighting for greater rights in Macedonia:

Macedonia's ignorant view and hypocritical disrespect of the demands and the patience of the Albanians has surpassed all limits.

Our people have for decades been insulted, discriminated against and banned from all civilisation traditions in Macedonia.

These are the main reasons that forced the Albanians to take up weapons and fight for their rights. In vain we tried for years to have our rights realised through a change in government, and to have Macedonia refrain from a wrongful policy... we chose a president who we hoped would be a president for all. We gave him time and space to send us clear signals whether he was going to accept the Albanians as equals. But this did not happen. Therefore, we decided not to allow further humiliation and trampling on our dignity.

We appeal to all political and non-political Albanian figures not to delude themselves that our rights would be granted by this government. The present trend of recognition of our rights is trivial. We also appeal to all political factors, internal and external, to give their real recognition to those who are fighting to be equal, because such fighters could never be terrorists.

We are no adventurers. We had no lives to gamble away. We don't seek killings and war, because for centuries we were the victims. From this moment peace does not depend only on us.

We urge the Macedonian authorities to make public as soon as possible whether they want this to be resolved peacefully. After this we will bear no responsibility for the future chain of events. We urge the international community to recognise our demands, which are for peace.

National Liberation Army, Tetovo branch

fields.headline: Sheila Lawlor, Policy director
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

Since 1945 the public sector has stood for two different things. First it evokes the idea of a comprehensive service, such as health or education, publicly provided for the benefit of individuals and society as a whole.

Second, it includes the notion of other publicly provided services that uphold a free and stable society, such as the police and the army, and perhaps also other public goods, such as the civil service.

But today's debate about the public sector, its failings, morale, the urgency for change, tends to refer in the main to health and education. These are all too often perceived to fail the public who use them and to be a source of concern and frustration for many of the talented and dedicated professionals - doctors, nurses and teachers - who work in them often with a growing sense of frustration.

The problems of these two services owe much to the model they inherited: the centrally planned bureaucratic model, imposed on health via the 1948 NHS act, and by stealth on education throughout the last century. The model is bureaucratic, labour-intensive (as the social policy academic Richard Titmuss explained) and run from the centre via directives, plans, targets and paperwork.

It undermines the freedom of professionals and subordinates them to bureaucratic diktat (from central or local government). It keeps the salaries of the professionals artificially low, and can do so because the state acts as pretty much the only available employer. It treats able and qualified doctors and teachers as mere operators to carry out the latest bureaucratic blueprint.

The upshot is a crisis of recruitment and retention for those who should be given freedom and responsibility to meet the professional challenges, and be paid accordingly.

Where do we go from here?

The problem is the public sector model itself, a monument to the vast, failed collective planning experiments which spread like a cancer through east and west in the 1940s. Whether for health or education the model has resisted reform and governments have ended up promising - just as the Labour government here is doing now - more cash tied to more targets.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

If we believe, as I do, in the public funding of education and health, this does not mean we should put our faith in this failed model. On the contrary we need as a matter of urgency to change to a system which allows for accountability to the user and freedom for professionals.

We should move more rapidly to independent trust status for all schools, so that full budget goes directly to the school via the child, and each teacher is a free teacher under the head and governors who employ the teacher. But parents must have the right to choose - and remove from - a school.

Similarly for health: we now need to explore the models which work, in France and Germany and in this country. For the future, if this country is serious about reform, it will find that funding the user - to ensure accountability to patients, parents and pupils - must be combined with greater freedom and professionalism for teachers, doctors and nurses.

Sheila Lawlor is director of the thinktank Politeia

webTitle: Afghanistan diary of an aid worker: overview

fields.headline: Afghanistan diary of an aid worker: overview
fields.trailText: The reality of working in a country like Afghanistan probably only hits home when you're there, on the ground. Prue Peart, a 31-year-old British GP, spent three months in the country working to alleviate the effects of the worst drought in living memory with UK charity Ockenden International.
fields.body:
The reality of working in a country like Afghanistan probably only hits home when you're there, on the ground. Prue Peart, a 31-year-old British GP, spent three months in the country working to alleviate the effects of the worst drought in living memory with UK charity Ockenden International.

Her first big hurdle was finding Afghan women to work with. The Afghan authorities place severe restrictions on what women can do - they can't, for example, go anywhere without a male relative aged 15 or more - and the women are nervous of breaking the law. As such, Dr Peart soon realised she would have to go it alone, getting help along the way. This immediately hampered some of her work because only a women would be able to convince Afghan women to get involved in some of the projects she had planned, such as making quilts to protect people from the freezing weather.

The logistics of distributing aid can be equally difficult. Assessing exactly how many people are in the various camps is no mean feat, and constant new arrivals and suspicions that families are moving between camps only complicates matters. Calculating how much material and stuffing you need to make 5,000 quilts is tricky, especially when you have no guarantee that enough people will be available to make the quilts or that the local traders won't up the price from one day to the next. Local merchants not coming up with goods also frustrates progress. After 10 days of promises a blanket merchant finally delivered.

Getting permission from the Afghan authorities to carry out work can be difficult. They delay visas for no apparent reason and refuse certain agencies permission without saying why. Meanwhile, Security Council sanctions and rumours of US missile strikes heighten tension and make aid workers worry they will be the targets of retaliatory attacks.

Simple cultural differences can also hamper work. Ockenden International built latrines in the camps, but Afghan villagers usually go to the toilet in fields and don't know how to use them. As such, latrines get very dirty and unhygenic, or don't get used at all. Dr Peart said faeces surrounded the tents in many camps: a perfect breeding ground for disease, especially when the warm weather comes. The wooden roofed huts they built also raised concerns. The Afghans were grateful for the shelter but, as they cook inside the huts, were worried the roofs would catch fire. Traditionally, they make roofs out of mud.

Working and living conditions are, needless to say, difficult. Small heaters provide the only light and warmth and demand for the computer is intense. When money is available there is a rush to type up donor proposals, which often means queues of aid workers typing away until the early hours of the morning, often in the dark.

That being said, press reports that the disaster was getting more serious resulted in aid money pouring in, to the extent that there was more than enough money and it was more a case of how to spend it fairly. Seeing that money was available and could be translated into real aid for people in the camps was satisfaction enough for Dr Peart.

fields.headline: Community leadership: the basics
fields.trailText: • Councils have led their communities for years, but with the decline in the number of services delivered directly by local government, their role has become increasingly more important.
fields.body:
 Councils have led their communities for years, but with the decline in the number of services delivered directly by local government, their role has become increasingly more important.

 At its most basic, community leadership is about finding innovative solutions to the problems faced by local people, and acting as their representative with central government and its quangos.

 Labour ministers, and many councillors and officers, accept that this will be local government's future job. There is, however, still a great deal of confusion about what it will mean in practice. The government hopes councils will develop individual definitions to suit local needs.

 Ministers have given local government a number of new freedoms and responsibilities to help fulfil this role. The most important is a power that allows councils to do anything not prohibited by law in the name of improving the social, economic and environmental wellbeing of their communities.

 New powers for local government to scrutinise the health service are also being seen as part of the community leadership agenda. Supporters argue that these will allow councillors to make the voices of local people more forcefully heard in a highly undemocratic NHS.

fields.headline: Community leadership: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Ministers will tell you that local government's new role is as a 'community leader' - but four years into a Labour government, many are still confused over just what that means.
fields.body:
It's all change for local authorities in the next few years. The days when the council just collected the bins, ran the schools and organised the meals on wheels seem to be over. Ministers will tell you that local government's new role is as a "community leader" - but four years into a Labour government, many are still confused over just what that means.

With rumours circulating last year that the government wanted to run both schools and social services from Whitehall, it could signpost the beginning of the end for directly delivered council services. Local government supporters believe, however, that it could instead make local authorities the leading player in the revitalisation of their communities and, by extension, civic society as a whole.

The government is already giving councils new powers to fulfil their community leadership role. The Local Government Act came into force last summer, giving councils a new power to improve the quality of life of local people. In practice, this power allows authorities to do anything not prohibited by law in the name of promoting the economic, social and environmental wellbeing of communities. It is a reversal of the previous prohibitive legal framework.

Developing community plans and strategies for improving an area is also a key new role for councils. These plans are meant to assess the priorities of local communities and look at how their needs can be best met. They are to be put together in partnership with other local organisations, including businesses, charities and the NHS, and are intended to be a prime example of how "joined up" government can improve quality of life, linking together council services and wider issues such as health, regeneration and environmental sustainability.

Local government has been moving away from its old role as a service provider for well over a decade. Compulsory competitive tendering - brought in by the Conservative government in the 80s - forced authorities to make use of the private sector to deliver services. Councils began to develop a new "enabling" role, making it possible for others to meet the needs of local people. Many now argue that this trend should continue.

Influential think tank the New Local Government Network sees councils in the future as bodies which link together the work of other agencies at a local level. This would mean that the council's role in delivering services would continue to diminish. Instead they would become genuine, strategic "community leaders".

But the Local Government Association is more cautious. It backs the idea of community leadership. It also welcomes working in partnership and accepts that sometimes councils should allow other bodies to take a central role. However, it continues to defend councils' ability to run services themselves.

The government might spell out more clearly its thinking on the role of local authorities in the future, but ministers are also keen for councils to develop their own definitions and ways of fulfilling them. In the meantime, local government must wait to know the exact role central government expects them to play in the years to come.

fields.headline: Hasselbaink denies Chelsea criticism
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has denied he told a magazine he thought Chelsea were "too old" and "going nowhere" and is ready to take legal action.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has denied he told a magazine he thought Chelsea were "too old" and "going nowhere" and is ready to take legal action.

The 28-year-old striker, currently with the Dutch national team in Hoenderloo, claims the interview in the Champions League magazine was copied from an old Dutch article.

"That is why I will not leave this alone. I really like it at Chelsea and London is a wonderful city. I still think I made the right choice and I really do not think about leaving at all," he said today.

"Sure, the results are not really great, but with this team we have a lot of possibilities left.

"The only thing I ever said was that Chelsea had to watch out for the fact the team must not get too old, but for the present we still have a few years to go with this team."

Hasselbaink had some explaining to do to his team-mates, and said: "The people I work with were worried of course, but I have explained the facts to them. It is really annoying."

Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson said: "It is important we discover if he has been quoted out of context before we take action." Despite saying they would never enter Europe via the Intertoto Cup, Chelsea's poor season has seen them apply for next season's competition.

The decision represents an extraordinary backdown by the club, however the severe financial losses suffered by not having an extended run in European competition this season, coupled with the very strong possibility of not even being in contention for a UEFA cup place has meant that the club will join the other seven Premiership sides who also have applied.

The other clubs are Aston Villa, Leicester, Newcastle, West Ham, Coventry, Everton, and Leeds. To reach the UEFA Cup stages, Chelsea will need to win three two-legged ties. The first to be played on the weekend of July 14-15.

webTitle: Revolving door at Argentine finance ministry

fields.headline: Revolving door at Argentine finance ministry
fields.trailText: Argentina yesterday appointed its third finance minister in two weeks as it battled to stave off an intensifying economic and political crisis.
fields.body:
Argentina yesterday appointed its third finance minister in two weeks as it battled to stave off an intensifying economic and political crisis.

Amid fears that the country could be the catalyst for a bout of financial market instability like that of four years ago, the Argentine cabinet turned to Wall Street favourite Domingo Cavallo as it sought to rebuild credibility at home and abroad.

Mr Cavallo, the architect of Argentina's hardline reform package of the early 1990s, replaces Ricardo Lopez Murphy, who quit overnight after his plans for a $4.45bn austerity package of spending cuts over two years drew strong protests from the opposition and brought a string of government resignations. Mr Lopez Murphy replaced the unpopular Jose Luis Machinea this month.

Mr Cavallo, initially brought in to work with Mr Lopez Murphy, immediately launched his own package of spending cuts, totalling $3bn. His plans won the backing of the IMF, which has pledged a $40bn aid package. "The effort announced by Cavallo will evidently allow Argentina to meet its year's end targets," according to IMF director Claudio Loser.

Argentina's economy has been moribund for more than two and a half years as it has struggled with a one-to-one exchange rate against the strong dollar.

Yesterday there was doubt that Mr Cavallo would garner sufficient support for his package. "It will require early signals from Congress - which we have not yet seen - that they are willing to place their own ambitions aside and work with thisgovernment if the credit standing of Argentina is to be preserved," said John Chambers, deputy head of sovereign ratings at Standard & Poor's.

Worries that the crisis could spill over into Brazil, Latin America's biggest economy, drove the Brazilian real down to a two-year low on Monday. Brazil has shown signs of bouncing back from the devaluation of 1999, with growth of 4.2% last year and an expected 4% this year.

webTitle: Foot and mouth spreads to Holland

fields.headline: Foot and mouth spreads to Holland
fields.standfirst:
As foot and mouth spreads to the Netherlands, Labour ministers come under fire from the Tories and farmers, writes Derek Brown

Special report: foot & mouth
fields.trailText: As foot and mouth spreads to the Netherlands, Labour ministers come under fire from the Tories and farmers, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
An outbreak of foot and mouth has been confirmed this morning in the Netherlands, raising inevitable fears of a Europe-wide farming crisis.

The Dutch agriculture ministry said that four cows were slaughtered, and that urgent checks are now being carried out on the country's huge national herds of cattle and pigs. France has already confirmed one case, directly connected with sheep imported from Britain.

Across western Europe, farmers and officials are on high alert.

The disease is spreading throughout Britain at an ever-increasing rate, with 394 confirmed cases as of this morning. The scale of the outbreak is threatening to overwhelm efforts to contain the menace.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, admitted this morning that serious backlogs are building up in the process of diagnosis, destruction, and disposal of affected animals.

Mr Brown and government chief vet Jim Scudamore appeared before the all-party Commons select committee on agriculture, in what was a bruising interrogation. Mr Brown claimed that the disease was not being spread by the movement of animals, because of the restrictions that had been put in place. The decision to impose these measures was, he said, "absolutely right".

Vets and slaughterers drafted in by the ministry are struggling to keep up with a vast and ever-growing caseload. Small teams of soldiers are now helping with the grisly task of incinerating carcasses in farm fields, but tens of thousands of dead animals are rotting where they lie.

The British farm crisis is developing into an ugly political confrontation, with Tory leader William Hague urging the government to delay local council polls due on May 3 - the date most observers believe Tony Blair has earmarked for the general election.

In another ominous development for the government, a survey of electors published in this morning's Guardian shows a small majority in favour of postponing the elections. It also suggests a significant erosion of Labour's lead over the Conservatives, down from 15% to 9% since last month.

Ministers have consistently dismissed calls for postponement of the polls, arguing that such a move would smack of panic, and send the worst possible signal to the global food and tourism trade.

Ministers are trying to fend off damaging allegations by Tories - and by farmers - that their foot and mouth strategy is crumbling. Nicholas Soames, a Tory MP and a former defence and agriculture minister, has suggested that the Treasury is blocking moves to involve a larger number of soldiers, on cost grounds.

fields.headline: Taco Bell cashes in on Mir landing
fields.trailText:
1pm: A fast food chain has offered a freebie to every American if the space station hits a floating target. By Claire Cozens.
Mar 20: Gameshow prize out of this world
fields.body:
An American fast food chain is hoping to garner publicity from the crash landing of the Mir space station with the offer of a freebie to every American if the Mir hits a floating target in the Pacific.

Taco Bell has pledged to give every American a free taco if the Russian space station lands on its target, which carries a bull's-eye with the bell symbol in the centre and the words, "Free Taco Here".

A 20-tonne section of Mir is expected to fall into the Pacific Ocean on Friday morning British time. The target is floating 15km off the Australian coast.

Taco Bell company has even taken out an insurance policy to pay for all the free tacos, which would cost an estimated £7m.

But it is unlikely to have paid a very high price for the policy. Experts say the chances of the Mir landing on the 144 square metre target are virtually non-existent.

webTitle: Labour fails to match Tory era spending

fields.headline: Labour fails to match Tory era spending
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government's claims to be boosting investment in Britain's crumbling public infrastructure were undermined yesterday when official figures showed Labour on course to spend less in every year of this parliament than the Conservatives in their last 12 months in power.
fields.body:
The government's claims to be boosting investment in Britain's crumbling public infrastructure were undermined yesterday when official figures showed Labour on course to spend less in every year of this parliament than the Conservatives in their last 12 months in power.

Only a last-minute spending spree by Whitehall departments in the final month of the financial year would spare the blushes of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who had pledged to use part of his burgeoning war chest on improving schools, hospitals and roads this year.

Data released jointly by the Treasury and the Office for National Statistics showed that in the first 11 months of the 2000 to 2001 financial year Mr Brown amassed a surplus of £21.2bn, but public investment amounted to£2.9bn of the £7.4bn he had earmarked.

This follows three years in which Labour's ferocious control of public spending meant investment in schools, hospitals, roads and the rest of the UK's infrastructure never reached the £4.7bn spent in the final year of John Major's administration.

With public spending set to become one of the key battlegrounds in the forthcoming election, Mr Brown expressed frustration yesterday at the failure of departments to spend the money allocated to them.

"We've asked departments to produce investment plans. We now look to them to imple ment these strategies effectively so that the country can benefit from the substantial increase in resources," he told members of the Treasury select committee.

Edward Davey, the Liberal Democrat member of the committee, said Labour's underspending was not confined to public investment. Mr Davey said the government was spending less on health and education as a proportion of national income than the Conservatives spent under Mr Major.

During the 1992 to 1997 Tory administration, spending on health amounted to 5.5% of GDP, but in the four years since Labour's landslide victory it has amounted to 5.4%.

Despite the manifesto com mitment to increase the share of the national economic cake spent on education, it has fallen from 5% of GDP to 4.6% between the last parliament and this.

Mr Davey said: "This is conclusive evidence of a bust-boom approach to public investment. It's not surprising people have seen no difference in our schools, hospitals and police under Labour."

Mr Brown announced ambitious plans in last year's comprehensive spending review for higher public investment over the next few years, rising to £18bn by 2003 to 2004.

However, the size of this year's underspend has raised doubts that the money will actually be spent, with some economists blaming the "pub lic bad, private good" culture inherited from the previous government for the reluctance by Whitehall officials to sanction spending.

Investment has fallen sharply since the introduction of the private finance initiative in the mid-90s.

Spending in 1999 to 2000 stood at £3.5bn, lower in inflation-adjusted terms than in all but one of the 18 years in which the Conservatives were in power, and only a quarter of what Labour was spending in the last year of the 1974 to 1979 government, when investment had been scaled back at the behest of the International Monetary Fund.

fields.headline: Independent group posts below-par results
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Shares in Independent News & Media have tumbled after the company posted below-par results, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in Independent News & Media have tumbled after the Ireland-based owner of the Independent newspapers posted below-par results.

Revenues grew by 38.5% to £132.5m at its UK newspaper division, although no mention was made of the Independent and Independent on Sunday's progress towards profitability.

INM said both papers had reached their highest circulation peaks since 1997, reflecting the "continued vitality" of the publications and the "ongoing investment" they are receiving.

The company's stock fell 6% in early trading after a 10% rise in full-year profits failed to impress investors, who were expecting a climb of around 16%.

INM produces 12m newspapers a week worldwide, and it reported a boom in the UK market following last year's £300m acquisition of the Belfast Telegraph Group.

However, INM added that the uncertainty which has engulfed the global advertising market had made it difficult to predict the group's fortunes in the year ahead.

"It is too early to forecast an outcome for the year in view of global market uncertainty," the company said in its results statement.

Revenues from its operations in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland - including the Irish Independent, the New Zealand Herald and APN News & Media in Australia - all came in below forecasts.

INM has also promised to "rationalise" its new media investments in the face of the depression in the technology market.

Pre-tax profits for 2000 were £97m, with turnover climbing 15% to £660m.

webTitle: Moulin Rouge confirmed as Cannes opener

fields.headline: Moulin Rouge confirmed as Cannes opener
fields.trailText: Baz Luhrmann's musical drama set in the famous Parisian club at the turn of the 20th century will open the 54th Cannes Film Festival on May 9
fields.body:
Baz Luhrmann's Moulin Rouge was last night confirmed as the opening night film at this year's Cannes International Film Festival. A big-budget musical set at the turn of the 20th century and played out around the famed Paris cabaret, Moulin Rouge is Luhrmann's first feature since Romeo + Juliet in 1996.

Moulin Rouge is the first Cannes opener which will also be in competition for the Palme D'Or since Patrice Leconte's Ridicule in 1996. It also represents a coup for the festival's organisers, who have been reportedly keen on securing more heavyweight Hollywood fare following the poor reception to last year's curtain-raiser, the European costume drama Vatel. "I am particularly happy to welcome to Cannes a studio film that is in the finest show tradition to launch the festival," said Cannes president Gilles Jacob.

Moulin Rouge stars Ewan McGregor as a young writer who becomes seduced by the Paris cabaret (in general) and Nicole Kidman's tempestuous starlet (in particular). Rounding out the cast are Jim Broadbent and John Leguizamo as the artist Toulouse Lautrec. The film blends period trimmings with a modern soundtrack and is being regarded as an usually international production.

"[I am] especially gratified that a film financed by the US, almost entirely created in Australia and about French history and culture should be chosen by Cannes," Luhrmann told Variety. "I think the opening night of Cannes should be about heralding a new energy. I hope that night will mark the beginning of the return of musical cinema." The 54th Cannes Film Festival begins on May 9.
fields.bodyText: Baz Luhrmann's Moulin Rouge was last night confirmed as the opening night film at this year's Cannes International Film Festival. A big-budget musical set at the turn of the 20th century and played out around the famed Paris cabaret, Moulin Rouge is Luhrmann's first feature since Romeo + Juliet in 1996. Moulin Rouge is the first Cannes opener which will also be in competition for the Palme D'Or since Patrice Leconte's Ridicule in 1996. It also represents a coup for the festival's organisers, who have been reportedly keen on securing more heavyweight Hollywood fare following the poor reception to last year's curtain-raiser, the European costume drama Vatel. "I am particularly happy to welcome to Cannes a studio film that is in the finest show tradition to launch the festival," said Cannes president Gilles Jacob. Moulin Rouge stars Ewan McGregor as a young writer who becomes seduced by the Paris cabaret (in general) and Nicole Kidman's tempestuous starlet (in particular). Rounding out the cast are Jim Broadbent and John Leguizamo as the artist Toulouse Lautrec. The film blends period trimmings with a modern soundtrack and is being regarded as an usually international production. "[I am] especially gratified that a film financed by the US, almost entirely created in Australia and about French history and culture should be chosen by Cannes," Luhrmann told Variety. fields.headline: C5 results boost RTL fortunes
fields.trailText:
11am: Channel 5 has given a much-needed boost to RTL Group's lacklustre results by posting a cut in losses, writes Dan Milmo.
Mar 21: RTL profits halved as expansion bites
Mar 20: RTL promotes Cohen
Mar 19: Eyre quits RTL
Mar 6: RTL and Canal Plus in sports merger talks
fields.body:
Channel 5 gave a much-needed boost to RTL Group's lacklustre results by posting a cut in losses.

The UK's youngest terrestrial channel ended last year £3.7m in the red, compared with a deficit of £6.3m in 1999.

Channel 5 also reported revenues of £148m - a rise of 23% - while its audience share climbed from 5.4% to 5.7%.

RTL said the broadcaster, which made headlines last week with Dale Winton's Touch the Truck, had "flourished in a competitive marketplace".

RTL owns 65% of Channel 5 and is engaged in a game of cat-and-mouse with remaining shareholder United Business Media.

The companies clashed in court late last year in a dispute over a £10m film deal for the channel, in a row widely interpreted as a prelude to haggling over the estimated £280m price of the stake.

RTL insiders have made no secret of their desire to take complete control of the channel.

But the tension has abated recently, with United chief executive Lord Hollick saying the company would not sell its holding for the next two years.

Pearson Television, RTL's production arm, produced more than 200 different shows over the year and sold TV series and films in over 100 different territories.

RTL added that Pearson TV's acquisition of Talkback Productions from Griff Rhys-Jones and Mel Smith last summer had "greatly enhanced" the company's reputation for "quality programming".

Pearson TV, which makes hits such as The Bill and Neighbours, reported revenues of £46m - a rise of 12% from 1999.
