webTitle: What Britain needs is innovation - not spin

fields.headline: What Britain needs is innovation - not spin
fields.standfirst: David Willetts on how Labour's mistakes in social policy have left us trailing other countries
fields.trailText: David Willetts on how Labour's mistakes in social policy have left us trailing other countries.
fields.body:
Britain used to be at the forefront of thinking about the welfare state and the delivery of public services. Throughout the 20th century, we were only rivalled by Germany and New Zealand for policy innovation. But the last time Britain led the world was when privatisation of the nationalised industries and competitive tendering in the public sector were at the cutting edge during the 1980s. Now we are left behind as other countries press ahead with more radical reform. It is very instructive to see where we have fallen behind and why.

First, we have an unusually centralised welfare state. This problem did not begin on May 1 1997 but it has certainly got a lot worse since then. I recently met a Russian who was teaching at an English school as part of an exchange programme. She had been shocked at the degree of central control over English schools - far more than in her native Moscow.

It is a tragedy that the Labour Government abolished grant maintained schools and GP fundholders. These had been valuable sources of new ideas and innovation in delivering public services. But they have been flattened under the bulldozer of centrally imposed uniformity. Dynamic, high quality public services depend on freeing professional people to try out different ways of doing things.

That is why one of our first pledges across a wide range of public services is to give greater freedom to individual schools and GP practices. I cannot think of any other large-scale organisation which would operate on the basis that the way to raise standards in 25,000 individual schools, or 8,600 primary care practices is to have even more planning from the centre. It completely cuts across everything we know about how to raise commitment from staff and how to raise quality of service.

There is another feature of the British system which makes us an outlier compared with just about every other advanced Western country. They do of course have substantial levels of public finance for education and health - and quite rightly so. But they also have more private spending in addition.

This is not a matter of taking away anyone's entitlement to health care or schooling financed by the taxpayer and free at the point of use. But other countries have been far more innovative than us in combining that with extra mechanisms to allow people to spend some of their own money as well. One of the unexplored aspects of Labour is how they remain well to the Left of Continental social democracy on so many welfare state issues. The sort of mixture of public and private provision which are accepted features of healthcare systems in most continental countries would be denounced by Labour here as right-wing extremism. We do not have to copy those countries, but my colleague Liam Fox developed imaginative ideas to show how we can make it easier for people to spend their own money on top of accepting the levels of public spending planned by the Government.

So these are the first two Conservative principles when it comes to reform of public services - less central control and new mechanisms to add private spending on top of planned public spending. But it does not stop there. I would add a third principle as well - one of the best ways for Government to help our deprived areas is by competent delivery of core services. This might sound uncontroversial, but one of the worst problems in our deprived areas nowadays is the ceaseless flow of new schemes and initiatives. Again, the problem did not begin on May 1 1997, but it has got far worse since then. Decent people who are trying to help deliver high-quality public services instead spend all their time bidding for penny packets of money for some special scheme. I have identified over 30 special area-based initiatives and zones, often overlapping in their coverage and purpose.

The House of Commons Library analysed the number of schemes in individual areas as against the level of deprivation that area suffered. It found little correlation between the number of schemes and the level of deprivation. And even if the schemes work, there is no guarantee of continued funding. In fact the next trick is to dress up a project in some fancy new name so as to disguise the fact that you want to carry on delivering the mainstream service. We want to bring much-needed common sense into this, with a review of the number and complexity of the schemes.

I see very similar problems in the social security system. Here again, complexity is the enemy of delivery. The chancellor talks as if all his special schemes such as the Minimum Income Guarantee, or the Working Families Tax Credit, or the Children's Tax Credit, go to people automatically. Indeed, all the treasury's modelling of the distributional impact of Gordon Brown's measures assumes that they reach everyone they are supposed to reach. But they do not. We know that there are a million families that have not applied for the Children's Tax Credit. The Working Families Tax Credit was supposed to reach 1.5m families, but has only got to 1.1m. An expensive £15m take-up campaign for the Minimum Income Guarantee has led to only 82,000 successful claims when the Government estimates there are at least 600,000 pensioners who are eligible for the benefit but not claiming it. There is no point fine-tuning intricate distributional effects if you end up creating a system so complicated that people cannot actually benefit from it.

There is a common thread between these different problems. Too much spin and pre-occupation with announcements and re-announcements is getting in the way of good social policy. The best thing is for Governments to get out of the way. Cut the hype. Trust the people. And allow far greater flexibility.

David Willetts is MP for Havant and shadow social security secretary

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 22
fields.trailText: March 22: Unilever has finalised the structure of its combined Unilever Bestfoods UK business.
fields.body:
Unilever has finalised the structure of its combined Unilever Bestfoods UK business, dividing the business into five category groups and dropping the Van den Bergh company name.

New Look, the discount fashion retailer, has hired HHCL & Partners to handle its UK advertising.

Vizzavi, the multi-access web portal owned jointly by Vivendi Universal and Vodafone, has hired BT's head of sponsorship Vanessa Miner to develop a sponsorship strategy.

Carlton Television commercial development director Caroline Hunt has left her post without a job to go to. Jane Brown has been promoted to the role of head of commercial development and takes over Ms Hunt's responsibilities.

The Home Office and the Football Association are to seek an agency for a joint anti-racism advertising and promotional campaign as part of a government assault on football hooliganism.

Sainsbury's has hired Penny Slatter, a former senior marketeer at Somerfield's 24/7 home shopping arm, to head marketing for its online grocery interests.

ITV's marketing and commercial director John Hardie is to urge advertisers to put money back into TV.

BSkyB has shifted its £12m Open media business out of MindShare and into Universal McCann as it moves to bring Open into its Sky Interactive division.

Sara Lee has promoted Julie Baker to marketing director for its Household & Body Care division, following Caroline Clarke's appointment as UK president and managing director.

webTitle: Mental health to have its day

fields.headline: Mental health to have its day
fields.standfirst: New NHS advocacy and scrutiny arrangements could herald a "revolution" for service users with mental health problems
fields.trailText: New NHS advocacy and scrutiny arrangements could herald a "revolution" for service users with mental health problems, writes Ray Rowden
fields.body:
Getting rid of community health councils (CHCs) as outlined in the NHS plan has proved tougher than ministers might have thought. CHC's have been a part of the NHS landscape since 1974 and despite uneven performance, the public, many voluntary groups and a fair number of backbench labour MPs were far from happy to see their demise.

The government argued that the role of the CHC was too complex. It was expected to be an NHS watchdog, a patient advocate and the scrutineer of its local NHS. The government's solution was to carve up these roles.

The watchdog role in NHS trusts was to fall to newly created patient councils. Advocacy was to go to a new independent patient advocacy and liaison service (Pals), with scrutiny moving to an oversight and scrutiny committee (OSC), in every local authority.

The problems with the idea of patient councils and Pals became apparent. The proposed councils will be established by statute, with all nominations and appointments put through Nolan processes.

This must reassure critics, who suspected that a NHS board might be tempted to put tame cronies onto patient councils. The problem lies in the fact that any council would have a narrow remit, focused only on the trust in which it operates. The problem with Pals was the suggestion that the health authority might commission its services. What if a complainant wanted to complain about the health authority? Could a Pals framework, commissioned by a NHS body, really be independent?

David Hinchcliffe MP secured some important changes to these arrangements in a recent debate on the health and social care bill. The chair of the Commons health select committee suggested that the CHC, for all its weaknesses, could at least take an overview of the whole of the local NHS scene. He therefore secured an arrangement where patient councils will be able to form an overarching local committee to take a more strategic look at the local health economy.

He also secured agreement that the NHS was not the right organisation to commission Pals. The local authority or an appropriate voluntary body will commission these services. Where a local patient council is unhappy with Pals arrangements, it will have reserve powers to commission such services itself. A watchdog with some teeth to bite.

These more robust arrangements, coupled with the right of the chair of each patient council to sit as a full non-executive director on the trust board, do much to ensure a strong patient voice in all parts of the NHS. CHCs often had observer status on NHS boards, but could never vote and were excluded from more sensitive parts of the agenda. The chair of the patient council will be privy to all parts of board meetings and have a vote as of right.

It is mental health services where these arrangements could do much to refocus the NHS on the patient agenda. Too often, the experience of patients using acute mental health services is wholly negative. People frequently complain of poor environments, a lack of credible and meaningful information about treatment options, over-reliance on a cocktail of powerful medication, while women and black people often face discriminatory behaviours.

User groups in mental health have struggled with fragile funding and uncertainty about their function. At last, some serious and stable funding will open up for such groups under the proposed new arrangements. Local voluntary groups in mental health will be free to nominate people of their choice to sit on the new patient councils. Proper funding for Pals will allow good mental health voluntary groups to bid and win contracts to provide such services. Who better to advocate on behalf on mentally ill people than groups run and led by themselves?

I do not know if ministers planned on revolution, but what is proposed could radically alter mental health services for the better, but the challenges to the professionals will be complex. With an independent patient council examining every mental health trust and their chair sitting at the board table, it will be difficult to marginalise or ignore patient opinion in these new frameworks. A properly funded Pals framework will lead to more even standards of advocacy across NHS mental health services, good news for vulnerable people who use such services.

In addition, the patient councils and their overarching committee will begin to build dialogue with elected councillors who sit on the OSC. CHCs have a long and proud history, but they were not elected. The formation of the OSC allows for proper democratic scrutiny of the NHS by elected people.

This, coupled with new voices for patients, could make the NHS much more sensitive to the views and needs of communities and individuals using the NHS. A vigorous alliance between the OSC and the patient councils will be crucial in delivering real improvement, especially in Cinderella services such as mental health.

 Ray Rowden was a specialist adviser to the recent inquiry into NHS mental health services by the House of Commons health select committee.

webTitle: Bush revives plan to put embassy in Jerusalem

fields.headline: Bush revives plan to put embassy in Jerusalem
fields.trailText: President Bush indicated yesterday the US would take a less active role in Middle East peacemaking, saying he did not want to "force" a settlement, but he caused more controversy by restating his campaign promise to move the US embassy in Israel to Jerusalem.
fields.body:
President Bush indicated yesterday the US would take a less active role in Middle East peacemaking, saying he did not want to "force" a settlement, but he caused more controversy by restating his campaign promise to move the US embassy in Israel to Jerusalem.

Speaking at the White House with the new Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, sitting beside him, Mr Bush said: "I told him that our nation will not try to force peace, that we'll facilitate peace and that we will work with those responsible for peace."

He was echoing the theme adopted by his secretary of state, Colin Powell, who said on Monday that the US "stands ready to assist, not insist" on peace measures.

Mr Powell has abolished the shuttle envoy job carried out by Dennis Ross in the Clinton years.

The new administration is seeking to differentiate itself from its predecessor, whose strenuous efforts to bring about peace between the Palestinians and Israelis collapsed last year.

But Mr Bush reopened a long-running controversy over the location of the US embassy, which, like most other embassies, is in Tel Aviv.

This stems from a reluctance to put the seal on Israel's claim to Jerusalem as its "eternal and undivided capital" when it is also claimed by the Palestinians.

The Clinton administration's policy on the embassy was that it was a subject of negotiation between the Israelis and Palestinians, and that moving it unilaterally would cause an Arab uproar.

Mr Bush sent a mixed message yesterday. He said: "Well the status of ... Jerusalem will be ultimately determined by the interested parties." But he reminded journalists: "During the campaign I said we'll begin the process of moving our embassy to Jerusalem."

In a campaign speech in May last year Mr Bush told the American Israel Political Action Committee: "As soon as I take office, I will begin the process of moving the US ambassador to the city Israel has chosen as its capital."

Mr Powell added to the expectation among Israel's supporters that policy is shifting by referring, apparently accidentally, to Jerusalem as Israel's capital when he spoke to the congressional foreign affairs committee.

Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, played down the importance of the Bush and Powell remarks, repeating the Clinton-era line that the capital would be "dealt with in the final-stage negotiations" for an overall peace settlement.

In the coming weeks Mr Bush is due to meet King Abdullah of Jordan and Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian president, but no invitation has yet been issued to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Mr Fleischer pointed out yesterday that Mr Bush spoke to Mr Arafat by phone after taking office in January, and might have "further announcements" to make about future visits by Middle East leaders.

Speaking at the White House with the new Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, sitting beside him, Mr Bush said: "I told him that our nation will not try to force peace, that we'll facilitate peace and that we will work with those responsible for peace." He was echoing the theme adopted by his secretary of state, Colin Powell, who said on Monday that the US "stands ready to assist, not insist" on peace measures. Mr Powell has abolished the shuttle envoy job carried out by Dennis Ross in the Clinton years. The new administration is seeking to differentiate itself from its predecessor, whose strenuous efforts to bring about peace between the Palestinians and Israelis collapsed last year. But Mr Bush reopened a long-running controversy over the location of the US embassy, which, like most other embassies, is in Tel Aviv. This stems from a reluctance to put the seal on Israel's claim to Jerusalem as its "eternal and undivided capital" when it is also claimed by the Palestinians. The Clinton administration's policy on the embassy was that it was a subject of negotiation between the Israelis and Palestinians, and that moving it unilaterally would cause an Arab uproar. Mr Bush sent a mixed message yesterday. He said: "Well the status of ... Jerusalem will be ultimately determined by the interested parties." But he reminded journalists: "During the campaign I said we'll begin the process of moving our embassy to Jerusalem." In a campaign speech in May last year Mr Bush told the American Israel Political Action Committee: "As soon as I take office, I will begin the process of moving the US ambassador to the city Israel has chosen as its capital." Mr Powell added to the expectation among Israel's supporters that policy is shifting by referring, apparently accidentally, to Jerusalem as Israel's capital when he spoke to the congressional foreign affairs committee. Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, played down the importance of the Bush and Powell remarks, repeating the Clinton-era line that the capital would be "dealt with in the final-stage negotiations" for an overall peace settlement. In the coming weeks Mr Bush is due to meet King Abdullah of Jordan and Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian president, but no invitation has yet been issued to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. Mr Fleischer pointed out yesterday that Mr Bush spoke to Mr Arafat by phone after taking office in January, and might have "further announcements" to make about future visits by Middle East leaders.

fields.headline: Scottish finance minister supports Cosla
fields.trailText: Cosla receives a boost as the Scottish finance minister makes a public statement of confidence in the beleagured organisation. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
The beleagured Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) has received a boost after Scottish finance minister Angus MacKay today made a public statement of confidence in the organisation.

Cosla has lost three of its members since the start of the year, with Glasgow city council leading the way. The remaining members have demanded a root and branch review of the body.

Mr MacKay, speaking at Cosla's conference in Creiff, Perthshire, told council leaders: "It's extremely important that local government in Scotland has access to collective representation."

His statement will bolster the Cosla leadership, which has already been buoyed by Dundee council's decision to continue its membership of the convention. The council's Labour administration looked set to be forced into pulling out by opposition parties, but won a key vote on the issue on Monday.

Julie Sturrock, Dundee's Labour administration leader, said of Monday's decision: "This is a victory for common sense. It means Dundee city council can play an automatic part in national pay negotiations that have an impact on several thousand local authority employees in the city."

Cosla president Norman Murray appealed to the conference for unity, and said he hoped Dundee's decision would mark the return of the remaining three drop-outs. "Now more than ever, Scottish local government needs to speak with one voice."

Mr MacKay used his conference speech to exhort councillors to "grasp the opportunities" presented by community planning, a process by which councils produce a blueprint for the future of their area in consultation with local people, and then work with partners in the public, private and voluntary sectors to achieve their goals.

He said he would consider bringing forward incentives to persuade those partners to work with councils, but rejected calls for other organisations to be forced to work with local government.

The finance minister's deputy, Peter Peacock, told the conference the Scottish executive was determined to up the pace of its modernising agenda for public services: "It is my firm intention to set a faster pace. The dividends to be had by making progress are very real."

Mr Peacock cited the executive's work in developing online projects, including its role in setting up the government portal UKonline, as evidence of Scotland's willingness to move forward.

webTitle: Jewellery is the ultimate male status symbol

fields.headline: Diamond geezers
fields.standfirst: Until recently, the only men who wore earrings were punks. Now that David Beckham spends £20,000 on a platinum pair, jewellery is the ultimate male status symbol, says Charlie Porter
fields.trailText: Until recently, the only men who wore earrings were punks. Now that David Beckham spends £20,000 on a platinum pair, jewellery is the ultimate male status symbol, says Charlie Porter.
fields.body:
A quick straw poll of the nearest men to me in my office reveals that, excluding wedding rings, just one is wearing jewellery - a simple hoop earring in his left lobe. An email circular to friends brings back the odd joke about "Prince Alberts", but none of them say they wear much more than the odd hippy bracelet or a ring on one finger. But even if we're not wearing much more of it than we were, our reactions to men and their finery have changed hugely in recent years. A few years ago, David Beckham was humiliated for wearing a sarong, but now the footballer sports his latest taboo-breaking fashion piece - a pair of £20,000 platinum and diamond earrings, said to be by jeweller Theo Fennell - and no one is batting an eyelid.

"Mercifully, the world has become so less homophobic," says Fennell, who refuses to confirm whether he designed Beckham's earrings. "Men are far more comfortable with themselves and far less worried about looking feminine."

Beckham obviously doesn't care. These luxurious hoops look as if they could have been the overflow from his wife's own jewellery box. They are the sort of style that are copied on the shopping channel QVC, resplendent for a fraction of the cost in its trademark fake stone, Diamonique. They are incredibly feminine, but according to Fennell, what a man's jewellery conveys is no one's business but his own. "When a man wears jewellery, it sends out far more signals than for a woman," he says, "be it ones of aggression, with ID bracelets and dog tags, or of ineffable wealth. But if it does send out a signal, the man wearing it doesn't mind any more."

Beckham's ostentatious display of his bank balance is clearly influenced by the ghetto- fabulous world of Puff Daddy and the American gangsta rappers. These men, who thought jewels went hand in hand with guns, often appeared to emulate Liberace in their collection of diamonds and gold. Recently, with a court case rumbling on, Puff Daddy has toned down his act, only wearing the Israeli red thread bracelet called a bendel, supposed to bring the wearer good luck. But the influence has rubbed off on Britain's R&B stars: straight after Craig David found fame with Re-Rewind, he treated himself to a platinum and diamond medallion, with his initials carved into the middle.

Beckham is well known for his love of gangsta styles - many of his tattoos echo those that were inked on the body of the late rapper Tupac Shakur. So it follows that he should dispose of some of his income on a few pieces of insanely expensive jewellery. Also in his collection, alongside his diamond wedding ring, is a £40,000 diamond cross, a £45,000 platinum and diamond Cartier watch, and a gold and diamond Cartier bracelet.

Perhaps Beckham's extravagance is accepted because many men have a fond allegiance to their adolescent dabbles in jewellery. "Men of a certain age are wedded to their earrings," says Peter Howarth, editor of Esquire. "When we were 15, at the time of the Buzzcocks and the Clash, the biggest sign of rebellion was to get your ears pierced."

And so it proves with other generations - Britpop-era men have a proclivity for beads round their neck, as once worn by Damon Albarn from Blur. And survivors of grunge have a taste for piercings, though theirs are usually in harsher places than just the bottom of their ears.

But don't think that men are necessarily about to follow Beckham's example and start shoving carats through their ears: this look is strictly for the famous. "I do think it comes down to who is wearing it," says Howarth. "If you are a footballer or an actor - to all intense and purposes people who do something dramatic - then in a sense it's part of the pantomime. If you work in a building society, you won't wear jewellery because of the peer pressure."

But Fennell, whose other celebrity clients include Elton John and his partner David Furnish, believes that as long as men have the courage of their convictions, nothing is going too far. "I quite like it when men wear jewellery," he says, "for the reason that it is over the top. For the same reason I like snakeskin trousers."

Howarth, though, is less sanguine. Tellingly, the only jewellery he wears are simple, non-gaudy rings. "Us mere mortals can aspire to that sort of thing," he says, "but jewellery is still considered by some to be extreme. In the end, we all settle down into things that pass more for normal."

fields.headline: Budget 2001: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, chose investment in public services over tax cuts in a Budget aimed at tackling child poverty, decaying inner cities and NHS staff shortages.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, chose investment in public services over tax cuts in a Budget aimed at tackling child poverty, decaying inner cities and NHS staff shortages.

The public and voluntary sector broadly welcomed the the chancellor's Budget speech but there was underlying disappointment that he had chosen not to channel more of the Treasury's healthy surplus into public services.

At the heart of his Budget, expected to be the last before the general election, was a range of tax credits and benefits aimed at boosting the incomes of the poorest families and taking more children out of the poverty trap.

Mr Brown also unveiled six tax benefits worth £1bn aimed at revamping dilapidated homes in run-down urban areas. He said he wanted Britain's inner cities to be seen "not as no-go areas but as places of untapped potential".

The NHS will get an extra £1bn over the next three years, including £135m to help tackle shortages of key staff such as nurses, and capital grants of up to £1m for hospital trust to revamp outdated wards.

"Our priority has been and is public services. We will not cut investment but we will raise it, said Mr Brown. "After a generation of under-investment in both our industries and our public services, the ambitions we have for our countryan end to child poverty, a modern NHS and modern public services, can only be realised if we make the choice to invest in the long term."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy poured scorn on the Budget: "He has tinkered with the tax system but failed to make a significant impact on police shortages, teacher shortages and nursing shortages.

"This Budget will not make nearly enough impact on waiting lists, class sizes and getting more police on the streets, neither will it give pensioners dignity and security in retirement."

But public sector union Unison praised Mr Brown for drawing a "a clear line between Tory plans for spending cuts and Labour's new investment programme in public services".

Mr Brown announced a new children's tax credit, help for low-paid workers with child care costs and improved maternity and paternity rights and benefits.

Low-income families could be up to £2,240 better off, the chancellor said. Child benefit, paid to all 7.5m families with children, will go up in April to £15.50 a week.

The Sure Start maternity grant would be set at £500 a week. He also found £200m over the next three years for community anti-drugs initiatives, and announced an imminent anti-drugs campaign featuring celebrities and business leaders.

Former drug addicts who claim benefits will be offered mentoring to get them back into work under a new three-year, £40m scheme - provided they are off drugs.

Disability benefits also get a boost, with a bigger than expected guaranteed weekly income for the severely disabled of £142. For those in full-time work, the disabled person's tax allowance goes up this year by £5, to ensure a weekly family income of £250.

There was also a boost to companies who are researching cures and treatments for diseases such as Aids, tuberculosis, malaria and other diseases that kill eight million people a year around the world.

Pharmaceutical firms will get extended tax credits "subject to a commitment by the pharmaceutical companies to invest in and deliver new drugs and vaccines in a way that truly meet the needs of the poor and sick".

webTitle: Birmingham slapped down again by Atherton handball

fields.headline: Birmingham slapped down again by Atherton handball
fields.trailText: When does a setback become a crisis? On the face of it an away point in difficult conditions taken off a Grimsby team fighting for its First Division life may not look a bad result, but after defeats in their previous two games, the fact remains that Birmingham again proved distinctly second-best against supposedly inferior opposition.
fields.body:
When does a setback become a crisis? On the face of it an away point in difficult conditions taken off a Grimsby team fighting for its First Division life may not look a bad result, but after defeats in their previous two games, the fact remains that Birmingham again proved distinctly second-best against supposedly inferior opposition.

In the circumstances, manager Trevor Francis's avowed determination not to panic is beginning to have the ring Corporal Jones in Dad's Army.

It is hard to believe that just over a week ago the Blues were riding high on the back of eight wins from nine league games and automatic promotion was being whispered in the vicinity of St Andrew's. Now another stomach-churning tilt at the play-offs appears to await Francis's hard-working but essentially prosaic team.

After failing to score in those last two games Francis rushed back Stan Lazaridis and the big striker Dele Adebola for him to aim at. It was soon obvious that they are still recovering from injury.

In addition Adebola was pitted against China's captain Zhang Enhua, playing his last game at Blundell Park before completing his loan period from Dalian Shide. The centre-half has been invaluable, with his manager Lennie Lawrence rating him Premiership standard, but he was a spectator when his side went behind.

Paul Groves or the goalkeeper Tommy Coyne should have cleared Curtis Woodhouse's through-ball, but neither did so and they were still looking at each other when Andrew Johnson rolled it into the net.

Given their tentative start it was a welcome break for the visitors, but by immediately sitting back they surrendered the initiative. Groves' curling free-kick brought out a solid save from Ian Bennett, and with time running out in the first half Michael Jeffrey almost lobbed him after beating the offside trap. When Peter Atherton inexplicably handled the resulting corner, the substitute Alan Poulton's penalty sent Bennett the wrong way for his first goal for the club.

Last Saturday's win at Queens Park Rangers clearly did Grimsby's confidence a power of good. Indeed they all but when Groves rose to a corner, Woodhouse headed the ball off the line and Enhua poked the loose ball on to the bar.

In the end Birmingham were happy to hang on for the single point. In mitigation Francis cited missing players, as he is wont to do. And the weather. "It's terribly difficult to play football when the wind blows off the North Sea, which it always does here," was the manager's less than convincing lament.

For Grimsby, on the other hand, survival beckons. They do with a will what John Ruskin called the "hard and dirty work", and that may be enough.

fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell in LA laments the use of popular tunes in advertising campaigns.
fields.body:
It's always sad to see a much-loved song being used in a commercial. When a tune that was associated with a particular time or love affair gets linked instead to a car or a building society or an investment bank, a bit of the music dies with it.

Last summer I was lucky enough to bump into Jello Biafra, late of the Dead Kennedys - as opposed to dead of the Late Kennedys - at a demonstration during the Democrats convention in Los Angeles. In the course of chatting to a bunch of his fans gathered in Pershing Square, he divulged that a lot of his energy in recent years had been used in trying to stop one of the band's songs being used as a commercial by a jeans manufacturer.

It was an admirable stance and was costing him, as I recall, around $250,000 in lost money. How many have others made the same decision, I wondered?

Then in the course of reading a review of the new rock book, Tomorrow Never Knows by Nick Bromell, I discovered that Biafra is indeed a rare breed. In his review in the Nation magazine, Jon Weiner declares that he still has not recovered from "Michael Jackson selling the sound of John Lennon singing Revolution to Nike for a sneakers commercial more than a decade ago or from Bob Dylan himself selling the rights to The Times They Are A-Changin' to the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand".

Weiner, who has a show on the LA radio station KPFK, says that there are still a few holdouts refusing to sell their music for ads. He cites Bruce Springsteen, REM, Tom Petty, Neil Young, U2, Pearl Jam, Phish and Tom Waits and adds "here's hoping that they never 'stare into the vacuum of his eyes/And say do you want to make a deal?'"

I know that this site is a helpfully responsive one so is there anyone out there who knows of other bands and musicians who have turned down money from advertisers to keep their music pure? Or who is aware of particularly egregious examples of music being used in commercials?

In the meantime, it would be only fair to acknowledge the responsible use of advertising as a medium. This week in the LA Weekly there is the chance to win a free "Duck Tape" wedding and honeymoon. All - all - you have to do is agree to wed entirely in outfits made of sticky tape at a ceremony which will take place this September at Universal studios with a free honeymoon in Hawaii - "for two", adds the ad sweetly - and a reception for 75 thrown in.

To qualify, you need to send the tape people a video explaining why you would enjoy a "Duck Tape" wedding. Not too difficult surely. But let's hope that the happy couple refuse to allow the wedding video to be used in a Duck Tape commercial with Stuck In the Middle with You as the soundtrack.

webTitle: Cool US welcome for conciliatory Chinese

fields.headline: Cool US welcome for conciliatory Chinese
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: As President George Bush prepares for his first meeting with a senior member of the Chinese government tomorrow, there are signs of a marked cooling in Washington's relations with the country he now calls a "strategic competitor".
fields.byline: John Gittings  in Shanghai and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
As President George Bush prepares for his first meeting with a senior member of the Chinese government tomorrow, there are signs of a marked cooling in Washington's relations with the country he now calls a "strategic competitor".

The Chinese vice-premier, Qian Qichen, had been due to meet Mr Bush at the White House on Monday. But in a decision designed to show a shift in its Asian priorities, the administration decided to invite the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, to Washington first instead.

A similar signal was sent last week when the White House announced that Mr Bush's first presidential visit to Asia in October, to attend the Asia-Pacific economic summit in Shanghai, would be preceded by visits to the US's two main traditional allies in the region, Japan and South Korea.

When Bill Clinton last visited China, he flew straight to Beijing, and only stopped over in Japan on his way home.

The snub to Beijing and the cultivation of Japan partly reflect a shift in personnel in Washington, and a change of ideology. Unlike the Clinton foreign policy establishment, which included many China specialists, Mr Bush's early appointmentsinclude many "Japan hands".

The need to appease Japanese feelings after the destruction of the Japanese fisheries training vessel Ehime Maru by a US submarine off Hawaii last month played a part in the insistence on giving Mr Mori precedence.

On Monday the state department unveiled a further shift in the US approach, confirming that it has dropped the so-called Three Nos policy on Taiwan outlined by Mr Clinton two years ago.

"We adhere to the one China policy," spokesman Richard Boucher announced, signalling that the Three Nos - no support for Taiwan independence, no recognition of a separate Taiwanese government, and no backing Taiwan for membership of international organisations - would no longer apply.

That change could imply that the Bush administration is moving towards a more combative position towards Taiwan, which could trigger a war of words, and perhaps worse, between Washington, Beijing and Taipei.

A key test of that shift will come next month, when Washington is due to give its decision on Taiwan's latest requests for US weapons to defend itself against what it claims is a large military build-up by Beijing.

Last month, China announced an 18% increase in defence spending and Beijing is adding 50 new short-range missiles a year to the 300 already trained on Taiwan.

Taiwan's list is headed by up to four guided-missile destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system. Supplying them would be a huge step towards providing the island with a theatre missile defence system. Many conservative congressional Republicans favour that, but it would outrage Beijing. Mr Qian is expected to make it a top issue when he meets Mr Bush.

A further test will be the administration's handling of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, promoted by the chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee, Jesse Helms, a leading anti-Beijing hawk. It allows Washington to give Taiwan more US defence information and upgrade its military assistance.

"There's no question that this administration is much more wary of China and much more supportive of Taiwan," a former Pentagon Asia specialist, Derek Mitchell, said yesterday.

Chinese officials say that the visit to the US by Mr Qian, who is in charge of China's foreign relations, is intended to avoid a public confrontation, and that Beijing is leaning over backwards not to give ammunition to hardliners in the Bush administration.

"They really are prepared to give the US time," a European diplomat in Beijing said. "They are saying to all sorts of different people: 'Please listen to us ... Let's set the ball rolling on a good foot'."

One sign of this was the much more muted tone this year of Chinese complaints about the US intention to vote against Beijing at the UN human rights commission in Geneva this month, the diplomat observed.

Mr Qian gave an upbeat assessment yesterday to a meeting of US business people, pointing out that the US is China's second biggest trading partner and has become the largest source of direct foreign capital investment in China.

His visit follows conciliatory remarks about US-China relations by the Chinese premier, Zhu Rongji last week, when he avoided polemics on contentious issues such as Taiwan and missile defence.

webTitle: Younger inmates to be moved out of Portland

fields.headline: Younger inmates to be moved out of Portland
fields.trailText: More than 150 youths are to be moved out of a troubled young offenders' institution which was at the centre of allegations that it brutalised its teenage inmates over a 14-year period, the home secretary, Jack Straw, is expected to announce.
fields.body:
More than 150 youths are to be moved out of a troubled young offenders' institution which was at the centre of allegations that it brutalised its teenage inmates over a 14-year period, the home secretary, Jack Straw, is expected to announce.

The move will mean that Portland young offenders' institution in Dorset will no longer hold inmates under the age of 18. It is part of a wider "root and branch" shake-up of the way teenage offenders are locked up, to be announced by Mr Straw today.

Portland is at the centre of a police investigation into allegations of abuse of inmates exposed last year by the Howard League for Penal Reform.

A year ago, the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, described conditions as "a moral outrage" and said that for too long it had used "outdated militaristic systems" and unauthorised bullying routines to keep order.

Many of the 150 juvenile offenders at Portland come from as far afield as south Wales and the home counties, and after an abortive search to find places for them in secure units in Wales it has been decided to move some to Ashfield, a new prison near Bristol.

Charlotte Day, policy officer at the Howard League, welcomed the decision - taken by the board, which from last April became responsible for "buying places" in prisons, local authority secure units and privately run secure training centres, to hold the 3,000 juveniles under 18 whom the courts have ordered should be in custody.

The board, chaired by Lord Warner, has also decided to cap the numbers going into Feltham young offenders' institution in west London by di verting some to Hollesley Bay Colony youth offenders' institution in Suffolk.

The shake-up comes after a further board decision to stop sending sentenced juveniles to two local authority secure units because of concerns about conditions.

The board has just resumed sending children to a third local authority unit, over which concerns were raised last November. None of the three units have been named.

webTitle: Martyn primed for a late promotion

fields.headline: Martyn primed for a late promotion
fields.trailText: Nigel Martyn is again set to replace David Seaman if England's usual goalkeeper does not recover from a back injury in time for the World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield on Saturday. Martyn kept goal in Sven-Goran Eriksson's first training session yesterday as Seaman continued to have treatment.
fields.body:
Nigel Martyn is again set to replace David Seaman if England's usual goalkeeper does not recover from a back injury in time for the World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield on Saturday. Martyn kept goal in Sven-Goran Eriksson's first training session yesterday as Seaman continued to have treatment.

If he does play the Leeds goalkeeper will at least have had more notice this time. When England met Romania last summer in what proved to be their last game in the European Championship, Martyn found himself thrust into the side at the last possible moment after Seaman had broken down during the warm-up.

His nerve-ends almost visible, Martyn performed shakily and was responsible for at least one of Romania's goals in England's 3-2 defeat. His only appearance since was for the second half of the 3-0 defeat of Spain at Villa Park last month. This time at least he will be forewarned and therefore forearmed.

Eriksson will give Seaman as much chance as possible to get fit but the Arsenal goalkeeper will need to be back in training by Friday at the very latest and possibly earlier. "Normally you need to be in full training two days before a game," said Tord Grip, Eriksson's assistant, last night. "It depends on what the injury is."

Either way Ray Clemence, the former Liverpool and Tottenham goalkeeper who was capped 61 times by England and now coaches his successors full-time, will have a big input into who plays against Finland on Saturday and Albania four days later.

Eriksson admits he is no goalkeeping expert and although Grip can claim a little more knowledge of this highly specialised position he admitted that Clemence knows what it takes "better than we do".

Martyn apart, yesterday's England line-up in training was much what has been anticipated, with Gary Neville, Rio Ferdinand, Sol Campbell and Chris Powell in defence and Andy Cole up front supported by Michael Owen. David Beckham was on the right wing and Paul Scholes in midfield, while Nicky Butt and Emile Heskey were presumably keeping the other places warm for Steven Gerrard and Steve McManaman.

Gerrard was due to arrive late last night after having further treatment in France for his ongoing groin and thigh problems. McManaman was rested after his flight from Madrid. Sunderland's Gavin McCann was resting a sore knee and Gary Neville finished training early because of a sore throat.

Grip was part of the Swedish coaching team when his country reached the semi-finals of the 1994 World Cup, for which Graham Taylor's England did not qualify. Last night he stressed the importance of teamwork to the Swedes, the implication being that while England may have a wider choice of players the need for good organisation is just as necessary.

"In Sweden good teamwork is crucial for every sport in which we compete," Grip said, "whether it's football, ice hockey or handball."

Grip insisted that he was not just being diplomatic when he said he felt that if England qualified for next year's World Cup they would be good enough to compete against any country, always provided the draw treated them kindly.

"I really believe it," he said, "and if we did not have the talent I would not say that. I don't know how long it will take our good young players to develop but they will improve, you can be sure of that."

Meanwhile, Brian Kidd has stepped down as one of the England Under-21 coaches to concentrate on his job at Leeds United, where he was appointed first-team coach ear lier this month. The 51-year-old's promotion from academy director at Elland Road means he leaves his international post under Howard Wilkinson after less than five months. He will play no part in the Under-21 fixture against Finland at Barnsley on Friday.

"I now want to concentrate on my new job at Elland Road," said Kidd. "I have spoken to Howard Wilkinson and thanked him for permitting me to work with the Under-21s."

webTitle: Open for business, but beware of the pigs

fields.headline: Open for business, but beware of the pigs
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the commanding figure now in charge of the war against foot and mouth, reported to the Commons yesterday about government help for the rural economy.

Quite right too. Mr Meacher has so many homes around the country that just by shifting a bit of furniture he can do more to spread foot and mouth than half a dozen race meetings.

I have to say though that, if I were a farmer, I would not be opening the champagne or sinking to my knees in gratitude at what the minister and his rural taskforce have decided to do.

Some of it might be useful, I suppose. There will, he told us, be temporary reductions in rateable value, mandatory relief for pubs and garages whose present rateable value is less than £9,000, provided they are the only one in the village, and a brand new public information hotline to tell us which pottery barn, village fete and bouncy castle it is currently safe to visit. Ms Kali Mountford was particularly concerned about hang gliders. We were relieved to hear that there is a number they can ring too.

Several attractions will be reopened to bring visitors into the countryside, provided hikers prepare to flee if they spot a pig. (You're welcome to walk anywhere, we learned, except near an animal. If you see a cow, you will be asked to kill it, with your bare hands if necessary. Then take it home in the boot and bury it.)

Inland revenue and customs officers will be instructed, Mr Meacher said, to take a "sympathetic approach" to farmers in trouble. He also claimed that the big banks plan to do the same, which will be a first for them.

I have to say it all sounded a bit wishy-washy. My mind wandered as his voice droned onwards, intelligent, articulate, yet curiously dull and bucolic, like an Oxford don with a straw in his mouth. I reflected idly that the people of the 14th century should have been pleased that Mr Meacher wasn't in charge of combatting the Black Death.

"I am happy to inform the house that the tumbril tax will be temporarily halved from one groat, or alternatively an impost of all corn milled between Lammas and Michaelmas, enabling speedy disposal of human carcasses in the present distressing circumstances.

"A special town criers' hotline, Cadavers Direct, will be established. Specially trained teams of town criers will tour affected areas shouting 'Oyez, oyez, you've all got three days, tops'.

"The government will be doing everything it can to assure our European partners, and citizens of the United States when it's founded in 300 years time, that Britain is a perfectly safe place to visit.

"Latest statistics from the chief apothecary show that at least half and possibly as many as 60% of the population can expect to survive this outbreak. A small circle of black pustules on the skin is no reason to delay your holiday!

"Visitors from abroad can also continue to enjoy all our traditional rural pastimes, including bear-baiting, throwing stones at the village idiot, wench-deflowering and public executions.

"Let the message go forth: Britain is open for business!"

And Labour is about to be returned to office. When the Tories' Archie Norman mildly suggested that there might be a bill to enable the local elections to be postponed if needs be, Mr Meacher was outraged. "The idea that the whole country is in quarantine, and that democracy has to be suspended, is not an image we wish to project!"

So if foreign tourists can't go near the animals, at least they can follow our thrilling election campaign from the safety of their locked hotel rooms. Or possibly not.

fields.trailText: Javier Bardem, the first Spaniard to be nominated for best actor at the Oscars, talks to Kristin Hohenadel
fields.body:
To prepare for the role of the writer Reinaldo Arenas, the Spanish actor Javier Bardem learned to walk his walk, to speak with his Cuban accent, to kiss a man as if he meant it. And, on a hot Mexican afternoon a week before shooting began, he sat himself down to learn how to type. Tapping out a message with two fingers - "Help me" - he began a running letter to Arenas himself, trying to slip into the author's heart.

"When I was reading Reinaldo's work I didn't understand why someone might need to write," says Bardem. "What is he looking for when he writes? Who is he writing to? To himself, to God, to the audience? What's he trying to do? I started writing poems and letters every day, telling him my experience, asking him for help. When I'm writing in the movie, I'm writing to him."

Bardem's performance in Julian Schnabel's Before Night Falls, based largely on the memoir that the Aids-ravaged Arenas dictated in New York before he committed suicide in 1990 at the age of 47, has won him an Oscar nomination for best actor - the first ever for a Spaniard.

Bardem, who turned 32 this month, has made some two dozen films in Spain. He was first noticed in Bigas Luna's 1992 film Jamon, Jamon and gained further attention for his role in Pedro Almodovar's Live Flesh (1997), in which he played a paraplegic policeman. But his role in Before Night Falls - his second English-language film - earned him a nomination for a Golden Globe and the best actor prize at the Venice film festival last September.

The excitement mounted with the Oscar nomination. In Spain fans mobbed Bardem on the street; paparazzi waited on his doorstep in Madrid; and King Juan Carlos invited him to dinner.

Which brings us on a sleepy Saturday afternoon to his hide-out, a borrowed doctor's office in Barcelona. Bardem has never courted fame in his own country, and he has turned down such commercial propositions as Robert Carlyle's bad-guy role in the James Bond movie The World Is Not Enough. He was troubled by all the excitement. "It was as if I was playing soccer in the second division, and then someone suddenly put me in the first league."

He is also in awe of the other best actor nominees. "They are people I've watched on tape to help me learn to act. When I was doing Arenas dying of Aids, I watched Philadelphia 13 or 14 times, because I thought Tom Hanks was making good choices. And here I am nominated next to him. Russell Crowe, Ed Harris and Geoffrey Rush are magnificent, and for me to be chosen to be one of them is like a dream."

If that sounds like a rough draft for an acceptance speech, Bardem remains down-to-earth. "This great imperialistic world called the United States has made us believe that an Oscar is the most important thing in the world for an actor. But if you think about it for five minutes you realise it can't be."

Bardem's career has been marked by his ability to play a junkie or a cop with equal skill. "After the success of Jamon, Jamon, Javier was offered lots of very similar roles," says Almodovar. "The very tough, very Spanish kind of guy, but he really never played that same type of role again." Almodovar says that while Bardem transforms himself emotionally and physically for each role - he dyed his black hair auburn and lost 12kg for Arenas - "there's a certain tenderness that is captured by the camera in all his performances, and a kind of masculine nobility that appears in all his characters."

Schnabel had originally cast Benicio Del Toro as Arenas and Bardem as Lazaro Gomez Carriles, a friend and fellow Cuban refugee who was with the writer during his exile in the US. Arenas was fleeing persecution for his homosexuality and for smuggling his anti-Castro literature out of Cuba.

"I watched his movies, because I wanted to see who this guy was who was going to play me," says Carriles, who wrote the script with Schnabel and Cunningham O'Keefe. "From the moment I saw Javier, he looked like Reinaldo."

In the end, Del Toro dropped out and Bardem was cast as Arenas. At Schnabel's urging, he read Arenas's work and went to Cuba for three weeks to meet people who had known the writer. "When I read his books I was feeling his pain - he was an emotional person telling me his truth. I thought that I could do the role, because he was not a thinker, he was a person who entertained through the emotions. And I'm trying to be that kind of actor."

Bardem says it was hard to convey those emotions in a for eign language (he has since finished shooting John Malkovich's directorial debut, The Dancer Upstairs, also in English). "In Spain I have my background, my language, but in English I don't have any tricks." He overcame his apprehension with hard work. "Javier has become a specialist in doing roles that are very far from his own personality," says Almodovar. "It seems that he is interested in parts where the preparation takes almost as long as the shooting. He delves into a character very deeply."

Bardem was too shy to ask Schnabel why he offered him the part, but he never doubted the director's confidence. "Julian is really in touch with his emotions," says Bardem, "and you sometimes feel overwhelmed by his love. I guess love is trust in a way, and he trusted me 100%. You feel responsible for that."

Bardem watched documentary footage of Arenas, and Carriles gave him the audio tapes of the writer dictating Before Night Falls. Carriles also helped teach him how to walk like his old friend. "Reinaldo not only had a little country walk," Carriles says, "but he had this little gay walk too. For almost a year, it felt as if Reinaldo was here, and I could talk to him. Then, after Bardem finished the movie, he became Javier Bardem again, and I felt sad, almost betrayed - as if he had been teasing me."

To hear Bardem talk, however, you'd think they'd got the wrong man. "When I first saw the movie, I almost killed myself. I spent six months of my life doing it, so I was expecting to see more. I look at myself, and I see a Spanish person who's trying to be understood by an English-speaking audience and is putting a lot of energy into that, instead of into expressing himself freely and feeling comfortable."

The rest of the world has a more flattering take. Schnabel says that Bardem won his nomination the hard way. "He didn't get nominated because he had friends at the academy. "He earned this nomination because other actors look at this and they see one of those performances that you come across once in a lifetime."

Malkovich said in a recent interview that Bardem was the best actor in Europe. In Interview magazine, Dennis Hopper called his work "the best performance of the year and perhaps many years".

Bardem, a wrinkle forming on his brow, says that he found all the attention baffling. "There are some parts of this movie that I like very much, where I can say to myself, 'Javier, you got it, that's Reinaldo. But there are some other parts where I don't believe what I'm watching."

Bardem says he would like to get started on a new role but hasn't found anything worth taking on. Besides, he is having a hard time concentrating on anything but making it to Oscar night.

Almodovar suggests that Bardem should wait until everything has settled down and refuse all offers for the next three months: "In spite of being so young, Javier really has a grip on things. He doesn't really want to conquer the American market and become a movie star." But Bardem says that he feels lost without an assignment. "Sometimes I say to myself, what are you doing in this absurd job? Why don't you go to Africa and help people? But I cannot help people, because I am a hypochondriac. I don't know how to drive a car. The only thing I can do is act, but it's not something I even feel comfortable doing. It costs me a lot, because I'm a shy person, even if I don't look it. I want to act because I don't know how to do anything else. But don't call me an actor. I'm just a worker. I am an entertainer. Don't say that what I am doing is art."

In a final act of deflection, he explains away all this Oscar business by blaming Arenas. "I don't believe in God," he says. "But I do believe in guardian angels. He chose me for his movie. This is his revenge - for reaching a huge audience, which he couldn't do. That's why I'm getting all this recognition."

webTitle: BBC drama triumphs at RTS programme awards

fields.headline: BBC drama triumphs at RTS programme awards
fields.trailText:
10.45am: It was the BBC's night at the RTS programme awards, taking more than half of the prizes including a clean sweep of the drama awards, writes Jason Deans.
Full list of winners: RTS website
fields.body:
It was the BBC's night at last night's Royal Television Society programme awards, with the corporation taking more than half the prizes, including a clean sweep of the six drama categories.

In all, the BBC walked away with 14 out of the 26 awards.

Channel 4 also enjoyed a successful night, picking up seven awards. But ITV had to settle for four, of which just two were for network shows.

Channel 5 and cable and satellite had just one nomination between them, for Disney/BBC children's drama co-production Microsoap - which did not win its category.

The champagne corks were popping on BBC Drama tables at London's Grosvenor House for BBC1 series Clocking Off, which picked up best drama series and best writer award for creator Paul Abbott.

The single drama prize went to BBC2's Storm Damage; while another BBC2 offering, Nature Boy, carried off the best serial award.

Steven Mackintosh was named best actor for his performance in BBC1 drama Care and Katy Murphy scooped best female actor award for her work in Donovan Quick.

Other BBC successes included The Royle Family, which beat another Granada TV production, Cold Feet, to the best sitcom and comedy drama award; while Blue Peter won the best children's factual category.

Two of the most popular awards of the night were for Rob Brydon, judged best on-screen network newcomer for BBC2's Marion and Geoff; and Julia Davis, who picked up the best TV performance prize for another BBC2 show, Human Remains.

But perhaps the biggest cheer of the night greeted the announcement that Graham Norton had won best presenter for Channel 4's So Graham Norton.

Channel 4's awards haul also included two gongs for Big Brother, in the primetime features and production team categories.

The broadcaster's Da Ali G Show triumphed in the entertainment category.

Channel 4 also picked up best single documentary for True Stories strand offering 100% White, and best documentary series for 15.

ITV's only RTS awards successes came in the children's categories, with SM:TV judged best entertainment show for the second year running and My Parents Are Aliens picking up best drama.

But on a bad night for ITV overall, Scottish Television enjoyed some regional success.

STV came away with the best regional programme award for drama New Found Land: I Saw You, and best regional presenter in Stephen Jardine.

The Cyril Bennett Judges Award went to LWT and United Productions managing director John Willis.

Useful link

RTS website: full list of award-winners

webTitle: No room for men behaving badly

fields.headline: No room for men behaving badly
fields.standfirst: Eriksson trusts his players to act responsibly, writes  David Lacey
fields.trailText: In the build-up to their World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania, Sven-Goran Eriksson expects his squad to behave "like England football players". No sooner had the nation's Swedish coach uttered these words than an involuntary groan arose from the assembled reporters.
fields.body:
In the build-up to their World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania, Sven-Goran Eriksson expects his squad to behave "like England football players". No sooner had the nation's Swedish coach uttered these words than an involuntary groan arose from the assembled reporters.

Memories of tequila-swilling nights in dentist chairs die hard, and if Cathay Pacific is ever called upon again to fly the cream of the nation's footballing talent to Hong Kong and back, presumably the airline will reserve the right to jettison cabin wreckers over the South China Sea.

Behaviour-wise, this squad offers a similar mix to any other. The boozers and headbangers will be in a minority, but so will the cola-supping successors to Trevor Brooking. The majority will be somewhere in between, and more than a few will be professional athletes who may like the occasional drink but are more concerned to look after the bodily well-being without which their future earning power is limited.

Eriksson has already made it clear that, while he will not impose an alcohol ban, neither does he expect players to consume anything more than a glass of wine with a meal. This is the norm in the footballing environment from which he has emerged to try to take England to next year's World Cup.

At the same time, it is obvious he will expect a degree of self-discipline which in the past has proved beyond some England footballers, including those with an abundance of international caps.

During Don Revie's reign as manager, for instance, two well-known players broke ranks in a late-night drinking session and added insult to injury by charging large champagne bills to the Football Association. Neither played for England again.

Eriksson is unlikely to experience such excesses now, although when footballers are cooped up for more than a week with time on their hands, the danger, however remote, will always be there. England's present headquarters at a hotel, golf and leisure centre 10 miles south of Chester will offer the players plenty of legitimate relaxation, but the coach is keen to stress the importance of setting the right mood and remaining focused on the task in hand.

"If you are together for a long time, getting a good atmosphere is as important as practising well," Eriksson explained. "At this level, if you don't have a good atmosphere, a good ambience, then you will never get a good result.

"That is not only up to myself. It is also up to the players. If they want to be here they have to accept that it means more games, more training and less rest, less holiday."

In the immediate term, this will mean no slipping home between Saturday's qualifier against Finland at Anfield and Monday's departure for the encounter with Albania in Tirana a week today. "There is no reason why they should go home for half a day," Eriksson observed, although the inmates will be allowed a conjugal visit at their Burnham Beeches HQ on Sunday.

Eriksson is no martinet, just a professional who expects certain standards to be maintained. "I'm not going to make 10, 15 or 20 rules for the players," he insisted. "I am not creating a regime. But I would like them all to turn up on time and we need a feeling of respect for one another; respect for the kit man, respect for the people who prepare the meals. We are all the same."

All for one and one for all, then, but this sense of togetherness will not include forced integration to break up the club cliques which will inevitably develop, particularly among the preponderance of players from Manchester United and Liverpool. In fact, Eriksson sees this as a strength, not a drawback.

"I make the line-up when we play," he said, "I do not make the line-up when we are eating. I'm not going to tell Paul Scholes that he has to take tea with Sol Campbell. It's not got to be like that. It's more about mutual respect."

Talking of which, there is some concern about the attitude of Liverpool fans towards the Manchester United players in Eriksson's team when England play at Anfield. David Beckham, the England captain, may well be the target for more of the abuse which is his lot whenever United visit Liverpool in the Premiership.

"I hope everybody will be there to support England," said Eriksson. "It's England that's going to play at Anfield come three o'clock on Saturday, not Manchester United.

"I don't see how anyone can come to this game and not support England if they are English," he added. But with two Liverpool players, Sami Hyypia and Jari Litmanen, appearing for the opposition, Anfield's loyalties may not be so easily reconciled.

 Greece has been threatened with expulsion by Fifa from all international competition at club and national level, including the World Cup qualifying group involving England, unless the government in Athens agrees before the end of the month to cease its alleged interference in the workings of the domestic game.

webTitle: Sunderland buck trend with 10% price cut

fields.headline: Sunderland buck trend with 10% price cut
fields.trailText: Sunderland, within sight of a money-spinning place in the Champions League and enjoying their second biggest average attendance ever, yesterday announced that they were cutting season ticket prices for the 2001-02 campaign.
fields.body:
Sunderland, within sight of a money-spinning place in the Champions League and enjoying their second biggest average attendance ever, yesterday announced that they were cutting season ticket prices for the 2001-02 campaign.

Next season Mackems will, according to the club, enjoy the cheapest season tickets in the top flight with an average reduction of around 10% on this year's prices. The move was taken as the Wearsiders, who currently boast 36,000 season ticket holders, gauge public demand before beginning work on a £9m expansion of the Stadium of Light to a capacity of 55,555 in time for the 2003-04 season.

"We are proud of our pricing policy and the fact that we can reward the fans," said the Sunderland chairman Bob Murray. "It's not the most affluent of places but we will now, on average, have the cheapest season ticket prices in the Premiership."

The adult price range will run from £320 to £435. "The crowds here are phenomenal. When you look at the population base of 3.5m and the wealth, it's absolutely stunning. Sunderland's progress over the last few years is unmatched by anybody in football, anywhere in the world."

Sunderland's average attendance is nearly 48,000, and Murray is hoping the move to secure the club's future support will justify building England's second biggest club stadium.

"By the 2003-04 season we will be one of the 20 wealthiest clubs in the world and this is a continued investment in the success of Sunderland," he said. fields.headline: New boy Fraser makes a splash
fields.trailText:
10am: Photographer Jason Fraser kicked off his first day at the Express with a front-page scoop of Emma Thompson, writes Jessica Hodgson.

Celebrity stalker: Jason Fraser profile

fields.body:
The Express's new signing, Jason Fraser, has made his first splash at the Express with a front-page, long-lens scoop picture of Emma Thompson relaxing with her boyfriend and small child.

Mr Fraser, claimed by many to be the world's number one paparazzo, announced yesterday he was joining the Express as executive director under new owner.

In a trademark beach shot by Mr Fraser, a shaven-headed Ms Thompson is snapped in an intimate moment with her boyfriend and 16-month daughter Gaia Romilly on holiday in Cyprus.

In an unprecedented appointment, Mr Fraser has joined the company to co-ordinate photographic coverage across the newspapers and magazines owned by Express Newspapers and Northern & Shell.

The appointment signals that Mr Desmond wants to put top celebrity scoops - as well as posed pictures - at the top of his agenda.

Although Mr Fraser yesterday claimed he would not be taking long-lens pictures for the Express, his world-wide network of contacts with other paparazzo will prove invaluable to Mr Desmond.

webTitle: Journalists flee TV show as Cantona vents his spleen

fields.headline: Journalists flee TV show as Cantona vents his spleen
fields.trailText: Rumours that a new career as a beach football celebrity and part-time film star have mellowed Eric Cantona are clearly unfounded: the former Manchester United striker has lost none of his eccentric temperament.
fields.body:
Rumours that a new career as a beach football celebrity and part-time film star have mellowed Eric Cantona are clearly unfounded: the former Manchester United striker has lost none of his eccentric temperament.

"I piss on the lot of you," he bellowed at two French sports journalists on a television chat show on Monday night, frightening them so much that they fled the studio 15 minutes before the scheduled end.

"We were genuinely scared," said Patrick Urbini of the sports daily L'Equipe, a fellow guest on the football show Céte Tribune. "We felt he was building up to something, and then it all came out. He completely lost his rag. We left before he could punch us."

Cantona had been invited to discuss beach football, his home town of Marseille and life since leaving Manchester. But he quickly veered into a diatribe against French sports journalists, who he feels have never really understood him.

"Six months after my moment of madness, the English press were able to recognise my talent by voting me the best player in England," he stormed. "But the French press, who had labelled me 'indefensible', made no mention of that. For me, 'indefensible' is worse than an insult. It's an adjective I would use only for criminals."

Urbini said the outburst came "out of the blue. It was like he was getting rid of years of frustration. He clearly feels he was never treated fairly by the French footballing establishment, and most particularly by journalists."

Cantona has appeared in four films, including as a French ambassador in the award-winning 1998 movie Elizabeth.

His strong Marseille accent and abrasive character - he once called the former France coach Henri Michel a "bag of shit" - prevented him fulfilling his potential in French football.

"He even accused us of not paying enough attention to beach soccer, purely because it was him who was involved in it," said Urbini. "He said if Didier Deschamps [whom Cantona once described as 'a water carrier'] was playing beach soccer, we'd pay it a lot more attention."

webTitle: Boro move to lure Neill from Lions

fields.headline: Boro move to lure Neill from Lions
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough hope to boost their defensive ranks by signing Millwall's Australian international defender Lucas Neill before tomorrow's transfer deadline.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough hope to boost their defensive ranks by signing Millwall's Australian international defender Lucas Neill before tomorrow's transfer deadline.

Neill, 23, a graduate of the Australian Institute of Sport, played under Boro's coach Terry Venables when he guided the Socceroos to within a game of qualifying for the 1998 World Cup. He is out of contract in the summer and available for a cut-price fee.

The Queens Park Rangers manager Ian Holloway has taken Newcastle's 20-year-old striker Jamie Coppinger on loan for the rest of the season, but failed in a similar move for the £2.25m forward Lomana Tresor Lua-Lua.

Lua-Lua, who moved to St James' Park from Colchester in October, has yet to score and has failed to earn a regular starting place.

Steve Claridge has accused Portsmouth of "moving the goalposts" after they stalled on his proposed loan move to Millwall. The 34-year-old striker, sacked as Pompey's manager last month, is wanted by the Second Division promotion hopefuls as cover for Neil Harris and Paul Moody, who face three-match suspensions.

Claridge said: "Portsmouth have moved the goalposts a little bit. I don't quite know what's going on." Millwall must complete the deal before tomorrow's deadline.

Leeds' Champions League quarter-final opponents, Deportivo La Coruna, have until today to prove that four of their side are not playing under false passports. Helder, Emerson, Jacques Songo'o and Aldo Pedro Duscher have been investigated by the Spanish football federation which has threatened to ban any player found to be falsely registered as a European Union player.

webTitle: Labour fails to match Tory era spending

fields.headline: Labour fails to match Tory era spending
fields.standfirst: The government's claims to be boosting investment in Britain's crumbling public infrastructure were undermined yesterday when official figures showed Labour on course to spend less in every year of this parliament than the Conservatives in their last 12 months in power.
fields.trailText: The government's claims to be boosting investment in Britain's crumbling public infrastructure were undermined yesterday when official figures showed Labour on course to spend less in every year of this parliament than the Conservatives in their last 12 months in power.
fields.body:
The government's claims to be boosting investment in Britain's crumbling public infrastructure were undermined yesterday when official figures showed Labour on course to spend less in every year of this parliament than the Conservatives in their last 12 months in power.

Only a last-minute spending spree by Whitehall departments in the final month of the financial year would spare the blushes of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who had pledged to use part of his burgeoning war chest on improving schools, hospitals and roads this year.

Data released jointly by the Treasury and the Office for National Statistics showed that in the first 11 months of the 2000 to 2001 financial year Mr Brown amassed a surplus of £21.2bn, but public investment amounted to£2.9bn of the £7.4bn he had earmarked.

This follows three years in which Labour's ferocious control of public spending meant investment in schools, hospitals, roads and the rest of the UK's infrastructure never reached the £4.7bn spent in the final year of John Major's administration.

With public spending set to become one of the key battlegrounds in the forthcoming election, Mr Brown expressed frustration yesterday at the failure of departments to spend the money allocated to them.

"We've asked departments to produce investment plans. We now look to them to imple ment these strategies effectively so that the country can benefit from the substantial increase in resources," he told members of the Treasury select committee.

Edward Davey, the Liberal Democrat member of the committee, said Labour's underspending was not confined to public investment. Mr Davey said the government was spending less on health and education as a proportion of national income than the Conservatives spent under Mr Major.

During the 1992 to 1997 Tory administration, spending on health amounted to 5.5% of GDP, but in the four years since Labour's landslide victory it has amounted to 5.4%.

Despite the manifesto com mitment to increase the share of the national economic cake spent on education, it has fallen from 5% of GDP to 4.6% between the last parliament and this.

Mr Davey said: "This is conclusive evidence of a bust-boom approach to public investment. It's not surprising people have seen no difference in our schools, hospitals and police under Labour."

Mr Brown announced ambitious plans in last year's comprehensive spending review for higher public investment over the next few years, rising to £18bn by 2003 to 2004.

However, the size of this year's underspend has raised doubts that the money will actually be spent, with some economists blaming the "pub lic bad, private good" culture inherited from the previous government for the reluctance by Whitehall officials to sanction spending.

Investment has fallen sharply since the introduction of the private finance initiative in the mid-90s.

Spending in 1999 to 2000 stood at £3.5bn, lower in inflation-adjusted terms than in all but one of the 18 years in which the Conservatives were in power, and only a quarter of what Labour was spending in the last year of the 1974 to 1979 government, when investment had been scaled back at the behest of the International Monetary Fund.
