webTitle: Food preparation may be crucial clue to CJD deaths

fields.headline: Food preparation may be crucial clue to CJD deaths
fields.standfirst: Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: The long-awaited report into a cluster of five deaths from the human form of BSE in Leicestershire will today seek to establish a common link in the preparation of food eaten by victims years ago.
fields.body:
The long-awaited report into a cluster of five deaths from the human form of BSE in Leicestershire will today seek to establish a common link in the preparation of food eaten by victims years ago.

Speculation last night centred on the possibility that the infection may have been spread from the carcasses of cows harbouring the agent responsible for the fatal cattle disease by unwitting butchers using knives to prepare meat.

But the claim made on BBC Newsnight was dismissed by Philip Monk, the doctor who has led the nine-month investigation into the deaths between August 1998 and Sep tember last year. Four of the five victims had close links to the village of Queniborough.

Dr Monk refused to divulge the results of his enquiries before they were given to villagers this morning. But he said: "We have no idea whether this involves knives or not. We have a hypothesis but we cannot get it down to anything as specific as that."

Newsnight claimed in its report local butchers had brought in whole animals rather than carcasses and prepared the meat themselves to provide cuts which were popular locally. The knives were contaminated with brain material from BSE-infected animals and used to prepare other cuts of meat thereby cross-contaminating other meat in their shops, it said.

The programme suggested the findings would intensify concerns about the safety of surgical instruments .

The government ordered hospitals to improve their decontamination and sterilisation procedures to reduce the theoretical risk of patients catching the fatal human form of BSE in January.

The investigation into the Queniborough cluster, which started before the final victim Christopher Reeve died last year, has centred on food preparation including the years before anti-BSE controls were phased in from 1989. But Dr Monk said the BBC report was "irresponsible journalism"

"They have not got enough of the story to make sense. It would be irresponsible to spec ulate in advance and to play a twentieth of the story because people could not assess the risk to themselves or their children without knowing the whole story."

The government and its advisers are hoping the results of the investigations can throw vital light on how BSE leapt from cattle to humans. Ninety Britons have died since March 1995, five more are sliding towards inevitable death, and scientists have little idea of exactly how many more deaths there will be.

Although infected meat has long been accepted by most government advisers as the most probably cause of human BSE, little is known about how transfer of the rogue prions responsible occurs.

fields.headline: RTL profits halved as expansion bites
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Channel 5 owner RTL is expecting a 'flat' 2001 after its profits were hit by restructuring and expansion costs. By Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Channel 5 owner RTL is expecting a "flat" 2001 after its full-year profits were savaged by restructuring and expansion costs.

The pan-European broadcaster said restructuring its Pearson TV production outfit in the US and a declining audience for its RTL Radio station in France would affect the group over the next 12 months.

It added that setting up operations in Poland, India and Indonesia had also eaten into earnings.

"Combined with the effects of restructuring Pearson Television North America and a decrease in the audience of RTL Radio in France, market conditions at present lead us to expect a comparatively flat earnings performance in 2001," said Didier Belens, chief executive of RTL.

Mr Belens painted an even gloomier picture when he added that television advertising income had declined since the beginning of the year.

He said the core German market had suffered a 2.8% drop in advertising revenue between January and February this year.

However, Mr Belens added the group was "better placed than most of our competitors" to withstand the slump in the advertising market.

RTL's preliminary results for 2000 registered a fall of over 50% in pre-tax profits - from £366m in 1999 to £184m.

The 1999 results were presented on a "proforma" basis, as RTL was formed last year by the merger of Pearson TV in the UK and Luxembourg-based CLT-Ufa, owned by German media giant Bertelsmann.

Television brought in £1.76bn of RTL's £2.55bn earnings last year, with reduced costs at its Channel 5, Vox and RTL Klub channels helping to boost the figures.

New media ventures were an inevitable drain on the company's performance, with the group's internet arm reporting a loss of £21.5m.

RTL is hoping to break into the flagship FTSE 100 index later this year when it releases more shares onto the market, and the chance to invest in a group that is 67% owned by Bertelsmann.

Some analysts believe Financial Times owner Pearson would reduce uncertainty over its own shares if it sold its 22% stake in RTL, although it is unlikely to get a good price for its holding in current market conditions.

fields.headline: Reinventing Russia
fields.standfirst: Following recent knocks to the nation's pride, a programme of 'patriotic education' has been launched by the government, says Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: Following recent knocks to the nation's pride, a programme of 'patriotic education' has been launched by the government, says Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
A six million dollar campaign to boost patriotic pride in Russia was launched by the Kremlin this week, aimed at rallying the country's media, its film industry and the military to work together to inspire the entire nation with a reawakened love of the motherland.

Video games based on glorious episodes from Russian history are to be commissioned to instil a respect for Russia's past in its youth; the Soviet tradition of naming schools after contemporary and historical national heroes is to be revived; and patriotic websites will be established on the Internet at the government's expense to bolster the population's self-belief.

Russia's media will be invited to produce "programmes, shows, films and books that further patriotic education" and encouraged to favour "positive heroes"; they will also be asked to "energetically oppose the distortion of the Fatherland's history". Prizes will be offered to those film makers and journalists who work hardest to build a triumphant image of modern Russia.

With thousands of young men seeking to evade military service every year, the programme is also designed to foster respect and enthusiasm for the army - by the creation of a network of "patriotic-military" sports and social clubs throughout the country.

The concept of patriotic education, which was used to powerful effect throughout the Soviet era, has largely disappeared over the decade of transition and President Vladimir Putin's government believes it is vital to restore it in order to nurture Russia's wounded self-esteem.

In the wake of recent blows to Russian pride - the Kursk nuclear submarine tragedy, the humiliation of catastrophic economic crises and the ongoing debilitating war in Chechnya - the government has very ambitious hopes for the new campaign, optimistic that it will not only improve national morale, but will also "aid the preservation of social stability, help the resurrection of the nation's economy and strengthen the country's defensive capacity".

The project is backed by Mr Putin who has repeatedly referred to the need to foster a new sense of pride amongst the population for their homeland.

The full text of the curiously anachronistic five-year plan for "patriotic education of citizens of the Russian Federation" explains that the "gradual loss of traditional Russian patriotism has become more and more noticeable". It claims that the "economic disintegration, social breakup of the community and the erosion of spiritual values" in recent years have led to "indifference, individualism, cynicism, unmotivated aggression and disrespectful attitudes towards the state".

Designed to cater for every group in Russian society, the programme declares that its main aim is to "create in citizens a high patriotic consciousness, a sense of loyalty to the fatherland, and a readiness to perform civil duties and constitutional obligations in order to defend the interests of the homeland".

A source from the Ministry of Education said fostering patriotism should not be confused with encouraging nationalism, and argued that the initiative was simply an attempt to help Russia's population rediscover an affection for its country after a period of disorientating political upheaval.

"Sociological research has shown that since the collapse of the Soviet Union, when a great many shocking facts were published about the USSR's history, there has been a wholesale rejection of the country's past by its population - including those aspects of it in which one could take pride," the source said.

"Our programme isn't aimed at imposing some kind of new ideology on the population; we are highlighting the importance of education in love and respect for one's country."

No extra money from this year's budget has been set aside for the project, although the government intends to spend about $6m (£4.2m) over the course of the five-year programme. The education, defence and culture ministries are this year obliged to find the resources to launch the initiative out of their own already tight budgets. It was not clear whether the money available would be enough to finance the high expectations of the project's creators.

State Duma deputy Sergei Yushchenkov, a member of the liberal Union of Right Forces party, said whatever sum of money was allocated to the project would be too much. "This is a completely unnecessary and potentially dangerous programme. The language of the text is evocative of the cold war era and sounds like it may have been inspired by George Orwell's Ministry of Truth, " he said. "The programme appears to have been written by the Communist party with the aim of instilling old-fashioned, outdated values in the population. The whole idea is stupid from beginning to end."

Russia's mobile phone companies are already doing their bit for the patriotic cause. This year's most popular telephone ring is an electronic version of the recently resurrected Soviet national anthem.

webTitle: Damaged by the evils of the market

fields.headline: Damaged by the evils of the market
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's campaign to revive public services is backed by George Monbiot
fields.trailText: The Guardian's campaign to revive public services is backed by George Monbiot.
fields.body:
All too often the education process is entrusted to people who appear to have no understanding of industry and the path of progress," the European Roundtable of Industrialists complained in 1998. "The provision of education is a market opportunity and should be treated as such."

Companies have not been slow to respond. Some have donated free exercise books to British schools. Interleaved with the blank pages are such salutary exhortations as "Stand up for your beliefs and values; take responsibility for your own actions; [get] spot protection by simply washing daily [with] Clearasil". Others have handed out teaching materials. A pack about "puberty and menstrual health", kindly provided by Tampax, warns girls that sanitary pads are uncomfortable, unhygienic and environmentally damaging; Tampax tampons, by contrast, are good for you and good for the planet.

A school newspaper partly sponsored by Nestlé pub-lished a page of children's poems and stories about Nestlé products, such as "Nestlé chocolate is the best/ Eat it for a hairy chest..." A teaching pack from Coca-Cola instructs pupils that non- refillable bottles are more environmentally-friendly than returnable ones.

But the sponsorship of teaching materials is the least of the market opportunities education now provides. The government's education action zones are clusters of schools run by committees on which businesses must be represented. Last year the government launched a network of "city academies": urban secondary schools partly run by the private sector. Next month schools in Leeds will be outsourced to a "joint venture company".

The market, the champions of privatisation argue, is keener and leaner than the public sector. With a vested interest in cost-effectiveness, companies are more efficient than the bureaucracies handling other people's money. The opponents of commercialisation argue that market efficiency and social efficiency are very different matters. Company directors have a "fiduciary duty" towards their shareholders: they are legally obliged to put their interests first, even if these clash with the interests of society.

Some parents fear, for example, that companies running schools will seek to exclude failing pupils in order to improve their ratings, and hence their market value. The firms involved in education action zones are likely to be more interested in training a pliable corporate workforce than turning out well-rounded citizens.

This is not to say that public and private interests are always in conflict. Few would argue, for example, that telecoms worked better when they were controlled by the state. The government nationalised the railways in 1948 partly to avoid paying the compensation necessary for reinvestment after the war. They have been run down ever since. But reprivatisation in 1996 merely compounded the damage, as the operating companies were also relieved of the responsibility to invest.

The problem is that market values are now intruding into almost every aspect of public life, whether or not they are appropriate. When aristocrats enjoyed inordinate power in Britain, they insisted that they were the only ones who had the expertise needed to run the country. Today business people make the same claim, and governments seem prepared to believe them. There are two principal means by which the market is coming to run the country.

The first is the establishment of quasi-corporate systems in public services. Management structures and pay scales mimic those of the private sector. Public provision is tested according to "best value" criteria. If it's found wanting, it's sub-contracted to the private sector. New ac counting procedures, such as "capitation" in the NHS and "producer choice" in the BBC, enable public services to become interchangeable with private ones.

Interestingly, many of the new accounting methods would never be tolerated in a real corporation, as staff who should be saving lives or making programmes are instead buried in paperwork.

But the most effective means of subjecting public services to the rigours of the market is to privatise them. The "private finance initiative" was described by one of its architects as "the Heineken of privatisation - taking the private sector to the parts of the government machine not reached by previous privatisations". Though most of us have yet to notice, corporations are gradually taking over almost every public service in Britain. The government claims that by attracting private money it can start building more hospitals, schools, prisons, roads and underground stations than it could have funded by itself.

The first problem is that the private sector will only invest in schemes which make money. It's not interested, for example, in renovating hospitals, as the budgets are too small to be worth pursuing. It's more interested in knocking them down, selling off the valuable city centre land they sat on, then rebuilding new facilities on greenfield sites, for which they can charge big rents. So the NHS has redesigned its modernisation programme to attract private money.

The £30m scheme to renovate Coventry's two hospitals, for example, was transformed into a £174m plan to knock them both down and build a new one. Instead of paying £30m once, the NHS will now have to pay the private contractors £36m a year for the next 25 years. This money has to come from somewhere: the NHS will have to cut the number of beds in Coventry by 25%, and the number of doctors and nurses by 20%

Even when private companies offer the same services as the public sector was providing, it's not clear that the savings they make could really be regarded as "efficiencies". As Richard Tilt, director general of the prison service, remarked in 1996, "the great majority of the cost reduction comes from the payment of much lower wages and poorer conditions of service for staff working in the private sector". What this means is more prison riots, less rehabilitation and more crime when the inmates are released. The costs the service would have carried, in other words, are dumped instead on to society.

The aristocrats who once ran Britain failed to distinguish between their interests and those of the country as a whole. Today, our business leaders appear similarly confused. The market and the public sector can live together only when the interests of business are subordinated to the interests of society.

 George Monbiot is the author of Captive State: the corporate takeover of Britain

fields.headline: Tube bosses have no Heart
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Yet another company has had its posters banned by the London Underground, writes Claire Cozens.
Mar 14: ASA clears Spitfire adverts
fields.body:
Advertisers are demanding new rules on poster advertising after yet another company had its posters banned by the London Underground.

Heart 106.2 has become the latest advertiser to have its posters blocked by London Underground bosses.

The advert shows a couple snogging over the words, "Just another night in?", followed by Heart's tagline, "The right song, right now".

The decision follows London Underground's controversial refusal to carry a poster for the fashion retailer Miss Selfridge that showed women posing in bikinis.

"Rulings by London Underground over what is acceptable and what is not are leaving advertisers more and more confused," said Gill Woods, marketing manager of Heart 106.2.

"The objective of any Heart 106.2 campaign is to raise awareness in the public domain and any which we have embarked on has always been based on research and our knowledge of our target market.

"Ultimately any creative we use is going be representative of the brand and appeal to our audience, not offend them," she added.

Only last week, the ASA cleared a campaign for Spitfire beer that had previously been banned by the London Underground.

The beer's manufacturer was ordered to pull down its tongue-in-cheek posters after London Underground bosses decided they could be offensive to German tourists.

But the ASA cleared Spitfire of any wrongdoing.

London Underground was last night insisting it did not have to abide by the ASA's rulings.

"The company that sells our advertising space does turn down a lot of posters that they know we'll get complaints about, even if they have been cleared by the ASA," said a spokeswoman for London Underground.

"Three million paying customers use the underground every day and we don't want to offend them," she added.

The ASA said it had received seven complaints about the Heart 106.2 posters, which have run outside London Underground, and was in talks with the advertiser.

Related story

fields.headline: Pregnancy costs jobs of thousands
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of women each year are illegally sacked or threatened with dismissal when they tell their employer they are pregnant, according to a report today by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of women each year are illegally sacked or threatened with dismissal when they tell their employer they are pregnant, according to a report today by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux.

After analysing employment problems handled by the bureaux last year, the association found widespread flouting of employees' maternity and paternity rights.

Cases included a mother-to-be who was dismissed from her job in a shop on the grounds that "a pregnant woman is not an attractive sight to customers". Another woman was contacted while on maternity leave and told not to return to work because "regardless of your rights, there is no job for you".

A sales assistant with seven years' service returned to her full time job after maternity leave to be told she was being put on a three day week and her pay cut by 35p an hour.

The association said: "Even when employers stop short of dismissal, women are often asked to resign or reduce their hours, and are denied time off to attend ante-natal appointments and the right to return to the same job after maternity leave."

David Harker, the association's chief executive, said there were many good ideas in the government's recent green paper on helping parents to balance work and family life. "But additional rights will be worthless to many unless the problem of enforcement is tackled and there is real, practical assistance for small employers."

He said the government should set up a fair employment commission to enforce employees' rights at work and support firms having difficulties in meeting their statutory duties. The agency should also have powers to investigate complaints, carry out random checks and impose fines.

Mr Harker said there should be a statutory right for mothers and fathers to work child-friendly hours after the birth or adoption of a child.

The association's evidence was based on analysis of 700,000 employment problems handled at bureaux in England, Wales and Northern Ireland in 1999-2000.

fields.headline: Former PC sues Met for £400,000
fields.trailText: A former police officer who claims to have suffered a breakdown within days of being sent to patrol the streets after nine years of working behind a desk is suing the Metropolitan police for £400,000.
fields.body:
A former police officer who claims to have suffered a breakdown within days of being sent to patrol the streets after nine years of working behind a desk is suing the Metropolitan police for £400,000.

Riccard Parsonson, 49, from East Ham, east London, told the high court that when told of the transferral from the work he "loved", he suffered "great anxiety" and fought against the move.

He was so anxious about the transfer from his position as community liaison officer that his doctor prescribed anti-depressants. He was moved from his post in Chadwell Heath, Essex, in January 1995, because of restructuring, and assigned to frontline traffic duties based at Euston, central London, the court heard.

Mr Parsonson, a constable with the Met for 26 years, claimed he had told superior officers he would be prepared to work as a patrol officer if he received the appropriate retraining. He had been on non-operational duties for nine years and was "rusty" in some areas.

"I could see myself becoming very ill if I was transferred. I was gradually getting worse up to the transfer date," he said. He had been on motorcycle patrol for two days when he had a "breakdown" at the scene of an accident where he was so paralysed with fear he could not get off his bike to help.

He was off work sick for eight months after the incident, returning to desk work at Westminster before being medically retired in July 1997.

He is suing the Metropolitan police over alleged negligent failure to take reasonable care of his health and well being. The force is contesting the claim. The judge is expected to give his ruling on Friday.

webTitle: New institute for excellence in social care

fields.headline: Sky-high hopes
fields.standfirst: Kendra Inman  on a new institute for excellence that aims to make research relevant to those who put it into practice
fields.trailText: Kendra Inman on a new institute for excellence that aims to make research relevant to those who put it into practice
fields.body:
Evidence-based practice may be the latest trend among policy makers in social care, but studies suggest that only one in two managers and frontline staff believes day-to-day working is informed by research findings. A survey carried out by the Centre for Evidence Based Social Services (Cebss) confirmed academics' fears: while professionals on the ground are keen to use research to improve their services, there are few opportunities to do so.

Last month, the government committed itself to raising the profile of research, promising establishment in the summer of a social care institute for excellence (Scie). Next week, in London, social care professionals will meet to discuss ways of harnessing evidence to improve life for social services clients.

The joint Guardian and National Institute for Social Work (NISW) conference, Using Knowledge to Promote Quality, will look at the future for evidence-based practice. Taken together with two other emerging bodies, the general social care council and the national care standards commission, ministers hope Scie will improve care in England and Wales, overcoming variations in standards of service provided across the country. This will be partly through the creation of a database of what works in social care, reviews of research and best practice guidance.

Scie - pronounced "sky" - may be the first central body dedicated to promoting evidence-based practice in social care, but a handful of organisations has for some time been beavering away on a similar agenda.

The south-west of England is a veritable hive of activity. Brian Sheldon, director of Cebss, and his team at the University of Exeter have held no fewer than 163 conferences on evidence-based practice. The Research in Practice initiative, based at the Dartington Social Research Unit, in Devon, but working with Sheffield University, concentrates on improving services for children and families. Also under the umbrella, a consortium of universities known as Making Research Count is working to disseminate research on children and community care. Meanwhile, NISW has formed the electronic library for social care to give professionals easy access to data already available.

Creation of Scie has been welcomed by professionals who see it as complementing work already underway. Celia Atherton, Dartington's director, wants Scie to establish a scientific method for reviewing social services research, akin to that used by the health service. "There's no need to reinvent the car, but we do need a vehicle suitable for our terrain," she says.

Scie will also need to commission research reviews and work with organisations like Dartington to ensure that research-based guidance works in practice, says Atherton. Research in Practice, like Cebss, is a partnership venture and its work is shaped by the agencies it works with. "It means we can talk to busy frontline teams about how they can best use research," Atherton says.

She also believes that Scie should work to bridge the gap between what research is carried out in the universities and what is needed on the ground - while, at the same time, involving service users in decisions about research priorities. This gap is a source of much resentment in the social care world. Sheldon pulls no punches: "From the social work perspective," he says, "a great deal of research has been commissioned for the career prospects of academics, not for the benefit of social care clients."

Academics and practitioners inhabit very different worlds, says Atherton. "Research generally talks about patterns, but social welfare staff deal with individuals. Organisations like ours help translate the research into information that can be used on the ground."

A common complaint from practitioners is that the Department of Health commissions research that takes four years to complete, is subjected to peer review and is out of date by the time it is published. "So much has a negligible impact on practice," says David Johnstone, Devon's social services director. He argues that the gap between commissioning and publication is too long, insufficient emphasis is placed on dissemination and the quality of work is highly variable.

Sheldon agrees. "The wheat to chaff ratio is worringly low," he says. Some studies involve "little more than grabbing the nearest 60 people and interviewing them with tape recorders".

Daphne Statham, NISW director, accepts that there are gaps in research. Social care is a poor relation to health in many ways and research is no exception, she says, with health spending dwarfing what is spent on social care studies. However, she argues that evidence-based practice is about more than conventional research: it should include information from service users about what works for them, as well as managers' views on what constitute successful outcomes.

Atherton wants to see more short-term research, which will produce results quicker, and far more longitudinal studies which track people over time. "If someone's looked after until they're 18, we don't know the impact of that care until they are in their 20s or are parents themselves," she says.

Academics are not solely to blame for the fact that so much research fails to trickle down to the area social services office. Universities' research is funded according to how well previous studies have been rated following peer review. A department's success in disseminating and changing practice in the secular world, say critics, has little currency when it comes to securing funds for future work.

When Cebss was established in 1997, it surveyed 2,500 staff in the south-west to discover how research was used in practice. The team uncovered numerous obstacles to effective dissemination.

"There is a wealth of material out there, but electronic access to data bases has been limited," Sheldon explains. Also, a culture of action, as opposed to contemplation, means staff are rarely given the time to consider the principles behind their decision-making. But most important of all, he says, is that inadequate social work training means social workers simply do not know how to access or interpret research. "Only a tiny proportion of our sample could identify or describe evidence for what they did," he says.

Scie is seen as following in the footsteps of Nice, its sister body in the NHS. The new institute may have an equally friendly-sounding acronym, but experts predict that some of its missives will be just as hard to digest. If Scie does its job properly, it will be telling the social care world what does not work as much as what does, says Statham.

If this is the case, will Scie's instructions meet with the same resistance that has greeted some of Nice's less palatable pronouncements? Statham is hopeful: "People find change difficult, but they will move if they think the evidence makes sense in their day-to-day work," she says. Although evidence-based practice does not provide staff with all the answers, "it will help them make more intelligent judgments and explain the decisions they've made to service users and up the line of command to the managers".

Using Knowledge to Promote Quality, sponsored by Sheridan Systems, takes place next Tuesday. For details contact Camilla Varley on 020-7713 4961.

webTitle: Stepstone expected to write off 4m euros

fields.headline: Stepstone expected to write off 4m euros
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Stepstone, the online recruitment group, is expected to write off around 4m euros (£2.5m) as part of a restructuring of its business. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Stepstone, the online recruitment group, is expected to write off around 4m euros (£2.5m) as part of a restructuring of its business.

Stepstone, which has expanded into 18 countries, yesterday said the charge would cover the closure of a number of regional offices on the continent and payments to redundant staff. One hundred employees in southern Europe have already left the business.

The group is reducing the number of telesales staff it employs and taking on more IT workers, expecting the restructuring to reduce its overall costs.

Giles Clarke, Stepstone's chief executive, denied that the reorganisation followed a downturn in the company's markets across Europe. But he did admit the group was facing cautious attitudes from European companies.

Mr Clarke said he expected to see significant growth this year, despite the economic climate and a slow start to trading in 2001.

According to the company it is restructuring because the nature of its business is changing. "We are doing a lot more web-enabled business and we are moving into software and IT which requires different sorts of people, so in some of the countries we are in we don't need the people that we have," Mr Clarke said.

The group was looking to employ 50 or 60 IT staff and did not rule out the possibility of more job losses. A company spokesperson said there had been a slowdown at the beginning of the year but it was more "sentiment" than anything else.

The company's sales for 2000 were just over €60m, nearly four times more than 1999, and revenues were up by 327% to €52.2m. Operating losses were €138.7m, compared with a loss of €24.4m in 1999, due to the group's rapid expansion throughout Europe. The company said that the online recruitment market in Europe was estimated to have reached 2% of the print classified market last year.

webTitle: BT calls off debt crisis meeting

fields.headline: BT calls off debt crisis meeting
fields.trailText: British Telecom yesterday called off a crucial meeting with key investors amid mounting speculation that its chief executive was about to resign. By David Teather and Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
British Telecom yesterday called off a crucial meeting with key investors amid mounting speculation that its chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, had caved in to shareholder pressure and was about to resign.

Sir Peter yesterday attended a marathon board meeting of the troubled telecoms company which is facing increasing pressure to find convincing solutions to reduce its £30bn of debt.

BT insiders said the meeting with investors had been postponed because the intensity of media interest had turned it into a "circus". But the cancellation prompted accusations from institutional investors that the company was out of touch with the City.

One institutional investor said: "It shows BT in its most secretive light. It really is the old way of doing business."

Speculation in the markets that Sir Peter was preparing to step down proved to be the best tonic in some time for BT shares, which rose 4.5% to 522.5p.

The meeting was the second in a planned series with investor s to sound out support for the various, narrowing, options that BT now has for reducing its debts. The agenda of options is said to have included a £5bn rights issue, the full demerger of BT Wireless or toughing out the present situation and facing a downgrade of its credit rating.

"The option is: Do you take the kind of hit from a downgrade or risk selling your assets at fire sale prices," a BT insider said.

The insider said the "temperature was getting too hot" to go ahead with the investor meeting. It was suggested that the meeting had been cancelled on the advice of BT's broker Cazenove.

Publicly, BT has stuck to the plan announced at the end of last year of floating up to 25% of BT Wireless to raise a significant chunk of the £10bn of debt it has promised to pay back this year.

webTitle: He roots in rubbish bins. And he's the real contender for scoop of the year

fields.headline: He roots in rubbish bins. And he's the real contender for scoop of the year
fields.standfirst: Benji the Binman named as source of story in the running for top press award
fields.trailText: And the winner is ... Benji the Binman? The so-called Oscars of British journalism were thrown into confusion last night after it was claimed that a News International entry was the work of notorious rubbish recycler Benjamin Pell. By Kevin Maguire.
fields.body:
And the winner is ... Benji the Binman? The so-called Oscars of British journalism were thrown into confusion last night after it was claimed that a News International entry was the work of notorious rubbish recycler Benjamin Pell.

An executive from the group told German TV that a Sunday Times story shortlisted for tonight's coveted "scoop of the year" prize was the result not of investigative journalism but a strange fellow who steals waste from addresses across London.

The newspaper's spectacular front page story last June - headlined "Secret memo says Blair is out of touch" - was the first of a series of private memos from Tony Blair's pollster Philip Gould that rocked the government when made public.

The paper's editor, John Witherow, and his senior staff have repeatedly denied that the Gould memo and several other scoops were provided by Mr Pell who makes a decent living selling documents found in bins.

But Andrew Pierce, an assistant editor on the Times, its stablemate in Wapping, east London, told the German ARD channel: "The Sunday Times, our sister paper, is up for scoop of the year because Pell provided them with leaked documents from a man called Philip Gould."

His comments in a film on the exploits of Mr Pell broadcast on ARD's Weltspiegel (World Mirror) current affairs programme at the weekend raised the intriguing thought that Mr Pell, who dresses in flat cap and overalls to collect plastic bin bags, should really be at the black tie dinner to collect the award if the Sunday Times was to win.

"Of course I should be up there tomorrow night," said Mr Pell yesterday, before fuelling the intrigue by accusing Mr Pierce of "lying" and declaring: "I swear on the Bible I was not involved with Philip Gould; I was not involved with Tony Blair."

Mr Pell, who watched a copy of the ARD film yesterday with his father, added he did not enjoy formal occasions anyway and would not be attending a Bafta ceremony despite another programme on him being shortlisted.

A Downing Street inquiry is understood to have concluded that a string of private memos, including the Gould note shortlisted for an award under the name of the Sunday Times Insight investigative team, had indeed been recovered from refuse sacks rather than leaked by a mole.

Mr Gould yesterday declined to be drawn into the latest row. "I'm not commenting on it in any way," he said. "I must say, what a business!"

Nor would Philippa Kennedy, editor of the Press Gazette and organiser of tonight's British Press Awards at the Hilton hotel in Park Lane, London - though a colleague speculated that she probably hoped another entry would win to avoid controversy.

"Journalists get their information from a variety of sources and let's hope that they came to an honourable arrangement if it was Mr Pell," said Ms Kennedy.

Mr Witherow was unavailable for comment but Richard Caseby, the paper's managing editor, said: "Absolutely, totally false. It is not true that Benjamin Pell provided any document in relation to that article."

The Gould memo shortlisted for an award appeared on June 11 2000 and was the pollster's candid advance assessment of a speech that was to prove a disaster when delivered to a national gathering of the Woman's Institute - Mr Blair was subjected to the indignity of slow handclapping.

The four-page note disclosed that Labour focus groups found voters viewed the prime minister as "out of touch" as Mr Gould predicted the speech would backfire because it was "condescending" and made the PM "look rather sad".

Two weeks earlier, the same paper had revealed another Gould memo in which he had warned that Labour had lost much of the political centre ground, with many voters believing that the Tory leader, William Hague, was "speaking for the mainstream majority".The paper later published a third memo.

Documentary evidence exists of a financial relationship between the Sunday Times and Mr Pell in the form of a News International invoice dated June 18 1999, authorising payment of £3,375 for three stories on Jonathan Aitken, James Hewitt and Hackney in east London.

Leaked Gould memos also started appearing last July in two other News International papers, the Sun and the Times. Those in the Times were written by Mr Pierce. The Sun and the Times published identical memos on the same day in a co-ordinated operation and it emerged that Max Clifford, the PR guru who has advised Mr Pell, played a role.

Mr Clifford was aware in advance that plans by the two papers to publish one particular set of memos had to be postponed 24 hours after Concorde crashed in France, dominating the news.

The Guardian, in common with many other newspapers, has used documents in the past retrieved by Mr Pell but has never paid him.

Mr Pierce, who probably never expected the programme to be watched in Britain said: "What I should have said was that Benjamin Pell suggests that he was behind it, but I have absolutely no idea where the Sunday Times got its scoop from."

Benjamin Pell

Benji the Binman is a professional muckraker, raiding the bins of prominent people and their advisers to sell any private papers he unearths to national newspapers.

His victims range from Elton John and the Queen Mother to the pop group All Saints, the lottery company Camelot and politicians such as Philip Gould.

He boasts of being behind 25 big stories in the past two years and of making the careers of a string of well-known journalists.

"We all know that I'm not public enemy number one," said Mr Pell yesterday. "We all know I'm the best thing that's happened to Fleet Street for the last 150 years, the last 200 years."

Mr Pell, 36, who has been diagnosed as suffering from an obsessive-compulsive disorder, has enjoyed a lucrative relationship with the Sunday Times and one invoice shows he was paid £3,375 in a single month, though in an angry scrawled note the binman says he was promised £6,000.

John Witherow

The editor of the Sunday Times has a reputation for enjoying the chauffeur-driven car, generous expense account and a hefty salary, but he is happy to leave dealing with Mr Pell and the newspaper's other sources to trusted lieutenants.

"Witherow, in common with virtually every other editor, does not get his hands dirty," said a Sunday Times journalist. "If he trusts you, he is good to work for."

The key is "deniability" so the editor, not knowing which confidential source has been used, never has to lie to conceal identities.

There is a certain tabloid swagger about Mr Witherow, 49, who threatens to "turn over" those who cross him.

He has been editor of the Sunday Times since replacing Andrew Neil in 1994 and is thought to have his eye on Peter Stothard's chair at the Times.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst:
He is an expert on advertising in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the past 10 years. Every Wednesday morning Stefano Hatfield, now based in New York heading up Ad Age Global, will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue.
This week, he investigates Interpublic's purchase of True North and why size matters in adland
fields.trailText: March 21 There's no real surprise about Interpublic buying True North, other than perhaps the price, writes Stefano Hatfield.
fields.body:
There's no real surprise about Interpublic buying True North, other than perhaps the price. It had always seemed a more likely suitor than Havas, its chief rival. What's more, in the current warped fin de siecle value system, $2.1bn for a upper middle-ranked global network group doesn't seem too bad a price for Interpublic's new CEO John Dooner to pay.

US analysts suggested just that in a remarkably tame conference call on Monday morning held to explain the move. The all-stock deal to acquire brands like FCB, Marketing Drive, BSMG and Bozell seems better value for the buyer than similar amounts paid by Havas for a highly-priced Snyder Communications, and WPP for a badly-holed Young & Rubicam. It certainly appears better relative value than the $265m Dooner paid for Deutsch in December.

Some senior industry figures contend that the analysts do not fully understand the sector. Most notably, there continues to be an obsession with the higher profile advertising agency components of the groups. Advertising now accounts for only 44% of Omnicom's revenues for example. And, it is the non-advertising services that traditionally do better during the kind of downturn in which the US advertising industry is currently mired.

So, it's interesting to note that although the deal propels Interpublic ahead of Omnicom and WPP to the number one slot, it actually increases the group's share of revenues from traditional advertising, and puts yet more of its focus on the ailing US market. What's more, it still doesn't resolve the thorny issue of the group's media buying operations.

Crucially, Interpublic can point to an expected $25m of cost savings. And, it is the apparent relative ease with which it will be able to digest True North which held sway over an ostensibly higher offer from Havas. The True North CEO, David Bell, and FCB's Brendan Ryan are certainly on board and making positive nosies, which is good. It also helps that Interpublic looks more likely to be in a position to buy back shares if need be than Havas.

If all of this appears far removed from the craft of creating marketing messages, then it both is, and is not. Ever more global clients are demanding ever more geographical and multi-disciplinary resources of their suppliers. Funding extensive media research or loss-making offices in China are both expensive. The horrible "synergies" that come with being part of a larger group really do help here.

True North has needed to do something to compete in the global premier league, ever since its partnership with the French group Publicis (still a shareholder, and one that would not be happy to sell to Havas) fell apart. Last November's loss of the giant Chrysler business to Omnicom's BBDO only accelerated the inevitable.

There really is a big three now, and the rest of the industry will be playing catch-up. As the giant groups consolidate, it gets ever harder to separate out being bigger from being better, certainly in media buying, research and internet services. That is, unless you are a client that is simply looking for some talent to create great advertising. The truth is, advertising today is much more about Wall Street than Soho. And this deal will keep Wall Street happy.

fields.headline: Advertising watchdogs savage internet firms
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Freeserve and NTL have had their knuckles rapped by the Advertising Standards Authority, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Freeserve and NTL have had their knuckles rapped by the Advertising Standards Authority over false claims in their advertising.

In an advertising campaign for Freeserve HomeTime, the internet service provider promised there would be "No charges until March 2001".

Only in the small print were consumers informed they would face a monthly charge from BT for the service.

The ASA ruled the advert was misleading and advised Freeserve to consult its copy advice team before advertising similar offers in future.

The watchdog also upheld a complaint from BT against cable company NTL over a direct mailing for a digital TV and telephone package. The mailing compared BT's offering unfavourably with its own.

The ASA agreed with BT's complaint that NTL's claim to offer "Free local talk time to other NTL phone users" was misleading because customers paid a 3.5p connection charge for all calls.

The watchdog also ruled the comparison with BT was unfair because NTL had compared its direct debit only package with a package from BT that allowed customers to pay however they wanted.

fields.headline: Sleaze Nation launches aspirational music title
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Swinstead Publishing is to turn its Xfm magazine into a quarterly music lifestyle publication, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The publisher behind lifestyle and clubbing titles Sleaze Nation and Jockey Slut is to publish X-Ray - a magazine for radio station Xfm - as a standalone magazine from April.

Six issues of X-Ray have already been published as fanzine pull-out in Sleaze Nation.

But Swinstead Publishing is to turn X-Ray into a quarterly music lifestyle publication.

"X-Ray is the result of the natural evolution in the magazine market that has caused the demise of Select, Melody Maker and Touch," said chairman John Swinstead.

"X-Ray will reshape this market to reflect readers' demands for a more clued-up and aspirational approach to editorial, design and photography."

From April, X-Ray will go out to a controlled circulation of around 195,000 in London.

The magazine will be produced by the existing Jockey Slut and Sleaze Nation editorial teams.

fields.headline: Hewlett-Packard launches global campaign
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Hewlett-Packard is launching a major advertising campaign to change its public image. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Hewlett-Packard is launching a major advertising campaign under the tagline "Invent" in an attempt to change the public perception of the company as a computer firm.

The global campaign uses members of HP's staff explaining what they do to present the company as innovative and high-tech.

One commercial features Rycharde Hawkes, an engineer in HP's research laboratory, who has developed technology that sends people a Wap phone alert as their bus approaches.

Another shows Eugenie Prime, who is working on a system that will make it easier to search the internet.

"We are looking at a broad target, from anyone who owns a printer or a PC to high-level business clients," said Julia Mee, brand advertising manager for HP.

"In the past, the brand has been seen as old and a little stuffy. This is about introducing some humour and trying to become more modern."

The new advertising follows on from a commercial aired last year in which HP chief executive Carly Fiorina went before the cameras to announce the company was reinventing itself.

The adverts break in the UK on March 23 and will get their first airing on Channel 4 during Friends, Frasier and So Graham Norton.

They were created by HP's US agency, Goodby Silverstein & Partners. Media planning and buying were by Optimedia.

fields.headline: Docs hit out at Peak Practice
fields.trailText: 8.30am: GPs want Peak Practice and 'other such drivel' axed because they do not reflect the hardships of surgery life, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
GPs want rural medical drama Peak Practice and "other such drivel" axed from TV because they do not reflect the hardships of life in the surgery.

A survey of nearly 4,000 GPs found the portrayal of GPs' workloads in TV dramas raised patients' expectations to unrealistic levels.

They said programmes such as Peak Practice led patients to believe doctors have unlimited time for consultations and home or hospital visits.

The survey, for trade magazine GP, found 60% of the 3,761 doctors who responded believed the growing number of medical shows on TV led to patients being misinformed about their work.

Dr John Grenville, a GP who has in the past allowed Peak Practice scenes to be shot in his Derby surgery, said it raised more unrealistic expectations than other medical dramas.

"The GPs seem to only have two or three patients on their lists, or three on a busy day, are always available and never need to see their families," Dr Grenville told GP.

Dr Tim Parkin, medical adviser to Peak Practice, accepted the show contained unrealistic elements.

But he said he believed most viewers could distinguish between fantasy and reality and claimed the programme helped some patients received the correct treatment.

"We have had letters from viewers saying my doctor was struggling to diagnose me until I saw last night's show."

Dr Adrian Noon, medical adviser to BBC1 daytime soap Doctors, the newest of the medical drama shows, said BBC research showed most GPs thought it accurately reflected their work.

"We bring actors out to my practice so they can see how we work. We try to focus more on the medicine and less on the doctors' relationships to reflect the pressures they're under."

fields.headline: Express signs key paparazzo for £1m
fields.trailText: The Express's new chief, Richard Desmond, sent tabloid picture desks reeling yesterday with the announcement that their biggest source of celebrity snaps is to work exclusively for Express newspapers and OK! magazine in a £1m deal.
fields.body:
The Express's new chief, Richard Desmond, sent tabloid picture desks reeling yesterday with the announcement that their biggest source of celebrity snaps is to work exclusively for Express newspapers and OK! magazine in a £1m deal.

The signing of Jason Fraser, who brokered the first pictures of the relationship between Princess Diana and Dodi Fayed, is a blow to rivals for whom his work is staple fare.

Previously, the Express has trailed behind the leading tabloids such as the Sun, Mirror and Mail in the chequebook battles for Fraser's pictures.

Fraser, 34, joins the Express as executive director, with responsibility for bringing in exclusive celebrity pictures to the Daily and Sunday Express, Star and OK! magazine. He will sit on the board of Northern & Shell, putting him above the papers' editors.

The signing by Mr Desmond, just days after he announced plans to shed 145 editorial staff at the Express, is a clear indication that he wants to drive costs down in order to recruit a small number of key, expensive talents.

Fraser's deal is understood to be worth at least £1m, to compensate him for loss of earnings from other newspapers. In addition, he will retain the secondary rights to his pictures.

webTitle: Field trip pupils 'led into rail peril'

fields.headline: Field trip pupils 'led into rail peril'
fields.standfirst: Train driver tells court of school group on track
fields.trailText: A teacher and school governor risked the lives of pupils, railway staff and passengers by leading a group of children on a field trip over a railway line and into the path of an oncoming train, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A teacher and school governor risked the lives of pupils, railway staff and passengers by leading a group of children on a field trip over a railway line and into the path of an oncoming train, a court heard yesterday.

The driver of the passenger train sounded his horn and had to pull on the emergency brakes after he spotted a group of children and two adults on the track just 150 yards ahead, Preston crown court was told.

The pupils, accompanied by teacher Melanie Rankin and parent governor Philip Ramsden, were from Fairway primary school in Stockport, Greater Manchester. No one was injured during the incident.

The 13 children - all aged 11 at the time - were led across the railway track near Grange over Sands, Cumbria, in June 1999, the court heard

Rankin, 26, and Ramsden, 41, deny endangering the safety of the pupils in their care and people on the train by trespassing on the line. They also deny obstructing the train.

Headteacher Lynn Boyle, 42, denies two charges of aiding and abetting the endangerment and obstruction by ap proving the route of the field trip. Paul Dockery, prosecuting, told the jury that all three defendants thought the route over the railway line was an approved route.

He said that by trespassing they had risked the safety of themselves and the people on the train.

"By their presence on the railway track they not only endangered the safety of those on the train, but also themselves ... particularly when they had not even looked at the train timetable."

The group was on a trip to study the estuary of the River Winster when they walked up a flight of steps and along the railway track to reach a second set of steps leading down to the estuary on the other side.

Mr Dockery told the court that on the return journey from the estuary the group heard a train approaching.

He said Rankin, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, told the children to line up or sit on the sea wall next to the track because she did not know how far away the steps on the other side were.

Mr Dockery continued: "The driver saw a group of school children walking in the same direction that the train was going. To the driver's eye he saw the gang as walking between the rails but as far as the prosecution are concerned whether some of the gang were between the rails or on the side of the rails matters not".

The driver, he said, "saw them ahead of him, he estimated 150 yards. What he did was apply the emergency brakes and sound his horn and attempt to bring the train to a halt but he did not bring the train to a halt, it stopped beyond the group."

The case continues.

 A nine-year-old girl on a school sailing trip drowned beneath a capsized boat after her teacher failed to realise she was missing, according to an official accident report yesterday.

Elizabeth Bee was one of nine pupils from Boundary Oak independent school in Fareham, Hampshire, thrown from their craft with their teacher, Paul Dove, into Portsmouth harbour amid strong winds in September 1999.

Mr Dove, 64, failed to count his pupils after the incident and it was at least nine minutes later that Elizabeth's twin sister, Victoria, noticed her absence, the report by the marine accident investigation branch found.

Investigators criticised the school for failing to carry out professional safety checks on the "grossly overloaded" 14ft dory.

The crown prosecution service decided last year not to act against Boundary Oak or Mr Dove, but Elizabeth's mother, Lesley Bee, yesterday said she planned to take legal action against the school. The school said all sailing activities had been suspended after the accident and permanently discontinued last year.

The driver of the passenger train sounded his horn and had to pull on the emergency brakes after he spotted a group of children and two adults on the track just 150 yards ahead, Preston crown court was told. The pupils, accompanied by teacher Melanie Rankin and parent governor Philip Ramsden, were from Fairway primary school in Stockport, Greater Manchester. No one was injured during the incident. The 13 children - all aged 11 at the time - were led across the railway track near Grange over Sands, Cumbria, in June 1999, the court heard Rankin, 26, and Ramsden, 41, deny endangering the safety of the pupils in their care and people on the train by trespassing on the line. They also deny obstructing the train. Headteacher Lynn Boyle, 42, denies two charges of aiding and abetting the endangerment and obstruction by ap proving the route of the field trip. Paul Dockery, prosecuting, told the jury that all three defendants thought the route over the railway line was an approved route. He said that by trespassing they had risked the safety of themselves and the people on the train. "By their presence on the railway track they not only endangered the safety of those on the train, but also themselves ... particularly when they had not even looked at the train timetable." The group was on a trip to study the estuary of the River Winster when they walked up a flight of steps and along the railway track to reach a second set of steps leading down to the estuary on the other side. Mr Dockery told the court that on the return journey from the estuary the group heard a train approaching. He said Rankin, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, told the children to line up or sit on the sea wall next to the track because she did not know how far away the steps on the other side were. Mr Dockery continued: "The driver saw a group of school children walking in the same direction that the train was going. To the driver's eye he saw the gang as walking between the rails but as far as the prosecution are concerned whether some of the gang were between the rails or on the side of the rails matters not". The driver, he said, "saw them ahead of him, he estimated 150 yards. What he did was apply the emergency brakes and sound his horn and attempt to bring the train to a halt but he did not bring the train to a halt, it stopped beyond the group." webTitle: Best companies to be freed from arts funds fight

fields.headline: Best companies to be freed from arts funds fight
fields.trailText: The government is proposing a super-league of arts companies which will be guaranteed six years funding from the Arts Council
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The government is proposing a super-league of arts companies which will be guaranteed six years funding from the Arts Council and then left to get on with the job with minimal interference.

The beneficiaries could include some of the leading national theatre, opera and ballet companies. They would escape the annual competition for Arts Council grants, and instead be guaranteed funding to plan ahead, to experiment, and take risks.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said the only criteria would be creativity and excellence.

The idea is a central plank of the green paper, Culture and Creativity: the next 10 years, which was launched yesterday.

It arose out of discussions with the veteran theatre director Peter Brook, who 30 years ago left England for the tattered charms of a semi-derelict theatre in Paris, the Bouffes du Nord. Mr Smith said he asked what had driven him away. He replied: under-funding and excessive bureaucracy.

"At this stage I think he is probably not likely to abandon Paris and return," Mr Smith said, "but I do think we can create a much more welcoming atmosphere in which excellence and creativity can flourish."

The super-league proposal was promptly welcomed by the Royal Shakespeare Company, which would be a prime candidate. The company is on a roll at the moment, with ac claimed new productions of Shakespeare's histories, and a national tour of the 10-hour epic Tantalus co-production with Sir Peter Hall.

A spokesman said: "We're now looking five to seven years ahead so working with the government on the same timescale could give us enormous freedom - the chance to develop effective partnerships with education, business and other artists."

The green paper, agreed across departments, contains policies to encourage individual creativity in every age group. These begin in the cradle, with Books for Babies, a lottery funded pack to be given to every baby by health visitors, containing books, a library card, and an invitation to free story telling events in local libraries. All children should have a guaranteed right to learn a musical instrument, and creative partnerships would bring performing artists into schools and guarantee school visits to plays and concerts.

The green paper contains the bald statement: "All national museums and galleries must be free to everybody." Some museums, including the Imperial War Museum and the Natural History Museum, are known to be reluctant to abandon charging, and take up the VAT concession offered in the budget in return to free admission. Yesterday Mr Smith said he was convinced they would be persuaded.

 Mr Smith announced last night that he had reappointed Gerry Robinson for a further three year term as chairman of the Arts Council.

webTitle: Error cost lives of teenage stowaways

fields.headline: Error that cost the lives of teenage Cuban stowaways
fields.standfirst:
Bid to reach US led to freezing death on flight to Gatwick
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Bid to reach US led to freezing death on flight to Gatwick
fields.body:
The two boys had taken advantage of the darkness, the heavy rain and the long grass so that they could stow away in the wheel arch of a flight out of Havana which they hoped would bring them a new life.

As they eased their way into the 6ft by 8ft wheel compartment they could not have known that their desperate airport run had led them to the wrong aeroplane.

Instead of hiding on a flight to Miami, Alberto Rodriguez, 15, and Maikel Almira, 16, mistakenly sneaked on to a British Airways flight to London's Gatwick airport which had been delayed. Instead of a relatively short, low-altitude trip which they had a chance of surviving, the pair were starved of oxygen as the Boeing 777 went to 37,000ft in temperatures of -57C.

At an inquest at Haywards Heath, West Sussex, yesterday, a pathologist said that the boys, who had been to cadet school in Cuba together, had probably died of hypoxia just 20 minutes after take-off from Havana's Jose Martin airport. Colin Hunter-Craig said: "It was like shooting up from sea level to more than the height of Everest in just a few minutes."

The boys' desperate attempt to flee their home was not discovered until Alberto's body fell on to the runway at Gatwick airport and Maikel's tumbled on to a field in Surrey.

The news of their terrible deaths provoked Cuba's president, Fidel Castro, to attack US immigration policies, saying the boys were "victims of murderous law, victims of deceits and illusions" in reference to the 1966 US Adjustment Act, which offers preferential treatment to Cubans seeking asylum in the US. More than 1m Cubans joined in a march past the US diplomatic mission.

The boys - friends for just two months - had mentioned nothing of their plans to their parents. They sneaked away in darkness late on December 23 last year. Police officers from the UK who travelled to Havana to investigate their deaths believe the pair had planned to go to Miami where Alberto's grandfather now lives.

A third friend, Yassel Diaz, had agreed to go with them but did not manage to climb aboard the plane. When interviewed he said the whole idea had been that of Alberto, who drew a plan of the aircraft in their classroom on the morning of December 23. He explained where they were to hide, and how they were to climb on to the plane as it was turning on the nose wheel. The diagram was left in the notebook of a sick friend as well as farewell notes.

Maikel also left a letter which was found by his mother, Gicela Almira. In it he said he intended to go to America to find work. The letter told her not to worry and he apologised for missing his sister's impending 15th birthday celebrations.

Mrs Almira said that her son was easily influenced. She said: "He knew nothing about planes and he never said in the letter how he intended to get to the US."

Alberto's mother, Orieta Santos, reported her son missing on Christmas Eve. She later told police that her son was probably trying to reach her father who lives in Miami. Staff at Jose Martin international airport told how British Airways flight BA4504 to London Gatwick was pushed back as normal shortly after midnight on December 24.

First officer Roger Barnes carried out a routine visual check of the plane before take off. The co-pilot, Colin Valis, then taxied to the runway holding point before finally taking off without incident after a short delay.

He admitted someone could have climbed into the wheel bay, using suspension rods for grip, but said nothing of that sort had been reported to him.

It was not until three hours into the flight that a male passenger sitting by a window told stewardess Beth Hammond that he had seen someone running alongside the plane as it lifted off - police now believe this was Yassel's failed attempt to get into the wheel bay.

Ms Hammond told the court: "I thought when he told me that whoever it was must have been a good runner. I reported it."

The plane landed as normal. But at 4.45pm on Christmas Eve, Stuart Parker discovered a body in a field at Oakwood Hill in Surrey, five miles from the airport on the flightpath.

He told the court he had been hunting rabbits in an 80-acre field. "My dog chased after a fox but then stopped. I shone my light and saw something reflect. It was a white trainer. I looked again and saw a body."

At 9am the following day, the same BA jet took off from Gatwick bound for Cancun in Mexico. As it took off, crew on board a jet on the ground saw something fall from the plane.

Emergency checks were carried out before the captain of the Boeing received a private satellite telephone call to say the object was a body. As the plane was not damaged, it continued to Mexico.

Simon Morgan, first officer of flight BA4503 to Cancun, told the court: "We went through the checks but nothing was wrong. We knew the plane had come in from Cuba and when we heard it was a body we put two and two together."

Police checked the plane's wheel bay for fingerprints but found nothing. Detective Sergeant Mick Jones said there was only one place someone could sit without being crushed by the huge wheels, and only one source of heat, a hot air pipe.

But, he added, nothing could save anyone in the wheel bay as the temperature dropped to -57F.

After the coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, Det Sgt Jones said: "It is a tragic waste of young life and it is something that should never, ever be attempted."

fields.headline: Just what is a 'key worker'?
fields.standfirst: The government must provide affordable housing for all members of the public services team
fields.trailText: Comment: If government doesn't value all members of the public services team then those services won't be there when you turn up to use them, says Geoff Martin.
fields.body:
They're all at it. No matter where you look, you'll find a politician from some point on the spectrum banging on about the need to do something to provide "affordable housing" for "key workers" in "property hotspots". There's no shortage of elected representatives happy to talk the talk on the staffing crisis in the public services but how many are seriously prepared to walk the walk?

First off, let's have a look at the coded language.

Just what is it that constitutes "affordable housing"? When I was a councillor back in the mid-eighties, we still had a housing committee and we still talked about council housing. However, the Thatcher government stopped us from building any new units, forced us to flog off the best stock, locked all our capital receipts away in the vaults of the local Nat West bank and banned us from touching it.

We were reduced to a few nomination rights for housing association stock and had little choice but to introduce punitive points systems for the dwindling pool of accommodation at our disposal. Way back then, we housed thousands of public sector staff in council properties at reasonable cost. You won't find many people talking about council houses now, just a few of us old Labour dinosaurs. Now it's called social or affordable housing and getting access to it is a damn site harder than breaking out of the Big Brother compound.

Parallel to the assault on council housing stock came the search and destroy policy on directly-provided NHS accommodation. While yuppie estate agents queued round the block to plunder the health service's housing assets, the trade unions warned there would be a long-term price to pay. Perhaps one or two of those estate agents have felt a pang of guilt when the heart attack has kicked in and there are no specialist nurses at the local coronary care unit. Call me a vindictive bastard, but I'd like to think so.

And what defines a "key worker"? We know some politicians mean the police, nurses, possibly teachers and, on a good day, maybe even social workers. However, few, if any, would include heath care assistants, support workers, cleaners and the rest of the hidden staff who play a crucial role in the social care team and who really make the services tick.

This divisive approach is nothing new but the long-term implications are horrendous. Various odds and sods of bonuses and special housing deals have been handed out to small groups of staff in the public eye to give the impression that they're tackling the issue. Meanwhile, thousands of the other key staff who count just as much are buggering off to work at Tesco's, where they'll get better pay and flexible working conditions and more respect. I don't blame them at all.

And finally, "housing hot spots". As a London trade unionist, I can understand why some of my colleagues from other areas in the UK give me a jaundiced look when I tell them how tough things are in the capital. But it's a fact that nowhere is the gap between the haves and have-nots wider than in areas such as the East End. But there are plenty of other inner cities - Manchester, Leeds and Bristol to name just three - where they are catching up fast.

Politicians will pay lip service to these issues all the time they can get away with it. Our job is to confront the public with some hard truths, and the hardest truth of all is that if government doesn't start making some concrete moves to value and respect all members of the public services team then those services just won't be there when you turn up to use them. So how do we get that up the political agenda in time for the general election? I'm open to suggestions.
