webTitle: George Monbiot: Damaged by the evils of the market

fields.headline: Damaged by the evils of the market
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's campaign to revive public services is backed by George Monbiot
fields.trailText: The Guardian's campaign to revive public services is backed by George Monbiot
fields.body:
All too often the education process is entrusted to people who appear to have no understanding of industry and the path of progress," the European Roundtable of Industrialists complained in 1998. "The provision of education is a market opportunity and should be treated as such."

Companies have not been slow to respond. Some have donated free exercise books to British schools. Interleaved with the blank pages are such salutary exhortations as "Stand up for your beliefs and values; take responsibility for your own actions; [get] spot protection by simply washing daily [with] Clearasil". Others have handed out teaching materials. A pack about "puberty and menstrual health", kindly provided by Tampax, warns girls that sanitary pads are uncomfortable, unhygienic and environmentally damaging; Tampax tampons, by contrast, are good for you and good for the planet.

A school newspaper partly sponsored by Nestlé published a page of children's poems and stories about Nestlé products, such as "Nestlé chocolate is the best/ Eat it for a hairy chest..." A teaching pack from Coca-Cola instructs pupils that non-refillable bottles are more environmentally-friendly than returnable ones.

But the sponsorship of teaching materials is the least of the market opportunities education now provides. The government's education action zones are clusters of schools run by committees on which businesses must be represented. Last year the government launched a network of "city academies": urban secondary schools partly run by the private sector. Next month schools in Leeds will be outsourced to a "joint venture company".

The market, the champions of privatisation argue, is keener and leaner than the public sector. With a vested interest in cost-effectiveness, companies are more efficient than the bureaucracies handling other people's money. The opponents of commercialisation argue that market efficiency and social efficiency are very different matters. Company directors have a "fiduciary duty" towards their shareholders: they are legally obliged to put their interests first, even if these clash with the interests of society.

Some parents fear, for example, that companies running schools will seek to exclude failing pupils in order to improve their ratings, and hence their market value. The firms involved in education action zones are likely to be more interested in training a pliable corporate workforce than turning out well-rounded citizens.

This is not to say that public and private interests are always in conflict. Few would argue, for example, that telecoms worked better when they were controlled by the state. The government nationalised the railways in 1948 partly to avoid paying the compensation necessary for reinvestment after the war. They have been run down ever since. But reprivatisation in 1996 merely compounded the damage, as the operating companies were also relieved of the responsibility to invest.

The problem is that market values are now intruding into almost every aspect of public life, whether or not they are appropriate. When aristocrats enjoyed inordinate power in Britain, they insisted that they were the only ones who had the expertise needed to run the country. Today business people make the same claim, and governments seem prepared to believe them. There are two principal means by which the market is coming to run the country.

The first is the establishment of quasi-corporate systems in public services. Management structures and pay scales mimic those of the private sector. Public provision is tested according to "best value" criteria. If it's found wanting, it's sub-contracted to the private sector. New ac counting procedures, such as "capitation" in the NHS and "producer choice" in the BBC, enable public services to become interchangeable with private ones.

Interestingly, many of the new accounting methods would never be tolerated in a real corporation, as staff who should be saving lives or making programmes are instead buried in paperwork.

But the most effective means of subjecting public services to the rigours of the market is to privatise them. The "private finance initiative" was described by one of its architects as "the Heineken of privatisation - taking the private sector to the parts of the government machine not reached by previous privatisations". Though most of us have yet to notice, corporations are gradually taking over almost every public service in Britain. The government claims that by attracting private money it can start building more hospitals, schools, prisons, roads and underground stations than it could have funded by itself.

The first problem is that the private sector will only invest in schemes which make money. It's not interested, for example, in renovating hospitals, as the budgets are too small to be worth pursuing. It's more interested in knocking them down, selling off the valuable city centre land they sat on, then rebuilding new facilities on greenfield sites, for which they can charge big rents. So the NHS has redesigned its modernisation programme to attract private money.

The £30m scheme to renovate Coventry's two hospitals, for example, was transformed into a £174m plan to knock them both down and build a new one. Instead of paying £30m once, the NHS will now have to pay the private contractors £36m a year for the next 25 years. This money has to come from somewhere: the NHS will have to cut the number of beds in Coventry by 25%, and the number of doctors and nurses by 20%

Even when private companies offer the same services as the public sector was providing, it's not clear that the savings they make could really be regarded as "efficiencies". As Richard Tilt, director general of the prison service, remarked in 1996, "the great majority of the cost reduction comes from the payment of much lower wages and poorer conditions of service for staff working in the private sector". What this means is more prison riots, less rehabilitation and more crime when the inmates are released. The costs the service would have carried, in other words, are dumped instead on to society.

The aristocrats who once ran Britain failed to distinguish between their interests and those of the country as a whole. Today, our business leaders appear similarly confused. The market and the public sector can live together only when the interests of business are subordinated to the interests of society.

George Monbiot is the author of Captive State: the corporate takeover of Britain

Interleaved with the blank pages are such salutary exhortations as "Stand up for your beliefs and values; take responsibility for your own actions; [get] spot protection by simply washing daily [with] Clearasil". Others have handed out teaching materials. A pack about "puberty and menstrual health", kindly provided by Tampax, warns girls that sanitary pads are uncomfortable, unhygienic and environmentally damaging; Tampax tampons, by contrast, are good for you and good for the planet. A school newspaper partly sponsored by Nestlé published a page of children's poems and stories about Nestlé products, such as "Nestlé chocolate is the best/ Eat it for a hairy chest..." A teaching pack from Coca-Cola instructs pupils that non-refillable bottles are more environmentally-friendly than returnable ones. But the sponsorship of teaching materials is the least of the market opportunities education now provides. The government's education action zones are clusters of schools run by committees on which businesses must be represented. Last year the government launched a network of "city academies": urban secondary schools partly run by the private sector. Next month schools in Leeds will be outsourced to a "joint venture company". The market, the champions of privatisation argue, is keener and leaner than the public sector. With a vested interest in cost-effectiveness, companies are more efficient than the bureaucracies handling other people's money. The opponents of commercialisation argue that market efficiency and social efficiency are very different matters. Company directors have a "fiduciary duty" towards their shareholders: they are legally obliged to put their interests first, even if these clash with the interests of society. Some parents fear, for example, that companies running schools will seek to exclude failing pupils in order to improve their ratings, and hence their market value. The firms involved in education action zones are likely to be more interested in training a pliable corporate workforce than turning out well-rounded citizens. This is not to say that public and private interests are always in conflict. Few would argue, for example, that telecoms worked better when they were controlled by the state. The government nationalised the railways in 1948 partly to avoid paying the compensation necessary for reinvestment after the war. They have been run down ever since. But reprivatisation in 1996 merely compounded the damage, as the operating companies were also relieved of the responsibility to invest. The problem is that market values are now intruding into almost every aspect of public life, whether or not they are appropriate. When aristocrats enjoyed inordinate power in Britain, they insisted that they were the only ones who had the expertise needed to run the country. Today business people make the same claim, and governments seem prepared to believe them. There are two principal means by which the market is coming to run the country. The first is the establishment of quasi-corporate systems in public services. Management structures and pay scales mimic those of the private sector. Public provision is tested according to "best value" criteria. If it's found wanting, it's sub-contracted to the private sector. New ac counting procedures, such as "capitation" in the NHS and "producer choice" in the BBC, enable public services to become interchangeable with private ones. Interestingly, many of the new accounting methods would never be tolerated in a real corporation, as staff who should be saving lives or making programmes are instead buried in paperwork. But the most effective means of subjecting public services to the rigours of the market is to privatise them. The "private finance initiative" was described by one of its architects as "the Heineken of privatisation - taking the private sector to the parts of the government machine not reached by previous privatisations". Though most of us have yet to notice, corporations are gradually taking over almost every public service in Britain. The government claims that by attracting private money it can start building more hospitals, schools, prisons, roads and underground stations than it could have funded by itself. The first problem is that the private sector will only invest in schemes which make money. It's not interested, for example, in renovating hospitals, as the budgets are too small to be worth pursuing. It's more interested in knocking them down, selling off the valuable city centre land they sat on, then rebuilding new facilities on greenfield sites, for which they can charge big rents. So the NHS has redesigned its modernisation programme to attract private money. The £30m scheme to renovate Coventry's two hospitals, for example, was transformed into a £174m plan to knock them both down and build a new one. Instead of paying £30m once, the NHS will now have to pay the private contractors £36m a year for the next 25 years. This money has to come from somewhere: the NHS will have to cut the number of beds in Coventry by 25%, and the number of doctors and nurses by 20% Even when private companies offer the same services as the public sector was providing, it's not clear that the savings they make could really be regarded as "efficiencies". As Richard Tilt, director general of the prison service, remarked in 1996, "the great majority of the cost reduction comes from the payment of much lower wages and poorer conditions of service for staff working in the private sector". What this means is more prison riots, less rehabilitation and more crime when the inmates are released. The costs the service would have carried, in other words, are dumped instead on to society. The aristocrats who once ran Britain failed to distinguish between their interests and those of the country as a whole. Today, our business leaders appear similarly confused. The market and the public sector can live together only when the interests of business are subordinated to the interests of society. George Monbiot is the author of Captive State: the corporate takeover of Britain

webTitle: Open for business, but beware of the pigs

fields.headline: Open for business, but beware of the pigs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the commanding figure now in charge of the war against foot and mouth, reported to the Commons yesterday about government help for the rural economy.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the commanding figure now in charge of the war against foot and mouth, reported to the Commons yesterday about government help for the rural economy.

Quite right too. Mr Meacher has so many homes around the country that just by shifting a bit of furniture he can do more to spread foot and mouth than half a dozen race meetings.

I have to say though that, if I were a farmer, I would not be opening the champagne or sinking to my knees in gratitude at what the minister and his rural taskforce have decided to do.

Some of it might be useful, I suppose. There will, he told us, be temporary reductions in rateable value, mandatory relief for pubs and garages whose present rateable value is less than £9,000, provided they are the only one in the village, and a brand new public information hotline to tell us which pottery barn, village fete and bouncy castle it is currently safe to visit. Ms Kali Mountford was particularly concerned about hang gliders. We were relieved to hear that there is a number they can ring too.

Several attractions will be reopened to bring visitors into the countryside, provided hikers prepare to flee if they spot a pig. (You're welcome to walk anywhere, we learned, except near an animal. If you see a cow, you will be asked to kill it, with your bare hands if necessary. Then take it home in the boot and bury it.)

Inland revenue and customs officers will be instructed, Mr Meacher said, to take a "sympathetic approach" to farmers in trouble. He also claimed that the big banks plan to do the same, which will be a first for them.

I have to say it all sounded a bit wishy-washy. My mind wandered as his voice droned onwards, intelligent, articulate, yet curiously dull and bucolic, like an Oxford don with a straw in his mouth. I reflected idly that the people of the 14th century should have been pleased that Mr Meacher wasn't in charge of combatting the Black Death.

"I am happy to inform the house that the tumbril tax will be temporarily halved from one groat, or alternatively an impost of all corn milled between Lammas and Michaelmas, enabling speedy disposal of human carcasses in the present distressing circumstances.

"A special town criers' hotline, Cadavers Direct, will be established. Specially trained teams of town criers will tour affected areas shouting 'Oyez, oyez, you've all got three days, tops'.

"The government will be doing everything it can to assure our European partners, and citizens of the United States when it's founded in 300 years time, that Britain is a perfectly safe place to visit.

"Latest statistics from the chief apothecary show that at least half and possibly as many as 60% of the population can expect to survive this outbreak. A small circle of black pustules on the skin is no reason to delay your holiday!

"Visitors from abroad can also continue to enjoy all our traditional rural pastimes, including bear-baiting, throwing stones at the village idiot, wench-deflowering and public executions.

"Let the message go forth: Britain is open for business!"

And Labour is about to be returned to office. When the Tories' Archie Norman mildly suggested that there might be a bill to enable the local elections to be postponed if needs be, Mr Meacher was outraged. "The idea that the whole country is in quarantine, and that democracy has to be suspended, is not an image we wish to project!"

So if foreign tourists can't go near the animals, at least they can follow our thrilling election campaign from the safety of their locked hotel rooms. Or possibly not.

webTitle: Analysis: Advances in the genetic modification of rice

fields.headline: Grain of hope
fields.standfirst:
Advances in the genetic modification of rice may lead to a variety which helps to alleviate vitamin deficiency in developing countries

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Advances in the genetic modification of rice may lead to a variety which helps to alleviate vitamin deficiency in developing countries
fields.body:
Greenpeace calls "golden" rice fools' gold but many scientists and nutritionists believe it could save millions of people's lives. It is a type of rice into which genes for beta-carotene have been inserted - and it is being made to carry a crushing load of ideological baggage in the GM debate. These tiny grains reflect the worst sides of the participants.

Basic facts are not in dispute. More than 100m children worldwide are affected by vitamin A deficiency. As a consequence, 2m children die each year and 500,000 go permanently blind. They are from the poorest families in the developing countries, with little or no access to the balanced diets we enjoy in the industrialised world.

For example, poor families in Asia consume rice as a staple; babies are often weaned on rice gruel. But the rice grain lacks beta-carotene, the precursor of vitamin A. There is plenty in the leaves and stems, but none in the grain endosperm. And no amount of traditional breeding has been able to get it there. (Brown, unmilled rice contains only minute amounts of beta-carotene.)

That has now changed as a result of the work of Ingo Potrykus of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology. His team has been able to transfer two daffodil and one bacterial gene into rice that will ensure the rice grain contains beta-carotene. It is a classic piece of genetic modification, and that is why the anti-GM activists are so strident in their condemnation. The food industry, which had no part in its development, is also using golden rice for its own ends. It has featured the golden grains as part of a $50m campaign to promote GM foods. The message is that GM is not just about profits, it can save children's lives.

All of this hype is premature and dangerous. The science that led us to golden rice is at a very early stage. Until the product is fully developed and tested, no one can be sure how well it will work and whether there may be unwanted side effects. Nor can many of the other promising applications - adding more nutrition to basic staple crops, such as cowpeas and sweet potatoes - be pursued. But some anti-GM activists would like the work to be stopped before we know its real value and are going to extraordinary lengths to rubbish the science

Much play has been made of the amounts of rice people would have to eat to gain a full day's supply of vitamin A. But this misses the point that it is a deficiency we have to tackle, not a total lack of vitamin A. No one is suggesting rice should be the only source of vitamin A. Children die or go blind because they do not get enough. The first golden rice varieties, which will be improved, should provide enough beta-carotene to meet 10%-20% of the dietary requirements of a child. In many instances this will keep a child alive.

This all sounds worthwhile but, says the opposition, it is a quick fix. We should be working instead on the causes of malnutrition. Of course we are working on those, but changing people's livelihoods and farming patterns takes time. And in the meantime, millions will die or go blind.

The insistence on focusing on fundamentals is also in consistent, if not downright hypocritical. At the Rockefeller Foundation, we are also funding the development of vaccines against HIV in Africa (the first ones are currently being tested in Kenya). Should we stop all efforts at this and devote our funds solely to the attempt to change sexual behaviour or wait until the fundamental problem underlying the Aids epidemic - grinding poverty - is eliminated? There are alternative ways of dealing with vitamin A deficiency. They are all being tried (we fund some of them), but they all have drawbacks.

Giving children twice yearly massive doses of vitamin A in tablet form will greatly reduce mortality. Several countries are doing this, but it is relatively costly and the poorest children are difficult to reach. Also, the mortality rate can be further reduced if, instead of massive doses, children are given smaller doses every day.

Ideally farmers should cultivate diverse kitchen gardens, but in many regions they have to cope with long dry spells during which there are few fruits or vegetables. Besides, researchers have recently found that the beta-carotene available in green, leafy vegetables is much less than previously supposed. The best sources of vitamin A are animal products - butter, cheese, eggs, liver - but they are often out of reach for the poor.

While nutritionists disagree on the relative merits of better diets, supplements or fortification, they agree that some combination is needed and multiple tools must be brought to the task.

But before Golden Rice can be part of the solution we do need more answers to the questions raised by anti-GM activists: answers which careful testing can safely provide. First, we need to ensure the grain is freely available to the poor and that it is acceptable; second, that there are no serious environmental consequences from growing golden rice and third, that there are no adverse effects on health. There is no hazard in ingesting excess beta-carotene but we should watch for possible allergies.

The potential for saving lives is there and this makes it a moral imperative to seek out the answers. That is why I welcome the recent statement by Benedikt Haerlin of Greenpeace that they will not disrupt testing. I hope that other anti-GM activists will give up a good campaign icon for the sake of hungry children.

 Gordon Conway is president of the Rockefeller Foundation.

G.Soule@rockfound.org

webTitle: Labour scorns new Robinson allegation as 'nonsense'

fields.headline: Labour scorns new Robinson allegation as 'nonsense'
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor dismisses claim of pressure on top Treasury official during Commons hearing

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday described as "fiction" allegations that he tried to arm twist the Treasury's most senior official, Lord Burns, into issuing a statement that he had approved the financial affairs of former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday described as "fiction" allegations that he tried to arm twist the Treasury's most senior official, Lord Burns, into issuing a statement that he had approved the financial affairs of former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.

The row broke out at a hearing of the Commons Treasury select committee in the wake of the Daily Mail's allegations that Mr Brown had pressured Lord Burns to explain in the statement that Mr Robinson had not broken the ministerial code of conduct by failing to declare details of a family offshore trust.

David Ruffley, Tory MP for Bury St Edmunds, tried to press the chancellor on the report but was firmly rebuffed.

"The Treasury has already issued a statement about this completely misleading report in the Daily Mail and I intend to add nothing to that," said Mr Brown. "I am not prepared to diminish this hearing on the budget by getting into gossip. I was invited to this committee to discuss the budget and related matters. I have issued a statement that this is fictional nonsense. I am not prepared, without prior notice, to go into issues that are related to gossip and fiction that I have no knowledge of."

When Mr Ruffley tried to press Mr Brown further on what he said were "highly damaging" claims, he was rebuked by the committee's Labour chairman, Giles Radice. "The Daily Mail is interested in muck-raking in the run-up to the election. Unfortunately one member of the committee is prepared to act as the Daily Mail's mouthpiece," Mr Radice said.

The allegations from a book by investigative journalist Tom Bower claim that in 1997 Mr Brown and Mr Robinson put pressure on the then Treasury permanent secretary Sir Terry (now Lord) Burns when the paymaster general faced an investigation by the Commons standards and privileges committee into a family trust.

The Guernsey-based Orion trust was set up for his family by Madame Joska Bourgeois, the Belgian millionaire, who left him £12m and a luxury flat in Cannes in her will. He also transferred £13m of shares from his British based com pany, TransTec, to the offshore trust.

Mr Bower claims that the chancellor typed out the first draft of a "grossly inaccurate" press release saying the minister had been cleared by Whitehall of not breaking the code by keeping back the details of the trust. Mr Bower said that Sir Terry then refused to endorse the statement, "insisting that Mr Robinson had tried to conceal from him, that his family trust was an offshore tax haven". Sir Terry is also said to have replied to Peter Lilley, then shadow chancellor, saying he had not looked into all the details of the trust.

Mr Brown's strong denial of the incident is partly undermined by Mr Robinson's memoirs - also serialised in the Daily Mail - which do accuse Sir Terry of attempting to undermine him.

Mr Robinson wrote: "Gordon went to his word processor and pounded out the first draft. The problem was not with the drafting but getting the permanent secretary's approval for the wording and his agreement that I had adhered to the ministerial code. The apparent prevarication at official level seemed a bit odd after all the trouble I had taken to seek his advice and to ensure the fullest compliance."

Mr Robinson at the time issued a statement to the press saying: "Sir Terry Burns completely vindicated me. I acted in accordance with the ministerial code and on the advice of the Treasury permanent secretary."

Sir Terry's more equivocal reply to Mr Lilley led the Tories to accuse the minister of keeping the permanent secretary in the dark.

Earlier yesterday Downing Street said solicitors for the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, would be writing to the Daily Mail about Monday's story - which alleged that he "buried" an official report on Mr Robinson's links with crooked tycoon Robert Maxwell. "My understanding is that Mr Byers's solicitor will be writing today to the Daily Mail and the publishers demanding an apology and a donation to charity and I think he will be saying that if that isn't forthcoming he will be taking the matter further," a spokesman said.

But the newspaper said in a statement yesterday: "Tom Bower and the Daily Mail stand 100% behind our story and are more than happy to defend it in a court of law. "We note that the government has not denied the central allegation - that the former pay master general, a man who has helped financially both the prime minister and the chancellor, and also provided them with use of his holiday homes, lied repeatedly to MPs and the parliamentary standards commissioner about a £200,000 cheque from Robert Maxwell."

The claim that Mr Robinson had received the £200,000, yet failed to disclose it, was investigated by the then parliamentary commissioner, Sir Gordon Downey, in 1998. He concluded the "likelihood" was that the payment was never made and the Hollis company books were wrong. The shadow trade secretary, David Heathcoat-Amory, last night demanded a new inquiry following the discovery of a lost document that suggested Mr Robinson had been paid the cash.

Mr Brown's strong denial of the incident is partly undermined by Mr Robinson's memoirs - also serialised in the Daily Mail - which do accuse Sir Terry of attempting to undermine him. Mr Robinson wrote: "Gordon went to his word processor and pounded out the first draft. The problem was not with the drafting but getting the permanent secretary's approval for the wording and his agreement that I had adhered to the ministerial code. The apparent prevarication at official level seemed a bit odd after all the trouble I had taken to seek his advice and to ensure the fullest compliance." Mr Robinson at the time issued a statement to the press saying: "Sir Terry Burns completely vindicated me. I acted in accordance with the ministerial code and on the advice of the Treasury permanent secretary." Sir Terry's more equivocal reply to Mr Lilley led the Tories to accuse the minister of keeping the permanent secretary in the dark. Earlier yesterday Downing Street said solicitors for the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, would be writing to the Daily Mail about Monday's story - which alleged that he "buried" an official report on Mr Robinson's links with crooked tycoon Robert Maxwell. "My understanding is that Mr Byers's solicitor will be writing today to the Daily Mail and the publishers demanding an apology and a donation to charity and I think he will be saying that if that isn't forthcoming he will be taking the matter further," a spokesman said. But the newspaper said in a statement yesterday: "Tom Bower and the Daily Mail stand 100% behind our story and are more than happy to defend it in a court of law. "We note that the government has not denied the central allegation - that the former pay master general, a man who has helped financially both the prime minister and the chancellor, and also provided them with use of his holiday homes, lied repeatedly to MPs and the parliamentary standards commissioner about a £200,000 cheque from Robert Maxwell." The claim that Mr Robinson had received the £200,000, yet failed to disclose it, was investigated by the then parliamentary commissioner, Sir Gordon Downey, in 1998. He concluded the "likelihood" was that the payment was never made and the Hollis company books were wrong. The shadow trade secretary, David Heathcoat-Amory, last night demanded a new inquiry following the discovery of a lost document that suggested Mr Robinson had been paid the cash.

webTitle: Ramblers' court win over blocked path

fields.headline: Ramblers' court win over blocked path
fields.trailText: A footpath which crosses land on which millionaire Nicholas van Hoogstraten is building his own palace near Uckfield in East Sussex must be reopened, Lewes magistrates ordered yesterday in the first case under the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000.
fields.body:
A footpath which crosses land on which millionaire Nicholas van Hoogstraten is building his own palace near Uckfield in East Sussex must be reopened, Lewes magistrates ordered yesterday in the first case under the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000.

The case brought after a complaint by Kate Ashbrook, of the Ramblers' Association, was against Rarebargain Ltd, a company which owns a small amount of land on the edge of Hamilton Palace estate.

The company was fined £4,000, but more important from the ramblers' point of view was the order that the barbed wire, locked gates and a refrigeration unit be removed within 28 days and the barn built across the 140-year-old path removed within six months. Under the act, which came into force on January 30, the power to order removal of obstruction passed from East Sussex council to the courts, and this was the first time such a power has been exercised.

Ms Ashbrook was delighted. "This is the legislation we have been waiting for to force reluctant landlords to obey the law and remove obstructions to rights of way," she said.

Mr van Hoogstraten has resisted all attempts to get obstructions removed from the existing path, which crosses his 200 acre estate, a mile from Uckfield.

David Engleheart, solicitor for Mr van Hoogstraten, said that his client was in Zimbabwe. He did not own Rarebargain, on whose land the obstructions stood, although Hamilton Palace Ltd, in which his client did have an interest, owned the land round about.

High tech
A-level technology students at a school in Wrexham, north Wales, have designed a vibrating device to discourage birds from perching on electricity pylons and fouling houses below.
Daily Post, 5.3.01 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Burning face
A firefighter in Tonbridge, Kent, set his own station alight when he went to answer the phone and forgot that he had left a cheese sandwich under the grill.
Birmingham Mail, 3.3.01 (Simon Briggs, Bearwood)

Poles apart
A woman booked for a minor traffic offence while visiting Southend-on-Sea, Essex, was ordered to produce her licence in Warsaw, Poland, after the police officer misheard her when she gave her address in Walsall.
Evening Echo, 27.2.01 (John McGarvey, Chelmsford)

Lost track
Passengers on a train to London had to get off at Orpington, Kent, after a Tannoy announcement that the driver didn't know his way.
Hastings Observer, 6.3.01 (Richard Jones, Hastings)

Early warning
Mountain rescue teams called off a search on Rannoch Moor, in the Scottish highlands, after a man who phoned to say that his daughter had failed to get in touch realised later that she was not due to start her walk in the area until the following week.
Lochaber News, 3.3.01 (Marc Hindley, Nairn)

Splash smash
Three cars were involved in a pile-up after another vehicle ended up in a pond when it swerved to avoid a duck crossing a busy road near Kidderminster, Hereford and Worcester.
Metro, 2.3.01 (Judith Brierley, London W5)

Purrsonal care
Staff at the accident and emergency department of Solihull hospital, West Midlands, saved a cat brought in by its owner because it was choking on a chip.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 9.3.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Longing for home
A pensioner who booked a holiday in Eastbourne, 10 miles from her home, was taken on a 200-mile round trip as the coach picked up passengers from as far away as St Albans, Hertfordshire.
Brighton Argus, 6.3.01 (E Leslie, Shoreham-by-Sea)

Nose for money
A member of staff at a supermarket in Bangor, Northern Ireland, won a £16,800 award for the wackiest charity fundraising idea after pushing a pea round the store with his nose for four hours.
Belfast Telegraph, 2.3.01 (T Dougan, Belfast)

Far better jobs
A woman stripagram is looking for work further away from her home in Hove, Sussex, after recently being hired by an ex-partner, her former teacher and her driving instructor.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 5.3.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Bubble bursts
A woman from Buxton, Derbyshire, was given a conditional discharge after telling magistrates she was so hard-up that she had to steal a bottle of champagne to celebrate her boyfriend's release from prison.
Buxton Advertiser, 28.2.01 (R Hassett, Buxton)

What a cheek
An unemployed man from Stoke-on-Trent has set up a website appealing for sponsors to help him raise £20,000 for plastic surgery to give him the perfect face.
Stoke Sentinel, 20.2.01 (DP Hughes, Crewe)

Do as I say . . .
Wiltshire county council has been criticised for offering a car as part of the package for a new member of staff employed to persuade people not to drive to work.
Western Daily Press, 8.3.01 (Francis Harvey, Exeter)

Glaring fault
Scientists have warned that reflected sunlight from a mirror sculpture planned for the centre of Nottingham could be strong enough to blind members of the public and barbecue birds.
Sunday Independent, 11.3.01 (Carol Pink, Bigbury on Sea)

webTitle: 'Condemned' council wins top social services award

fields.headline: Turnaround for Ealing
fields.standfirst: 'Condemned' council wins top social services award
fields.trailText: 'Condemned' council wins top social services award
fields.body:
Less than three years ago, Ealing council was condemned for a "culture of hopelessness" in its social services department. Today, the same authority is proud holder of the title social services team of the year.

In one of the most remarkable turnarounds in public services management, the Labour-led west London authority has given hope to all "named and shamed" councils by scooping the new social services category in the annual local government "oscars", organised by Local Government Chronicle.

The judging panel, which included Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, found that Ealing had not only transformed the performance of its social services department, but had achieved change in its very culture. "To do this, it had involved children, staff, members, partners and other departments," the panel said. "The judges particularly liked the way they celebrated success along the way."

Ealing's children's services were scathingly criticised in 1998 in a report by the social services inspectorate, which warned that the consequences for vulnerable youngsters were "potentially catastrophic".

Ministers ordered the council to take immediate action to remedy matters and one of its first steps was the appointment of Norman Tutt as social services director. Tutt, a specialist in performance management of children's services, embarked on a fundamental restructuring.

"There were very clear performance targets that some of the middle managers were plainly never going to achieve," says Tutt. "We had to replace those staff."

The council was put on monthly report to the Department of Health and the social services department underwent five intensive inspections in less than two years. Last year, it was taken off the department's "special measures" list and now it has staff on secondment to other London boroughs deemed to be struggling.

Tutt is not resting on his laurels, however. "In social services you are only as good as your last case," he says. "We have a joint review coming up early next year and already we are saying to staff: 'It's great that we have made this amount of progress, but we are going to be under scrutiny again'."

 Suffolk was honoured as council of the year in the awards. Manchester was named top housing team and Hackney, east London, contract services team.

webTitle: Human resources practice in aid sector

fields.headline: Help the helper
fields.standfirst: Aid agencies are finally realising that they should look after their own employees too.  Daloni Carlisle-Pesic reports
fields.trailText: Aid agencies are finally realising that they should look after their own employees too. Daloni Carlisle-Pesic reports
fields.body:
Marie-Christine Lux was in Honduras when she became ill. She was unsure of the diagnosis but knew she needed major surgery, so it was a huge relief when her employer made all the necessary hospital appointments, flew her home and sent someone round to visit.

Nothing unusual in that, perhaps, except that Lux works for aid agency Tearfund. And aid agencies, despite their core purpose being to help those in need, are notoriously bad at looking after their own employees.

"I have worked for Tearfund on and off since 1982," says Lux, now given the all-clear from what turned out to be cancer. "The way they responded was fantastic and it took a load off my mind at a very worrying time. This is a big change from the way things were in the past."

It is not only at Tearfund that things are changing. Aid agencies have begun to act on the mantra that they are only as good as the people who work for them, and tomorrow sees the launch of the first audit of human resources practice in the sector.

It has been a long process, stemming from research in 1995 that suggested aid workers were suffering high levels of stress from long hours in difficult and dangerous environments, with little management support. In 1996, in a bid to improve matters, a number of agencies came together to form People in Aid. This group designed a code of best practice in human resources, to which 12 international aid and development agencies signed up.

The dozen agreed to audit their practice, consult with staff and improve human resources policies and practice in light of the findings. They also agreed to an external audit of their work and to publish the findings.

Only seven stayed the course -British Red Cross, Concern Worldwide, Health Unlimited, International Health Exchange (IHE), Missionary Aviation Fellowship Europe, RedR and Tearfund. Tomorrow's report, Ahead of the Field, sets out the audit findings.

The three years of the pilot project saw some marked changes, such as improved briefing and health checks, tightening of security procedures and better insurance. All seven agencies took action as a result of their consultations with field staff. Some introduced equal opportunities policies and staff appraisals and began work on career planning. Others began to record and use data from accidents and security incidents.

The agencies involved say it was hard work but worth it. Ivan Scott, director of IHE, which recruits health staff on behalf of other agencies, says: "It's a very diverse sector. Just getting everyone to sit down, agree and start sharing experience was no mean feat and has been enormously helpful."

Bobby Lambert, director of RedR, which recruits and trains engineering staff adds: "It is consistent with our whole reason for being here: you do not have good relief programmes unless you have the right people and they are properly supported."

At the British Red Cross, international personnel manager Leanne Taylor admits it was an innovation to consult staff about policies affecting their working lives. She says: "For the first time it gave us some concrete feedback on how we were doing. It reconfirmed some of what we already knew, but also highlighted some areas we need to tackle, such as excessive working hours."

But the work also raised some very difficult issues, chief among them being institutional racism. While an expatriate aid worker in a refugee camp in Sudan might receive train ing, his African counterpart doing an equally skilled job would not. Whereas a British manager working in South America would receive one level of salary, a locally recruited manager with the same level of responsibility would be paid much less. The report puts the matter delicately: "With its traditions of volunteerism and inheritance from colonial or missionary institutions_ the aid sector is not immune from prejudice or institutional racism."

Scott draws a sharp breath at the suggestion that aid agencies may be institutionally racist. "That's a strong way of putting it and a lot of people in this sector would be offended by that," he says. "It is a very difficult issue."

A few agencies have begun to address the issue, however. Tearfund is looking at how to deliver equivalent terms and conditions to staff recruited in different locations. Ian Wallace, its international manager, says: "We have done a lot of recruiting overseas in recent years for quite senior staff to act as regional advisers. We found that they were coming under quite different contractual arrangements from the people we recruited here in the UK. These people felt quite rightly that they were not being cared for in the same way."

While tomorrow's report marks a departure from the shoddy treatment that many aid workers have been resigned to, some old hands remain sceptical. "I have a very low opinion of personnel in aid agencies," says one, who prefers to remain anonymous. "They are always talking about how they value staff, and put staff at the centre, and then nothing changes."

The point is well taken by the aid agencies involved in the pilot. As Lambert says: "People want to see real results. But human resources is like clear glass. When it's working, you don't see it."

Ahead of the Field is available free from People in Aid, 9 Grosvenor Crescent, London SW1X 7ES.

fields.headline: Where there's a wheel
fields.standfirst: Bibi Herrera, potter-poet who rebuilt her life after the Pinochet terror
fields.trailText: Profile: Bibi Herrera, potter-poet who rebuilt her life after the Pinochet terror
fields.body:
Pottery has been a lifeline to Bibi Herrera, giving her the will to survive the memories of the brutality she suffered as a young woman in detention in Pinochet's Chile. She started working with clay on the suggestion of therapists in London; now she not only makes her own pots - with just one hand - but helps other people in need of therapy. Next month, an exhibition of her work is to be staged at a gallery in south London.

Herrera was 16 in 1973, studying Chilean Indian art; she was a young communist and an active supporter of president Salvador Allende. She was helping to organise distribution of food to Santiago's poorer districts and was general secretary of a women's print union. On the morning of the coup, she was at her father's printing works when soldiers burst in, arrested her and took her by lorry to the notorious Chile Stadium in Santiago.

She was to be held there for three and a half years, enduring interrogation, torture and rape. "They burned my hand with hot oil to make me talk... but you get to a point that you just don't care and you know what is coming," she recalls. "You try to help each other because there are always some people who need more help than others.

"At the beginning it is terrible because you are so scared. You don't know what is going to happen to you. They used to come around at three o'clock in the morning and say: 'All out'. And the captain - or whatever he was - said 'That one, that one, that one', and 'Shoot them'. And so you were there every night and you never know when they would shoot you. The worst thing is when you see other people being killed - especially the old people, just because they were old. It was really bad for about two and a half years. After that it was less."

Herrera started to write poetry on scraps of paper, which she hid until her release when she gave them to a UN representative to smuggle out of jail. She was released into the hands of the UN and taken by car to Buenos Aires where she was given the choice of five countries to go to as a political refugee. She picked Britain, and flew into Heathrow airport on June 12, 1977.

Initially she lived in a hotel in Notting Hill Gate, west London, with about 42 other Chileans, and became involved with the Chile Solidarity Campaign, on the printing side. But there was no one that she could talk to about what she had suffered. "In my country, if for any reason you are raped then nobody wants to talk to you because they blame you even if it is not your fault. I tried to talk about it but they told me to shut up," she says.

In 1979 she was moved to a big estate in Tulse Hill, south London. Somehow the estate reminded her of the stadium, and she was lonely: shortly after the move she made her first suicide attempt, cutting her wrists. A neighbour found her, her wrists were patched up and she was taken to the Bethlem hospital in south London. She saw a psychiatrist but her English, she says, was poor and they spoke only briefly. A psychologist wanted her to place figures on a board, and make word associations. She thought it ridiculous, refused to take part and was put on Mogadon, she says.

Her second suicide attempt was in 1993, prompted by the news of the death of a close Chilean friend in a farm accident. Herrera was doing copper work with a Stanley knife, and immediately slashed her wrists. Again she ended up at the Bethlem hospital but this time treatment was very different. She saw a psychologist (whom she is still seeing) and a psychiatrist who encouraged her to talk about what had happened in Chile. And she was offered occupational therapy in the form of pottery.

Having lost the use of her left hand in the suicide attempt, at first she didn't want to know. "I was annoyed that I was still alive," she says. Then she saw another patient holding a cigarette in one hand and coiling clay in long rolls with the other. "I thought I can try that_ You stroke the clay down to cover the joints and then you do the inside as well, and so it's not going to break," she says, describing how she taught herself from books about ceramic art.

She had lost her job in printing while she was in Bethlem and was at a loss what to do after being discharged, with the result that she was back within six weeks. "There was nothing for me to do. I am not a person to sit down in front of the television. I have to use my brain and my hands. My consultant had a word with the lady in charge of OT [occupational therapy] and I was allowed to come back here once a week. And I started coming every day. I wasn't supposed to be here."

She was doing her own work and also, as a volunteer, helping others to learn pottery in the arts workshop, which is run by trained artists for the 350 in-patients under the charge of the OT department. Each week about 100 patients pass through the workshop.

"If there was no project, I'm sure I wouldn't be here- or I would be here as a patient," says Herrera, 45. "This is my life now. I can't live without it because I enjoy it so much, giving pleasure to others. I am trying just to show them what I know. It's not going to work for everyone, but because I was a patient I know what they are going through. That's the main thing - to help others."

Her pots come in all shapes, sizes and colours. They and the designs draw heavily on three months she spent as a young student with Indians in the south of Chile when she was learning about their culture, art and traditional symbols. fields.bodyText: Pottery has been a lifeline to Bibi Herrera, giving her the will to survive the memories of the brutality she suffered as a young woman in detention in Pinochet's Chile. She started working with clay on the suggestion of therapists in London; now she not only makes her own pots - with just one hand - but helps other people in need of therapy. Next month, an exhibition of her work is to be staged at a gallery in south London. Herrera was 16 in 1973, studying Chilean Indian art; she was a young communist and an active supporter of president Salvador Allende. She was helping to organise distribution of food to Santiago's poorer districts and was general secretary of a women's print union. On the morning of the coup, she was at her father's printing works when soldiers burst in, arrested her and took her by lorry to the notorious Chile Stadium in Santiago. She was to be held there for three and a half years, enduring interrogation, torture and rape. "They burned my hand with hot oil to make me talk... but you get to a point that you just don't care and you know what is coming," she recalls. "You try to help each other because there are always some people who need more help than others. "At the beginning it is terrible because you are so scared. You don't know what is going to happen to you. They used to come around at three o'clock in the morning and say: 'All out'. And the captain - or whatever he was - said 'That one, that one, that one', and 'Shoot them'. And so you were there every night and you never know when they would shoot you. The worst thing is when you see other people being killed - especially the old people, just because they were old. It was really bad for about two and a half years. After that it was less." Herrera started to write poetry on scraps of paper, which she hid until her release when she gave them to a UN representative to smuggle out of jail. She was released into the hands of the UN and taken by car to Buenos Aires where she was given the choice of five countries to go to as a political refugee. She picked Britain, and flew into Heathrow airport on June 12, 1977. Initially she lived in a hotel in Notting Hill Gate, west London, with about 42 other Chileans, and became involved with the Chile Solidarity Campaign, on the printing side. But there was no one that she could talk to about what she had suffered. "In my country, if for any reason you are raped then nobody wants to talk to you because they blame you even if it is not your fault. I tried to talk about it but they told me to shut up," she says. In 1979 she was moved to a big estate in Tulse Hill, south London. Somehow the estate reminded her of the stadium, and she was lonely: shortly after the move she made her first suicide attempt, cutting her wrists. A neighbour found her, her wrists were patched up and she was taken to the Bethlem hospital in south London. She saw a psychiatrist but her English, she says, was poor and they spoke only briefly. A psychologist wanted her to place figures on a board, and make word associations. She thought it ridiculous, refused to take part and was put on Mogadon, she says. Her second suicide attempt was in 1993, prompted by the news of the death of a close Chilean friend in a farm accident. Herrera was doing copper work with a Stanley knife, and immediately slashed her wrists. Again she ended up at the Bethlem hospital but this time treatment was very different. She saw a psychologist (whom she is still seeing) and a psychiatrist who encouraged her to talk about what had happened in Chile. And she was offered occupational therapy in the form of pottery. Having lost the use of her left hand in the suicide attempt, at first she didn't want to know. "I was annoyed that I was still alive," she says. Then she saw another patient holding a cigarette in one hand and coiling clay in long rolls with the other. "I thought I can try that_ You stroke the clay down to cover the joints and then you do the inside as well, and so it's not going to break," she says, describing how she taught herself from books about ceramic art. She had lost her job in printing while she was in Bethlem and was at a loss what to do after being discharged, with the result that she was back within six weeks. "There was nothing for me to do. I am not a person to sit down in front of the television. I have to use my brain and my hands. My consultant had a word with the lady in charge of OT [occupational therapy] and I was allowed to come back here once a week. And I started coming every day. I wasn't supposed to be here." She was doing her own work and also, as a volunteer, helping others to learn pottery in the arts workshop, which is run by trained artists for the 350 in-patients under the charge of the OT department. Each week about 100 patients pass through the workshop. "If there was no project, I'm sure I wouldn't be here- or I would be here as a patient," says Herrera, 45. "This is my life now. I can't live without it because I enjoy it so much, giving pleasure to others. I am trying just to show them what I know. It's not going to work for everyone, but because I was a patient I know what they are going through. That's the main thing - to help others." Her pots come in all shapes, sizes and colours. webTitle: Choice-based letting schemes for council housing

fields.headline: Lets be quick
fields.standfirst: It's soul destroying spending years on the council house waiting list. But choice-based letting schemes aim to change all that, reports  Alison Benjamin
fields.trailText: It's soul destroying spending years on the council house waiting list. But choice-based letting schemes aim to change all that, reports Alison Benjamin
fields.body:
Janice and David Ryan have been married 10 years. Five of those were spent living with David's mum, waiting for a council house in Market Harborough, Leicestershire, for themselves and their children Tiffany and Jason, now six and three.

Like thousands of people on council waiting lists across the country, the Ryans filled in forms sent by the local authority from time to time, asking them if they still wanted to be on the list and if their circumstances had changed. But they heard nothing back. Then, last April, Harborough district council introduced a new way of allocating homes to the 1,000 people on its housing register. Nine months later, the Ryans moved into a three-bedroom, semi-detached council house.

Instead of the traditional points system, which invariably puts homeless families and teenage mothers at the front of the housing queue, and gives housing officers sole control over who is allocated which property, Harborough Home Search is based on the principle of consumer choice.

Each fortnight, a newsletter advertising the latest vacant homes arrived on the Ryans' doormat, inviting them to view any of the council and housing association properties that met their requirements. "Most of them were unsuitable," says Janice. "They were out of town, or bungalows for older people, but I was sure that if we hung on something was bound to turn up."

They finally spotted their ideal home in the December newsletter, completed a form to register their interest, and a couple of weeks later were invited for a viewing. "We said 'yes' straight away and, to our surprise, were told we could move in the following month after the rewiring had been done," says Janice.

The Ryans were lucky. Not everyone on the housing register will be successful. While this affluent part of the East Midlands does not suffer from a social housing shortage on the scale of London or the south-east, the ratio of applicants to properties is still two to one; each week, about 40 applicants chase 20 homes. First choice goes to people issued with a time-limited priority card, followed by those longest on the housing register.

Home Search has supplied cards to 100 households which, under the old points system, would have been at the front of the queue. This gives them three months to pick a home. Yet many have forgone this priority status, preferring to wait like everyone else for suitable accommodation, instead of taking what's on offer within 12 weeks.

To date, 500 properties have been advertised through Home Search, most of which have been snapped up, and 80% of participants say they prefer it to the old system.

Tim Brown, director of the centre for comparative housing research at De Montfort University, which is evaluating the Harborough pilot and two similar schemes in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, and Caerphilly, south Wales, says the value of the choice-based lettings approach is that it opens up a hitherto impenetrable system.

"The schemes have the important advantages of openness, transparency and accountability," says Brown. They do not raise unrealistic expectations, he insists. "When people are able to see all the vacancies in an area, they will understand far better the lack of available social housing. In the whole of Harborough there are only 23 four-bedroom houses, so people will have to make realistic choices."

Harborough council and its three housing association partners are hoping to develop Home Search so that vacancies are advertised on a website as well as in the newsletter. They have applied to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) for funding. Next week, along with 91 other bidders, they will hear whether their pitch is one of the 20 or so chosen to secure a share of the government's £11m to support choice-based lettings schemes.

This idea was promoted by the housing green paper, issued in April last year. "Our objectives are to empower people to make decisions over where they live and exercise choice; help create sustainable com munities and encourage the effective use of the nation's stock," it said.

The DETR has been impressed with the number and quality of the 94 bids - covering areas of low, as well as high, demand for social housing. Oldham has teamed up with Manchester, Rochdale and a number of housing associations and private landlords in the north-west in a bid to expand "instant homes" - an estate agent approach to marketing empty properties.

In its first 11 months, the scheme - operating from a shop and a website - has let 360 homes owned by Oldham council. The only criteria a prospective tenant must meet is that they need somewhere to live. In a region plagued by low demand for all types of rented accommodation, the council believes all sectors must work together not only to give applicants more choice, but to revitalise the rented sector's tarnished image.

But where housing demand is very high, how can choice help tenants who have been stuck on waiting lists for years? In its response to the green paper, the Association of London Government (ALG) said it could not, and described choice-based lettings as "clearly inappropriate in most of London". Yet, a year on, 12 London boroughs have put in bids to the DETR, spurred by the success of a choice-based approach pioneered in Holland and followed closely in Harborough.

This so-called Delft model has operated since the early 1990s in areas of Holland where housing is hard to find. In Utrecht, where 75,000 people are on the housing register, 6,000 units of housing are advertised each year. On average, there are 34 responses to each advertisement. As a result, the typical time on the register is between four and five years.

Mike Morris, chief executive of the William Sutton Trust, a housing association which is part of a London and south-east consortium bid to the DETR, says the issue is how to ration a scarce resource in a more humane way - not how to produce more homes. "This is about humanising lettings and getting rid of the dependency culture that we as bureaucrats have bred by taking responsibility," he says.

Nevertheless, Kensington and Chelsea council in west London - one of the trust's local authority partners - has a shortfall of 4,400 social houses and flats and 840 homeless families living in hostels and bed and breakfast accommodation. It hopes the proposed central register of landlords' vacant properties will increase housing options outside the borough. Another consortium, led by Hammersmith and Fulham council, also in west London, hopes to make it easier for tenants of 10 landlords to transfer across borough boundaries - a feat that has been likened to scaling the Berlin wall - while a proposal from the once sceptical ALG and Homes, the nationwide transfer agency, wants to offer the capital's waiting list applicants the choice of a home and a job up north.

Whoever wins DETR funding next week, it seems that the way social housing is let will never be the same again. Many of the choice-based bids are so well developed that they are likely to be implemented even without extra funding. Few will mourn the points system.

One important lesson from Holland is that injecting choice creates more sustainable communities. Janice Ryan says: "If you've chosen your home yourself, it feels like your own place and it's worth making it nice and getting on with the neighbours."

Queue for change

More than 1m households are on local authority housing waiting lists in England alone, according to the most recent annual figures.

Of the total, more than 800,000 are registered as "in need", including 325,000 with or expecting children and 130,000 with special needs.

Almost 200,000 households are on waiting lists in London alone, including 86,000 with or expecting children, and 116,000 in the rest of the south-east. More than 160,000 are on lists in the Yorkshire and Humberside region.

Official figures last week showed that the number of households living in bed and breakfast accommodation has soared 22% in a year, standing now at 9,860. In 1999, this type of emergency housing cost the state £152m.

Housing charity Shelter is calling for a national target to cut the use of bed and breakfast accommodation. Chris Holmes, the charity's director, says: "Bed and breakfasts do not provide families with security, stability or a chance to create a settled environment."

David Brindle

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: environment news
fields.body:
Bush fires

Fears that George Bush would follow in his father's footsteps and stall progress on tackling environmental problems were not expected to be fulfilled so early. In the first 60 days, he has declared that his most specific campaign pledge to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from power plants was a mistake, delayed implementation of a plan to protect the remaining 30% of US national forests and proposed massive cuts in renewable energy and energy-efficiency programmes. Just for good measure, he has cast doubt on whether man-made climate change is really sound science. Even Klaus Toepfer, executive director of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), felt obliged to issue a rebuttal, pointing to the three giant tomes from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change issued in the last three months, which say exactly the opposite. Next on the agenda is the resumed climate talks in July. Those who remember George's father at the Earth Summit in 1992, when the US president refused to sign the Biodiversity Agreement, are already dismayed at the havoc Junior might cause at the 10-year follow-up conference in South Africa next year.

Goodbye beech

While George may not believe in climate change, the Woodland Trust certainly does, predicting it is the greatest threat to our trees. A new trust report out today says beech woods in south-east England could be dying out in 30 years due to drought and water shortages. It also predicts that oak trees will be wiped out by disease from North America.

Unwanted gifts

Talking of unwanted gifts from North America, the Campaign for the Accountability of US Bases is enraged by US navy flares having to be detonated on Skegness beach. With the countryside closed and beaches the only place to go for a walk, Yarmouth coastguards are warning that more flares "may appear" on beaches. They are 18- inches long and extremely dangerous. Surplus to requirement, they were thrown out of fighter planes during an exercise over the North Sea last month. Charming.

Stinging nettlers

Friends of the Earth have become experts at chipping away at European directives to embarrass the UK government, which is so often guilty of non-compliance. The pattern is that the reluctant European Commission is finally chivvied into bullying the UK, which is then forced into action - for example, to clean up beaches or waterways. The lengths that FoE are prepared to go to sting the commission into action deserve admiration. Peter Roderick, FoE's legal adviser, has just heard from the European ombudsman that he has found the commission "guilty of maladministration in refusing to provide FoE with information the EC holds on the UK government's failure to comply with the habitats directive and various waste directives". That sentence represents months of hard graft banging away at brick walls. The central point was that various pages of evidence had been blanked out to spare the UK's blushes about why it had not obeyed the law - but the ombudsman judged this was not sufficient reason for secrecy. The FoE is now waiting for the commission to cough up so we can see what everyone was trying to hide. The next instalment will probably take another six months.

That dam again

The government has been trying hard to forget its involvement in the Ilisu dam scheme in Turkey, hoping the whole issue of its £200m backing would go away until after the election. The Kurdish people - whose homes will be swamped - and an international campaign are determined to keep up the pressure and get the scheme cancelled. Balfour Beatty, leading the construction consortium, claimed over the telephone they would be delighted to receive and study a report from the Corner House and the Ilisu Dam campaign saying why it should not be built . Repeated efforts to hand the document in to the company's London headquarters were, however, rebuffed by security guards.

Rare plaudit

Vauxhall, which has been running into trouble in Luton with the closure of car production, has never the less been supporting car sharing clubs, which are still struggling to be popular enough to stand on their own four wheels. Vauxhall provides most of the cars, and has delivered the first liquid petroleum gas car to Bristol Club, which makes for cheaper motoring. Cars cost as little as £2 an hour, plus 15p a mile. Details at www.carshareclubs.org.uk

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: society letters
fields.body:
Carers need looking after

I couldn't agree more about the poor pay of home carers (Personal insult, March 7). My aunt, who died at the age of 90 in her own home, could not possibly have spent the last year of her life in a room full of happy memories, looking out of her sunny window at the magnificent willow tree she had planted, if it had not been for her rota of carers.

Some of them used to arrive on bikes, in all weathers - often, of course, in the dark - cheerfully pulling off dripping waterproofs before starting their work. This they typically recorded in their contact diary as "Miss X fine . . . usual routine . . . washed and dressed, tablet and inhaler taken . . . all's well on leaving". They seemed to enjoy talking with my aunt, but several said they were not intending to stay in the job for long, and when I found that one was considering swapping to a job in which her interpersonal skills would have been sadly wasted, I realised that their pay must be a pittance.

Their "usual routine" seemed to me like nursing - and I felt embarrassed at colluding in such exploitation when I added to that: their having to work sensitively in other people's homes; their being entrusted to look out for any signs of deterioration in their clients' health, and their need to juggle a timetable of visits to people who might well be anxious if they were "late".

Gillian Harris
Swanley, Kent

 Service users continue to express a need for domestic help, but in many local authorities this has become an area of dereliction, with elderly people left to make their own arrangements.

External contracts for home care, intended to save local authorities money through reduced overheads, are failing to do so. Increased professional time is spent on the paper chase necessary to create the audit trail for public money spent outside the council.

Any benefits derived through the process are inevitably achieved at the expense of proper treatment of the workforce. We may find, as we have with children's homes, that public provision can be as effective as independent alternatives.

Nick Johnson
Poole

Heads you win

Clearly Roger Backhouse is entitled to his opinion (Letters, March 14), but I felt I must write to establish a few facts about the true value of using headhunters.

In particular, I would like to address the point that headhunters "add an unnecessary and expensive layer in the appointment process". The use of reputable headhunters is indeed an expensive - but cost-effective - procedure. The cost of hiring the wrong individual is substantially higher than the cost of employing a reputable headhunter.

Good recruitment consultants are better positioned to offer impartial advice to both client and candidate, and match the right person to the right organisation. Our experience strongly suggests that candidates prefer dealing with external organisations when discussing their potential career moves. While many organisations still base their appointments largely upon "gut feel", good headhunters add science to the art of selection.

To suggest that headhunters persuade clients to offer unnecessarily high salaries, in order to obtain a larger fee, insults the intelligence of the organisations concerned.

Matthew Jaquiss
Director, eResourcing, TMP Worldwide

Return to regional power

Malcolm Dean is right about the confusion over provision of services at local level (March 14). If the government was really brave, it would legislate to abolish all the Sure Starts, action zones for educa tion and health, community health councils and various Whitehall quangos, and bring in regional government for England, restore local council powers and ensure that the resources currently spent by all these bodies were given back to the locality.

Some national services, such as the NHS, could easily be carried out by regional government. This issue is a non-debate: people know what needs to be done.

Neville Collins
London

The bypass blues

Like Sarah Hipperson, (Letters, March 7), I read Michael Symmons Roberts's view of the town I grew up in, Newbury, with great interest (Nuclear families, February 28).

Being seven years younger than Michael, and his sometime next-door neighbour, I vividly remember the fear and fascination generated by the close proximity of the cruise missiles. I also remember the gentle spirit the peace women brought to the town, softening somehow the influx of these loud (but pleasant), hulking US army officers.

Roberts surely can't have noticed the altered view from Greenham Common on his last trip home, as he did not mention another high-profile, local-but-global protest. Curving sinuously round the other side of Newbury, and laid on foundations removed and re-used from Greenham Common's own runway, is the Newbury bypass.

Hipperson's letter prompted a reflection on both the bias exhibited by the Newbury Weekly News against the anti-bypass protests, and also the hostility shown to protesters (local or otherwise) by some elements of Roberts's and my own local community.

There were remarkable similarities: a local man who spent days suspended in a tripod was shot at; camps and people were attacked; and anyone who looked like a protester (whatever that meant) was turned down for jobs and refused travel on buses, service in shops - including one superstore - and drinks in pubs (often formerly their locals).

I wrote poems (as therapy) about this, Michael. Did you?

Nicola Chester
Compton, Newbury, Berkshire

fields.bodyText: Carers need looking after I couldn't agree more about the poor pay of home carers (Personal insult, March 7). My aunt, who died at the age of 90 in her own home, could not possibly have spent the last year of her life in a room full of happy memories, looking out of her sunny window at the magnificent willow tree she had planted, if it had not been for her rota of carers. Some of them used to arrive on bikes, in all weathers - often, of course, in the dark - cheerfully pulling off dripping waterproofs before starting their work. This they typically recorded in their contact diary as "Miss X fine . . . usual routine . . . washed and dressed, tablet and inhaler taken . . . all's well on leaving". They seemed to enjoy talking with my aunt, but several said they were not intending to stay in the job for long, and when I found that one was considering swapping to a job in which her interpersonal skills would have been sadly wasted, I realised that their pay must be a pittance. Their "usual routine" seemed to me like nursing - and I felt embarrassed at colluding in such exploitation when I added to that: their having to work sensitively in other people's homes; their being entrusted to look out for any signs of deterioration in their clients' health, and their need to juggle a timetable of visits to people who might well be anxious if they were "late". Gillian Harris Swanley, Kent  Service users continue to express a need for domestic help, but in many local authorities this has become an area of dereliction, with elderly people left to make their own arrangements. External contracts for home care, intended to save local authorities money through reduced overheads, are failing to do so. Increased professional time is spent on the paper chase necessary to create the audit trail for public money spent outside the council. Any benefits derived through the process are inevitably achieved at the expense of proper treatment of the workforce. We may find, as we have with children's homes, that public provision can be as effective as independent alternatives. Our experience strongly suggests that candidates prefer dealing with external organisations when discussing their potential career moves. While many organisations still base their appointments largely upon "gut feel", good headhunters add science to the art of selection.
