fields.headline: Against the grain
fields.standfirst: In the shadow of foot and mouth, the WTO is launching a new agriculture agreement. But the trade free-for-all has caused enough damage already, warns  Tom Crompton
fields.trailText: In the shadow of foot and mouth, the WTO is launching a new agriculture agreement. But the trade free-for-all has caused enough damage already, warns Tom Crompton
fields.body:
The crisis in European agriculture caused by foot and mouth comes at a critical moment - Monday sees the World Trade Organisation (WTO) negotiators gathering in Geneva to start the "reform" of the agreement on agriculture.

With the epidemic of foot and mouth in the UK - the latest in a series across the globe, which are both disrupting trade and ruining many farmers - fundamental questions should at last be addressed about what should be in this agreement.

It is exactly the larger farm sizes, bigger herds, and trading and shipment of livestock over long distances, which the WTO rules encourage that has created the problems the EU is currently experiencing.

One of the first thoughts of agriculture minister Nick Brown, when he realised what the rapid sheep movements round Britain meant for the spread of foot and mouth, was that the whole system of modern livestock farming needed to be reviewed. This must include WTO rules that treat animals as a commodity.

The outcome of this renegotiation will have an impact on farmers throughout the world: the decisions will determine how our food is produced and traded, how we address issues of food shortages, and the extent to which farmers can be subsidised and supported. They will determine whether or not the environmental costs of intensive agriculture will worsen, the world's small-scale farmers will survive or go to the wall, and countries will be free to promote more socially and environmentally sustainable agricultural practices. Alternatively, they may result in farmers being pushed into cutting yet more corners in order to force the immediate costs of food production still lower.

The external costs of intensive agriculture - costs which are borne by society at large, rather than being reflected directly in the price of food - are colossal. Increased farm size under agricultural policies which discriminate against small-scale producers, increased international movement of produce and an intensification of production methods all tend to drive these external costs even higher, while leaving livestock and crops more vulnerable to pest and disease outbreaks. Although seen to be more "efficient", agriculture that depends on intensified use of external inputs - pesticides and fertilisers - and undermines the livelihoods of rural communities, is, of course, far from that. Intensive agricultural systems all too frequently exhaust those resources which are least renewable - soil, soil nutrients, and water. They may also entail huge social expense in accommodating those displaced from rural communities.

Agricultural intensification also has a direct impact on the environment. Loss of crop biodiversity entails increasing susceptibility to climatic fluctuations, vulnerability to pest outbreaks and increased reliance upon pesticides. The increased use of crop varieties dependent on higher levels of fertiliser has accelerated the loss of soil minerals. Water courses have become polluted, and soils degraded. The costs of addressing these impacts - cleaning water courses following contamination with pesticides or fertiliser run-off, for example - are immense but not paid for by farmers or the multinational companies that trade in food and animal products. But there are also the unquantifiable costs of biodiversity loss - the collapse of populations of farmland birds, for example.

These problems are not specific to developed countries. Misplaced agriculture trade policies are now exported worldwide. The drive for international competitiveness has forced many third world farmers to grow new and unfamiliar crops for export markets, undermining local food security and leaving them vulnerable to crop failure. Farmers in Andhra Pradesh in India, who recently planted large areas with a single cotton hybrid that proved particularly susceptible to insect attack, faced uncontrollable pest outbreaks and insurmountable loans. Some resorted to killing themselves, drinking the pesticides intended for their fields.

Poorly targeted interventionist policies can generate as many problems as wholesale subscription to the liberalisation agenda. Under the European common agricultural policy (CAP), production-linked subsidies have encouraged over-production, and have benefited those who produce most. With half of the CAP subsidies going to the top 17% of producers, such payments have driven intensification while failing to reduce the economic vulnerability of many farmers.

The renegotiation of the WTO agreement on agriculture, which is likely to drag on for several years, presents an opportunity to address problems such as the misplaced use of subsidies and the drive to liberalise markets in agricultural produce.

Over the course of the last few months, countries have been submitting their preliminary negotiating proposals to the WTO. Many developing countries - particularly those struggling to produce sufficient foodstuffs to provide for their domestic needs - identify the importance of finding ways in which small-scale domestic producers can be protected from cheap produce imported from elsewhere. Food insecurity threatens more than 800m people worldwide and is best addressed through local food production. But it is increasingly based on the availability of imported food, which is frequently under-priced as a result of financial incentives for over-production in developed countries, or the provision of export subsidies.

The reliability of such imports is contingent on uninterrupted transportation, and the recipient having an ongoing supply of hard currency. Failure to compete with cheap imports has undermined the production of staple foodstuffs and threatens the future of rural communities in many developing countries.

Trade policies must be constructed in such a way that they do not infringe the rights of countries to choose sustainable local production for domestic food security over and above the production of commodities for world markets. This flies in the face of the drive to liberalise markets in agricultural produce. Some countries that champion the unfettered market - at least in terms of their rhetoric - have preferred to offer the third world increased access for commodity export to markets in the North. Developing countries should not settle for such palliatives where they are bought at the cost of further erosion of their national food "sovereignty".

The RSPB thinks that the renegotiation of the agreement on agriculture should go far further. These reforms present an opportunity to begin to address the need to move towards more sustainable methods of production across the world. Current payments which support domestic production, used mainly by the OECD countries, should be more clearly targeted at environmental and rural development goals. Subsidies which merely promote increased production should be abolished.

In presenting their negotiating proposals, no country so far has identified the need for freedoms to permit the discrimination of imports on the basis of the sustainability of their production. To the WTO, restrictions on the import of produce on the grounds of methods of production is anathema. At present, WTO rules lead to production practices which wring out every possible short-term saving in the course of trying to produce more cheap food - irrespective of the environmental and social costs.

Over the last few weeks, we have been confronted by the enormity of the knock-on impacts when things go wrong with our means of food production. Changing the way we produce food will require fundamental changes in our obligations under the WTO. The opportunity presented for such changes by the renegotiation of the agreement on agriculture must not be lost. Unless the drive towards an ever freer market is moderated, high external input agriculture will continue to wreck the environment without proper internalisation of the true costs, small farmers worldwide will continue to go to the wall as the biggest grow bigger, and the domestic food security of developing countries will continue to be undermined.

Tom Crompton is the RSPB's policy officer for global agriculture and is author of Eat This: Fresh Ideas on the WTO Agreement on Agriculture, a new report by the RSPB. tom.crompton@rspb.org.uk

fields.headline: Evolution, not revolution
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: What has happened since Gordon Brown announced two months ago that "the biggest transformation in the relationship between the state and voluntary action for a century" was just beginning? Quite a bit
fields.body:
What has happened since Gordon Brown announced two months ago that "the biggest transformation in the relationship between the state and voluntary action for a century" was just beginning? Quite a bit.

First, we discovered the January initiative was a pre-emptive strike by Labour, scuppering the launch of a new Tory plan to "reform" the voluntary sector the following week. Second, we learned that the £300m over three years for voluntary action was in fact an extra £180m on top of the already announced £70m for the children's fund and £50m for deprived areas.

Third, fears that large swathes of public services were going to be switched from state to voluntary provision have been allayed. An extra £100m a year for voluntary action is welcome, but needs to be kept in perspective. At least half the voluntary sector's £14bn budget already comes from local or central government.

Fourth, the American engine for change which Tories want to copy, and to which Labour has paid lip service, has run into trouble. President Bush has set up an office for faith-based and community initiatives within the White House, but it is already under attack - not just from the left for the threat it poses to the separation of church from state, but, more surprising, from the religious right, too. They fear federal interference with their message as well as mission, and want it confined to Christians.

Where does this leave the UK? The chancellor's rhetoric ran ahead of reality. The biggest change between the state and the voluntary sector in the last 100 years will remain what happened 50 years ago: the creation of the welfare state. We know why the state took over responsibility for health, education, and social security. Voluntary effort was not enough. Charitable hospitals were, in the words of the NHS historian, in a state of anachronism, parochialism, inertia, duplication and waste.

Tony Blair got it right when he succinctly divided the last century into two: in the first half, the country learned it could not achieve its aims without the help of government; in the second, that government could not achieve the nation's aims without the help of the voluntary movement.

We do have 400,000 voluntary organisations and over 20m volunteers. But we need more. Volunteers have declined in numbers. Recruitment among the young, retired and unemployed remains low. These challenges are being addressed. New, imaginative anti-poverty programmes are embracing voluntary groups. An evolution not "a revolution". What needs changing is the leadership: the Home Office is the wrong home. Give it to the Cabinet Office, please.

fields.headline: War on waste
fields.standfirst: Mixed verdict on council services
fields.trailText: Mixed verdict on council services
fields.body:
Council environmental services, such as waste recycling, street cleaning and lighting and inspection of risky food premises, have improved in the past five years, the audit commission says today. But there remain huge disparities between neighbouring authorities.

Moreover, the quality of bin collections, the number of public toilets and the processing time for planning applications has worsened slightly, according to the commission's first report exclusively on environmental performance indicators in England.

Councils which stand out as having made gains in most or all of the services assessed include Breckland in Norfolk, Cornwall, Croydon in south London, Darlington, Devon, Kirklees in West Yorkshire, and Newham in east London.

Possibly the most dramatic improvement has been in the recycling of household waste, which has doubled since the mid-1990s. But the survey shows considerable variation: in relative terms, Stockport manages to recycle more than 30 times as much as its neighbour Manchester; similarly, in Northamptonshire, Daventry recycles 25 times the proportion achieved by Corby.

The biggest disparity in services surveyed is the time taken to give a decision on planning applications by householders. The best of the London boroughs, Newham, manages to process 85% of applications within the eight-week target set by government. The worst, Haringey in north London, achieves only 20%.

The report, which looks at performance in 1999-2000, the last year before the "best value" regime took effect, reveals that some of the best performing councils are not necessarily doing well across the board. While Islington, in north London, achieves a 100% inspection rate of high-risk food premises, it is placed bottom of the capital league when it comes to the number of public conveniences, managing just two per 100,000 residents. This compares to 20 per 100,000 residents in Greenwich, south London.

Away from towns and cities, the commission looked at footpaths and other rights of way and assessed how easy it was for the public to use them. It found a marked drop in ease of access in county council areas: only 70% of them are deemed user-friendly, a 5% deterioration over two years.

Sir Andrew Foster, the commission's controller, says most councils have risen to the challenge of improving services that affect every resident in their areas. "Nevertheless, some councils have a lot of work to do to catch up with the better performers. Best value is shining an ever brighter spotlight to show local people how their councils are performing and what improvements could be made."

Local Authority Performance Indicators 1999-2000: Environmental Services in England is available at £20 from Audit Commission Publications on 0800 502030, or at www.audit-commission.gov.uk

webTitle: The role GPs can play in helping heroin addicts

fields.headline: Dose of good sense
fields.standfirst: By the time hospital treatment is offered to heroin users who want to kick their addiction, it may be too late. So could GPs offer a solution?  Clare Wilson reports
fields.trailText: By the time hospital treatment is offered to heroin users who want to kick their addiction, it may be too late. So could GPs offer a solution? Clare Wilson reports
fields.body:
Getting heroin users to admit they need medical help is a key factor in determining whether they can overcome their addiction. So imagine the frustration of addicts and their families when, having made that crucial step, they face a waiting list for treatment of several months. By the time their turn for treatment arrives, many will have given up waiting and may be either untraceable or have lost their resolve.

According to Mark McPherson, operations manager at addiction charity Turning Point, this is a frequent occurrence. "Drug users aren't like people waiting for a hip transplant - they can't just sit at home until the hospital is ready for them," he says. "Drug users can have very chaotic lifestyles. Time and time again when their turn comes up, we have lost track of them."

As with many NHS services, the problem stems from lack of manpower and resources. Many heroin addicts are helped by methadone maintenance programmes, requiring regular doctors' prescriptions of the legal drug so that patients can stabilise their habit, then gradually reduce the dose. A shortage of specialist clinics, where doctors will prescribe methadone, is a key factor causing waiting lists to build up.

There is, however, an alternative solution. The country's 36,000 GPs are legally allowed to prescribe methadone - and, it can be argued, they are ideally placed to help drug users. A GP is cheaper than a hospital doctor and will often know the heroin user and his or her family personally.

However, very few GPs are willing to prescribe methadone. Simon Fradd, a member of the GPs' committee of the British Medical Association (BMA), says many doctors have had - or have heard of - off-putting experiences with drug users. "Many drug addicts are extremely manipulative and many GPs get drawn into this area without adequate training," he says. "Sometimes the addicts can start selling the methadone or may overdose on it - and then the doctor may find themselves up before the General Medical Council in danger of being struck off."

Some GPs are also put off by the labour-intensive nature of treating drug users, at a time when their workload seems to be ever increasing. And others may even believe that their time is better spent on patients whose condition is not "their own fault".

McPherson says: "I'm sure there are prejudices about it. Drug users are certainly not being embraced by GPs. There's a sort of fear of the risks that they pose - to the GP and also to themselves."

Not all family doctors refuse to treat drug users. A new scheme in Middlesbrough is expected to treat 500 users at one practice. But in some parts of the country, particularly rural areas, there is a dearth of any GPs willing to prescribe methadone.

McPherson says: "In areas where there isn't a visible drug problem, GPs say it isn't a priority for them. One GP claimed to me there weren't any addicts in his area and I knew there were at least 20. The irony is that rural areas are the very places where primary care services are most needed, because the hospitals are further away."

Recently, however, there have been signs that attitudes among GPs are changing. The BMA and the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) - the two main groups representing family doctors - have agreed a policy statement acknowledging that GPs have a role to play in this area. It says that drug users should be able to get their basic health services from GPs and specialist treatment from either hospital doctors or GPs, stressing that family doctors "should offer appropriate care to all patients on their lists".

The RCGP is also setting up special training courses for GPs, teaching them how to prescribe methadone safely and recommending techniques for ensuring they are not fooled by users into overprescribing. To encourage GPs to take the courses, the government has made money available to help them cover the cost of hiring locum doctors when they are absent from their surgeries.

Clare Gerada, a south London GP who has set up her own clinic for treating drug users, hopes that all these measures will encourage growing numbers of family doctors to take on this field of work. She describes the BMA/RCGP statement as a "watershed" in attitudes to methadone prescribing, saying: "We are coming of age. At last we will start playing our part."

Gerada, who has advised the Department of Health on drug abuse policies, says: "Drug users prefer to receive their treatment from us. We're community based, open at all hours, and accessed through self-referral. We are also used to treating the different needs of patients - social, physical, and psychological. GPs should be the backbone of treatment services."

The government seems to be using the carrot-and-stick approach to getting family doctors to shoulder more of the burden of treating drug users. As well as helping GPs get training, the health department is in the process of setting up a new agency to set standards and monitor services across England.

From April, the national treatment agency, as it will be called, will assess both specialist and GP services to ensure certain standards are being met within local areas. The quality of addiction services varies notoriously. One of the agency's aims will be to bring all areas up to national targets. That way, family doctors who choose not to work in this field would be able to refer their patients on to colleagues who do.

One model is to provide "shared care", where GPs do some of the work, with back-up from hospital doctors for some of the more time-consuming and specialist services. The ultimate aim is to ensure that primary care services no longer abandon responsibility for this vulnerable patient group.

Gerada says: "If GPs refer drug users on to someone up the road who has more training in methadone prescribing, that's fine. But they should not just refuse because they don't like the patients. We need to see patients like human beings, as opposed to some sort of Martian."

The Guardian, together with Turning Point and Pavilion Publishing, is staging a major conference on the national treatment agency and its implications. The event will be in London on June 21. Details from Pavilion on 01273-623222.

Latest official figures show an estimated rise of 7% in just six months in the number of people coming forward for help with drug habits.

The figures show that more than 39,000 people in Britain presented to drug treatment agencies for the first time, or the first time for six months, in the six-month period ending March 31 last year. Just over half were in their 20s and a further one in seven was even younger.

Heroin was the most frequently reported main drug of use, in 61% of cases, and methadone accounted for another 11%. Men outnumbered women drug users by three to one.

Of almost 34,000 episodes of treatment provided in England alone during the period - almost double the number in an equivalent six months in 1993 - just over 1,800 were reported by GPs. The great majority (more than 26,600) were delivered by community-based drugs services.

Analysis of the 1998 British Crime Survey, the most recent to have been studied, showed that 14% of men and 8% of women admitted using drugs in the previous year. In the 16-24 age range, however, these proportions rose respectively to 36% and 25%.

Overwhelmingly, the drug of use was cannabis. Only 1% of people of all ages admitted to having ever used heroin, but 9% said they had taken cocaine.

Despite the survey's confidentiality, the figures are likely to have been underestimates. Home Office researchers calculated on the basis of the findings that up to 2m people in England and Wales had used some kind of drug in the previous year

fields.headline: Walls of sound
fields.standfirst: Even hard cases in a high-security prison can be touched by the therapeutic power, and fun, of music.  John Cunningham reports
fields.trailText: Even hard cases in a high-security prison can be touched by the therapeutic power, and fun, of music. John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
In the prison gym, a group of men rhythmically stamp their feet and chant in unison. It's not a protest about poor equipment or conditions, but something more constructive: the sound of music in the making.

Chanting and stamping are the warm-up; after three two-hour sessions over a week, the participants will put on a show on the final evening, much of it their own material. It is the sort of rehearsal familiar to amateur performers, but for a group including murderers, sex offenders and violent burglars, to be doing this in a high security prison is highly unusual.

But Grendon prison, in Buckinghamshire, is unusual: the only British prison offering a therapeutic regime of education and personal development for up to 230 inmates. Men can ask to be transferred here from other institutions. If they are assessed as suitable, it takes 18 to 24 months for the programme to show results, says education officer Jill Lewis, who prefers to describe the regime as challenging rather than liberal.

The group running the workshop is out of the ordinary, too. The six classical musicians of the Oxford Concert Party (OCP) have been working in prisons, hospitals, hospices and residential homes for almost a decade. They are basically a chamber ensemble with a sense of humour, describ ing themselves as Europe's only baroque and tango orchestra. They have done tours and TV, and been voted pick of the fringe at the Edinburgh Festival.

As well as composing and recording music, and playing the accordion and harpsichord, artistic director Arne Richards is an authority on music for healing. "There's no deep philosophy behind it, but music does have great transformative power," he says. "Certain types of music can help people, where other types can have a negative effect. For instance, physically handicapped people may react badly to music with a strong rhythmic content. In a prison, you can soon see what does or does not work.

"There's a highly charged atmosphere in a place like Whitemoor [high-security prison in Cambridgeshire]. To harness that high energy through music is a most wonderful experience. We've seen people in tears, tapping their feet, laughing for joy, no matter how reluctant they were before the performance."

The potential effect of professional musicians working with prisoners became clear when, as violinist Isabel Knowland, Richards's wife, explains, they found after one of their first prison concerts that the men wanted the "hands-on communication" of trying the instruments. And so the workshops started.

It remains a mystery to Richards how, after the chaos of the first two sessions, the pieces the inmates have brought to play or sing, and the improvisations he gives them, always cohere into a smooth third session and then a final performance - all accomplished within eight hours.

The aim is clear: to increase the men's self-confidence and sharpen their sense of identity. It is the policy of governor Tim Newell to invite music and other groups to supplement Grendon's core education programme. Lewis is sure the workshops bring results. "It's a definite learning curve for [prisoners] to realise they can entertain other people," she says. "There's a definite growth in self- esteem, when the law has told you you're a load of rubbish."

By the second session of the workshop, some of that confidence has begun to emerge. So has rather a lot of talent. George is rehearsing his bagpipes solo; Noel, with recent events in mind, has written a dramatic poem about a rail disaster, for which OCP musicians will provide a soundtrack; John is playing the electric guitar; Tom, as well as having poems published in OCP's newsletter, is going through his saxophone solo.

The two hours are broken into a time for improvising in small groups. Each is given a theme, such as a circus or a procession, which will be interspersed into a longer work Richards and his musicians will play at the concert. Sounds weird, but Richards is a great blender and bender of world music. He might include in the programme anything from Argentinian tangos to Irish laments, but he says it always works.

The buzz starts early in the session. There is a soundtrack of drumming, but, strangely, no one is letting rip. It's all taut self-controlled. Richards does not raise his voice and hardly seems to be pulling things together, but a process is at work.

George, serving a sentence for a murder he committed at 16, has performed at previous workshops. "The first time, the adrenalin was running down my back," he recalls. But don't other inmates get annoyed by the wailing pipes when he is practising? "If you're liked, you can get away with anything," he grins.

Grendon, which has an education budget of £400,000 (shared with Spring Hill prison on the same site) pays for a local RAF pipe major to coach George. John, similarly, has lessons with a professional guitarist. He, too, is inside for a murder committed as a teenager - "a paedophile abusing kids in my area," he says.

The guitar has been his salvation; he has been passionate about it since he was 16. Now, through the opportunity to play in prison, he sees himself as a guitarist, with a plausible career he hopes to take up on his release.

But for all the relative liberalism of the regime, and a timetable which allows men out of their cells for most of the day, these are pent-up men. John, taking a break with a roll-up and a mug of black coffee, says it is difficult to relate to others in the group who are at different levels "musically and intellectually".

Despite such frustrations, music has been his saviour. "When I started, it was a bit of an ego trip," says John. "I wanted to play rock guitar. But after two years, it became more genuine. But it's not about competing; it's about working as a team."

The team, in turn, is part of a wider community of music. For Grendon has its graduates: two former prisoners, who have participated in workshops, have returned to help with this one. One, a former sex offender, will be singing an aria or two in the final concert. Another was sent to Grendon for protesting at nuclear bases; he is now a music student at Oxford Brookes University, and says OCP's workshops impressed him because they're "all very egalitarian; everyone gets a chance to do a piece".

Some unlikely characters turn up, too. Knowland says: "Some of the men are very musical and skilled. But some haven't touched an instrument in their lives, or heard anything that wasn't either rock or pop."

The only puzzle is that, of the circle in the gym, only about a dozen are prisoners. A pity that such an excellent project (it costs £3,000 to stage a workshop) does not get bigger numbers. "There are other things on tonight," explains one participant. "It clashes with their programmes. And most of the guys would probably rather be watching telly."

All names of prisoners have been changed. Information on OCP at www.classical-artists.com/oxford-concert-party

fields.headline: People's palaces
fields.standfirst: Many local councils are adopting a new approach to public accountability. And even the buildings that house them must shape up to an era of access, argue  Matthew Taylor and  Becky Hatch
fields.trailText: Many local councils are adopting a new approach to public accountability. And even the buildings that house them must shape up to an era of access, argue Matthew Taylor and Becky Hatch
fields.body:
New local government reforms will raise the profile of council leaders and improve decision-making and accountability. But as councillors become community champions, rather than committee fodder as at present, they will find their roles constrained by the physical layout of town halls designed for a rather different mode of running our towns and cities.

We need a new generation of town halls to put councils at the centre of civic renewal - buildings designed to promote local government's new values of accountability, inclusiveness and transparency, and help close the gap between citizens and representatives. Councils should consult their communities about designing these buildings to reflect the present and future aspirations of towns and cities.

As a preparatory step, experts in local government, architecture and civic renewal are taking part in a project, organised by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and the Design Council, to investigate how local government can promote its new values through architecture and, specifically, the ways in which the new town hall can reinvigorate community democracy and civic debate.

Many existing British town halls are impressive, beautiful landmarks built by the Victorians in a spirit of optimism. It was the heyday of prestige for elected representatives. Town halls were built in celebration of municipal prosperity and unity, councillors competing with rival towns for the most ostentatious seat of power. They were an affirmation of local government and expressed civic pride in the town and its councillors alike.

The buildings sustained and encouraged this boosterish attitude, and helped to build up a sense of identity and community in burgeoning Victorian towns. They were opened with huge celebrations, were widely used by the local people, and formed a focal point for the community. Many of these splendid municipal piles survive: they're well-known, well-used and well-loved. But, in planning their replacements more in tune with the needs of communities in the 21st century, care must be taken not to lose these positive associations.

Victorian town halls were constructed to awe and even intimidate visitors with their opulence, and they also imply the elitism and the impregnable nature of the council's proceedings and its members and officials. They were constructed around a large central hall, surrounded by offices and often without windows. The insular, secretive and decadent implications of such buildings - for instance, Manchester's town hall - are precisely what the modernisation of local government seeks to get away from.

By contrast, the evolution of local government in the post-war decades produced buildings which emphasised the functional and administrative role of councils. Town halls were designed more functionally as administrative spaces, without showy trappings. The council chamber itself was now sidelined, often tucked at the back of the building. Town halls of this period were run as large office complexes - often laid out to meet the needs of staff rather than citizens. But with our current emphasis on public engagement in scrutiny, these buildings are not satisfactory either. To have decision-making processes and scrutiny panels meeting in the least accessible part of the building creates an unhelpful impression of the balance of power and of the council's attitude to transparency.

The design of a building has a profound effect on its atmosphere and the behaviour of those inside it. A transparent meeting space which the public can access at any time is likely to encourage a more open and efficient style of council meeting.

A town hall conceived on these lines would tip the balance away from political theatrics, and towards practical solutions. When building the new Reichstag in Berlin, after the reunification of Germany, Sir Norman Foster, a British architect, put a glass-domed roof over the parliament chamber, which was below ground level, so that the public could literally look down on the politicians.

The effects of this symbolism on the relationship between electors and elected should not be underestimated. If the council chamber is at the back of the building, councillors' perception of their roles will tend to focus on administration and bureaucracy; if the chamber is in the midst of the community, the community-leader role will be more dominant. It is hard to be outward-looking and open-minded in a closed room without windows. The interests of the community will be more immediate when you can see locals outside.

So the design and the utilisation of our new civil offices should focus on serving the community. There should be a one-stop shop for all council services, and there should be extensive space for galleries, community projects - and for just chatting with friends and neighbours. To include shops and other facilities, such as creches, would encourage wider use and recognition of the area - although the space should be regarded primarily as a place for democracy and community.

The government has put forward proposals to modernise and streamline civil law courts. Court buildings could be included in the new town halls, so that the justice system could also benefit from the atmosphere of transparency and accountability. Town halls should welcome all tiers of government, as well as other community groups or quangos, with an emphasis on promoting interaction between the different groups and sharing resources. This could go some way towards addressing the democratic deficit in the NHS, the police and quangos.

Local MPs and MEPs could hold their surgeries in the building. Community groups or school groups could hold public meetings within specially designed areas. And space could also be set aside as a Speaker's Corner, to allow members of the public to voice their own political opinions.

The construction of a new town hall is a forward-looking, exciting project which will arouse local interest and is a good way to renew inter est in public participation. Large-scale architectural projects also bring publicity and recognition to an area. The prize-winning Peckham library, south London, designed by Alsop & Stormer, is an example of a public building bringing positive media attention to an area of urban deprivation.

Instead of looking back to the glory of former days, local government needs to take up its place in the democratic spaces of the future.

Matthew Taylor is director of IPPR and Becky Hatch is an IPPR researcher.

Pattern of democracy

Playing at Kubla Khan is the last thing on the minds of most contemporary councillors, who doubt the public's enthusiasm for any more large town halls, however full of access ramps and glass roofs they may be.

"People still write to the local paper complaining that we knocked the old one down," says Colin Anderson, leader of Sunderland city council, which boasts the biggest - and perhaps architecturally best - civic centre of the late 20th century.

Flooded with light, and Babylonian in its wealth of gentle terraces, indoor galleries and tumbling plants, the building was designed by Sir Basil Spence, of Coventry Cathedral fame, with very democratic ideas in mind. Spence once explained that his pattern of hexagons was designed to be "informal and allowing free pedestrian movement to all parts".

This works, says Anderson, in terms of the courtyards in the middle of the hexagons - and the absence of puffed-up civic pride. He says: "The centre is big, but not overwhelming. It has more of the air of an office block than anything grandiose."

After only 30 years, though, the centre is being renovated, partly to help the public find their way through a well-intentioned but bewildering arrangement of approach paths and ramps.

Council taxpayers quite properly want the council to come to them, rather than to set out its stall on a central hill. Anderson says: "We've surely seen the end of the golden age of building new town halls. The real answer is to devolve our services to local centres; to give people mini-town halls on their doorstep."

This is what has happened in Leeds, which has possibly the most grandiose town hall in Britain, though now it is used only for concerts and conferences. The staff the public need to reach - for benefits, housing or environmental issues - are accessible in 13 "one-stop shops" across the city.

This change has been so successful that the results were featured, ironically, in a Channel 4 probe into stress, which showed what happens when public inquiries rise from 290 to 700 a day, but staff numbers fail to keep pace. Even at the height of the queues, though, the main one-stop building in the centre of Leeds was registering satisfaction rates of more than 60%.

That rate has now reached 95% - an increase helped by the smart conversion of two redundant schools and a former printing works by Leeds civic architect John Thorp. "We were saving three listed Victorian buildings, but the entrances needed to be welcoming, bright and especially visible, so you can see the staff before you go inside," Thorp says. "It's a matter of changing the buildings' mood, and I think we have."

What matters most is that the flagship one-stop shop in Leeds makes good financial sense. Opened in 1995, just before the city's boom in property prices, the conversion cost £7m - and saved £12m through staff moves from other dreary premises. The freehold is worth £14m to the city council. "We haven't sold the family silver," says Thorp. "We've found a way of using it to make more."

fields.bodyText: New local government reforms will raise the profile of council leaders and improve decision-making and accountability. But as councillors become community champions, rather than committee fodder as at present, they will find their roles constrained by the physical layout of town halls designed for a rather different mode of running our towns and cities. We need a new generation of town halls to put councils at the centre of civic renewal - buildings designed to promote local government's new values of accountability, inclusiveness and transparency, and help close the gap between citizens and representatives. Councils should consult their communities about designing these buildings to reflect the present and future aspirations of towns and cities. As a preparatory step, experts in local government, architecture and civic renewal are taking part in a project, organised by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and the Design Council, to investigate how local government can promote its new values through architecture and, specifically, the ways in which the new town hall can reinvigorate community democracy and civic debate. Many existing British town halls are impressive, beautiful landmarks built by the Victorians in a spirit of optimism. It was the heyday of prestige for elected representatives. Town halls were built in celebration of municipal prosperity and unity, councillors competing with rival towns for the most ostentatious seat of power. They were an affirmation of local government and expressed civic pride in the town and its councillors alike. The buildings sustained and encouraged this boosterish attitude, and helped to build up a sense of identity and community in burgeoning Victorian towns. They were opened with huge celebrations, were widely used by the local people, and formed a focal point for the community. Many of these splendid municipal piles survive: they're well-known, well-used and well-loved. But, in planning their replacements more in tune with the needs of communities in the 21st century, care must be taken not to lose these positive associations. Victorian town halls were constructed to awe and even intimidate visitors with their opulence, and they also imply the elitism and the impregnable nature of the council's proceedings and its members and officials. They were constructed around a large central hall, surrounded by offices and often without windows. The insular, secretive and decadent implications of such buildings - for instance, Manchester's town hall - are precisely what the modernisation of local government seeks to get away from. By contrast, the evolution of local government in the post-war decades produced buildings which emphasised the functional and administrative role of councils. Town halls were designed more functionally as administrative spaces, without showy trappings. The council chamber itself was now sidelined, often tucked at the back of the building. Town halls of this period were run as large office complexes - often laid out to meet the needs of staff rather than citizens. But with our current emphasis on public engagement in scrutiny, these buildings are not satisfactory either. To have decision-making processes and scrutiny panels meeting in the least accessible part of the building creates an unhelpful impression of the balance of power and of the council's attitude to transparency. The design of a building has a profound effect on its atmosphere and the behaviour of those inside it. A transparent meeting space which the public can access at any time is likely to encourage a more open and efficient style of council meeting. A town hall conceived on these lines would tip the balance away from political theatrics, and towards practical solutions. When building the new Reichstag in Berlin, after the reunification of Germany, Sir Norman Foster, a British architect, put a glass-domed roof over the parliament chamber, which was below ground level, so that the public could literally look down on the politicians. The effects of this symbolism on the relationship between electors and elected should not be underestimated. If the council chamber is at the back of the building, councillors' perception of their roles will tend to focus on administration and bureaucracy; if the chamber is in the midst of the community, the community-leader role will be more dominant. It is hard to be outward-looking and open-minded in a closed room without windows. The interests of the community will be more immediate when you can see locals outside. So the design and the utilisation of our new civil offices should focus on serving the community. There should be a one-stop shop for all council services, and there should be extensive space for galleries, community projects - and for just chatting with friends and neighbours. To include shops and other facilities, such as creches, would encourage wider use and recognition of the area - although the space should be regarded primarily as a place for democracy and community. The government has put forward proposals to modernise and streamline civil law courts. Court buildings could be included in the new town halls, so that the justice system could also benefit from the atmosphere of transparency and accountability. Town halls should welcome all tiers of government, as well as other community groups or quangos, with an emphasis on promoting interaction between the different groups and sharing resources. This could go some way towards addressing the democratic deficit in the NHS, the police and quangos. Local MPs and MEPs could hold their surgeries in the building. Community groups or school groups could hold public meetings within specially designed areas. And space could also be set aside as a Speaker's Corner, to allow members of the public to voice their own political opinions. The construction of a new town hall is a forward-looking, exciting project which will arouse local interest and is a good way to renew inter est in public participation. Large-scale architectural projects also bring publicity and recognition to an area. The prize-winning Peckham library, south London, designed by Alsop & Stormer, is an example of a public building bringing positive media attention to an area of urban deprivation. Instead of looking back to the glory of former days, local government needs to take up its place in the democratic spaces of the future. Matthew Taylor is director of IPPR and Becky Hatch is an IPPR researcher. Pattern of democracy Playing at Kubla Khan is the last thing on the minds of most contemporary councillors, who doubt the public's enthusiasm for any more large town halls, however full of access ramps and glass roofs they may be. "People still write to the local paper complaining that we knocked the old one down," says Colin Anderson, leader of Sunderland city council, which boasts the biggest - and perhaps architecturally best - civic centre of the late 20th century. Flooded with light, and Babylonian in its wealth of gentle terraces, indoor galleries and tumbling plants, the building was designed by Sir Basil Spence, of Coventry Cathedral fame, with very democratic ideas in mind. Spence once explained that his pattern of hexagons was designed to be "informal and allowing free pedestrian movement to all parts". This works, says Anderson, in terms of the courtyards in the middle of the hexagons - and the absence of puffed-up civic pride. He says: "The centre is big, but not overwhelming. It has more of the air of an office block than anything grandiose." After only 30 years, though, the centre is being renovated, partly to help the public find their way through a well-intentioned but bewildering arrangement of approach paths and ramps. webTitle: Survey reveals public still ignorant on discrimination issues

fields.headline: In the dark on disability
fields.standfirst: Survey reveals public still ignorant on discrimination issues
fields.trailText: Survey reveals public still ignorant on discrimination issues
fields.body:
Widespread ignorance about who is covered by the Disability Discrimination Act, and widely differing views of what the public regards as disability, have been revealed in a survey for the disability rights commission.

Only half of 2,000 people questioned had heard of the 1995 law, which aims to protect the rights of disabled people. And of those who were aware of the act, only 48% thought it covered Aids, 52% long-term heart conditions, 50% facial disfigurement and 44% cancer. In fact, it is illegal to discriminate against people with any of these conditions.

Overall, the survey found that many people had a limited notion of the extent and nature of disability. There are some 8.5m disabled people in Britain, but when asked what proportion of them used wheelchairs, 46% of respondents said up to a quarter, and 22% about half. The reality is that fewer than 5% of disabled people use a wheelchair. More encouragingly, the survey findings do show a general recognition that disabled people are not treated fairly by society, with 50% agreeing this is so.

Asked if disabled people should have the same right to vote as the rest of the population, only 1% said they should not. But 17% reckoned there could be occasions when it might be justifiable to treat them less favourably.

Paul Gemmill, the commission's policy director, says the findings show that a majority of the public realises there is still considerable discrimination against disabled people, and a real lack of awareness of their rights under law.

The commission, set up a year ago, does not itself emerge from the survey with a high public recognition rating. Of those questioned last month by BMRB, 76% had not heard of it and only 19% said they had. More alarmingly, 71% of disabled people - one in 10 of the sample - had not heard of it and just 24% were aware of its existence.

In an attempt to raise its profile, the commission is embarking on a series of initiatives - the latest of which is a drive to emphasise the rights of disabled customers. A poster and local advertising campaign has been launched, with supermarkets and travel companies in particular being reminded of their obligations.

The commission has also set up a conciliation service to help settle discrimination disputes between businesses and disabled people without the need to go to court. Bert Massie, who chairs the commission, says: "We know from thousands of calls to our helpline that disabled people get a raw deal as customers on a daily basis.

"Disabled people have around £40bn a year to spend - a fact that business owners and service providers need to bear in mind."

The commission's helpline is 08457-622633

webTitle: Pressure on government to reward charity commitment

fields.headline: Cutting to the core
fields.standfirst: Pressure on government to reward charity commitment
fields.trailText: Pressure on government to reward charity commitment
fields.body:
Charities that enter into long-term commitments to provide services on behalf of national or local government should be rewarded with state funding of their core costs, a voluntary sector leader is proposing.

The idea of a council-style "revenue support grant" for the not-for-profit sector will prove controversial. But Stephen Bubb, chief executive of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (Acevo), insists the time has come for radical thinking on the core costs issue.

"Frankly, if the government wants to deliver mainstream services through the sector, then we need to have a grown-up conversation about the relationship," says Bubb. "The compact [the 1998 agreement between the government and the voluntary sector] pretends it's a relationship of equals, but everybody knows it just ain't so.

"The thinking is still about supplicant and donor. The sector needs to be saying: 'Yes, we are prepared to enter this or that arrangement, but these are the rules from our side'."

His comments come after Acevo yesterday published a new edition of its 1999 report, Who Pays for Core Costs?, which touched a nerve in the charity world and quickly sold out. The report, by Julia Unwin, exposed the way in which many charities were feeling trapped by a short-term funding culture that hampered their development.

The new publication, Funding Our Future - Core Costs Revisited, is an update by Unwin endorsed by three voluntary sector heavyweights: the Charity Finance Direc tors' Group, the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers and the Directory of Social Change (DSC), the sector's leading research and training body.

Mike Eastwood, DRC director, says in a commentary in the new report that the current funding environment is "deeply unsatisfactory", and runs counter to the sustenance of stable and mature voluntary organisations. "It even encourages a degree of dishonesty in the funding relationship through a constant pressure - actual or implied - to present existing work as if it is new. It creates great insecurity for service users because providers are unable to guarantee continuity of delivery."

While government has shifted decisively from making grants to offering service contracts, a three-year funding cycle has been adopted widely by grant-makers, including the national lottery charities board. Eastwood cites one officer of a grant-making trust as saying that a charity had "gone rather boring on us" by opting to focus on incremental development of its existing services, rather than anything new.

Unwin proposes three models of funding to break the mould: "full project" funding, in which all reasonable associated costs are built in; "development" funding, through which infrastructure costs are met for a time in order to enable the service provider to grow and develop; and "strategic" funding, by which a funder recognises a need for the provider to exist to meet its own (the funder's) objectives and is prepared to contribute over an agreed period of time.

Bubb is keen to take the debate still wider. Ministers, he says, will fail to achieve their aim of a huge increase in volunteering unless voluntary organisations are resourced to offer management and leadership.

Anticipating the argument that state funding of core costs would undermine charities' independence, Bubb says: "We would need to make clear that one of our rules is that we remain free to criticise. We don't expect the government to come back with: 'We don't like what you say; what chance your next revenue grant?'"

Funding Our Future is available at £25 inc. from Acevo, Middlesex House, 130 College Road, Harrow, HA1 1BQ (020-8424 2334).

fields.headline: House officer, Doncaster royal infirmary
fields.standfirst:
Helen Linklater
Salary: £17,260
fields.trailText:
Helen Linklater
Salary: £17,260
fields.body:
The house officer is the most junior doctor. We do the day-to-day tasks of medical management, ordering investigations, responding to changes in the patient's condition. If the nurses are concerned, we're the first people to be called. But if there's anything that might be serious then we call senior members of the team.

It tends to be a nine-to-five day, generally busy, getting called all the time for what can be little things. At the beginning I wasn't leaving till 6.30 or7pm - and when it does get very busy it can be difficult to leave, because you know some of your patients are quite ill. I've frequently left late and rarely leave dead on time.

I also do one in five nights resident on-call. I get protected sleep so from midnight I am actually covered by my senior house officer until eight o'clock the next morning.

There's a lot of educational supervision, a lot of support - and a fantastic sense of teamwork that you only get in a public service. The NHS really is a good thing to work for if you believe in it - and I think most of us do - although it's grossly under-resourced. There's only one solution, and that's more staff.

Unfortunately there's a culture of complaints, and some patients have lost their trust in doctors altogether. Often they perceive doctors as being quite dishonest and uncaring, and doctor-bashing in the media reinforces that.

I feel I have enough money, and have no complaints about that. But this has to be balanced against the responsibilities, the conditions, the intensity of work and stress of the job. We're underpaid for what we do - but the public still perceives us to be rich.

fields.headline: Executive assistant, British Film Institute
fields.standfirst:
Karen Aniola
Salary: £18,000 - £26,000
fields.trailText:
Karen Aniola
Salary: £18,000 - £26,000
fields.body:
I have been in my current position a year and I have been with the BFI for three years. I oversee the secretary to the director, make sure Jon's [Jon Teckman, BFI director] PA work is taken care of, and organise and sit in on meetings. There is also liaising between Jon and his managers, and I look after the board of governors and see to their needs.

Joan Bakewell is our chair and the governors include Barry Norman and Terry Gilliam. I enjoy working with them - they are doing it for the benefit of the public and to promote film education.

I get general inquiries [from the public] - they come to me first and I direct them on to the relevant person or try and deal with them myself. There are so many different types of requests. Sometimes it is to do with a problem they are having with getting a film out of a collection.

Compared to the private sector it is much more laid-back, friendly and relaxed. I feel quite valued. It depends on your manager. I'm lucky - I've got a good boss who does value me. I do get less than in the private sector. I know I could get more for doing this kind of job but I'm quite happy here and there are benefits to this job. It is so varied - my job can be so many different things.

Encouraging staff to move up their grades and positions has never really been our priority in the past. That is one of the things Jon Teckman is trying to sort out now. If someone is doing their job well, managers are reluctant for them to move up out of that position.

And the BFI runs the London Film Festival, so I get to go to premieres and events during the festival.

fields.headline: Head gardener, Aberystwyth University
fields.standfirst:
Joy Harris
Salary: £14,000-£20,000
fields.trailText:
Joy Harris
Salary: £14,000-£20,000
fields.body:
I have been a professional gardener since 1983 and I have worked at the university for 12 years. To be honest, I went into the public sector because working as a private gardener, especially around here, is quite precarious. You are very climate dependent. If the weather is bad, you can't work and you don't get paid. I wanted job security, paid holidays and the opportunity to work on a larger scale.

My motivation now? I take great pride in what we do. We are creating and maintaining gardens for anyone who wants to come and enjoy them. It's not like working in a domestic garden which will only be seen by a few people. Our gardens are for the whole community. We have a responsibility.

You need to have long term vision and patience. It can take years for trees and plants to mature. There are sometimes conflicts between the needs of the gardens and the needs of the university. The university is expanding, which means new buildings and a lot of disruption. When things get destroyed or damaged, I take it personally. It can be soul destroying - I think of the plants and flowers as living things, not just a commodity.

The job has changed enormously since I started. We are much more conscious of finance and the need to be competitive, the need to get 'best value' for money. There is more paperwork and administration than there used to be. Staffing levels have dropped and we are more streamlined.

Apart from me, there are now nine full-time gardeners and we take on six 'summer hands.' The other gardeners are paid between £9,000 and £13,000 a year. I am on a clerical rate in a band between £14,000 and £20,000.

Wages in Wales generally are lower than the national average and that includes gardening, so I am not sure we would be any better off in the private sector. If I was prepared to move areas and leave the public sector, I could earn a lot more, but I am not prepared to move to another part of the country. One of my earliest memories was experiencing the magic of my mother's garden. I still find the gardens magical and like to think I am creating something for the future."

fields.headline: Street cleaner, Islington
fields.standfirst:
Peter Routledge
Salary: £12,000
fields.trailText:
Peter Routledge
Salary: £12,000
fields.body:
I start work at 11am and finish around 6pm. We work three staggered shifts and I'm on the middle one. It's good for me because it means I can walk Petra, my dog, before I have to get in to work. The stretch I clean is Essex Road to Newington Green roundabout. We call ourselves "drivers", but our official title is "machine minders". First thing I do is go to Albany Place depot and check the machine over.

If there's anything wrong we have to take out the barrow and broom and sweep the old way. I did that for five years. In those days I started at 6am, so you always hope the machine's all right. You're not allowed to listen to music or have a radio while you're driving. I suppose that's reasonable given that you're often working on the pavement and you need your concentration. It can get very cold though, as you can imagine. I've got some special extra-chunky mittens so that my hands grip properly in the winter.

Our job's now run as a joint venture between Islington council and a private company, ICLS. That happened in 1998. So although we work for a private company the job hasn't been privatised or fallen into that Tory idea of compulsory tendering. Our contracts stayed more or less the same. I've heard rumours that in other jobs no longer run directly by the council people have lost a lot in the way of benefits, but I don't know how true that is.

On Mondays I certainly get job satisfaction. It's the worst day for rubbish because there's only a skeleton staff on at weekends. When I look back at the street I've just done and all the piles of rubbish are gone and it's clean, I'm pleased. Driving the machine you get every response you can imagine, from the man who threatened to kill me - although I was never sure if it was me or the machine he hated most - to the woman recently who came out of a shop and apologised profusely for walking into my brushes."

fields.headline: Capital financial planner, Somerset
fields.standfirst:
Patricia Walford
Salary: £30,000
fields.trailText:
Patricia Walford
Salary: £30,000
fields.body:
In my role as capital financial planner, I am responsible for advising on the financial aspects of capital investment plans for the council's services, which include schools, social services, transport and a range of other services provided to the community. There are too many competing needs to satisfy within the limited money available and careful consideration of the financial options is necessary.

I have four children who are still quite young, and my husband has tended to do most of the childcare. He took a career break five years ago to be there for the kids, whilst I have been the main breadwinner. I do find my job quite demanding at times, and I often find it difficult to balance the demands of my family and my work.

I've been doing this job for five years. Unfortunately, like a lot of people who are employed in local government, I feel unfulfilled. There are many major new initiatives facing us and, although this creates a positive and challenging environment, we feel thinly spread.

Despite all of these problems though, I wouldn't want to work for a private company. I think that once you have worked in the public sector for a long time you develop a commitment to that kind of role and it is very hard to leave it behind.

fields.headline: Porter, Queen Elizabeth hospital, Birmingham
fields.standfirst:
Peter Hilton
Salary: £9,000
fields.trailText:
Peter Hilton
Salary: £9,000
fields.body:
Portering isn't like it used to be. People think it's all about grabbing a patient, putting them on a trolley or in a wheelchair and taking them down to the ward. But in fact we're a lot more involved with the patients, talking with them, calming them down, fetching bloods, holding the portable oxygen and the monitoring equipment when they're being rushed to treatment.

I'm a head porter responsible for 30 staff. I get into work at 1.30pm and we do the handover, but after that it's never predictable. Yesterday there was a fire alarm, so we had to investigate the fire and block off the corridors.

Otherwise, when patients come into casualty the sister will call the porters and we'll have to respond immediately. We log all our jobs on a computer these days.

My favourite times are when we go up to the local playing field to set up the helicopter landing pad to receive patients. We let off a flare and make sure traffic from the pad to the hospital is clear. The bad times, in terms of emergencies, I think you can deal with: you have to learn, not exactly to switch off, but to cope.

So the real bad times are actually when other members of staff talk down to you because of the job you're doing. All the porters come across that. Portering and catering just aren't recognised properly in the NHS, but they're its starting-point, I think: patients need food, they need bloods, they need the rubbish to be emptied.

That said, in the NHS, you've got more security and opportunities than the private sector - I've just finished an NVQ in management, organised through the hospital. Sure, you can get more money in private hospitals, but not the security. And the fact that we're working for the national health service, is what keeps us going. Well, it's certainly not the money that keeps us going.

webTitle: Second Secretary (Economic Financial) British embassy, Tokyo

fields.headline: Second Secretary (Economic Financial) British embassy, Tokyo
fields.standfirst:
Nick Bridge
Salary: £22,000
fields.trailText:
Nick Bridge
Salary: £22,000
fields.body:
I'm lucky to be in a very interesting job that doesn't necessarily fit the image of the strait-laced civil servant. So much depends on where you are and when - and right now this is a very exciting time to be in this part of the world. Although I'm just a small cog in a much larger machine, I feel that my views are an important part of the policymaking process.

My main job is to keep London up to date with economic and financial developments in Japan, which might feed into larger issues such as the Bank of England setting interest rates or the Treasury preparing for a G7 summit. If the chancellor of the exchequer, the governor of the Bank of England or government economists visit Japan, I also help to arrange their programmes and provide briefings.

The idea is that our contacts and local knowledge can supplement their specialist skills. I entered the government economic service at the age of 22 and have been on secondment to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office since 1997. That is a sign of how the FCO has modernized: both my boss, who is from the Treasury, and I have jobs that not so long ago would have tended to go to career diplomats.

A private sector job doesn't really appeal, though with economics and Japanese language skills, an investment bank would probably pay at least twice as much as my current salary. I'm not greatly motivated by money, but perhaps that attitude will change when I have a few more responsibilities. I guess its part altruism and - perhaps naively - a feeling that there's a lot of job satisfaction and interest here that I wouldn't find outside the public sector. My motivation may have something to do with the fact that my dad was a local government official for 40 years.

I'm not sure that I've found my vocation, but I'm pretty happy doing what I'm doing even though I doubt that I'll be in this job forever.

fields.headline: Commanding officer, HMS York
fields.standfirst:
Paul Porter
Salary: £49,000
fields.trailText:
Paul Porter
Salary: £49,000
fields.body:
I joined the navy when I was 18, straight out of school. I'd grown up with it - my father was an officer and my mum was in the Wrens. Almost immediately, I served aboard HMS Glasgow at the beginning of the tanker war, protecting shipping in the Persian Gulf, so I was exposed to operational service. After serving as a navigator, I moved on to warfare training.

I took over command of HMS York in January last year. It's the most fantastic job in the world as far as I'm concerned. I'm responsible for the welfare of 250 men on board but also for making sure the ship is operationally capable.

Being given the opportunity to drive this ship is a great privilege. Very clever people work for me - they're all specialists and I couldn't run this ship without any of them. It's a job of huge extremes: if we're at sea we could be carrying out humanitarian operations, or visiting our home port, the city of York, and showing the navy in the public eye.

The one bit of naval life that can be a downside is the time away from home. My wife and I have learned to cope, but now I've got a two-year-old son. Something I'm very aware of for my sailors and officers now is how difficult it is to be dragged away. There are times when you're on exercise in the middle of the night and the ship's bouncing up and down and you're not feeling too well and you're missing your son, but working outside the navy has even not crossed my mind. There are further career opportunities for me here and the navy offers financial security.

But I can't think of a comparable job in the private sector. The military isn't driven by profit. I have to make sure my people remain motivated despite this.

It's an honour to serve the country, but in the day-to-day running of the ship my focus is on providing a ship that is ready to do any task and on my loyalty to my people. I just feel incredibly lucky; there's this huge sense of pride in bringing the ship into port. Sometimes I have to pinch myself that I'm really in this position.

fields.headline: Computer services officer, Durham
fields.standfirst:
Sue Carr
Salary: c. £16,000
fields.trailText:
Sue Carr
Salary: c. £16,000
fields.body:
I work in computer services for Durham County Council, which means that when something has gone wrong with a user's PC or printer, we go out and fix it.

I don't work on the help desk, but on the technical side. We troubleshoot calls that come in via the help desk. You get a lot of job satisfaction if you can help people: they feel really appreciative of what you've done. So I enjoy coming to work, and I enjoy what I do. You're busy constantly. When I'm off, I'm at a loose end.

But I didn't set out to work in IT: it was circumstance. I just got a job working for Sunderland Council when I left school, through the careers office. So I've always worked in the public sector, but I've never ever thought of it on those lines before. I don't deal with members of the public directly, I deal with people who work for the county council.

I don't actually know how much I earn: I think it's round about £16,000. I don't know how that compares with the private sector. Lots of people want support staff, and sometimes you see adverts, but I've never been tempted.

webTitle: Keeper of science and maritime history, Aberdeen maritime museum

fields.headline: Keeper of science and maritime history, Aberdeen maritime museum
fields.standfirst:
John Edwards
Salary: £25,000
fields.trailText:
John Edwards
Salary: £25,000
fields.body:
I have worked in local authority museums for 26 years and there have been quite a few changes in that time. I studied history at university in Canada and came to Scotland to do a museum studies course in 1973.

Between 1992 and 1997, when we opened the new museum in Aberdeen, I was involved in the design process and project management. It was a very exciting time in my career, the museum expanded to five times its size. People look at the new building and ask who designed it, and it was a city architect. I don't think people appreciate that you can have very good people in local government who can achieve very high standards, work to a very good programme and bring a project in on time.

People ask me what I do and it is very difficult to explain all the different facets of a job in museums. My main job is looking after the museum collections, but more and more these days it has evolved into being very much a managerial type of position, dealing with the public and schools, looking at the needs of the wider community. And above all that, we have the requirements of a local authority that has standards to meet, so we have service reports, action plans, best value - that's the extra layer we have on our job nowadays.

"I think the old tradition of a curator is that you feel a sense of history and that you are passing objects, paintings, etc, on to the next generation. You have a duty of care to the collection. So there is a vocational aspect to it in terms of the dedication to the collection and trying to preserve it and enhance it.

webTitle: Hospital catering supervisor, Gartnavel hospital, Glasgow

fields.headline: Hospital catering supervisor, Gartnavel hospital, Glasgow
fields.standfirst:
Frances Smith
Salary: £185 a week
fields.trailText:
Frances Smith
Salary: £185 a week
fields.body:
I've been working at Gartnavel hospital in Glasgow for eight years. When I first applied for the job of catering assistant, I was 43 and I thought I had no chance because I was too old. But they gave me it. Since then I think I have done really well and I'm very proud of what I do. I have gone through all the catering courses and passed all the certificates.

Now I am in charge on the backshift in the evening. It is my job to make sure that the meals are presentable. Mostly, I feel appreciated by the public. Sometimes we get people complaining about the food, that it has gone cold or something - especially the chips. But these are the people who would complain about anything. Everybody else treats us with respect.

I don't notice any difference between how they treat us and how they treat the doctors and nurses. People come down to the restaurant and they talk to us about their relatives who are ill. We are a shoulder for them to cry on. We get letters and notes from them all the time thanking us for looking after them.

The politicians talk a lot about valuing the NHS, but they don't back that up with what they pay us. I work a 37-hour week and, after tax and national insurance, I take home about £185 a week. I know I could earn more in the private sector. But for me, the security of this job is more important. The patients will always need to be fed so they will always need someone to do this job. In the private sector, you just don't know.

fields.headline: War on waste
fields.standfirst: Mixed verdict on council services
fields.trailText: Council environmental services, such as waste recycling, street cleaning and lighting and inspection of risky food premises, have improved in the past five years, the audit commission says today. But there remain huge disparities between neighbouring authorities.
fields.body:
Council environmental services, such as waste recycling, street cleaning and lighting and inspection of risky food premises, have improved in the past five years, the audit commission says today. But there remain huge disparities between neighbouring authorities.

Moreover, the quality of bin collections, the number of public toilets and the processing time for planning applications has worsened slightly, according to the commission's first report exclusively on environmental performance indicators in England.

Councils that stand out as having made gains in most or all of the services assessed include Breckland in Norfolk, Cornwall, Croydon in south London, Darlington, Devon, Kirklees in West Yorkshire, and Newham in east London.

Possibly the most dramatic improvement has been in the recycling of household waste, which has doubled since the mid-1990s. But the survey shows considerable variation: in relative terms, Stockport manages to recycle more than 30 times as much as its neighbour Manchester; similarly, in Northamptonshire, Daventry recycles 25 times the proportion achieved by Corby.

The biggest disparity in services surveyed is the time taken to give a decision on planning applications by householders. The best of the London boroughs, Newham, manages to process 85% of applications within the eight-week target set by government. The worst, Haringey in north London, achieves only 20%.

The report, which looks at performance in 1999-2000, the last year before the "best value" regime took effect, reveals that some of the best performing councils are not necessarily doing well across the board. While Islington, in north London, achieves a 100% inspection rate of high-risk food premises, it is placed bottom of the capital league when it comes to the number of public conveniences, managing just two per 100,000 residents. This compares to 20 per 100,000 residents in Greenwich, south London.

Away from towns and cities, the commission looked at footpaths and other rights of way and assessed how easy it was for the public to use them. It found a marked drop in ease of access in county council areas: only 70% of them are deemed user-friendly, a 5% deterioration over two years.

Sir Andrew Foster, the commission's controller, says most councils have risen to the challenge of improving services that affect every resident in their areas. "Nevertheless, some councils have a lot of work to do to catch up with the better performers. Best value is shining an ever brighter spotlight to show local people how their councils are performing and what improvements could be made."

Local Authority Performance Indicators 1999-2000: Environmental Services in England is available at £20 from Audit Commission Publications on 0800 502030.

webTitle: Squadron leader, E flight 202, RAF search & rescue, Leconfield, Humberside

fields.headline: Squadron leader, E flight 202, RAF search & rescue, Leconfield, Humberside
fields.standfirst:
Richard Hooper
Salary: £50,000
fields.trailText:
Richard Hooper
Salary: £50,000
fields.body:
What flying a SAR helicopter can mean, in extremis, is a long dark night in the Galway Bay, winching 60 people off a stranded French factory-fishing ship, 10 at a time.

Slightly less dramatic was the other month off Whitby, looking for a lost fishing vessel whose radio had packed up. We came down from 200 feet, in fog, to 50. Despite night-vision goggles, we still couldn't see the surface of the water - such times are good for focusing the mind - but then there was the boat, just a little light over to the right.

Other days it can be searching for a couple lost in the snow in Upper Wharfedale, who then turn up and ask what the fuss was about.

I command 80 people on a 24-hours-a-day, 365-days-a-year job with E flight's two, four-person Sea King helicopters.

We are controlled from the rescue coordination centre at RAF Kinloss, which covers the entire country - and a large expanse of sea.

Our function is integrated into the rest of the rescue services. Our main task is to rescue military personnel but 95% of our work is about civilians.
