fields.headline: Walls of sound
fields.standfirst: Even hard cases in a high-security prison can be touched by the therapeutic power, and fun, of music.  John Cunningham reports
fields.trailText: Even hard cases in a high-security prison can be touched by the therapeutic power, and fun, of music. John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
In the prison gym, a group of men rhythmically stamp their feet and chant in unison. It's not a protest about poor equipment or conditions, but something more constructive: the sound of music in the making.

Chanting and stamping are the warm-up; after three two-hour sessions over a week, the participants will put on a show on the final evening, much of it their own material. It is the sort of rehearsal familiar to amateur performers, but for a group including murderers, sex offenders and violent burglars, to be doing this in a high security prison is highly unusual.

But Grendon prison, in Buckinghamshire, is unusual: the only British prison offering a therapeutic regime of education and personal development for up to 230 inmates. Men can ask to be transferred here from other institutions. If they are assessed as suitable, it takes 18 to 24 months for the programme to show results, says education officer Jill Lewis, who prefers to describe the regime as challenging rather than liberal.

The group running the workshop is out of the ordinary, too. The six classical musicians of the Oxford Concert Party (OCP) have been working in prisons, hospitals, hospices and residential homes for almost a decade. They are basically a chamber ensemble with a sense of humour, describ ing themselves as Europe's only baroque and tango orchestra. They have done tours and TV, and been voted pick of the fringe at the Edinburgh Festival.

As well as composing and recording music, and playing the accordion and harpsichord, artistic director Arne Richards is an authority on music for healing. "There's no deep philosophy behind it, but music does have great transformative power," he says. "Certain types of music can help people, where other types can have a negative effect. For instance, physically handicapped people may react badly to music with a strong rhythmic content. In a prison, you can soon see what does or does not work.

"There's a highly charged atmosphere in a place like Whitemoor [high-security prison in Cambridgeshire]. To harness that high energy through music is a most wonderful experience. We've seen people in tears, tapping their feet, laughing for joy, no matter how reluctant they were before the performance."

The potential effect of professional musicians working with prisoners became clear when, as violinist Isabel Knowland, Richards's wife, explains, they found after one of their first prison concerts that the men wanted the "hands-on communication" of trying the instruments. And so the workshops started.

It remains a mystery to Richards how, after the chaos of the first two sessions, the pieces the inmates have brought to play or sing, and the improvisations he gives them, always cohere into a smooth third session and then a final performance - all accomplished within eight hours.

The aim is clear: to increase the men's self-confidence and sharpen their sense of identity. It is the policy of governor Tim Newell to invite music and other groups to supplement Grendon's core education programme. Lewis is sure the workshops bring results. "It's a definite learning curve for [prisoners] to realise they can entertain other people," she says. "There's a definite growth in self- esteem, when the law has told you you're a load of rubbish."

By the second session of the workshop, some of that confidence has begun to emerge. So has rather a lot of talent. George is rehearsing his bagpipes solo; Noel, with recent events in mind, has written a dramatic poem about a rail disaster, for which OCP musicians will provide a soundtrack; John is playing the electric guitar; Tom, as well as having poems published in OCP's newsletter, is going through his saxophone solo.

The two hours are broken into a time for improvising in small groups. Each is given a theme, such as a circus or a procession, which will be interspersed into a longer work Richards and his musicians will play at the concert. Sounds weird, but Richards is a great blender and bender of world music. He might include in the programme anything from Argentinian tangos to Irish laments, but he says it always works.

The buzz starts early in the session. There is a soundtrack of drumming, but, strangely, no one is letting rip. It's all taut self-controlled. Richards does not raise his voice and hardly seems to be pulling things together, but a process is at work.

George, serving a sentence for a murder he committed at 16, has performed at previous workshops. "The first time, the adrenalin was running down my back," he recalls. But don't other inmates get annoyed by the wailing pipes when he is practising? "If you're liked, you can get away with anything," he grins.

Grendon, which has an education budget of £400,000 (shared with Spring Hill prison on the same site) pays for a local RAF pipe major to coach George. John, similarly, has lessons with a professional guitarist. He, too, is inside for a murder committed as a teenager - "a paedophile abusing kids in my area," he says.

The guitar has been his salvation; he has been passionate about it since he was 16. Now, through the opportunity to play in prison, he sees himself as a guitarist, with a plausible career he hopes to take up on his release.

But for all the relative liberalism of the regime, and a timetable which allows men out of their cells for most of the day, these are pent-up men. John, taking a break with a roll-up and a mug of black coffee, says it is difficult to relate to others in the group who are at different levels "musically and intellectually".

Despite such frustrations, music has been his saviour. "When I started, it was a bit of an ego trip," says John. "I wanted to play rock guitar. But after two years, it became more genuine. But it's not about competing; it's about working as a team."

The team, in turn, is part of a wider community of music. For Grendon has its graduates: two former prisoners, who have participated in workshops, have returned to help with this one. One, a former sex offender, will be singing an aria or two in the final concert. Another was sent to Grendon for protesting at nuclear bases; he is now a music student at Oxford Brookes University, and says OCP's workshops impressed him because they're "all very egalitarian; everyone gets a chance to do a piece".

Some unlikely characters turn up, too. Knowland says: "Some of the men are very musical and skilled. But some haven't touched an instrument in their lives, or heard anything that wasn't either rock or pop."

The only puzzle is that, of the circle in the gym, only about a dozen are prisoners. A pity that such an excellent project (it costs £3,000 to stage a workshop) does not get bigger numbers. "There are other things on tonight," explains one participant. "It clashes with their programmes. And most of the guys would probably rather be watching telly."

webTitle: Pressure on government to reward charity commitment

fields.headline: Pressure on government to reward charity commitment
fields.trailText: Charities that enter into long-term commitments to provide services on behalf of national or local government should be rewarded with state funding of their core costs, a voluntary sector leader is proposing.
fields.body:
Charities that enter into long-term commitments to provide services on behalf of national or local government should be rewarded with state funding of their core costs, a voluntary sector leader is proposing.

The idea of a council-style "revenue support grant" for the not-for-profit sector will prove controversial. But Stephen Bubb, chief executive of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (Acevo), insists the time has come for radical thinking on the core costs issue.

"Frankly, if the government wants to deliver mainstream services through the sector, then we need to have a grown-up conversation about the relationship," says Bubb. "The compact [the 1998 agreement between the government and the voluntary sector] pretends it's a relationship of equals, but everybody knows it just ain't so.

"The thinking is still about supplicant and donor. The sector needs to be saying: 'Yes, we are prepared to enter this or that arrangement, but these are the rules from our side'."

His comments come after Acevo yesterday published a new edition of its 1999 report, Who Pays for Core Costs?, which touched a nerve in the charity world and quickly sold out. The report, by Julia Unwin, exposed the way in which many charities were feeling trapped by a short-term funding culture that hampered their development.

The new publication, Funding Our Future - Core Costs Revisited, is an update by Unwin endorsed by three voluntary sector heavyweights: the Charity Finance Directors' Group, the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers and the Directory of Social Change (DSC), the sector's leading research and training body.

Mike Eastwood, DRC director, says in a commentary in the new report that the current funding environment is "deeply unsatisfactory", and runs counter to the sustenance of stable and mature voluntary organisations. "It even encourages a degree of dishonesty in the funding relationship through a constant pressure - actual or implied - to present existing work as if it is new. It creates great insecurity for service users because providers are unable to guarantee continuity of delivery."

While government has shifted decisively from making grants to offering service contracts, a three-year funding cycle has been adopted widely by grant-makers, including the national lottery charities board. Eastwood cites one officer of a grant-making trust as saying that a charity had "gone rather boring on us" by opting to focus on incremental development of its existing services, rather than anything new.

Unwin proposes three models of funding to break the mould: "full project" funding, in which all reasonable associated costs are built in; "development" funding, through which infrastructure costs are met for a time in order to enable the service provider to grow and develop; and "strategic" funding, by which a funder recognises a need for the provider to exist to meet its own (the funder's) objectives and is prepared to contribute over an agreed period of time.

Bubb is keen to take the debate still wider. Ministers, he says, will fail to achieve their aim of a huge increase in volunteering unless voluntary organisations are resourced to offer management and leadership.

Anticipating the argument that state funding of core costs would undermine charities' independence, Bubb says: "We would need to make clear that one of our rules is that we remain free to criticise. We don't expect the government to come back with: 'We don't like what you say; what chance your next revenue grant?'"

Funding Our Future is available at £25 inc. from Acevo, Middlesex House, 130 College Road, Harrow, HA1 1BQ (020-8424 2334).

webTitle: Sue Richards, Professor of public policy

fields.headline: Sue Richards, Professor of public policy
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

We face two alternative scenarios for the public services, low and high capacity. Low capacity public service will be competent at a narrow range of mechanical tasks - giving grants and collecting taxes for example - but not very good at solving problems such as crime and health. By contrast, a high capacity public sector would achieve the joining up and the targets for improvement which figure so prominently in the Labour government's rhetoric.

I fear we are on track for a low-capacity future.

Where do we go from here?

The forthcoming election may be decided on the parties' promises about how much they will spend in future. But the election after that will be decided on delivery. Will services have improved and real social results be achieved?

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

Here is what a group of top public sector officials - assistant chief constables, local authority chief executives and senior Whitehall staff on our top management programme - told us needed to be done.

The new government should: * Dump the behaviour patterns it learned in opposition. Some ministers recognise that their job is to achieve change in the real world, not just to score points for the spin machine, but many do not.

* Reform the public sector, but recognise that you need public officials.

They are not the enemy. Make them your allies in achieving outcomes. No more talk about teachers or other public servants as "forces of conservatism".

* Set clear outcome targets - what should be achieved - but recognise that it is people with local knowledge who are the best judges of how it should be done. Give them more support and be less directive about how they should operate.

* Be strategic - focus on a few key priorities for the government as a whole. If you overload the system it will collapse rather than deliver. Government also has to be "corporate", joined up, working together, otherwise Whitehall departments will continue to pursue their own separate agendas.

* Develop public service agreements, pinning open individual cabinet ministers accountability for such key outcomes as crime reduction and improving health. Achieving these outcomes will require cooperation across the boundaries of Whitehall departments. Integrate the work of inspectors and auditors so they do not reinforce "silo" thinking.

* The government has talked avidly about partnership but the proliferation of partnerships at local level is beyond a joke. The government offices for the regions in Leeds, Manchester, Norwich and so on should be used to integrate Whitehall policy. Do not allow any departments to opt out, as the Department for Education and Employment does now.

This list is about the public sector rather than public servants themselves.

The message is clear. Pay and conditions matter, but what matters more is the sense that your life's work is valued and makes a contribution to a better society. People are crying out for enabling leadership from the Blair government. Is it up to the job?

The University of Birmingham's School of Public Policy is one of the country's largest centres for training public servants. Sue Richards, formerly a civil servant, is a professor there

fields.headline: Digby Jones, CBI director general
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

I spend much of my working life visiting businesses of all types and sizes up and down the country. Seeing for myself how, day in day out, those businesses are busting a gut to stay competitive. In a globally mobile business world, they have little option! As for productivity improvement, the chancellor is knocking on an open door - the key to survival is "making it happen".

But I am increasingly asked - by employers and unions alike - if similar productivity improvements are ever likely to be seen in the public sector. It does have a productivity agenda but so far it has just not gone far enough. Too often business growth is stifled and jobs are lost because of poor performance in both central and local government. All sides in the private sector, employees and employers, say they want more bang for the tax buck. It's too easy for the public sector to cry "lack of resources".

Where do we go from here?

The quality of delivery of our public services will be a huge issue after the election is over. The Blair government has committed to major 10 year plans on health, education and transport and if it is re-elected, the electorate - ever more sophisticated and demanding - will just not accept second-rate service delivery. The policy ambitions of government are laudable but the delivery mechanisms are simply not in place. I am talking here about the need for culture change in the public sector and ministers will have to be prepared to use the power of their office to achieve it. Civil Service managers need to become less risk averse. They need to be encouraged to set procedures to one side and focus on delivery. An official's ability to steer a bill through the House of Commons should no longer be the acid test of a senior civil servant's competence. Civil servants should all be able to manage projects successfully - and be rewarded for doing it.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

The programme of necessary change is going to be long and painful. Sacred cows will need to be sacrificed. Officialdom will need to roll up its sleeves and focus the end product - the service to you and me - the customers.

The private sector does not have all the answers but we have been through many of these pain barriers during the last 15 to 20 years - just look at the culture change the automotive and retail sectors have undergone. And the private sector does genuinely want to help. Government should cast pride and suspicion aside and import more and more private sector expertise, experience - and management control.

Linking the delivery of specific objectives to bonus payments or base line salary might be a start. Payment by results may go against existing culture - but the doctrine of "not made here" can no longer be an excuse for not engaging with change.

Digby Jones is director general of the Confederation of British Industry

fields.headline: Julia Neuberger,  Health charity executive
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

The government needs to talk up the public sector and say loud and clear how good an arena it is to be working in. I recently judged the Chartered Institute of Public Finance's public service awards. They showed me that people all over the public sector had done well beyond the call of duty, how they turned round the impossible and gave unstintingly of their time.

It is not good enough to get nurses to come and work here from Spain. Politicians need to say nursing is a noble profession. It's as much a matter of attitudes as more attractive pay. Politicians have got to stop denigrating public service professionals - too often they exhibit a kind of quick-hit mentality.

The media does not help either. Take the Shipman case: the actions of a single individual, a monster, became an attack on all doctors. Similarly with Alder Hey. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, could have done things differently. The matter of storage of children's organs in Liverpool was a one-off which got turned into a systemic question of trust between doctors and patients.

Where do we go from here?

To say we do not value public servants enough does not imply the public sector is above reproach. Reformers have to say public service matters but must not stop dealing with old-style work practices, the public sector's reluctance to accept genuine criticism and over-specialisation.

It's hard to justify nurses striking and teachers not covering for colleagues; I favour some kind of no-strike agreement for public servants, in exchange for more money, and not being subject to the sort of criticism we have heard too much of lately.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

I think Labour ministers have tended to adopt a sort of macho posture and there is not much sign that will change after the election. The government favours private and voluntary sector provision as a way of disciplining the public sector.

Some ministers may even see the promise of significant extra money for public services in the financial plans for the next three years as a sort of last-chance saloon - if they don't prove themselves the private sector will come in. The public sees things differently. It's significant how, in London, the debate about the tube system shows many people actually want the public sector to run transport. (In health people do not much mind who provides as long as it is paid for by the state.)

The immediate future for public sector works depends on what happens to the economy. If it goes down, the public sector will seem a more attractive place to work and also make it easier to recruit and retain staff.

Rabbi Julia Neuberger is chief executive of the King's Fund

fields.headline: John Monks, TUC general secretary
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

The public sector ought to be in good heart. After years of being starved of resources, spending is set to grow, particularly on health and education.

Whether the government was right to maintain the Conservative's two-year spending targets becomes more of an academic question each day we move into a period of growth.

The politics of the public sector is also changing. A few years the talk was of an end to "tax and spend". Yet the election will be a traditional contest between lower taxes and spending cuts on the right and a choice of parties of the centre and left that defend public spending and the taxation needed to sustain it.

And yet the public sector is beset with problems and low morale. It is of course by no means universal. Just talk to people in the employment service who have had their jobs transformed from little more than policing the unemployed to actively helping people chart a way through the New Deal to work. But this is not the rule.

Where do we go from here?

Despite the extra money there are still huge problems of resources and morale across all parts of the public sector. Much of this flows from a widespread feeling that this government shares with its predecessor a prejudice against the public sector and its employees.

It may be a caricature, but many public servants believe the government think the private sector is full of risk-taking entrepreneurs, brilliant project managers and leaders who root out six inefficiencies before breakfast every day while public sector staff are conservative, pen-pushing bureaucrats covering up for lazy and incompetent colleagues.

This approach is corrosive. Our traditions of public service provide a much needed alternative to the commercial ethos of the private sector. Just look at how the staff of the NHS cope with appalling conditions and lack of resources, or the dedication of teachers in inner city schools.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

The government has now started to undo some of the damage it did during its first years in office. But it still has to do more to really make the public sector feel valued. Pay is a large part of the problem, demonstrated graphically by the inability of public servants to compete in the London housing market.

PFI, privatisations and public private partnerships will make this worse as staff with protected public sector terms are replaced with staff on the worst private sector terms but still providing public service. That is why the TUC wants to see a new Fair Wages resolution to protect public service pay and conditions.

But pay is not the only issue. Public servants feel weighed down by endless, seemingly uncoordinated and over-spun initiatives, that can appear to be based on a lack of trust that existing structures can deliver. The irony is that if attitudes change and public servants feel valued, they are likely to become allies in the changes the government wants to make, as they did in implementing the New Deal.

The one lesson the government can learn from the best private sector companies is that their staff are their main asset, and that partnership, trust and openness are the keys to change.

John Monks is general secretary of the Trades Union Congress

fields.headline: Christine Whatford, Education director
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

In 10 years' time I still expect the public sector to be here - I think it is necessary to say that because, certainly within education, there have been times when I have wondered whether total privatisation wasn't on the agenda.

For my part I believe, fundamentally, that certain services, especially education, are a public good and will therefore stay within the public sector, one way or another.

But what we need is recognition. I say this really strongly: we need the value of what we do to be seen and upheld. If we do deliver to a high standard, we deserve recognition. By recognition I do not just mean money, but a shift in attitudes especially regarding the expertise of public sector managers.

There used, quite rightly, to be doubts about the quality of public services but things have changed dramatically. We are now subject to the same sort of efficiency measures as the private sector - through the Best Value programme, for example.

The quality of management in public sector compares well - it is a myth to say the private sector has any edge. Some of the skills acquired in recent years by public sector people are priceless, for example their willingness to "work outside the box", to forge partnerships and make things work locally.

I used to be a school head. And it is recognised by all parties that heads are key people. But the education service at large has suffered from getting the blame when things go wrong, getting no credit when things go right. Instead, the service and local education authorities should not always be presented as if local government were in some kind of permanent deficit.

We are in fact not just reliable but often the guarantee that things happen.

Where do we go from here?

Much has been made about bringing the private sector in - I have nothing against that. We are involved with private firms on an array of projects.

But when it comes to education action zones or city academies, it has been local education authorities that have made them work. They were billed as things the private sector would make work. But in fact local government has been indispensable.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

The public is usually more concerned about the quality of services rather than who provides them - that the bins get emptied rather than which authority does the emptying.

Nonetheless, I detect an innate concern on the public's part that services such as education may be taken away from it. There is no grassroots enthusiasm for privatisation or the removal of services from the public sector. They want good services and would prefer a publicly accountable authority to deliver them.

A trained teacher, Christine Whatford has been director of education for the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham for the past 11 years and before that head of a secondary school

fields.headline: Quality, not quantity
fields.standfirst: Matthew Taylor and  Gavin Kelly on the importance of making diversity serve its purpose across the public sector
fields.trailText: Matthew Taylor and Gavin Kelly on the importance of making diversity serve its purpose across the public sector.
fields.body:
With Labour on the verge of a second full term and at last substantially increasing public investment, the nation's commitment to public services has, if anything, grown stronger. This should be a golden age for the champions of public service; those who believe that Britain could and should aspire to provision which rivals that available in other successful European economies. But we have been here before. The bold plans of those who created the modern welfare state in the 20 years after the war subsided into the decades of retrenchment and flawed reform that followed.

If, after a sustained period of investment in the hands of a government unquestionably committed to the success of public services, citizens believed those services were failing, there would be a profound reaction. A resurgent right could start to win the argument that universal public services are an anachronism; blunt, inefficient, restricting of choice. If the case for universal public services cannot be won now it could be lost forever.

But this case is about values and outcomes, not about particular forms of delivery. The founding principles of the public service to which we are most attached - the national health service - specify it should be free, universal and comprehensive, not that it should be provided through a particular structure, process or set of employees. The enduring goals of public policy must be distinguished from the contingent means through which they are pursued.

This, of course, was the starting point for the debate that marked the birth of New Labour, the rewriting of clause four. But despite winning that debate, Tony Blair and his colleagues have failed to build a new account of the relationship between social ends, public spending, public service and private enterprise. In their recent overview of New Labour, Polly Toynbee and David Walker identified the experimentation with public private partnerships (PPPs) as the government's single greatest policy failure.

In assessing claims made about partnership, we need to remember there is nothing inherently new about PPPs. Many of the companies engaged in the PFI market lived off public contracts long before the phrase PPP had ever been coined. The public face of the NHS comes in the form of GPs who are independent contractors. In local government, health, social and community care, the prison service, defence, the employment service, careers' service, education, and social housing, a multitude of relationships with the private and voluntary sector already exist. Partnership is not new, but the current Government has moved closer towards a defining feature of its approach towards public services than others.

To see this we only need consider the new wave of public services that it has introduced - Sure Start, University for Industry, employment zones, children's fund. All have been founded on the concept of partnership. It has been recognised that the public sector working in isolation could not achieve the type of outcomes that citizens want.

Cabinet ministers have repeatedly made it clear that they have no ideological qualms about greater non-public sector involvement in core areas. This stance seemed to fit well with popular opinion. Both quantitative and qualitative work carried out by IPPR indicates that people care much less about who provides the service than about quality and equity.

The cases for PPPs in providing diversity, incentives for performance improvement, access to the skills and experience of the private and voluntary sector are well rehearsed, but there are other less obvious arguments. The biggest single challenge facing public services may be how to more fully engage communities. This is about empowerment and civic renewal but also because services need buy-in from parents, patients, carers and neighbours if they are to deliver real social benefit. Well-planned and ambitious partnerships can achieve a sharper focus on outcomes and open the door to innovation in service delivery. They provide scope to put the "public" back into public services by giving users and citizens groups a stronger role in commissioning and could ultimately mean communities themselves delivering or co-owning public services.

Politically, diversity in provision could provide something of a buffer against the possibility of a renewed assault from those seeking to residualise public services. PPPs may help forge new coalitions of support for adequate public spending between non-public providers and public sector commissioners.

None of this is to say that there are not major problems with the approach taken to the use of partnerships in public services over recent years. There is a large and seemingly growing gap - that between ideological rhetoric and implementation - which has hindered the effective use of partnership. This gap has revealed itself in a variety of ways.

First, there has been a tendency to spray the demand for 'private-sector involvement' across most new government initiatives in the areas of social and regeneration policy without proper consideration of what the different partners would have to offer. This has fuelled partnership-fatigue rather than unleashing new energy and innovations.

Second, the suspicion that PPPs are being used simply to get public investment 'off-balance sheet' still persists strongly on the ground. Third, the view that the private sector should be used as a punishment with which to threaten 'failing' public authorities (for example, LEAs, prisons, benefits offices, schools) has created a jaundiced view of the very notion of partnership.

Fourth, the early evidence from PFI projects suggests many are offering at best marginal value for monetary gains without delivering the promised innovations in design and service configuration. Finally, in a number of high-profile instances, including the London Underground and National Air Traffic Services, the government has made an almost ideological commitment to very particular models of PPP while turning its back on other partnership arrangements.

No one should think that resolving these problems and building effective partnerships is easy. In all of the areas where diversity has been introduced there have been teething problems. In some instances the quality of service provided through PPP has been lamentable or the tax-payer has received a poor deal (often they go together). Anyone who claims that, in every instance, the quality of service produced through a PPP supersedes what came before is wilfully misinterpreting the available evidence.

The evidence of the apparent shortcomings of both PPPs and direct-provision underlines the need to ensure that genuine alternatives to PPPs remain in place (and are perceived to be viable alternatives by public managers). There is also a need to reform the PPP approval process in order to improve quality and value for money.

And yet, despite all these concerns and caveats, there is little reason for anticipating that a return to a 'one size fits all' model of public sector provision would benefit citizens.

The concept of partnership between the sectors is not flawed, but often the practice has been. If managed properly, the gradual shift towards greater diversity in service-provision has the potential to generate favourable outcomes. We are not alone in holding this view. Few serious commentators are calling for the nationalisation of service provision in areas where a plurality of providers already exists.

Where these changes will take us is not yet clear. The 'industrial organisation', as economists term it, of the emerging public service sector will vary from area to area. In some service-sectors, such as social services, it will be made up of a dispersed set of auton-omous organisations, resembling a "flotilla of dinghies".

In other areas the traditional public provider will remain the dominant force but a small collection of non-public providers will continue to keep it on its toes. In all areas the era of the single, all encompassing, monolithic public provider seems to be passing. Diversity has crept into the UK's public services, often on terms with which the left is uncomfortable. It now seems set to stay. The challenge we face is to learn how better to make it serve our purposes.

Matthew Taylor is the director of IPPR. Gavin Kelly is secretary of IPPR's commission on PPPs

webTitle: Professionals' pay packets fail to keep pace

fields.headline: Professionals' pay packets fail to keep pace
fields.standfirst: Waves of privatisation have led to big changes, says Charlotte Denny
fields.trailText: Waves of privatisation have led to big changes, says Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
Mrs Thatcher couldn't resist a man in uniform. While teachers, civil servants and town hall officials were frequent targets of prime ministerial ire, the armed services and the fire service escaped virtually scot free.

The few bits of the public sector which the Conservative government liked have tended to do rather well in the pay stakes. Police and fire officers enjoy relatively generous pay and pension schemes - senior police officers earn more than the average lawyer, government figures show, while senior firestation officers are further up the pay ladder than accountants.

Unions representing other parts of the public sector say they have not been so lucky. Twenty five years ago, a teacher could expect to earn nearly 40% more than the average non manual worker. Today the gap has narrowed to just 10%, according to the National Union of Teachers. University lecturers say that while the average wage packet has grown by nearly 50% since 1980, allowing for the effects of inflation, their pay has only increased by 5%.

Despite union complaints, official data shows that on average public sector workers still earn more than private sector employees, but this in part reflects the fact that two decades of privatisation and outsourcing have changed the face of the state sector. Most low-paid manual jobs - garbage disposal, hospital cleaning - have been contracted out. Successive waves of privatisation have resulted in a total of 750,000 workers moving from the public sector to the private sector.

The typical public sector worker now is a female professional - 60% of public sector workers are women. By contrast, the private sector is made up of well paid male professionals, very poorly paid female service sector workers, and a declining number of male manual workers.

The few manual workers left in the public sector do relatively well by comparison with their private sector counterpart which is why they were scarcely affected by the introduction of the minimum wage - few of them were earning anywhere near the £3.70 wage floor.

For professional workers, it's a different story. Pay for private sector professionals has ballooned in the 1990s, widening the gap between top earners and the low paid. But the pay packets of professional workers in the public sector have not kept pace. The pay review bodies which set wages for most of the public sector have become a tool for government economic management - pay makes up about a third of government spending. The Conservatives operated a pay freeze, where any increases had to be paid for with job cuts, a policy which Labour continued for the first two years it was in power. Since then the Treasury has urged the pay review bodies to keep settlements consistent with the Bank of England's 2.5% inflation target.

Private sector employers couldn't get away with this kind of tight-fistedness. Workers would simply find a better deal elsewhere. But because the government is a monopoly employer when it comes to nursing and teaching, it is able to artificially suppress wages.

But even the government can't avoid market pressures for ever. Workers can always leave or retire, and that's what they've been doing in droves. Underpaid and overstretched, nurses and teachers have simply voted with their feet, causing a recruitment crisis which the government has belatedly woken up to.

The government has promised a better salary deal starting this April. Nurses' pay is set to rise by 3.7% with higher rises for senior nurses and allied professions. School teachers will also receive a basic rise of 3.7%, while new recruits will get a 6% increase.

Will this be enough to solve the recruitment crisis? The unions, while welcoming the cash are sceptical. The NUT says it will still be hard to attract good graduates into the profession, even with the higher pay rates.

The starting salary for a good honours graduate in teaching on the new pay scale will be £17,000, around £1,800 less than graduates in other professions. fields.headline: Overseas staff plug the gaps
fields.standfirst: After years of starving the public sector of funds, there are just not enough workers.  John Carvel reports
fields.trailText: After years of starving the public sector of funds, there are just not enough workers. John Carvel reports.
fields.body:
Staff shortages in the public sector were not officially recognised as a problem during the years of high unemployment and squeeze on public services that followed Margaret Thatcher's election victory in 1979.

Schools may have needed more teachers and hospitals may have lacked enough doctors and nurses to provide a satisfactory standard of care. But it was pupils and patients who paid the price through overcrowded classes and overlong NHS waiting lists.

Except in a few areas and specialisms, managers of these public enterprises were not technically short of staff because they did not have enough money in their budgets to pay for any more. They lived within their ration.

Since Gordon Brown moved two years ago to lift the lid on public expenditure, the legacy of 20 years of low levels of training, recruitment and nurturing of public sector staff has started to hit home.

The signs are everywhere. Spanish nurses who started work this year at hospitals in Blackpool, Blackburn, Morecambe and Preston were the advance guard of a contingent of 5,000 that the NHS has agreed with the authorities in Madrid can be poached to relieve a chronic shortage of skilled workers in the wards. Hospitals are reporting difficulties in the recruitment of psychiatrists, radiologists and pathologists. Schools in London would collapse without the services of temping teachers from Australia, New Zealand and South Africa who used to provide sickness cover for regular staff, but are now becoming the bedrock of the education service.

Directors of social services are looking abroad to find social workers after the home-grown supply dried up. Essex has recruited 46 from South Africa and is looking for 24 more.

The Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, has reported a shortage of 1,000 staff and warned that 200 fully fit officers would have to be switched from frontline duties to fill vacant support posts. Even the Ministry of Defence is reported to be considering relaxing its tough fitness requirements for new recruits to make up a shortage that has left the army, navy and air force nearly 10,000 below strength.

Across the boundaries

The shortage extends into professions that straddle the boundaries of public and private sectors. According to a survey by Incomes Data Services, local authorities are experiencing recruitment and retention difficulties in accounting and finance, building control, engineering, environmental health and planning.

And the problem is not confined to professionals. Councils are reporting problems across a range of low-paid occupations including care staff, cleaners, cooks and leisure staff. In Coventry the council said it could not find enough home carers because staff got better pay for less onerous work in the supermarkets. In Guildford the council offered a "market supplement" of £1.20 an hour above the nationally agreed rate to hang on to its footloose cooks.

For the unions, there is an appealing explanation for these difficulties. Pay increases in the public sector have fallen behind those in the private and the gap has become more troublesome as falling unemployment opened up more opportunities for people to switch sectors in search of higher pay. Since 1995 average earnings rose by 18.5% in the public sector and 25.5% in the private. That trend was continuing last year when public sector earnings went up by 3.7% and private by 4.3%. Latest official figures put average earnings in the public sector at £406.60 a week, slightly below the private sector average of £412.30.

That gap is bound to have had an effect on employment patterns in areas of low unemployment that were spreading from London and the south-east into East Anglia, the Midlands, the south-west and parts of Scotland around Edinburgh and Aberdeen. And the pressure came as the public sector was trying to increase its workforce for the first time in 20 years.

The number of public jobs fell from more than 7.4m in 1979 to below 5m in 1997, mainly due to the privatisation of nationalised industries. Between 1989 and 1999 it rose by 44,000, mainly due to recruitment by the NHS and primary schools.

These aggregate statistics cannot be used to prove that public sector workers are underpaid. At the level of the individual school, hospital or office, more complex factors are at play. Among teachers, for example, a lowering of morale caused by excessive paperwork and the drip feed of criticism from Ofsted may have done at least as much as pay rates to swell an exodus of experienced staff. Managers in the public sector have to ask themselves whether they have done enough to introduce family-friendly employment policies.

Annual ritual

Arguments about public sector staff shortages have become part of an annual ritual in the run up to decisions by the pay review bodies on how much the main professions should get.

The unions play them for all they are worth and the government - until recently - tried to pretend they did not really exist. But over the last 12 months, there were signs that ministers were taking the problem more seriously. In Scotland, there were three-year pay deals worth 23.1% for teachers and more than 18% plus bonuses for civil servants. In England, education ministers offered £4,000 golden hellos for newly-qualified teachers specialising in maths, science, technology and modern languages. Police officers and nurses in high-cost areas got supplementary allowances. And the Budget produced recruitment and retention funds worth £200m for education over the next three years and £130m for health.

These are probably the most worrying areas because shortages of teachers and NHS staff could derail the government's priority programmes - and the time lags for training new staff are long.

The nurses recruited from Spain join thousands of others from South Africa, the Philippines, New Zealand, the West Indies and Zimbabwe who have been poached by Britain to solve the problem of unfilled vacancies. Last year the number of foreign nurses and midwives registering to work in Britain increased by 48% to a record 7,361. Almost a third of nurses in London's hospitals trained abroad. The NHS would collapse without them.

The Royal College of Nursing estimates that 22,000 posts are vacant for lack of suitably qualified applicants. But the government is pressing ahead with proposals in the NHS plan to create an extra 20,000 nursing posts by 2004.

A study by Queen Margaret University College concluded that the NHS would have to recruit 110,000 registered nurses and midwives over this period to make up for those leaving the profession and meet the target growth. Bearing in mind likely patterns of recruitment, training and persuasion of former nurses to return, nobody is yet clear how these numbers will be achieved without further raiding of staff from overseas.

However, the trade in nurses is a two-way flow and there is no guarantee that Britain will be a net importer.

No wonder Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said the main problem facing the NHS was no longer shortage of money, but shortage of capacity. Mr Milburn will also have difficulties delivering the extra 7,500 consultants, 1,000 spe cialist registrars and 2,000 GPs promised by 2004 in the NHS plan.

The British Medical Association said it was hard to fill vacancies for radiologists, pathologists, anaesthetists and paediatricians, although the evidence was anecdotal. The most glaring shortages were in mental health. According to the Royal College of Psychiatrists, more than 20% of consultant posts were unfilled in the North-west and Mersey, 17% in Yorkshire and 8% in East Anglia, Oxford, Wessex and most regions in Scotland.

"Psychiatrists from abroad, with appropriate induction, can only be viewed as a short-term solution to a major recruitment problem. Unless this dilemma is resolved, the delivery of the _ NHS plan over a short time scale is almost impossible," the college said.

Unfilled posts

And in education, the shortages are getting worse. A survey of headteachers in February found nearly 10,000 unfilled posts in secondary schools in England and Wales, an increase of 150% on five months before. Although the highest vacancy rates were in London and the south-east, the Secondary Heads Association said problems were becoming more serious in the Midlands and north-east.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School masters Union of Women Teachers, said the overall shortage of teachers was probably between 20,000 and 30,000. The gap was partly filled by supply teachers, mostly from abroad.

In past years, teachers from Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and Canada provided temporary cover when permanent staff went sick. But now they were being used to fill long-term vacancies. "These overseas teachers are good kids, but they come and go. They are not the right way to staff schools permanently because their turnover is too high," Mr de Gruchy said.

Tish Seabourne, managing director of the teacher supply agency TimePlan, said 60% of the staff on her payroll were from overseas, rising to 75% in London. A recent recruitment drive in South Africa attracted 140 for the borough of Tower Hamlets. Waltham Forest was getting 70 from Australia. Other authorities are targeting New Zealand and Canada.

And the shortages are hitting hard at school leadership. John Howson, an educational employment analyst, said 60% of inner London schools failed to appoint a head when they first advertised last year - and in the north-west more than a quarter of schools had similar problems.

The government's response is to expand the number of training places for teachers and medical staff. It tries to plug gaps by targeting specific groups. For example, the latest Budget initiatives extended the golden hellos to English teachers. There will also be a £5,000 golden hello for newly-qualified GPs working in "under-doctored" areas and a £10,000 golden handcuff bonus for GPs continuing to work from 60 to 65. It is too soon to say whether these inducements will be enough to turn the tide.

Underfunding of the public sector is commonly associated with a collapsing physical infrastructure, but the lack of qualified and motivated workers who make up the human infrastructure may be harder to remedy than a shortage of buildings or equipment.

fields.headline: Future vision
fields.standfirst: Tom McNally  wants a system built on the best of what we know
fields.trailText: Tom McNally wants a system built on the best of what we know.
fields.body:
Two years ago I sat on a House of Lords Select Committee which examined the state of our public services. We found that the reforms of the Thatcher government in the 1980s had been deep and profound. Hundreds of thousands of people were moved from the public service into agencies and privatised companies. New tests of efficiency were imposed. Costs were cut. Yet our major conclusion was that the ethos of public service had survived the trauma. Somewhat to our surprise we found public servants who retained a concept of impartial service and public duty which Northcote and Trevelyan would have recognised when they reformed our public services 150 years ago.

If, then, we still have the men and women to do the job properly, do we have the political will to provide a well rewarded, well motivated public service? Can we achieve the public and political consensus to avoid the public service equivalent of stop-go and give instead a decade or more of consistent policy on which to build organisations attuned to 21st century needs? Is such consensus possible after 20 years in which the future of our public services has been the subject of bitter political differences?

On the eve of another general election the battle positions of all three parties have a vaguely 20th century air about them. Labour, having kept to spending limits which even the Conservatives would probably have abandoned, is loosening the purse strings while secretly fearing that extra resources will be swallowed by pent-up pay demands instead of producing improvements in service. The use of targets which proved such lethal weapons in opposition - targets fpr for class sizes, hospital waiting lists and police numbers - has a nasty habit of back-firing in government.

The Tories realise that the public no longer has enough faith in Thatcherite dogma to believe that the private sector holds the answers to our public service needs. In a mirror image of Labour's tax and spend apostasy, various pledges are put in place about the sanctity of public services while promised tax cuts have to rely on efficiency savings.

The Liberal Democrats for their part remain true heirs of Beveridge. They plan to rely on what the prime minister has described as the longest pee in history to finance higher public expenditure by an extra penny on the standard rate of tax. Yet over the rattling of swords as we prepare for battle there is at least the gleam of a consensus of two parties, and perhaps even three.

With too many examples of the private sector not delivering still fresh in the mind, the public sector has a chance to state its case to an electorate more welcoming than at any time since the troops came home in 1945 and said "Never again" not only to war but to 1930s style poverty.

People at large now know we cannot buy ourselves out of the problems of society as a whole with private pension provisions, private schooling, private health without creating other problems for which a bill has to be paid. Yet there is also an acceptance of a role for private thrift and personal responsibility if the behaviour of the feckless and the fraudulent are not to undermine the system and with it taxpayer support.

What is silly is to fight long and bloody political wars over the future of the public services. Far better to seek a new consensus on the need for a strong and robust public sector providing a wide range of services, but with the confidence to embrace the best of private sector practices and where it makes sense, partnership. Already there is talk of increasing hypothecation of taxes to increase tax-payer confidence that the taxes they pay go to services they want. There is talk of providing devolved government with greater local tax raising powers to establish its own priorities as to public service needs. A return to consensus would allow public servants to abandon the role of Aunt Sally and embark on a campaign to place the public service at the very heart of a successful society.

Such a campaign would require changes in attitude from public servants. London Underground workers would have to find better ways of expressing themselves than bringing the capital to a halt. Teachers would have to resist putting children in the front line of their disputes. A whole range of no-strike agreements would have to be a quid pro quo for a new status and an increased financial commitment from the taxpayer.

The building blocs of the new consensus are lying all over the political battlefield. The question is whether anyone has the courage and the vision to gather them and construct a revitalised public service for the 21st century. The alternative is not private affluence and public efficiency. It is private insecurity and public squalor.

Tom McNally is home affairs spokesman for the Liberal Democrats in the House of Lords

fields.headline: It's all about trust and moral support
fields.standfirst: Labour remembers the bad old days
fields.trailText: Labour remembers the bad old days.
fields.body:
For some the answer to the question we asked yesterday could not be simpler. Indeed, it could be boiled down to two words: more money. Ask those on the front line of public services, and they will often reply the same way. It is a lack of resources, plain and simple, which is preventing them from doing the job they so desperately want to do. The overcrowded classes could become smaller, says the school head, if only the budget could stretch to three new teachers. The cancer rate could come down, says the consultant, if only there was more money to buy hi-tech MRI machines. Prisoners could be out of their cells for longer, says the governor, if only there weren't so few guards on the already-squeezed payroll.

Labour has a straightforward response to this straightest of arguments. We agree, they say. That's why we're spending more money now - and promising to spend even more in the future: £44bn in extra departmental spending by 2003-04, with enormous waves of cash pumping into schools and hospitals.

Of course we recognise that programme of investment and we have consistently welcomed it But that does not quite end the argument. For the 18-year rundown of our public services under the Conservatives, effectively extended by Labour's two-year adherence to Tory spending limits, left Britain's infrastructure in such a shrivelled condition that even the huge sums promised by the government may not be enough. After two decades of under-investment, at least a decade of investment on an enormous scale is needed now.

Such a notion is not extravagant or even fiscally imprudent. Even by 2003-4, we should still be spending less as a share of national income than we were during the Major years. Labour's response is that today's total spend may not look that impressive, but the crucial difference is in where the money's going. While 44p of every public pound used to go toward paying off the national debt and footing the bills of social failure - unemployment benefit and the like - those items now account for just 17p. That 27p difference, says Brown, is being diverted to the neediest and to Britain's public services.

That is persuasive, but it misses a crucial change. For we can do more than merely shift the balance within our public spending. We could also spend more, in absolute terms. The nation is getting richer, tax revenues getting larger - thanks in part to the larger numbers now in work and earning a wage rather than living off the state.

Even if the right amounts of money were to start flowing into the public realm, the solution would not be complete. There are different views on how the cash should be spent. Take education. The Treasury is quite comfortable discussing extra resources for capital projects - repairing a leaky roof, building a new science lab - and for recruitment, enabling a head to hire an extra teacher or two. But they draw the line at the simplest move of all: making a dramatic increase in current teachers' pay. Even though that would transform Britain's schools, by attracting would-be professionals currently lured to more lucrative pastures elsewhere. Yes, the government is open to performance-related pay, and even to golden hellos in order to recruit staff in the needy areas of science and maths. But on the universal case, they are unmoved. They do not accept that if education were truly a national priority, then educators would be paid proper money. Nor is their view any different when it comes to the pay of other public servants whose work every politician insists we value, whether nurses or safety inspectors.

Still, if there's one theme that comes through from the 200 interviews we have published with men and women who work for the common good, it is that pay is not the central factor in their lives. It is not what motivates them: instead, they gain satisfaction from feeling genuinely useful to the people whose lives they often transform. Nor is pay the subject of their most frequent complaint. That distinction belongs to another factor altogether: control.

So many of the public servants we interviewed said it was power over their own circumstances that was missing and which they yearned for most. University professors who want to get on with teaching students, but who have to fill in box-files full of assessment forms instead; clinic managers who want to get on with treating the sick, but have to become masters of admin and bureaucracy - these are the complaints that come through loudest and clearest. You can pick your jargon word for what they seek - empowerment or autonomy - but what they really want is to be trusted to get on with the job they know best.

Labour is wary of this kind of talk, too. Their approach has been to take control for themselves, keeping close tabs on the providers of public services. So it is David Blunkett's department of education which prescribes how schools should run - bombarding heads with directives and guidelines - while it is Gordon Brown's Treasury which wants final say on the London Underground, no matter what Londoners' elected mayor or his appointed transport chief say about it. Where there were once regional health authorities, there is now a centralised, National Plan. Where there were once local education authorities, there is now head teachers and the Treasury - with next to nothing in between.

The origin of this centralising, control-freakish habit is not mysterious. Labour's high command remembers the bad old days, when public services were managed appallingly and when they failed to deliver the grand promises issued by Labour governments at the centre. That's why the government targets and monitors public work to within an inch of its life: nothing can be left to chance.

A vicious cycle is at work here. Whitehall doesn't trust local government to deliver, therefore it takes more and more of its power away (witness the evisceration of the LEAs). Those weakened local authorities begin to shrivel, attracting fewer people of calibre and garnering less legitimacy. Their service becomes poorer and in turn they become less trusted by central government. Somehow a second term Labour government has to break this cycle. It needs to learn to let go, to trust those in the country to do the country's work.

At present, the government says that it is only centralising now in order to decentralise later. But that recalls the US commander who spoke of bombing the Vietnamese village in order to save it: it makes no sense. No, now that Labour has the right template for local government it needs to give it a chance to work. Local authorities need to be able to run themselves; local services need to have the same opportunity.

That will, and should, lead to an outbreak of diversity - as different groups in different places use different methods to meet different needs. After all those who believe in decent public services are not dogmatically committed to the means by which those services is delivered - just the principle that they should be. As Matthew Taylor and Gavin Kelly argue on these pages, the founding vision of the NHS was that it should be free, universal and comprehensive, not that it should be provided through a particular structure, process or set of employees. If people on the front line want to try a new way to meet an old need they should be free to do so. In some cases that might mean, as Taylor and Kelly suggest, new partnerships between the public sector and others - whether local, voluntary groups or private enterprise. Either way, the era of the one size fits all_all-encompassing, monolithic public provider is passing.

Others including, Ed Mayo of the New Economics Foundation, seek to revive an idea deep in the left's heritage. They want the mutualisation of public services, transferring power over key functions away from the mandarins and ministers in Whitehall to stakeholders: the people who work in our services and use them. The goal, Mayo says, is to put the public back into public services.

These are not wacky, fringe ideas. On the contrary, even veteran social democrats like David Marquand are speaking the same language. He agrees that there can be no return to the pre-Thatcher days when public services were seen to be run by a condescending and exclusive elite. Instead, the social democracy of the 21st century must recover the decentralist, participatory strands in its own tradition _Top-down, central-state social democracy is a busted flush.

A kind of consensus is beginning to emerge. Yes, the sine qua non for the transformation of our public services is more money. They need that urgently and on a massive scale. They also need the kind of high-quality management which was long associated with the private sector and held to be alien to the public. These days people realise there is only good or bad management, in either sector, and our national services need the former.

But there are deeper changes needed, beyond money and management. Our public servants want to be empowered, freed to make their own decisions within broad goals set by the wider society. As our interviews today show, there are huge energies pent-up inside the key services. Yet all too often they have been thwarted by bureaucracy and state nannying. Granted greater autonomy, they will be allowed to flourish. The result will be a diversity of provision suited to the more diverse nation we are becoming. But such a shift will also see our public services gaining what they failed to develop in those crucial years before Thatcherism: roots within civic society. As a local school, hospital or library becomes the emotional, if not literal, property of the people who use it then that institution will become rooted in its community, supported and protected by it. That surely is the future we all want for our public services.

It comes down to a kind of bargain. We look to government to promise more money and more freedom. In return the public services themselves will be expected to manage themselves more efficiently, to deliver a better service and to nurture stronger roots in the communities they inhabit.

A second-term Labour government can start by giving something which is not quantifiable: moral support. They can end the rhetoric of denigration that has been routine over the last two decades, and replace it with a determination to honour those who work in public service. They can show they understand the motives of our public servants, men and women like carer Brenda Harding who washes, dresses and provides meals to the elderly. I absolutely love the work, she says of her 12 clients. You feed them, but they feed you back. People like Ms Harding represent the best of Britain. For their lives are dedicated to all of us: they work for the common good. It's time we gave them the power to do their job.

fields.headline: Battling the dreaded B-word
fields.standfirst: Richard Reeves  and  John Knell  assess progress as a government taskforce declares war on paperwork
fields.trailText: Richard Reeves and John Knell assess progress as a government taskforce declares war on paperwork.
fields.body:
'My in-tray is ridiculous,' says Spokey Wheeler. "I could spend all my time on it. I feel as if I am being asked to stick my finger in a dyke and wiggle it in the most imaginative way possible. I love my job - but the deck feels stacked against me."

As head teacher of the Wavell School in Farnborough, Wheeler laments the energy and time he devotes to paperwork. Red tape, regulation, administration - these are the most pejorative terms in the 21st-century public sector. And worst of all is the B-word: bureaucracy. Britain's public servants feel as if they are drowning in a sea of directives, regulations, rules and guidance. Head teachers are leaving the profession in a top-level "brain drain", with additional administrative burdens cited as one of the key sources of discontent.

The plight of the paper-logged principal has at least been spotted; the Government's Better Regulation Taskforce has highlighted the load faced by the women and men leading our schools - and Tony Blair has pledged to halve the flow of directives out of the Department for Education and Employment.

Setting standards

Government initiatives, such as the National Curriculum and performance-related pay, are often blamed for the rise in bureaucracy but Wheeler says that most of the problems lie elsewhere. "Yes, there are ways the Government could slim down the flow of initiatives. But by and large when bureaucracy is about setting standards, ensuring children's education it is impossible to oppose," he says.

"The real problem is this: I spend hours dealing with staffing problems caused by a shortage of suitably qualified teachers."

Similarly, health care professionals expend a huge amount of time and effort organising cover for short-staffed wards and surgeries. Doctors spend hours chasing beds for patients. It is not the bureau cracy causing the problem - it is the problem, in this case inadequate resources, causing the bureaucracy. It is the symptom, not the disease.

Nonetheless there has been a step-change in perceptions of bureaucracy - driven by two critical factors: first, the importing of a pro-business, market-know-best philosophy and second, the separation of bureaucracy from the values it is supposed to uphold, in particular accountability and responsibility.

Large organisations - and in particular public sector agencies - are increasingly seen as sclerotic, encased in rules and incapable of radical action. Management guru Tom Peters sets the tone when he says: "I beg each and every one of you to develop a passionate and public hatred of bureaucracy."

But Stephen Martin, head of Reed Executive, says a more sophisticated view of bureaucracy is required in both the public and private sector. "We need to distinguish between good bureaucracy - which establishes a clear system of checks and evaluations and bad bureaucracy, where the form-filling is more important than the doing, where every action has to generate a piece of relevant paper."

Choked on paper

The paper trail that Martin identifies chokes initiatives such as the New Deal, where "the emphasis is about getting pieces of information on pieces of paper". The Employment Service produces 49 pieces of paper for each New Dealer, according the Wise Group, a Scottish training and work-placement agency.

And while public-private partnerships (PPPs) are vaunted by the Government as a mechanism for bringing private sector "efficiency" into the state sector, in practice the influence has been at least as much in the opposite direction. Companies who are working with the public sector end up adopting similar procedures, according to Martin, whose company works with the New Deal and Employment Zones. Rather than PPP marketising the public sector, they are bureaucratising the private sector.

At the same time, firms are complaining that the weight of administering the Working Families Tax Credit, minimum wage, stakeholder pensions, Working Time Directive and so on is becoming unbearable. The tendrils of the bureaucratic state are spreading, the business lobby complains. Farmers spend four hours a week filling forms rather than tilling fields. But in truth, the introduction of progressive workplace regulations is a cross that firms ought to bear if they want to trade in a civilised society.

Bureaucracy, as Wheeler points out, "is only ever what other people do." So the fact that middle managers in blue-chip companies spend hours, according to one survey, looking for a lost file, is not "bureaucracy" - but maternity leave extensions are. Hugely complex internal change management and evaluation systems are not bureaucracy - but the minimum wage is.

In the public sector, the challenge is less to abolish or attack bureaucracy than to root out bad bureaucracy and strengthen good bureaucracy. Recent crises in the public sector, such as the North Wales care homes, Hackney Social Services, Railtrack and MAFF on the BSE epidemic have highlighted the lack of accountability in many areas of the public sector.

Reinvention required

This is why Paul Du Gay, author of In Praise of Bureaucracy, argues for a reinvention of bureaucracy rather than its abandonment in favour of a free-wheeling entrepreneurial culture. Otherwise we risk losing "fairness, probity and reliability in the treatment of cases and other forms of conduct that were taken somewhat for granted under traditional arrangements".

Effective bureaucracy provides systems for ensuring that the right person is held accountable for the right action. Bad bureaucracy, the kind which has flourished in recent years, dilutes accountability through the creation of lengthy paper trails: e-mail, of course, simply fuelling this cover-my-back tendency. Bureaucracy has become a hiding place for poor management in public sector - the wall behind which some public servants can hide.

This then is the paradox of bureaucracy in Britain's once proudly-bureaucratic public services: front-line staff are overwhelmed with the "bureaucratic" pressures caused by insufficient resources and poor management while Whitehall mandarins have become adept at using bureaucracy to defuse the very fibre of public service - accountability.

Spokey Wheeler is not opposed to good bureaucracy. "I am passionate about raising standards, and that means systems of evaluation and monitoring," he says.

"We all want to be stretched, to reach for that goal which is just beyond our fingertips. But right now, because of the time spent on administering to unnecessary issues, you have to be Magic Johnson to get anywhere close. I'm just not sure how long we can keep trying."

Richard Reeves is director of Futures at the Industrial Society and John Knell is deputy director

fields.headline: Social work team manager, Islington
fields.standfirst:
Gloria Hurren
Salary: £31,300
fields.trailText:
Gloria Hurren
Salary: £31,300
fields.body:
I manage a team of eight social workers, looking after 83 children in care and 40 or so more who are on the child protection register. I supervise, allocate cases and do child care reviews.

We feel under-resourced - there aren't enough of us and all the social workers under me are carrying too many cases.

My constant fear is that a child will slip through the net: you've seen the criticism heaped on social workers when that happens.

We do feel undervalued. I think that's because no one really wants to know what social workers do. We're associated with the lowest of the low - people who abuse their children. Social workers also aren't good at explaining what our skills are.

I've been a social worker for 31 years, and the role has changed tremendously in that time. It was a different economic climate when I started, and for the first 20 years I never thought about doing anything else. That changed in the 1990s when we were required to specialise.

The other major change has been that, because our service has been centralised by the council, we've lost our close connection with the local community through small neighbourhood offices. It's more prescriptive and bureaucratic, with government initiatives cascading down on already hard-pressed teams. Some of them are good, but we feel overwhelmed because of lack of resources.

Our caseload has grown, which reflects the increase in poverty and housing and education problems. Every five weeks up to six new cases are added to our work-load.

Pay has never been an issue for me, in the sense that I'm not in social work for the money. I do feel a bit bothered now when I see the pay increases teachers are being offered. I supervise, allocate cases and do child care reviews. We feel under-resourced - there aren't enough of us and all the social workers under me are carrying too many cases. My constant fear is that a child will slip through the net: you've seen the criticism heaped on social workers when that happens. We do feel undervalued. I think that's because no one really wants to know what social workers do. We're associated with the lowest of the low - people who abuse their children. It was a different economic climate when I started, and for the first 20 years I never thought about doing anything else. That changed in the 1990s when we were required to specialise.
