webTitle: What price for a roof over your head?

fields.headline: What price for a roof over your head?
fields.standfirst: The capital and south are pricing out those who service them.  Felicity Lawrence  reports
fields.trailText: The capital and south are pricing out those who service them. Felicity Lawrence reports.
fields.body:
Mike Shurety is a personnel director for the police, Christine Whatford is a chief education officer for a local authority, Deborah O'Dea is a director of human resources at a leading London hospital, but in the last couple of years they have all had to become experts in a completely new field. Housing.

No matter that new money is available for employing more officers on the beat, teachers in the classroom or nurses on the ward, they cannot attract the people they need. Each is trying to deal with a crisis in recruitment to their branch of public services and the crux of the matter is the price of property.

There are large parts of the south of England where people on the lower and middle rungs of public sector salaries can no longer afford to live. Experienced professionals from the north who might want to move jobs find themselves priced out of the market.

As Whatford explains "You have to be very rich, or in social housing or to have bought your house donkey's years ago" to be able to live near her schools in Hammersmith and Fulham. "It has got markedly worse in the last 18 months. I didn't know anything about housing till it became such a problem."

Loss of staff

The experience is common to the Metropolitan police. "We lose one in five officers because of the cost of housing," says Shurety.

"We traditionally rely on recruiting 50% of officers from outside a 70-mile radius of the capital, but they don't want to come. The further they get pushed out by prices, the harder it is to get them in for shifts."

O'Dea's hospital, St Mary's Paddington, has a vacancy rate of 20% for nurses. In its report to the housing commission set up by the mayor of London to look into the scale of the problem, St Mary's said it had offered about 200 jobs to people who did not take them up because they could not afford to live within reach of the hospital.

Chris Holmes, director of the housing group Shelter, chaired the commission and warns that if the problem is not tackled, maintaining the infrastructure in the south-east will be increasingly hard.

"People in the £15,000-£25,000 income range are being hit. It's not just nurses, teachers and police, it's also firefighters, social workers, civil servants. Evidence from a local education authorities' survey showed that a shortage of housing was the biggest single problem affecting recruitment and retention of staff."

Since the 1980s London house prices have risen by 3.9% a year to an average of £180,000, but wages have grown by only 2.7%. Even in relatively deprived areas in the south, the price of houses has soared so that it now outstrips average salaries by a ratio of seven to one or more.

In the US, they have already had to confront this 21st-century city affliction, the crisis of affluence, in the upmarket skiing resort of Aspen, Colorado, where prices rocketed as property was snapped up for holiday homes. Because no one else could afford to live there, the rich new part-time residents found themselves without the vital workers needed to make the town function.

The infrastructure started to collapse. Where the market was failing to meet a clear need, the state had to step in. The city began to offer subsidised housing to any family of four earning less than about £74,000 a year. Almost 50% of its permanent population qualifies for some subsidy and developers have been forced to set aside up to 70% of new homes for affordable accommodation.

In New York, employers have had to take action. New York University has built 10,000 residential units for staff and students in the city in the last 10 years.

Employers in London are also looking at ways of helping key workers. The Metropolitan police has negotiated free travel for some staff and can provide subsidised rental accommodation for new recruits. Many hospitals provide subsidised rooms for student nurses.

Home ownership

But a return to the tied houses of previous centuries, where having somewhere to live depended on the patronage of the boss is not the answer. There is now recognition that any solution has to take workers' aspiration to home ownership into account.

In Britain, the government has announced a Starter Homes Initiative under which 10,000 public sector workers will be eligible for grants averaging £25,000 to help them get a foot on the property ladder in London. The scheme will cost £250m over three years, but the grants are available only on houses worth up to about £100,000, well below the price of an average family home in most areas.

The Peabody Trust, a charity established by an American philanthropist in the 19th century, is working on a project with seven partners, including the NHS, local authorities, bus companies and the private sector, to develop a new model for providing housing for key workers.

The scheme, called Keep London Working, will create 150 or so homes over the new few years for those employed in the public sector. Some will be rented at subsidised rates, and some will be available for shared equity purchase.

With shared equity people can get a toehold in the property market and, if they want, trade up later, while the Trust keeps a proportion of the houses in perpetuity to offer to other key workers later.

"We're still trying to work out the details," says Peabody's director of development, Dickon Robinson, "but what we really need to do is extend some of these principles to the commercial sector."

Affordable houses

The full force of the crisis is yet to come. Many key workers entered the market years ago when it was still within reach. As they start to retire, affordable housing on the scale required will have to come from private developers.

Local authorities can use their planning powers to make developers provide a percentage of cheap housing on new sites, but there is a huge variation between different areas.

"It is much better that affordable homes are provided within developments. It avoids the segregation between council and private housing that used to create ghettos," says Holmes. "In Hammersmith and Fulham they have made it a priority and achieved 50% affordable housing on new developments, but over the river Wandsworth says it doesn't need any."

Other councils have allowed developers to sell back their obligation to provide mixed housing and used the cash for other needs.

The signs are that where councils take the lead, developers have woken up to the issues. St George, a major property developer, has a 10-year building programme at London's Imperial Wharf, which mixes social housing for rent, with some "shared ownership" property, student accommodation contracted to university organisations, homes for the elderly, and private flats selling at £300,000 and more.

Charmaine Young, the company's director of regeneration, says this will be the pattern of the future. "We're being brave in embracing a wider agenda. But gated developments a la Chelsea Wharf are not the way forward. There is an enormous shift in what you can negotiate now and we recognise that. The low waged but economically active are struggling so badly, it's having an impact on employers and services."


Paying the price for a career in the classroom

Toni Davis started as a new teacher at Kenmont Primary school in north west London last September and she loves her job. Her school is in a inner city area where teaching is tough, but she has a supportive head and she believes in what she is doing. The problem is money. She earns £19,000, which gives her about £1,100 a month to take home after tax. In the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham where she works the average price of a two-bedroom house is £230,000, so buying or renting near school are not possibilities. Instead she has gone out as far as Welyn Garden City to find affordable accommodation, and she and her partner pay £450 a month for a small one-bedroom flat. Like many new graduates, she has a student loan to pay off, which takes another £350 a month from her salary. Because she has to live so far away, travel also eats up a lot of her time and money. She spends £200 a month commuting by car (bought with a graduate loan). The train would take longer and be more expensive, and anyway isn't really practical because there are so many delays and she has to be certain of getting to school by 7am. She is left with only a couple of hundred pounds a month for all her other expenses. Her partner is an auditor earning £18,000; the maximum mortgage they have been offered is £110,000.

"In the future I want a family and a house with a garden and if teaching stays the way it is, I'll have to think twice about carrying on, even though I love it. I look at my friends in the City and they haven't even been to university and they're earning double what I am."

Her colleague Edward Bradley faces a similar dilemma. He wants to live in London but can only afford an 8ft by 8ft room in a shared ex-council house. "I work hard and I'd love to buy my own house, but you have to move out of the profession if you want to do that. We're all committed and we're not just doing it for the money, but we want a future."

For Kenmont head Melody Moran housing has become a preoccupation. Only half her staff were permanent when she took over two years ago, and recruitment and retention of teachers was a key issue in the school's Ofsted report. She has tackled the problem by bringing in young staff. "When you are starting out the attractions of city life help compensate for grotty accommodation. "But my next problem is, how am I going to get them to stay?

"After their first year or so people say, 'I don't want to live like this, I don't want to travel so far', and it's tough in inner cities. I haven't been able to get a supply temp since December. It is a terrible crisis."

fields.headline: Andrew Foster, Audit commission controller
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

"Nothing great was ever achieved without enthusiasm," said Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American philosopher. And one thing is for sure: there is little doubting the enthusiasm or appetite for modernisation of either the government or the wider public sector at the present time. Initiatives abound. There are targets for this and that. Plans proliferate. But what of delivery?

There is clearly a problem here. Some services may well be improving, but others, or parts of others are not. Managers and staff may well be delivering to specific targets, but sometimes at the expense of the bigger picture.

And whatever the complex realities of service delivery, the perception in the eyes of those who receive them is one of some service failure. Recent surveys show that one in three people feel that public services have got worse in recent years. And well-publicised "scandals" mean that professional groups - such as doctors, social workers, and those in the criminal justice system - who used to command high levels of trust and respect are now suffering a backlash. Given that people need services, and services they can trust, delivery is then the biggest problem facing the government and the public sector at the moment.

Where do we go from here?

Another huge challenge will be how best to involve the users of public services when drawing up strategies for delivery, while at the same time managing their increasing expectations. A new generation is growing up which doesn't have welfare anxiety, which no longer expects the state to provide well for its every need. For example, more and more of us are investing in company or private pensions and other financial products for our old age.

However, this new generation expects the services they still rely on - health, for example - to be of a much higher quality. And there are still those from previous generations who expect the contract they think they signed 50 years ago to be fulfilled.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

Those delivering frontline services in the immediate future then are even more likely than now to find themselves between the rock of political pressure and the hard place of public expectation and opinions. What Whitehall must realise is that more of the same will just not do. It will need a lighter touch and allow for much more to be delegated to a local level where people are more able to see the obstacles to delivery. In short, it needs to strengthen its management delivery skills.

This will need to be matched by a lighter touch regulatory framework, one that acknowledges that less direct management and more delegation from Whitehall means that a new breed of public sector leader is needed. Leaders who are allowed to innovate and be entrepreneurs. There is a myth that people in the private sector take risks. They don't, they manage them and that's just what the public sector has to start to do.

If these problems are not addressed, then the public sector could soon face a recruitment crisis. For there is undoubtedly enthusiasm at all levels, but this needs to be harnessed and released so that not only staff morale is reinvigorated, but so is delivery, public engagement and ultimately choice.

Andrew Foster is controller of the audit commission for local government and the health service in England and Wales

fields.headline: Cathryn Whiteside, IT marketing manager
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

Public servants will, I think, have to be much more courageous as they think about service delivery in the electronic age. But I hope and expect there to be a much closer relationship between them and us: we need more secondments to and from the sector, boundaries are going to have to blur little, perhaps even in terms of temperaments. There is one thing of which I am certain: the public sector is going to offer more scope for people as individuals, to think creatively.

At HP we give a lot of independence to individuals. I am encouraged to take risks, even to go to the brink of failure and relish the discoveries that you may make en route - that is inherent in our culture. Public sector colleagues tend to be more risk averse, less willing to move beyond the comfortable. But that is because they have to answer to politicians and auditors with the media watching at every step. There is a tendency to make things overly complicated.

But I am convinced there are as many good people in the public sector as anywhere. It is a question of harnessing their flair. They deserve a break.

Where do we go from here?

The market for electronic government services is growing - next year it has been estimated at £10bn. The public sector will continue changing its shape in the next 10 years, passing more services over to the private sector to deliver with the consequence that public sector personnel will have to become more strategic, less hands on in the way they work.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

Our business is not just helping the public sector get online or deliver services electronically. We need to step back and think about reorganising service delivery in the round - not just replicate paper-based processes electronically.

A lot has been happening in the public sector in terms of procurement and the opening up of the internet's potential but so far IT in government has not been tremendously useful for Joe Public.

I suppose we are in the business of transformation - fundamentally altering the way citizens get access to information about the public sector and interact with it. We have so far seen only the tip of the iceberg of how the citizen will engage with government via the new means of communication. Work we have been doing in Sweden has shown the huge potential in all areas of government-citizen interaction.

Hewlett Packard is a major supplier of IT services to the public sector and Cathryn Whiteside, who has been with the firm 15 years, is government marketing manager

fields.headline: Sebert Cox, Housing chairman
fields.trailText: What are the problems?
fields.body:
What are the problems?

There are differences between public, private and voluntary sectors - the public sector tends to be constrained by rules that are often inflexible and hence is slower - but our focus all the time ought to be what we can do and deliver not who is doing and delivering. That is why partnerships between the sectors are so terribly important.

Where do we go from here?

The public sector will always find new things to do in response to growing social problems and will continue treating traditional problems and providing such services as education, housing and health care.

But I certainly expect in the next few years to see the independent, voluntary and private sectors taking on a much bigger role in delivering such services. That has to be welcome because there is a wealth of expertise in those sectors that ought to be tapped.

How do we restore public confidence/trust in the public sector?

Democracy, I suppose you could say, has a cost: people in local authorities tend to have to check things out with those who elected or appointed them on a regular basis. If they did not have to do that, things would move quicker.

In public health, education and housing it takes time for the resources to hit the ground to realise results, and people are now much more impatient about seeing things happen.

It's not that the public sector does things badly, as some have alleged.

Take housing, for example. Is there convincing evidence that tenants believe councils to be worse landlords? Not if you look at the results of various recent polls. What they do is look at the resources alternative landlords can bring. Mythology abounds. It is often said private sector rents are always higher, which is not the case.

People fantasise too, about private sector pay levels. What we do need to do is break down the structures governing pay and conditions that inhibit movement of staff: we do need to attract the best of the private sector into public service. Private finance helps. At Places for People dependence on public funding for housing is constraining; bringing private money in helps us to be much more innovative in tackling the traditional problems.

webTitle: 'My dad is a living deterrent to becoming a teacher'

fields.headline: 'My dad is a living deterrent to becoming a teacher'
fields.standfirst: Oliver Burkeman discovers that the school generation doesn't really want to join in
fields.trailText: Oliver Burkeman discovers that the school generation doesn't really want to join in.
fields.body:
Melanie Zaalof was in a police station in central Birmingham when it hit her. "I was doing a work placement there when a call came in to rescue a five-year-old girl who was at risk in a house nearby," the 18-year-old A-level student recalls. "It took exactly two hours and fifteen minutes of filling out forms and filing papers before the officers could go and rescue that girl. And I just thought - that's not right. It can't be."

But drowning in paperwork is only one of many reasons why Zaalof and her fellow students at Bournville secondary school in Birmingham baulk at the prospect of life in the public services. For Douglas Brown, the 17-year-old son of two teachers, it was the dawning realisation that working in the classroom was much like being a nightclub bouncer that did it. "Three-quarters of the time it's just crowd control," he says. "No wonder so many people get so disillusioned with it." At least nightclub bouncers get free drinks.

There is nothing scientifically representative about Bournville, of course, but it is as good a snapshot of late-teenage Britain as any: an ethnically diverse urban comprehensive with a larger than average intake of below average pupils - popular with parents, rated good and improving when the Ofsted inspectors last called.

Here, if anywhere, is where the next generation of doctors and nurses, teachers and police officers, civil servants and air traffic controllers must be found. But if they are thin on the ground - and they are - it is not for the reason that might be expected. Money, in fact, is almost never mentioned.

It may be a timeless commonplace that each generation is more selfish than the last, bored by the pride in serving the community that supposedly quickened their parents' hearts - but it isn't true. When Bournville's 16- to 18-year-olds shun public-sector careers, they are not rebelling: they are following the advice of parents who took those jobs themselves and now dread their children doing the same.

"My dad is living proof for me, a living deterrent never to become a teacher," says one 16-year-old, an aspiring actor, echoing a widespread view. "He thought he could do it for five years, then quit, but by then he'd got a mortgage. He comes home every day regretting his decision, and now he's stuck with it until he retires. He doesn't want me to get trapped like that."

Hillcrest School, down the road from Bournville, has an arguably even more important role to play in the current recruitment crisis in the public services: it is an all-girls state school, and 80% of workers in the sector are women. There are some old-fashioned gripes among older students here - bureaucracy, lack of appreciation, too much routine - but one prevalent objection is of much more recent origin.

"You're constantly in the public eye and at risk of ending up in the papers - this doctor's done that, this teacher's done this, this nurse has done that," says Hayley-Jayne Kellerman, 16, who - despite everything, and seemingly uniquely - wants to teach maths (her academic father, needless to say, would rather she entered the world of finance). "My stepmother's a pathologist, and after the organ scandals they came in, opened all the morgues, looked through all the files - it was just too much stress for her. The majority is judged by the minority."

But even the traditional benefits of public sector work, such as relative job security, seem unattractive now. The anchorless insecurity of the new economy may have its losers - thousands of late-shift call-centre workers for every internet millionaire - but seeking the stability of a public service job seems like a kind of defeatism: an admission that one didn't even try to be a winner.

"Our generation is predicted to change career four times during our lives," says 18-year-old Seema Parmar. "I don't want to look back on my life and see that I went into a job because it was safe and stayed there forever."

"You're going to spend most of your life doing it, so it might as well be meaningful," says Tom Willshire at Bournville. "I'm told that the job I want will mean forget having girlfriends, forget having a regular place to live or anything like that, for years, but I'm happy to make that sacrifice."

There are pockets of enthusiasm for public service, mostly among those who say they would be teachers or hospital staff for almost any money, because they can never remember having wanted to do anything else. But even they have a more fundamental objection: that it is not rewarding to work in those services to which people are entitled - precisely because they act like they're entitled.

"People think they have a right, and they do," says Gina Hinsley, 17, who is more interested in marketing or advertising. "So they think - well, you better be a good teacher because it's my money, and I'm paying taxes. You don't get credit for being good."

This doesn't seem like selfishness - more like a refusal to accept that ambition and service need be antithetical. But Bournville's and Hillcrest's future young professionals know that, at the moment, they seem to be: they have, after all, spent the last 14 years watching their teachers find that out. "And let's face it," says Lauren Adkins, 18, who wants to work at the Home Office. "Some pupils are nightmares."

When Bournville and Hillcrest students go to the movies, as often as not they end up at Warner StarCity, the sprawling megaplex on the outskirts of Birmingham that is Britain's largest cinema complex. There is something for every taste - 30 screens showing Hollywood, Bollywood and European films - but the teacher training adverts they see before the films these days seem baffling, ridiculous. What kind of propaganda campaign could ever hope to counteract everything a sixth-former already knows about schooling?

"They've got Nick Hancock and Dawn French talking about how they taught for a year, how rewarding it was, and how they went on to be superstars," says Tom Willshire. "Well, if most teachers taught for a year and then went off to be Nick Hancock, they'd probably find it rewarding too."

Similar recruitment drives elsewhere in the sector meet with equally withering responses. "You read Black Woman magazine or something, and it's full of adverts for police recruitment," says Lauren Adkins. "For me, that's patronising, the idea that you have to be of a certain colour for them to really want you. But the police are just seen as going about nitpicking - I've got a friend who was fined for putting his seatbelt on as he drove off instead of before he started the car - so do they really think we're going to apply because of a magazine ad?"

But it is Caleb Opuku, an 18-year-old at Bournville, who puts it most succinctly. "With all these jobs, you can't just keep telling someone that something's not the way it is, over and over again," he says. "It's just not going to work."

webTitle: Lessing honoured for lifetime of writing

fields.headline: Lessing honoured for lifetime of writing
fields.standfirst: Author, 81, who started working when 'death knell' of novel was announced, wins £30,000 prize
fields.trailText: Author, 81, who started working when 'death knell' of novel was announced, wins £30,000 prize
fields.body:
The richest book prize in Britain went last night to Doris Lessing, author of 45 books, among them two landmark novels of modern English fiction, The Grass is Singing and The Golden Notebook.

She won the £30,000 David Cohen prize which is worth £4,000 more than the Whitbread and unique in the crop of British book awards in honouring a lifetime of excellence.

Mrs Lessing, 81, accepted the prize from the culture secretary, Chris Smith, at a London ceremony - 52 years after she arrived in Britain from Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, to be confronted by a media article announcing that the novel was dead as a literary form.

But in her suitcase was a manuscript which helped restore the novel to blazing life when it reached bookshops the following year, 1950.

It was her first book, The Grass is Singing. Published two years after South Africa made world headlines by electing its first white supremacist government, it told of the disintegration of a farming couple in her childhood homeland.

Prophetically, it was about the slow death of the white impulse and ability to maintain colonies. The novelist CP Snow praised her as writing with more "sheer horsepower" than any author since DH Lawrence.

More than half a century later, she remains cherished by a steady readership for her 19 other novels and nine volumes of short stories.

She has also been a political and cultural activist. Her other most praised novel, The Golden Notebook, is often seen as a central text of feminism, though she has said this is not its main theme.

Last night Gerry Robinson, chairman of the Arts Council, which administers the award, called her books "an accumulation of excellence - a body of work that has in its unique and determined way shaped the literary landscape".

In her speech, Mrs Lessing called the award "the best, the nicest of all our literary prizes. I really do feel so honoured, so pleased".

In a resounding defence of British novelists since the second world war as "an astonishing period in this country's literature", she championed other authors who were writing, or beginning to write, when "the death knell" of the novel was announced in 1949.

They included Evelyn Waugh, Graham Greene, Ivy Compton Burnett, William Golding, Kingsley Amis and Anthony Burgess. "That period has been the most lively, original, productive and inventive one. I am proud to have been part of it."

She conceded that it might prove to be a "silver age" of the novel rather than a golden one. "But we do not know which of our silver products will be judged as gold by our successors, nor does it matter." The two-yearly Cohen award, modelled on the French Prix Goncourt and also open to poets, playwrights and biographers, comes from a private family trust fund formed by David and Veronica Cohen. Dr Cohen said: "We set it up because there seemed to be a gap in British literary prizes. Unlike the French, we do not honour lifelong great writers. I am pleased that so far it has tended to go to outsiders who are not really establishment people."

Other winners have been VS Naipaul, Harold Pinter, Muriel Spark and William Trevor. The Welsh poet RS Thomas was a likely candidate for the latest award until his death last year.

Each winner gets £10,000 extra from the Arts Council to give to a young writer or literature group. Mrs Lessing - remembering a 1927 Rhodesian show staged by a boys' school wearing bedsheets as togas - gave hers to a London youth outreach theatre project, led by the Royal National Theatre, with a name which could serve as a subtitle for all her books: The Art of Regeneration.

The judging panel was rare among literary awards in being without celebrities. Led by the poet laureate Andrew Motion, it included the biographer Michael Holroyd, the literature professor Dame Gillian Beer, the actor Simon Callow, the ex-prisons inspector Sir Stephen Tumim and the Guardian literary editor, Claire Armitstead.

The Grass is Singing (1950)

Then as she heard the thunder growl and shake in the trees, the sky lit up, and she saw a man's shape move out from the dark and come towards her, gliding silently up the steps, while the dogs stood alertly watching, their tails swinging in welcome. Two yards away Moses stopped. She could see his great shoulders, the shape of his head, the glistening of his eyes. And, at the sight of him, her emotions unexpectedly shifted, to create in her an extraordinary feeling of guilt; but towards him, to whom she had been disloyal, and at the bidding of the Englishman. She felt she had only to move forward, to explain, to appeal and the terror would be dissolved. She opened her mouth to speak; and, as she did so, saw his hand, which held a long curving shape, lifted above his head; and she knew it would be too late. All her past slid away, and her mouth, opened in appeal, let out the beginning of a scream, which was stopped by a black wedge of hand inserted between her jaws. But the scream continued in her stomach, choking her; and she lifted her hands, clawlike, to ward him off. And then the bush avenged itself; that was her last thought. The trees advanced in a rush, like beasts, and the thunder was the noise of their coming.

When the dark returned [Moses] took his hand from the wall, and walked slowly through the rain towards the bush. Though what thoughts of regret, or pity, or perhaps even wounded human affection were compounded with the satisfaction of his completed revenge, it is impossible to say. For, when he had gone perhaps a couple of hundred yards through the soaking bush he turned, stopped, turned aside and leaned against a tree on an ant-heap. And there he would remain until his pursuers, in their turn, came to find him.

The Golden Notebook (1962)

But Anna would not laugh. "No, it's serious. Both of us are dedicated to the proposition that we're tough - no listen, I'm serious. I mean - a marriage breaks up, well, we say, our marriage was a failure, too bad. A man ditches us - too bad we say, it's not important. We bring up kids without men - nothing to it, we say, we can cope. We spend years in the communist party and then we say, Well, well, we made a mistake, too bad".

"What are you trying to say?", said Molly, very cautious, and at a great distance from Anna.

"Well, don't you think it's at least possible, just possible that things can happen to us so bad that we don't ever get over them? Because when I really face it I don't think I've really got over Michael. I think it's done for me".

"But it has to be on with the next thing."

"Why do our lot never admit failure? Never. It might be better for us if we did. And it's not only love and men. Why can't we say something like this - we are people, because of the accident of how we were situated in history, who were so powerfully part - but only in our imaginations, and that's the point - of the great dream, that now we have to admit that the great dream has faded and the truth is something else - that we'll never be any use. After all, Molly, it's not much loss is it, a few people, a few people of a certain type, saying that they've had it, they're finished. Why not? It's almost arrogant not to be able to."

webTitle: Three-star rating bypasses top beacon council

fields.headline: Three-star rating bypasses top beacon council
fields.trailText: More evidence has emerged that the best value regime is too tough after one of the top council housing departments in the country failed to pass a test that would give it access to a £160m government fund aimed at rewarding excellence.
fields.body:
More evidence has emerged that the best value regime is too tough after one of the top council housing departments in the country failed to pass a test that would give it access to a £160m government fund aimed at rewarding excellence.

A draft report by the housing inspectorate has given Kirkless council just two stars for its housing repairs - councils need three stars to access the fund - even though the council has been awarded beacon status by the government for its model repairs service.

Kirklees gained beacon status by having some of the best tenant satisfaction levels in the country for its repairs service and some of the fastest repairs response times.

The inspectorate's draft assessment has raised more doubts about the ability of any council to gain three stars. It comes after only two-star ratings were given to the highly regarded Harrogate council and Carrick council, which is also a beacon council on repairs. The inspectorate's excellence criteria has been criticised as being too exacting.

It is understood Kirklees's chief housing officer Tony Hood has written to the inspectorate highlighting that many of the points raised in the draft inspection report had been met or were about to be met.

Ann Raistrick, Liberal Democrat spokeswoman on housing at the council said: "What do we have to do get three stars? If we can't get there, when we are considered a beacon authority, then what chance the others?"

But she added: "Two stars is a good achievement, but it does not mean we are complacent. There is sense of slight disappointment, but we have got to be realistic, this was a snapshot survey."

Chartered Institute of Housing policy director John Perry said: "This is going to throw further doubt on the ability of other authorities to get three stars. The longer we have to wait for three stars to be awarded, and the more well thought of authorities fail to get three stars, the less likely it is that councils will gear up to the extra spending."

fields.bodyText: More evidence has emerged that the best value regime is too tough after one of the top council housing departments in the country failed to pass a test that would give it access to a £160m government fund aimed at rewarding excellence. A draft report by the housing inspectorate has given Kirkless council just two stars for its housing repairs - councils need three stars to access the fund - even though the council has been awarded beacon status by the government for its model repairs service. Kirklees gained beacon status by having some of the best tenant satisfaction levels in the country for its repairs service and some of the fastest repairs response times. fields.headline: Ticket to slide
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: With railways run by men who think a super saver is the person who cuts passengers out of the wreckage, the profit motive has not enjoyed a run of good publicity lately.
fields.body:
It is heartening but not surprising to read that the bulk of British people have had enough of privatisation. With railways run by men who think a super saver is the person who cuts passengers out of the wreckage, the profit motive has not enjoyed a run of good publicity lately.

I suspect that many rail passengers would also prefer the old surly and drably clad guard of yesteryear to what is now called the "Customer Operations Leader". That's not a job; it's just three random words strung together. He might as well announce himself as the Drummer Crisps Sandal. We want someone who gives the impression that he might know something about trains, not a man who looks and sounds like a holiday rep. The creative use of mauve does nothing for our confidence in our short-term future.

Londoners clearly want the underground to be run by the state. They will be highly bemused by John Prescott hiring as a spin-doctor a mate who has been lobbying him on behalf of consortia bidding to run the tube and air traffic control. Companies pay a man to advise a friend in government to consider their bids, and then the man gets a job advising his friend. Not what you might call an uphill struggle his career, is it?

The soundings put out by Prescott to bring private companies into the tube have been highly secret. However, I can exclusively reveal that some of the responses might have been as follows:

"Yes, sure. What's the tube?"

"How about turning it into luxury basement flats?"

"What's in it for us?"

"When you say safe, how safe does it have to be?"

Of course, the railways, schools and hospitals do need money, and private business has it. The question is how we get hold of it. We'd save an awful lot of bother if we just took it. After all, businessmen rely on the state to educate, nurse and transport the workforce. If companies want their staff delivered promptly and in one piece every morning, they should pay up. I'm not saying London Underground should threaten to act like a private company and start killing the passengers; I just mean the private sector needs the public sector more than the other way around.

Partnerships and the private finance initiative have done no more for the profit motive's reputation than has wholesale privatisation. They are so clearly schemes for handing public money to building firms that there is no question about the government's ideological position. It believes in transferring risk on to private contractors, who in turn transfer it on to train passengers.

The government is hostile to public ownership and holds private business in utter reverence. Capitalists receive so many state benefits that the rest of us are entitled to demand that they be humiliated by Department of Social Security officers from time to time. Balfour Beatty shareholders should be made to attend Restart interviews. Actually, what with export credit guarantees, businessmen are probably entitled to more state handouts than they are aware of. Perhaps they lose more in unclaimed benefits than they gain in tax breaks.

Apparently, the polls show that some privatisation is to our liking, notably that of BT. This, I don't understand. Why should hundreds of young Glaswegians go through the humiliation of having to ring customers at all hours to ask if we want any more friends or family? Is this the rationale behind teenage chat-lines - to train a whole generation of young people for a future making needless phone calls? Is this what we want for our children?

And frankly, the time one spends fielding calls from people telling us how we can save money more than outweighs the benefits of any possible saving. Let us seize back the utilities that once were our birthright, and no longer be pestered by desperate youngsters asking us of we want our gas supplied by the water board or our electricity delivered by Pizza Hut. I imagine that, after Prescott's chum has finished lobbying for the air traffic sell-off, Nats will be replaced by a call centre, and pilots will receive random radio transmissions advising them on how they could save lives by crashing in the sea.

Mind you, while Ken Livingstone is battling with Prescott over the tube, he is himself privatising policing. Private security is visible all over London, though why Trafalgar Square needs bouncers I don't know. Too many jeans and trainer, perhaps. But shouldn't the public own the means of repression? At least the real cops throw us down the stairs; private ones will probably drop us.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Crackdown on bigots | Two held over family murder | Snow showers greet spring | Firefighter cleared | Strike hits Eurostar | Libyan envoy at palace
fields.body:
Crackdown on bigots

Police raided dozens of homes across London yesterday in Scotland Yard's biggest single crackdown on racist and homophobic crime. The raids led to more than 100 arrests.

The alleged offences included racially aggravated threats to kill, homophobic harassment, and the publication of racist and homophobic material.

Two held over family murder

A 38-year-old man was still being questioned by police last night after being arrested on suspicion of murdering Swansea Valley grandmother Dorris Dawson, her daughter, Mandy Powell, and granddaughters, Katie and Emily Powell, who were bludgeoned to death at their home in Clydach 21 months ago.

Late yesterday a 32-year-old woman was arrested on suspicion of perverting the course of justice, police said.

Snow showers greet spring

The first day of spring was greeted with snow showers and sub-zero temperatures in parts of England and Wales yesterday.

Firefighter cleared

Firefighter Mark Stewart was cleared at the Old Bailey yesterday of causing the death of Mark Burns, 24, by dangerous driving while driving through red traffic lights answering an emergency call at Burgh Heath, Surrey, in December 1999.

Strike hits Eurostar

Eurostar passengers to Brussels will face disruption to Channel tunnel train services on Friday because of a 24 hour strike by Belgian rail workers, it was announced yesterday. Eurostar services to Paris will be operating normally.

Libyan envoy at palace

The Queen sealed diplomatic relations with Libya yesterday when the first Libyan ambassador to London in 17 years, Mohamed Abdul Quasim Al-Zwai, presented his credentials.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Whitehall officials predicted 40 years ago that South Africa would either be partitioned on racial lines or there would be a "bloodbath leading to black domination".
fields.body:
 Whitehall officials predicted 40 years ago that South Africa would either be partitioned on racial lines or there would be a "bloodbath leading to black domination".

Their prediction to ministers is revealed in papers released yesterday at the public record office.

A secret paper drawn up by Whitehall's coordinating committee on Africa warned the Conservative government in 1963 that "more emphasis should be given to the fact that it was historically inevitable that the present [apartheid] regime in South Africa would sooner or later have to give way to one based on popular consent; but it was most unlikely that there would be any agreement on a multiracial solution".

Officials added: "It followed that ultimately there would be either some form of partition or a bloodbath leading to black domination."

 British Railways, as it then was, hushed up the construction of a new coach for the Queen's equerries on the royal train, papers released yesterday show.

"I have told my officers concerned that all possible steps should be taken to ensure that no publicity is given to the new coach", David Blee, general manager of BR's London midland region, told the British Transport Commission in 1956.

 He might have been nicknamed the "Mad Axeman", but papers released yesterday show authorities at Dartmoor considered the Kray henchman Frank Mitchell to be a model prisoner who should have been paroled.

Mitchell, eventually sprung from prison and then killed by the Krays, was apparently a reformed character who had "counselled other prisoners against misconduct" and was known for having a fondness for small animals, reports by the governor and chaplain show.

fields.headline: Save Albanians from themselves
fields.trailText: We must act immediately to stop the tragedy in Macedonia, which was the only former Yugoslavian republic to avoid ethnic fighting (Nato calls for 1,000 troops to aid Skopje, March 20).
fields.body:
We must act immediately to stop the tragedy in Macedonia, which was the only former Yugoslavian republic to avoid ethnic fighting (Nato calls for 1,000 troops to aid Skopje, March 20).

The Albanian population is about 15-18% of the general population and has benefited from being within Macedonia and having avoided the worst of the old Albanian regime and the worst of Serbian domination. All this is being put at risk by a violent minority in the pursuit of a greater Albania.

The EU can stop this unnecessary violence by immediately imposing sanctions on Albania and stopping all aid to that country. Cutting off the arms supply will give the Macedonian authorities a chance to build upon the work of the UN's "prevention deployment force". We must not act again too late, otherwise there will be a further culling of people of good will.

Dr Colin Pritchard
University of Southampton
cp1@soton.ac.uk

 Martin Woollacott (Taking the easy way out, March 16) highlights the lack of long-term strategies and the fact that the US is ready to wind down before the dust has settled. This encourages extremism and those who trade on instability, as well as those who supply arms to it.

The easy way out risks all that has gone before, including aid and investment. The hard way forward is even greater investment in civil rehabilitation, in physical and social infrastructures, in holding borders. This takes more time, more money, more meet ings. If Serbia and Croatia can begin this process then surely Kosovo can also achieve it. Failure to invest in peace-building at an even higher level has an even greater cost.

David Grubb

Children's Aid Direct

 Martin Woollacott should recognise the image of Albanians as "teenagers" for the colonial justification it has always been. This insulting attitude also explains to a considerable extent the failure of the "internationals" in Kosovo. People who successfully ran a parallel infrastructure for 10 years - schools, banks, health care and so on - have been treated as irrelevant by uninformed decision-makers flown in from Angola or Rwanda.

Ruth Valentine
London
ruth@ereshkigal.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Straw on human rights
fields.trailText: John Wadham's attack on the supposed erosion of human rights omitted to mention legislation which has for the first time enshrined in UK law the enforceable rights of every citizen - namely the Human Rights Act 1998.
fields.body:
John Wadham's attack on the supposed erosion of human rights omitted to mention legislation which has for the first time enshrined in UK law the enforceable rights of every citizen - namely the Human Rights Act 1998.

He is also wrong about the proceeds of crime bill and the recovery of criminal assets. It would be the courts, not the police or the criminal assets recovery agency, who would determine if there were sufficient grounds for requiring individuals to disclose information about their financial affairs. The powers proposed would lead not to a conviction or imprisonment, but to civil proceedings. Such civil actions would be no more an erosion of civil rights than any other civil proceedings for the recovery of property to which a respondent is not entitled.
Jack Straw MP
Home secretary

 The aim of the government's Change A Life campaign is two-fold (Report, March 20). To raise awareness that giving money directly to people on the streets is likely to be sustaining the drug habit that keeps people homeless; and to encourage the public to help in other ways, particularly by giving their time and skills to local projects. To say the campaign has raised "just £10,000" belittles the efforts of the many people who dedicate their time or give goods to charities who so desperately need them.

Louise Casey
Director, rough sleepers unit

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: There were a number of errors in a piece in our financial pages on March 6, referring to lawsuits filed against a software company called Commtouch.
fields.body:
There were a number of errors in a piece in our financial pages on March 6, referring to lawsuits filed against a software company called Commtouch.

This Israeli company is not run, as we stated, by Isabel Maxwell, who is actually president emeritus of a US subsidiary. Furthermore, it was wrong of us to suggest any association between Commtouch and one of its competitors, Critical Path, run by Ms Maxwell's former husband David Hayden.

The couple divorced four years ago and there has since been no communication between them. Neither is there any connection between either Commtouch or Critical Path and Telemonde, a telecoms company run by Ms Maxwell's brother, Kevin. Apologies.

The word "not" insinuated itself into our account of a Guardian/ICM poll on the public services, page 1 of The common good, yesterday's special broadsheet wrap-around, completely changing the intended meaning. We meant to say (the unwanted word in square brackets): "...all voters ... overwhelmingly reject the idea that public services should [not] be run for profit".

In a graphic on page 13 of the supplement, the percentage of those surveyed who thought public sector workers were underpaid, should have been 50 and not 24. On page 9 of yesterday's supplement, The common good, we interviewed a marine surveyor working at the Harwich Marine Office in Walton-on-Thames. Walton-on-Thames is in Surrey. We meant to refer to Walton on the Naze, which is in Essex.

A double homophone from an obituary page 26, March 17, where we spoke of the subject's "flare for arresting effects", and his "flare for outsize presence and gesture". It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday.

fields.headline: Not so merry
fields.trailText: I was amused (Curious tale of the author and his two lovers, March 19) by John Bayley's, book detailing how he was besieged by unwelcome women following his wife's death. My own experiences as a relatively young widow (late 40s) echo those of every other woman I know of in this situation: that is, of being shunned by the majority of friends and colleagues alike.
fields.body:

My own experiences as a relatively young widow (late 40s) echo those of every other woman I know of in this situation: that is, of being shunned by the majority of friends and colleagues alike. Far from us gaining the attention of other men, it is assumed that no one will ever live up to the status of our dearly departed, and we are effectively outcasts from social parlance. We do not practice suttee for widows here, but we might as well.

University of Bristol

fields.headline: HIV furore
fields.trailText: Your leader (March 19) misrepresents our position on the transmission of HIV.
fields.body:
Your leader (March 19) misrepresents our position on the transmission of HIV. We agree with the Home Office position, which is that the deliberate transmission of HIV (when someone intends to cause injury) should be a prosecutable offence, but not the reckless transmission (when there is no deliberate intent or deception). Sexual behaviour is not always logical and planned, as anyone has become inadvertently pregnant will be able to tell you.

It should be remembered, amongst the furore, that the vast majority of people living with HIV go to considerable lengths to avoid transmitting the virus. It is vital that people feel able to come forward for testing and treatment.

Nick Partridge
Terrence Higgins Trust

fields.headline: Alongside Mandela
fields.trailText: A statue of Nelson Mandela opposite the South African high commission (Leader, March 20) would make a fascinating historical counterpoint to that of Jan Christiaan Smuts which stands a few metres behind the hulk of Winston Churchill in Parliament Square. Smuts, the Boer commando (scholar and lawyer turned soldier), was among the very last of the Afrikaner commanders in the field to stop killing British soldiers in the South African war (1899-1902).
fields.body:
A statue of Nelson Mandela opposite the South African high commission (Leader, March 20) would make a fascinating historical counterpoint to that of Jan Christiaan Smuts which stands a few metres behind the hulk of Winston Churchill in Parliament Square. Smuts, the Boer commando (scholar and lawyer turned soldier), was among the very last of the Afrikaner commanders in the field to stop killing British soldiers in the South African war (1899-1902).

He earned his plinth: in the first world war against the Germans in the Africa campaigns; at and after the treaty of Versailles as a founding force of the League of Nations; as a midwife (at least) to the Royal Air Force; and in bringing South Africa into the second world war during the dark hours in the face of deep antipathy (to put it mildly) among many of his fellow Afrikaners.

Yet it was Smuts, the "international statesman", who ducked the issue of what was called, in South Africa, the "native question". He preferred to leave its solution to the grandchildren of the white South African minority. Nelson Mandela offered a non-racial answer in opposition to the "separate but equal" racist social engineering of Hendrik Verwoerd's apartheid and spent 27 years in prison.

fields.headline: Sinking giant
fields.standfirst: Ships ready to block Brazilian oil slick
fields.trailText: The world's biggest offshore oil rig sank in Brazilian waters yesterday, five days after explosions ripped through the structure and killed 10 people.
fields.body:
The world's biggest offshore oil rig sank in Brazilian waters yesterday, five days after explosions ripped through the structure and killed 10 people.

Ships of the state oil company Petrobras were standing by with absorption barriers in case an oil slick develops. If they succeed in containing it the damage will be minimal, environmentalists said, adding that the area's currents did not flow towards the coast of Rio de Janeiro state.

Up to 395,000 gallons (1.5m litres) of crude and diesel oil stored in tanks on the rig and in underwater pipelines could leak into the sea.

The rig had the world's greatest pumping capacity, 180,000 barrels a day, but the stored oil is a fraction of that spilled in 1989 by the tanker Exxon Valdez - 11m gallons (41.6m litres) went into the sea off Alaska.

More than 160 people were lifted off the rig last week after three explosions. Among them were two British engineers from Teesside, Paul Raine and Andy Stayman.

Petrobras flew in experts and equipment from all over the world to try to keep the rig afloat, but yesterday it toppled over, and soon vanished.

fields.headline: More women in Labour
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee is right that Labour's women MPs have civilised parliament and influenced the government's "family's first agenda" (Better than men, March 16). The fact that we will have fewer women in the next parliament is a missed opportunity for my party and for the government. I believe the time has come for the government to grasp the nettle and legislate to provide for all-women shortlists as part of the future selection procedure. The voluntary route has not delivered.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee is right that Labour's women MPs have civilised parliament and influenced the government's "family's first agenda" (Better than men, March 16). The fact that we will have fewer women in the next parliament is a missed opportunity for my party and for the government. I believe the time has come for the government to grasp the nettle and legislate to provide for all-women shortlists as part of the future selection procedure. The voluntary route has not delivered.

Labour has 101 women MPs, but has only selected 126 candidates for the next election. That compares favourably with the other parties: the Lib Dems' women candidates account for 21% of their prospective candidates, the Tories just 14% and Labour 23%. Because of the 1997 landslide result, it is highly likely that women's representation will take a backwards step at the election.

In Belgium and France they have compulsory quotas, while in Sweden and Germany many parties have voluntary quotas. In UK, an employment tribunal has ruled candidates should be treated as employees, so the Sex Discrimination Act applies, yet there is provision in the Human Rights Act for positive action to redress under-representation.
Bill Morris
General secretary, TGWU

 It is a matter of debate how significant is the finding of Ermisch and Francesconi of a negative link between educational attainment and early maternal employment (Letters, March 16). I have found a similar association among other children, those born in 1970. But our report stressed that other predictive factors were at least as important, particularly family income, so children also stand to benefit from mothers' earning.

In the 70s, it hardly occurred to the designers of surveys to ask about childcare or fathers' involvement in it, nor about the relationships of mothers with their children rather than the labour market. In our new survey of family life, the ESRC millennium cohort, we plan to cover all these topics and perhaps in 20 years' time, when these children's qualifications are assessed, the "blame culture", whether of mothers who stay at home or who do not, will be a thing of the past.

Prof Heather Joshi
Institute of Education
hj@cls.ioe.ac.uk

 It's always a working mother that somehow blights her kids' future. These children grew up during 18 years of Tory government - with high inflation, negative equity, record unemployment. Wouldn't it be reasonable to say that the effects of the social conditions of the past two decades had a huge impact on family life and influenced growing children's view of the world? And who's to say that, without that part-time job to keep the wolf from the door, the family would not have been sucked into a hell of debt, divorce and despair? When is someone going to research the effects on children of having a go-to-work father?

Cllr Angela Gunning
Guildford, Surrey

 The notion of sisterhood was not "based on the assumption that all women would identify with one another to the exclusion of all men" (Mary Kenny, G2, March 19). It came out of the attempt to understand the ways in which women were kept from recognising what they had in common, and how divisions between them help to perpetuate male power. Although the slogan "sisterhood is powerful" glossed over the importance of class and race in understanding how women's liberation might come about, it was not sentimental. A sister is not necessarily someone you like, she is someone you are connected to; like it or not; your fate is bound up with hers.

Judy Greenway
University of East London

webTitle: Asia hit by hand, foot and mouth

fields.headline: Asia hit by hand, foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Twenty children have been infected with hand, foot and mouth disease in Johor Baru province, south Malaysia, according to the regional media.
fields.body:
Twenty children have been infected with hand, foot and mouth disease in Johor Baru province, south Malaysia, according to the regional media.

The disease, quite unrelated to foot and mouth disease in animals, although also caused by a virus, broke out in Kulai, about 40 miles north of Singapore, during the Eid al-Fitr celebrations at the end of Ramadan, the Muslim fasting month.

Wee Yoop Tawi, a local councillor, told the Malaysian newspaper the Star: "Many children aged between one and five came down with fever and had blisters in their mouths and rashes on their hands and feet."

since the outbreak occurred shortly after two children in Singapore died from the disease, dozens of parents rushed their children to hospital.

Malaysia and Singapore had barely recovered from a much bigger outbreak in October, when more than 2,000 children were infected in Singapore and hundreds in Malaysia.

More than a dozen children died in that outbreak, and schools, kindergartens, swimming pools and parks were closed for several weeks.

Medical experts in Singapore and the US say there is no link between hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) and the animal disease spreading in Britain.

"HFMD is a different disease than foot and mouth disease of cattle, sheep, and swine," the website of the National Centres for Infectious Diseases in Atlanta, Georgia, says.

"The two diseases are not related at all and are caused by different viruses".

The Singapore government and the Malaysian Medical Association say there is no known cure for HFMD, nor is it known why the disease is occasionally fatal although most bouts are mild, lasting only a few days. The vast majority of sufferers are children under the age of seven. A kindergarten teacher in Singapore said the children were being checked every day for the disease, and toys and utensils sterilised.

"We are more paranoid that the parents," she said. "If it infects a school like ours it could spread very fast indeed."

fields.headline: Overdue for dismissal
fields.standfirst:
The general has had too long an innings

Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: With that same lack of timing that distinguishes some of his country's test batsmen, Pakistan's military ruler chose this week to launch a sweeping purge of civilian opponents.
fields.body:
With that same lack of timing that distinguishes some of his country's test batsmen, Pakistan's military ruler chose this week to launch a sweeping purge of civilian opponents. According to the Alliance for the Restoration of Democracy, an umbrella group of 18 banned political parties, hundreds of people have been arrested in Punjab as the regime tries to stifle a rally planned (and already banned) in Lahore this Friday that will demand an end to army rule. This futile exercise in repression would be reprehensible at any time. But General Pervez Musharraf's stroke was particularly maladroit given that it came just as the Commonwealth's ministerial action group was wondering what to do about Islamabad's coup-meister at a meeting in London. As they pondered representations from the ARD, what more salient demonstration of Gen Musharraf's denial of democratic rights could the ministers be given?

Pakistan's self-styled chief executive, who is reportedly scheming to install himself as president-for-life, still claims that democracy will be restored by October next year, three years after he seized power. But, he insists, there will be no "interim measures". Gen Musharraf is good at not doing things. He has not achieved promised institutional and economic structural reforms, not ended Pakistan's reliance on IMF hand-outs, not fully implemented the tax and anti-corruption measures he championed, not noticeably curbed the influence of militant Islamists and not convinced Pakistanis, despite honeymoon goodwill after Nawaz Sharif's overthrow, that he is the man with the answers. He has not responded to India's ceasefire in Kashmir, not moved to revive the Lahore declaration and not used his controversial links with the Taliban to contain their philistine excesses and mitigate the Afghan refugee crisis on the western border.

Gen Musharraf's negative ratings have been reinforced by his improbable feat in alienating the US, Pakistan's most powerful friend, and driving it into the arms of India, Pakistan's oldest enemy. This man is no good at politics, no good at diplomacy, no economist and no democrat - and those in Pakistan (and Britain) who supported his 1999 coup should now admit they were wrong. The Commonwealth is right to threaten expulsion. But Gen Musharraf can save his country that embarrassment by calling national elections, quietly accepting the decision, and heading for the pavilion.

webTitle: Sold out: The Last Days of E

fields.headline: Sold out: The Last Days of E
fields.standfirst: In a few years' time - maybe 12 or 15 - you might pull the film down off the shelf at your local video store.
fields.trailText: In a few years' time - maybe 12 or 15 - you might pull the film down off the shelf at your local video store.
fields.body:
In a few years' time - maybe 12 or 15 - you might pull the film down off the shelf at your local video store. No, it will not by then be referred to as a DVD resource. And no, you will not be surfing movie archives from the comfort of your armchair, ready to click and pay. The interactive digital future will still be going through beta testing.

It will be a regular Thursday night, with little in the fridge and nothing on the telly. The film that catches your eye might be a soothing piece of nostalgia, harking back to early 2001, when the conservative forces of commerce were moving in on the new economy, when the markets were low and capital was in short supply.

The Last Days of E. The film could be shot this week in Hanover, Germany, at CeBIT, the world's largest trade show for the IT and telecoms sectors.

Braving ridicule and ignoring the warnings of plunging or non-existent profits, 8,106 new economy firms are displaying their wares across 431,000 square meters on the site of the Hannover fair, ready over the next week to welcome perhaps 800,000 visitors.

Here, in more than two dozen exhibition halls, it is as if the technology bubble has yet to burst. Firms from 60 countries have arrived, including 333 from Britain alone, outgunned only by the Germans, the Americans and the Taiwanese.

Ahead of tomorrow's public opening, CeBIT resembles a high-tech construction site as stands are thrown together in a flurry of torn packaging and shredded polystyrene amid the whine of wireless drills and cordless screwdrivers. The Messe, as the exhibition centre is known, is so vast that many visitors and exhibitors resort to scooters to get around.

At first glance it would appear that the level of activity here on the outskirts of Hanover - the miles of cabling being laid, connecting thousands of plasma screens and processors of every conceivable size - would be enough to kick-start the new economy on its own.

Of course, 8,106 firms are participating. The laws of commerce mean that they will not all make it - although the stand presenting TurboLinux - the US provider of the free PC operating system - was still being prepared yesterday, despite the firm cancelling its planned £40m initial public offering on Nasdaq - a move attributed poor market conditions. More than 60 firms have withdrawn planned flotations so far this year in the US.

All the firms attending the Messe will have booked and largely paid at least a year in advance, so the recent funding problems in new technology and the attendant buttoning-down of costs are not reflected at the Hanover convention.

Some exhibitors will have rather less to say than they hoped. Group 3G, for instance - a mobile telecoms joint venture between Spain's Telefonica and Fin land's Sonera - has cancelled a news conference planned for today, at which it was expected to detail its roll-out of high speed web access. It is one of six firms that paid 16bn marks for a 3G mobile licence in Germany. But a statement said there was "no point" in holding a media conference when there was "no news".

For most, however, it is business as usual, presenting at an exhibition which was spun out of the Hanover fair in 1986. CeBIT - Centre for Office and Information Technology - and has grown at about 10% year, whatever the prevailing economic climate.

In fact, there is an air of unreality in every CeBIT hall - not least at Equity World, a new forum introduced as part of the CeBIT banking center which, according to the organisers, "is designed to serve as a market place for companies seeking or offering investment capital".

There is also an "equity lounge" that promises a perfect ambience for "formal and informal discussions" and a "central meeting place for networking initiatives and the exchange of experience and ideas relating to emerging markets".

A banner being hung by the stand yesterday suggested that the 20 or so sponsors of this forum include names such as Greenfield Capital, MoBIZZ, eVision-Ventures and the distressed British internet investment bank, Durlacher - which at its own stand promises that it is still "researching the future, investing in today".

Whatever the economic climate, scores of new products will be launched here over the coming days. A German company named Opostor, for instance, is promising a new hologram-based system for mass data storage, capturing one "terabyte" of information within the space of a credit card - which, the company claims, "has a durability of 100 years". Meanwhile, that old techno-chestnut, 3D TV, has gained an extra dimension in Hanover, thanks to 4D-Vision. The firm claims its monitors give viewers the full experience without 3D goggles and, apparently, "this new 4D technology for 3D playback has the potential to make 3D TV a reality in every household around the globe".

So there is hope yet for that feature film on the final fling of the technology sector, where money that was earmarked for spending in Hanover before the downturn began to bite is now being spent regardless. There will not be as many companies exhibiting here in 12 months' time. But this year CeBIT is rolling, whatever the markets say.

fields.headline: Commonwealth ministers to visit Mugabe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Commonwealth agreed yesterday to send a mission to President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to express its concern about the recent attacks on the judiciary and the media.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, diplomatic editor and  Andrew Meldrum in Harare
fields.body:
The Commonwealth agreed yesterday to send a mission to President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to express its concern about the recent attacks on the judiciary and the media.

The British government hopes the ministerial delegation will press Mr Mugabe to curb further excesses.

The Zimbabwe government reacted angrily to the decision yesterday. Its foreign minister, Stan Mudenge, said it was illegal and vowed not to cooperate with it.

"We will not participate in illegality," he said, adding: "Instead of dispatching a ministerial group to Zimbabwe, it should send a mission to London to persuade Britain to honour its commitment to the land resettlement programme."

If the mission reports that Mr Mugabe is seriously threatening democracy, the Commonwealth could suspend Zimbabwe's membership. But there were significant differences in tone in the statements yesterday of Commonwealth foreign ministers.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was keen to promote the mission as a sign of the Commonwealth getting tough.

"We are not going there for a social call," he said, adding that the decision to send a ministerial delegation was the "top of the ladder" in terms of response.

"I stress that this was a unanimous agreement and therefore President Mugabe cannot now continue to pretend that it is only Britain who is criticising him."

But the Botswanan foreign minister, Lieutenant-General Mompati Merahfe, adopted a softer approach, saying it was difficult to say for certain if Zimbabwe had overstepped the mark.

The Commonwealth ministerial action group, which was established to try to maintain democratic principles, issued its statement after a two-day meeting in London. The tone of much of the statement was conciliatory.

The ministers had decided that the mission should "conduct consultations with the Zimbabwe government, convey its concerns and offer any appropriate Commonwealth assistance".

The mission will comprise the foreign ministers of Australia, Barbados and Nigeria.

A spokesman for the Zimbabwean opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, said in Harare that it was likely that a visit would be approved only if the delegation included countries considered friendly. Botswana and Nigeria would fit the bill.

Under present Commonwealth rules, Zimbabwe cannot be suspended. But the rules, which basically provide for the suspension only of countries in which the democratically elected government is overthrown in a coup, are under review, and new criteria are likely to be recommended at the Commonwealth meeting in Brisbane in October.

Relations between Britain and Zimbabwe have deteriorated sharply since the Foreign Office was highly critical of the illegal seizure of mainly white-owned farms.

The Commonwealth action group also expressed concern that Pakistan's military rulers were stifling political opposition and warned them to hasten the restoration of democracy.

Otherwise it would face "stronger measures", which would be taken if it did not make progress on a timetable for regional and nationals elections by October.

Pakistan was suspended from Commonwealth ministerial meetings after the military coup in 1999.

"We will not participate in illegality," he said, adding: "Instead of dispatching a ministerial group to Zimbabwe, it should send a mission to London to persuade Britain to honour its commitment to the land resettlement programme." If the mission reports that Mr Mugabe is seriously threatening democracy, the Commonwealth could suspend Zimbabwe's membership. But there were significant differences in tone in the statements yesterday of Commonwealth foreign ministers. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was keen to promote the mission as a sign of the Commonwealth getting tough. "We are not going there for a social call," he said, adding that the decision to send a ministerial delegation was the "top of the ladder" in terms of response. "I stress that this was a unanimous agreement and therefore President Mugabe cannot now continue to pretend that it is only Britain who is criticising him." But the Botswanan foreign minister, Lieutenant-General Mompati Merahfe, adopted a softer approach, saying it was difficult to say for certain if Zimbabwe had overstepped the mark. The Commonwealth ministerial action group, which was established to try to maintain democratic principles, issued its statement after a two-day meeting in London. The tone of much of the statement was conciliatory. The ministers had decided that the mission should "conduct consultations with the Zimbabwe government, convey its concerns and offer any appropriate Commonwealth assistance". The mission will comprise the foreign ministers of Australia, Barbados and Nigeria. A spokesman for the Zimbabwean opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, said in Harare that it was likely that a visit would be approved only if the delegation included countries considered friendly. Botswana and Nigeria would fit the bill. Under present Commonwealth rules, Zimbabwe cannot be suspended. But the rules, which basically provide for the suspension only of countries in which the democratically elected government is overthrown in a coup, are under review, and new criteria are likely to be recommended at the Commonwealth meeting in Brisbane in October. Relations between Britain and Zimbabwe have deteriorated sharply since the Foreign Office was highly critical of the illegal seizure of mainly white-owned farms. The Commonwealth action group also expressed concern that Pakistan's military rulers were stifling political opposition and warned them to hasten the restoration of democracy. Otherwise it would face "stronger measures", which would be taken if it did not make progress on a timetable for regional and nationals elections by October. Pakistan was suspended from Commonwealth ministerial meetings after the military coup in 1999.

fields.headline: Budget delivers a low blow
fields.trailText: The generosity of the chancellor to drinkers, drivers and smokers in this year's Budget will drive down the rate of inflation over the next two months and could force the Bank of England to explain why it has allowed the annual increase in the main cost of living index to fall so low.
fields.body:
The generosity of the chancellor to drinkers, drivers and smokers in this year's Budget will drive down the rate of inflation over the next two months and could force the Bank of England to explain why it has allowed the annual increase in the main cost of living index to fall so low.

Data published yesterday by the office for national statistics showed that higher petrol prices had helped push the inflation rate excluding mortgage interest payments, the government's preferred measure, up from 1.8% to 1.9% last month.

However, the office for national statistics said the combination of tax changes in the 2000 and 2001 Budgets would act to shave a tenth of a point off the underlying inflation rate in March and a further 0.4 points in April. That would drive inflation excluding mortgages down to 1.4% - its lowest level on record - and require the Bank of England's governor, Sir Eddie George, to pen an open letter giving reasons for inflation undershooting the government's 2.5% target by more than a full percentage point.

City analysts said that although Sir Eddie might enjoy a short-term reprieve as a result of the impact of foot and mouth on food prices, or dearer fuel as a result of production curbs by oil cartel Opec, underlying inflation would fall below 1.5% in 2001 and might drop as low as 1%.
