fields.headline: Corus defends steel chief's honour
fields.trailText: Steel group Corus hit back last night at demands that its chief executive, Sir Brian Moffatt, be stripped of his knighthood, saying the group of 50 MP's calling for his blood were badly informed.
fields.body:
Steel group Corus hit back last night at demands that its chief executive, Sir Brian Moffatt, be stripped of his knighthood, saying the group of 50 MP's calling for his blood were badly informed.

Corus said its chairman - knighted in 1996 for services to the steel industry - had no intention of handing back his honour despite an early day motion tabled in the House of Commons.

Ashok Kumar, Labour MP for Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, was still trying to build support for a motion that the Corus boss was no longer of service to the steel industry, following restructuring involving plant closures and 6,000 redundancies.

Unions and opposition MP's have been shocked by the setting aside of £250m to pay off workers instead of keeping the business running.

Dr Kumar, a former research scientist with British Steel, said Sir Brian was more interested in the short-term views of City institutions than trying to save the industry in areas such as Teesside and Wales.

"This isn't just my view, it is also the view of the all-party Trade and Industry Select Committee of the House of Commons," Dr Kumar said.

The motion was signed by 49 Labour MPs including Trade and Industry Select Committee member Jim Cunningham.

Corus continues to explore alternatives to its closure programme with government and worker representatives, the next meeting scheduled for Tuesday. But the Corus spokesman admitted any solution would have to be set against a background of falling demand for flat steel products.

webTitle: Baird presses on with M&S lawsuit

fields.headline: Baird presses on with M&S lawsuit
fields.trailText: Textiles group William Baird, will ask the House of Lords to decide its claim that Marks & Spencer should pay more than £50m for terminating a 30-year supply deal.
fields.body:
Textiles group William Baird, will ask the House of Lords to decide its claim that Marks & Spencer should pay more than £50m for terminating a 30-year supply deal.

Chief executive David Suddens said Baird would seek to contest an appeal court ruling in February rejecting the compensation claim.

He admitted the odds were stacked against the clothing firm, which owns the Windsmoor, Planet and Dan nimac brands, but insisted that the company was not throwing good money after bad pursuing the claim.

"It would be madness not to do it. It will take little management time and not much cash. It will cost £25,000 for the petition and another £100,000-£150,000 in twelve months' time if we get the go-ahead for an appeal. On the benefit side it is enormous, because we have a claim for £53m."

Baird's business has been savaged since M&S cancelled its supply deal as part of a cost- cutting drive. Turnover has fallen from £650m to £200m this year and it has shut 16 factories. Its workforce has been reduced from 13,000 to 7,000, with 4,500 staff made redundant in Britain. The rest were in parts of the business sold off. The closures and disposals have cost the company £26.5m in the past 12 months, after a £103m bill last year.

The firm yesterday reported a full-year loss of £16.1m.

Baird was the subject of an £88m management buyout plan earlier this year, but the deal fell apart over a disagreement about debt levels.

The financial backer, venture capital group Alchemy, still has a 30% stake, worth substantially less than the acquisition price. Mr Suddens said: "It is not the end game because they still have 30%. But I am not looking to resurrect the MBO and we have to refocus on running the business."

Baird has sold three rainwear businesses to concentrerate on Dannimac and is in talks to sell its corporate wear unit.

webTitle: Victorian album expected to fetch record £500,000

fields.headline: Victorian album expected to fetch record £500,000
fields.trailText: A collection of photographs by an aristocratic Victorian, showing his handsome house and grounds, is forecast to fetch more than £500,000 at auction next month, a world record for an album of photographs.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A collection of photographs by an aristocratic Victorian, showing his handsome house and grounds, is forecast to fetch more than £500,000 at auction next month, a world record for an album of photographs.

The work of William, second Earl of Craven, was almost unknown other than to specialist historians until examples of his work began to come on the market from family collections in the past few years.

Miles Barton, formerly of the photography section of Sotheby's, now with the internet auction house Icollect, predicted yesterday that the sale of the album with 109 photo- graphs would attract international interest.

Craven began taking photographs in 1853, using a massive camera trundled round on a wooden cart built specially for him.

The 109 photographs, all of his family estate in Berkshire, were taken over five years. In 1859, aged 50, he had a stroke, and could no longer operate the heavy equipment. He had a gold tooled leather album made to hold his photographs.

He died in 1866, and the album was completed by his family as a memorial.

The auction, which includes images by other early photographers, will be at Bearne's in Exeter on May 12.

View the catalogue

webTitle: US feared for Luther King killer in British jail

fields.headline: US feared for Luther King killer in British jail
fields.standfirst:
Round-the-clock guard for assassin awaiting extradition

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The prison authorities went to extraordinary lengths to protect the man convicted of killing Martin Luther King from possible assassination, suicide or escape while he was awaiting extradition from Wandsworth prison, papers released yesterday by the public record office reveal.
fields.body:
The prison authorities went to extraordinary lengths to protect the man convicted of killing Martin Luther King from possible assassination, suicide or escape while he was awaiting extradition from Wandsworth prison, papers released yesterday by the public record office reveal.

At the request of the US government, James Earl Ray was placed under 24 hour surveillance and put in a cell where a long range rifle could not be aimed at the window. According to Mark Maunsell, who was inspector general of prisons at the time and was summoned to the American embassy to discuss Ray's security, the US government feared that Ray's associates or enemies would try to kill him or he would try to kill himself.

"The real concern seemed to me to spring from the possibility that there may be people for whom Ray's return to the US in order to give evidence is so alarming that they will proceed to any lengths to kill him while he is in England," Mr Maunsell wrote in a memorandum to the governor of Wandsworth prison.

"In this area the use of a helicopter must not be ruled out," he wrote, emphasising that if a low flying aircraft went near to the prison during exercise Ray should be removed from the yard immediately.

Ray had fled to Europe following the assasination of the black civil rights leader in Memphis in April 1968. After spending three weeks hiding in London he was arrested at Heathrow airport on June 8 travelling under the alias Ramon George Sneyd. He was carrying a revolver with five rounds of ammunition.

Fred Vinson, the assistant US attorney general, told Mr Maunsell how concerned he was that Ray should be safely returned to the US. "This was solely due to the awful consequences within the US if anything intervened," Mr Maunsell wrote. "He [Vinson] said that his government knew, from the president downwards, that nothing would persuade the American public of the validity of the reasons given for any failure, and that disorders would unquestionably follow. They have no means of knowing whether and if so how he, his associates or his enemies might seek to secure his death or escape."

Mr Vinson warned that Ray was an expert in escape from prison, having successfully absconded from the Missouri state penitentiary on July 10 1967, where he was serving time for armed robbery.

Wandsworth prison officers were asked to guard against Ray's escape, suicide and assasination. Officers had to put the blade in Ray's razor before he shaved and remove it after he had finished shaving. Special care had to be taken to make sure he did not pick up any glass or other sharp object, and he was allowed to eat with only a melamine spoon.

Ray, who died in 1998 while serving a 99-year prison sentence for the assassination of the civil rights leader, initially confessed to the crime but later proclaimed his innocence, claiming it was a conspiracy. During his time in Wandsworth he made a number of references to killing, which were duly noted by prison officers who had to make a brief report after every shift spent guarding him.

"He said the assassination had been organised by one of his own lieutenants to gain control of the organisation funds," one officer noted.

"The assassination that has taken place in the USA [was] spoken of by him in association with the Black Muslim group. He implied they could be behind the Martin Luther King shooting," wrote another.

He told prison officers that his three weeks in London before his capture had not been enjoyable. "He said he did not like English food," an officer wrote. "He was in the habit of going out in the evening and purchasing half a chicken and a can of Heineken on the Cromwell Road."

webTitle: Napalm test sites in Scotland and Libya

fields.headline: Napalm test sites in Scotland and Libya
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The government agreed to drop napalm bombs in military exercises in Scotland and Libya, according to official documents released yesterday.
fields.body:
The government agreed to drop napalm bombs - widely used by US forces in the Vietnam war - in military exercises in Scotland and Libya, according to official documents released yesterday.

The plan was to drop the bombs in 1970 on firing ranges at Tain, north of Inverness, and at El Adem, an RAF base in the Libyan desert south of Tripoli.

In June 1969 - three months before Colonel Gadafy seized power from King Idris in a coup - the British ambassador to Libya, Roderick Sarell, told the Foreign Office that the RAF was confident that explosions from napalm, called "firebombs", looked like "ignitions of a barrel of oil to the uninitiated" and that "the fragments would not be identifiable".

He continued: "In the light of this advice I am quite clear that we can go ahead and certainly say nothing to the Libyans."

The papers do not say whether the RAF did go ahead with the training exercises. Denis Healey, the defence secretary, noted that napalm bombs were used to attack the Torrey Canyon, the tanker wrecked off the Isles of Scilly in 1967.

That was the first time British possession of napalm had "come to public knowledge", he said. But, he added, that appeared to have been forgotten.

webTitle: Goldman falls back 13% in first quarter

fields.headline: Goldman falls back 13% in first quarter
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank which employs the stock market bull Abby Cohen, yesterday warned that business conditions were getting tougher as it reported a 13% fall in pre-tax profits for the first three months of its financial year.
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank which employs the stock market bull Abby Cohen, yesterday warned that business conditions were getting tougher as it reported a 13% fall in pre-tax profits for the first three months of its financial year.

David Viniar, Goldman's chief financial officer, said the bank would respond to the downturn in activity by keeping a tight rein on costs and shedding any underperforming staff.

But, despite the fall in the bank's earnings during the year to $768m, Wall Street was relieved, fearing that the impact of fewer companies raising money on the stock markets or merging with rivals, could have been worse.

Coming at the start of a hectic reporting reason for other major US financial firms, Goldman's figures were regarded as the first barometer of the effect of the mounting fears of a rapid economic slow down in the US. Rivals such as Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers, each of which also employ thousands of bankers in the City, are due to report their first quarter trading today.

Mr Viniar admitted that the bank was operating in a much slower market, citing statistics which showed a 51% reduction in the amount of mergers and acquisitions business around the world and a 66% fall in demand from companies to raise new money. As a result, the bank's "backlog" of business was declining, Mr Viniar said.

The bank played down plans for redundancies among its 5,500-strong City workforce, insisting the usual numbers of underperforming staff would be shed.

webTitle: Catholic priests abusing nuns for sex

fields.headline: Catholic priests abusing nuns for sex
fields.trailText: Roman Catholic priests and bishops in several parts of the world have been exploiting their religious authority to obtain sexual favours from nuns
fields.body:
Roman Catholic priests and bishops in several parts of the world have been exploiting their religious authority to obtain sexual favours from nuns, in some cases resorting to rape and subsequently obliging the victims to seek an abortion, it was claimed yesterday.

Report of widespread sexual abuses were compiled by two senior nuns between 1994 and 1998 and passed to the Vatican, the Rome daily La Repubblica and the Italian Roman Catholic news agency Adista said.

Abuses were documented in 23 countries, many of them in Africa, but also in Ireland, Italy, the US, the Philippines and Brazil, they said.

The Vatican acknowledged the existence of the problem yesterday and said it was working with bishops and the heads of religious orders to try to resolve it.

"The problem is known and is restricted to a limited geographic area," its spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said.

"A few negative situations must not make us forget the often heroic faithfulness of the vast majority of monks, nuns and priests."

The Aids epidemic in Africa has led to nuns being seen as a potential source of safe sex, according to Sister Maura O'Donohue, of the Medical Missionaries of Mary, who visited numerous African countries to conduct an Aids study on behalf of the Catholic development agency Cafod.

"The superior of a religious community in one country was contacted by priests who asked her to make the nuns available for sexual services," she wrote.

On the superior's refusal, the priests said they would otherwise have to go to the village to look for women, exposing themselves to the risk of Aids."

The reports, one of which is said to have been delivered three years ago to Cardinal Eduardo Martinez Somalo, head of the Vatican department responsible for religious orders, say young female candidates for religious life are sometimes obliged to have sex with a priest to obtain the necessary certificates.

Nuns who became pregnant were forced to leave their religious congregation, the reports say, while the priests responsible were simply sent away for a brief period.

In one community 29 nuns are reported to have become pregnant after sexual relations with priests, but when the mother superior raised the problem with her archbishop she was removed from her post. One priest is said to have induced a nun he had impregnated to have an abortion and when she died during the operation he celebrated her funeral mass.

Another priest is reported to have been driven from his village by gunfire when the local men got fed up with the way he abused his power with their women.

Many African women have been raised to consider themselves inferior to men, and so find it difficult to say no to requests for sexual favours by priests, who are seen as authority figures, according to a report by Sister Marie McDonald, superior general of the Missionaries of Our Lady of Africa, quoted by Adista.

The priests are better educated than the nuns and sometimes use false theological arguments to persuade them, suggesting, for example, that sex between two celibate religious does not violate their vows of celibacy, she said.

Father Bernardo Cervellera, editor of the missionary news agency Fides, said the problem was largely confined to Africa, where the ideal of celibacy met resistance from cultural beliefs that set great store on fatherhood.

"In 25 years as a missionary priest I have never encountered this situation. I have come across the opposite, where priests have defended nuns from assault," he said.

"We shouldn't confuse a few individual errors with a tendency. I admire many African priests, who live their vocation with great heroism."

Many African women have been raised to consider themselves inferior to men, and so find it difficult to say no to requests for sexual favours by priests, who are seen as authority figures, according to a report by Sister Marie McDonald, superior general of the Missionaries of Our Lady of Africa, quoted by Adista. The priests are better educated than the nuns and sometimes use false theological arguments to persuade them, suggesting, for example, that sex between two celibate religious does not violate their vows of celibacy, she said. Father Bernardo Cervellera, editor of the missionary news agency Fides, said the problem was largely confined to Africa, where the ideal of celibacy met resistance from cultural beliefs that set great store on fatherhood. "In 25 years as a missionary priest I have never encountered this situation. I have come across the opposite, where priests have defended nuns from assault," he said. "We shouldn't confuse a few individual errors with a tendency. I admire many African priests, who live their vocation with great heroism."

webTitle: Chime's £14.3m profit keeps pace with acquisitions

fields.headline: Chime's £14.3m profit keeps pace with acquisitions
fields.trailText: Lord Bell's Chime Communications said yesterday that it intends to maintain the pace of acquisitions in the next 12 months that drove a 43% increase in profits to £14.3m last year.
fields.body:
Lord Bell's Chime Communications said yesterday that it intends to maintain the pace of acquisitions in the next 12 months that drove a 43% increase in profits to £14.3m last year.

The marketing services company has targeted direct marketing and media buying as the two key areas for expan sion. Lord Bell said talks with a direct marketing agency are already far advanced.

During 2000 the company made six acquisitions, including Roose & Partners, the third largest independent advertising agency in Britain, and beefed up a division which already includes HHCL. Chime recorded organic operating profit growth of 18%.

"This is a good time to buy," Lord Bell said. "Prices have topped out and people are being slightly less aggressive in their demands."

Lord Bell said the group, which also owns the Bell Pottinger financial public relations business, had not experienced any downturn in the market. "The advertising slowdown is in the US, not here, and we are primarily a UK business," he said. "Where the UK has felt any effect it has been from the US-based multinationals but we are seeing no sign of a slowdown in the marketplace. There is nothing to cause concern."

Chime recorded revenues during last year of £148m, an increase of 56%. Shares in the company climbed 6% to 184.5p.

The group kicked off its buying spree in 2001 with an agreement to buy Boston-based hi-tech public relations agency LNS Communications in January. Lord Bell said the group aimed to build businesses in the US and Germany based on the model of the UK operation.

Chime's share price has proved more robust than many of its peers, partly due to a re-rating after the HHCL acquisition and partly its elevation into the FTSE 250 which has attracted tracker funds.

fields.headline: US cuts interest rate
fields.standfirst: Markets fall as Fed's half-point reduction is seen as too little
fields.trailText: The US Federal Reserve reinforced its determination to steer the American economy off the rocks of recession yesterday by cutting interest rates by a half-percentage point for the third time in as many months.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
The US Federal Reserve reinforced its determination to steer the American economy off the rocks of recession yesterday by cutting interest rates by a half-percentage point for the third time in as many months.

The reduction, which takes the crucial federal funds lending rate to 5%, had been widely anticipated in financial markets, although equity dealers were disappointed that it was not bigger.

In its statement, the Fed warned that despite January's two half-point cuts in the cost of borrowing the economy was still fragile, and signalled that it stood ready to move again if necessary before its next scheduled meeting in May by saying that in a rapidly evolving situation, it would "need to monitor developments closely".

"The risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future," the Fed said.

Ahead of the decision dealers had been pinning their hopes on a three-quarter point cut to put a floor under tumbling equity markets unnerved by a rash of profit warnings from hi-tech groups such as Intel, Cisco Systems and Motorola.

For many in the financial markets the cut was not enough to save plunging share prices. Before the close the technology dominated Nasdaq composite index had lost 77.26 points, or 3.96%, at 1,873.13. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average fell 209.10 points, or 2.1%, to 9,750.01.

"[The Fed] is dancing to the music of the economy and not responding to cries for help from the stock market," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G Lanston & Co.

Alan Blinder, professor of economics at Princeton, told CNBC that the Fed might have chosen the smaller cut in order not to appear to be saving the stock market. Mr Greenspan had spent most of the past two years warning of the "irrational exuberance" among US investors driving share prices to unprecedented levels.

Following its normal procedure, the White House refused to comment on the independent central bank's decision, but President Bush expressed confidence about the long-term outlook for growth.

"People have got to know that I've got great faith in the American economy," Mr Bush told reporters when asked to reconcile his optimistic comments on Monday followed by him saying on Tuesday that growth was slowing down. "I was talking about the long term health of our economy is going to be very strong."

"We've got some problems, some short term problems," he added at the end of an Oval office meeting with Israeli prime minister Ariel Sharon. "If Congress were to act quickly on my tax stimulus package, it would make our recovery quicker."

The Fed's action will heighten expectations of another rate cut by the Bank of England's monetary policy committee - although the chancellor, Gordon Brown, insisted the UK was well placed to keep growing despite the slowdown in the US.

Defending his recent Budget Mr Brown told the Commons Treasury committee: "The major economy with which we trade - the rest of Europe - is experiencing growth this year, above 3%. So if 50% of our imports and exports are with the European market, we're still in a position to grow as a result of trade."

While conceding that the economic slowdown in the US could have some impact on the UK, he said sturdy consumer spending would help offset any repercussions.

"The disappointing factor in the world economy is the failure of Japan's economy to grow," Mr Brown said.

fields.headline: No wonder they're called non-executives
fields.standfirst: The BT directors who did not bark
fields.trailText: The non-executives on BT's board - which include several members of the British corporate master race, such as Sir Anthony Greener and Lord Marshall - must stop dithering and act swiftly if they are to restore the credibility of the BT management.
fields.body:
The non-executives on BT's board - which include several members of the British corporate master race, such as Sir Anthony Greener and Lord Marshall - must stop dithering and act swiftly if they are to restore the credibility of the BT management.

Yesterday BT abandoned its planned dinner with leading shareholders, blaming media frenzy over what might be said. All this information, of course, came from those that had been invited to this select little soirée. The company could not confirm that it had been cancelled, because it had never confirmed it was happening. It was a fine example of PR nonsense and Whitehall-type secrecy in the best traditions of Yes, Minister.

Never mind the basic ethics of information being available to all investors simultaneously and whether BT should be allowed select which investors to invite to a cosy little t te-à-t te with its top dogs. Never mind that other secret briefings have already taken place and that BT is essentially saying that some investors are more important than others. The world moves on.

The company has now, ignominiously, been placed on credit watch by Moody's Investor Services. A downgrade which, if things do not change rapidly, will cost the company an estimated £200m a year in extra interest charges.

A rights issue is now regarded as the least bad option available to this once-proud company weighed down with £30bn of debt. But investors will not cough up without changes at the top.

Yesterday's share price said it all. As speculation mounted that a platter was being prepared for the head of the chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, the shares spurted by 4.5%, adding £1.5bn to the value of the company. Just imagine what might happen if the rumour became fact.

But to concentrate on Sir Peter (whose salary package in the last two years has totalled £4.3m) is unfair. He should not be the fall guy for the chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, who at the very least shares the blame for BT's sorry predicament. He has been chief executive and/or chairman for nearly 15 years, in which time BT has plunged from potential global leader to bit-part player.

The "informed comment" now being peddled suggests that Sir Iain (paid £750,000 last year including a £400,000 "peformance bonus" on top of the £340,000 a year pension he has has been picking up since going part-time in 1998) will not depart ahead of his official retirement date next July.

He is undoubtedly battling to save his own skin. It simply wouldn't do for the new president of the CBI to be forced to quit his own company because of the unholy mess he has left it in. Goodness, he might have to quit the CBI's top table, too, in disgrace.

So why are the non-execs procrastinating? Surely they are not just looking after a fellow business grandee? It is not as though BT does not have a possible successor waiting in the wings. Many investors will be more than happy to give new finance director Philip Hampton a whirl in the chief executive's office.

He is undoubtedly a master of self-promotion, but he is all they have at the moment and at least he has done all of this demerger stuff before, and successfully, at BG.

Keep on cutting

Doves on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee hoping for weak data to back up their case for further interest rates cuts to ward off the threat of slowing global growth were thwarted by yesterday's trade figures.

January's global trade gap of £2.4bn was significantly narrower than expected, another small surplus with the EU combining with helpful revisions to the non-EU numbers to shave £500m off December's deficit. Provisional figures for February's non-EU deficit, at £2.1bn, were also better than forecast, suggesting that January's data were not a flash in the pan.

Most surprising of all, perhaps, was the news that exports to the US were holding up well despite deepening gloom in financial markets about the country's growth prospects. For the moment it seems that sterling's weakness against the dollar is cushioning the blow of softening US demand.

However, in the long run this is not a way out for hard-pressed British manufacturers. For every one exporter benefiting from a weaker pound, there are four or five more whose market will shrink as US growth slows in the months ahead.

Monetary policy is supposed to be forward-looking and, notwithstanding the relatively favourable weather at the moment, the storm clouds gathering on the horizon do not look at all promising.

Given the weakness of inflation, still more than half a percentage point below the government's 2.5% target despite yesterday's small rise, the MPC has plenty of room to take out some extra insurance against a nasty downpour. Another quarter-point cut, taking the Bank's repo rate to 5.5%, to match February's, still seems the best option.

fields.headline: Nasa ban prompts cosmonaut boycott
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Two senior Russian cosmonauts are boycotting training for their imminent mission to the International Space Station
fields.body:
Two senior Russian cosmonauts are boycotting training for their imminent mission to the International Space Station in protest at Nasa's decision to exclude the space tourist Dennis Tito.

It is the first notable upset to emerge from beneath the veneer of worldwide goodwill which has so far embraced the project.

Talgat Musabayev and Yury Baturin refused to begin the critical stage of training at the American space centre in Houston on Monday because of Nasa's insistence that the the Californian millionaire's presence would detract from the station's safety.

Their stand was described by the space agency in Moscow as "an emotional outburst", but financial reasons may have played a part. The refusal to take Mr Tito, 60, on a six-day space tour will cause the cash-strapped space agency serious money problems: Mr Tito will pay it £14m if his voyage goes ahead.

The Russian officials are incensed by Nasa's attempt to block his trip, insisting that it has no authority over who goes on Russian rockets.

"We don't need their permission. We just have to inform them," one said.

The standoff is seen as a dismal portent of future Russo-US relations, particularly once Moscow loses its own space station, Mir, which crashes to earth on Friday. There is growing concern in Moscow that its part in the project will be drowned by powerful US interests.

Nasa has been consistently sceptical of Russia's proposal for space tourism. A spokesman said it was opposed to launching Mr Tito into space on April 30 because "important assembly work is under way and the tourist may distract the crew". He was "a non-professional crew member who is untrained in all critical station systems".

A German, Thomas Reiter, is being trained to take Mr Tito's place.

Talks on solving the impasse began at the Johnson Space Centre in Houston last night.

Russia ordered its cosmonauts to start training, but there was undisguised bitterness on the Russian side.

"The failure of this partly paid contract will mean significant financial losses for Russia," its aerospace agency spokesman, Sergei Gorbunov, said.

"Russia, with its enormous experience in preparing flights, guarantees Tito's safety.

"Besides, Nasa's suggestion to send Thomas Reiter instead of Tito is technically impossible. There is not enough time to make a personal space suit for him."

Mr Tito, who spent months training in Russia last year, was said to be extremely distressed that his lifelong dream was fading.

fields.headline: House of cards
fields.trailText: High Stakes | Happiness | Stalked
fields.body:
It's always a bad sign when the producers of television documentaries start playing with the special effects buttons. As soon as things go into split screen, mad jump-cuts, or funny colours, we know one of two things: either they're suffering from a crisis of confidence about their material, or they've got carried away with a new bit of editing software. This almost marred High Stakes , BBC1's new series about the pleasures and pitfalls of gambling, but no amount of digital Vaseline round the top and bottom of the picture could blur the vivid characters who had been lined up to talk about this glamorous, disgusting underworld. Even when it all went split screen, the strength of the stories managed to win through - but only just.

The stars of the show were undoubtedly the former mobsters who recalled with barely repentant relish the glory days of Las Vegas. Nicky "The Crow" confessed that "I've been involved with 20 murders... maybe 25", while his fellow mafiosi recounted a comic litany of intimidation, bribery and violence. "We didn't have too many outstanding debts", said one, archly. Jockeys, we discovered, are particularly susceptible to bribery. "We laughed at the mugs who were betting on races we'd already fixed. It's crooked, but it feels great." All of these characters are currently taking advantage of the witness protection scheme, which may explain the lavish sunglasses they chose to disguise themselves with.

British wickedness was well represented by Sir David Llewellyn ("Gambling gets in the way of rogering the memsahibs") and Michael Winner, who effortlessly stole the show with memories of his mother. "She was a legend in the casino at Cannes", said Winner, who discovered that Mum's gambling addiction was being funded at his expense. After she'd hawked all the family heirlooms, she nicked the deeds to his Riviera flat and sold that to raise a few more stakes. The inappropriately named Winner was a model of filial forgiveness. "God bless her, she enjoyed herself."

Highlights there were many. Some smug American graduates recalled how they'd beaten the Vegas roulette wheels with tiny computers concealed in their shoes. Father Sean Breen, a jovial Irish priest, gave out racing tips after Holy Communion. Professional gambler Brian Zembic showed off the brand new breasts he'd had implanted for a $100,000 bet ("I love my little babies"), but confessed that he'd declined to have his "little Houdini" removed for a million. There was some great voyeuristic stuff about Russian roulette ("His brains flew all over my living room", deadpanned a gambling widow) and a few strangely redundant bits by presenter John Inverdale, who appeared so infrequently and to such little effect that we must wonder why he was there.

Paul Whitehouse obviously had fun rifling through his record collection for the soundtrack of Happiness (BBC2). The first episode was entitled Personality Crisis, and so we had an almost complete playback of the New York Dolls track of the same name. Things were kept rolling along with audio guest appearances by House Of Pain, Lemon Jelly and Dorothy Moore's Misty Blue, which was gratifyingly played at almost every opportunity.

Fortunately, the script and acting lived up to the music, and Whitehouse gave a neatly understated performance as Danny Spencer, a voice-over artist coming to terms with his wife's death. No star vehicle, this: Fiona Allen, Mark Heap and Johnny Vegas all turned in great performances. There weren't a huge number of laughs (Mr Vegas's stunt double fell into a hole to good effect) but there was plenty to enjoy, in a Cold Feet kind of way.

Channel 4 gave the evening over to two very solid hours on the grim topic of stalking. The first part, Stalked , contained video diaries by a handful of victims - ordinary women pursued by demented men who lurk in bushes, send mad letters and bug phones. The police and the courts seemed unwilling and under-equipped to tackle the problem; hopefully the unadorned eloquence with which these stories were told will do something to convince a few more people of the reality of the problem. In the second part, Stalkers , the baddies were played by actors, and someone had run amok in the edit suite, so we were regularly drenched with colour washes and strange changes of focus, which made a gruelling piece of viewing even less appetising.

The police and the courts seemed unwilling and under-equipped to tackle the problem; hopefully the unadorned eloquence with which these stories were told will do something to convince a few more people of the reality of the problem. In the second part, Stalkers , the baddies were played by actors, and someone had run amok in the edit suite, so we were regularly drenched with colour washes and strange changes of focus, which made a gruelling piece of viewing even less appetising.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Dances With Wolves | Mickey Blue Eyes | Gorillas In The Mist | Zero De Conduite | Cold Water
fields.body:
Films

Dances With Wolves (Kevin Costner, 1990) 8pm, FilmFour: Some critics found the PC view of history hard to stomach: noble, peaceful, perfectly shampooed Sioux persecuted by a grubby paleface invasion, but Costner in his Oscar-winning directorial debut creates a Western of huge sweep and stirring beauty (cinematographer Dean Semler won another of the film's six Oscars). He also gives one of his fine decent-guy performances as John Dunbar, the disillusioned Civil War veteran seeking solace in the wilderness.

Mickey Blue Eyes (Kelly Makin, 1999) 8pm, Sky Premier: Hugh Grant's posh English auctioneer gets married to the mob in this undemanding comedy: when he proposes to Gina (Jeanne Tripplehorn), he soon learns that her family are actually Family. He hires The Godfather videos, but called on to impersonate Chicago mobster Mickey Blue Eyes, he's a predictable disaster. It's never more than a gentle entertainment, though James Caan as Gina's mafioso dad, Frank Vitale, exudes charm - plus a little Corleone menace.

Gorillas In The Mist (Michael Apted, 1988) 9pm, 1am, The Studio: Sigourney Weaver takes time out from stalking Aliens to play the courageous anthropologist Dian Fossey, who devoted her life to protecting the mountain gorillas of Rwanda from ruthless hunters. Weaver and the apes are fine performers, but the romance with National Geographic photographer Bob Campbell (Bryan Brown) looks as though it was tacked on to enhance marketability.

Zero De Conduite (Jean Vigo, 1933) 11.10pm, FilmFour: French with tears: Vigo's 45-minute assault on the authoritarian regime in a boarding school, based on his own childhood experiences. It portrays the teachers as puppets, controlled by a higher, more malignant power, but despite the obvious anger - it was the basis for Lindsay Anderson's attack on the establishment and public schools in If... - there are moments of sublime beauty: the pillow fight is like an ecstatic dreamworld.

Cold Water (Olivier Assayas, 1994) 12.05am, FilmFour: Conceived as part of a TV series in which directors revisit their childhood, this is a hard but affectionate account of two delinquents in early-70s Paris. Virginie Ledoyen (Leonardo's love interest in The Beach) plays the daughter of separated parents who is committed to a psychiatric hospital after shoplifting; she escapes and heads (amid hints of Midnight Cowboy), for the sunny south with middle-class pal Cyprien Fouquet. Paul Howlett

Sports

Figure Skating 11.15pm, British Eurosport: The World Championships started on Monday, and until Sunday the world's best skaters have descended upon Vancouver. Close to 220 skaters from 50 countries will compete at General Motors Place, knowing that their performance will decide how many places their country gets at the Winter Olympics. Tonight's pairs free programme features reigning champions, Maria Petrova and Alexei Tikhonov of Russia. Simon Burnton

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Our diarist has her worst moment so far: Peter calls to say the sheep are off colour

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Our diarist has her worst moment so far: Peter calls to say the sheep are off colour.
fields.body:
At the weekend two of our farming friends were hit by foot and mouth. Two animals from Dennis and Richard Gibb's 320-cow dairy herd had symptoms on Saturday, and by Sunday some of their water buffaloes showed symptoms too. The water buffalo herd had been a much needed second enterprise, with the cows supplying milk for premium mozzarella cheese. The animals were imported from Romania in 1998, following strict quarantine procedures, and Richard and Dennis have worked hard to train them into some sort of domesticity and compliance. Water buffalo are hardy and do not suffer from common infections, but they are highly strung and temperamental. All gone to waste now. Their farm is about eight miles east of here and we now have another suspect case four miles to the west.

We have had a hectic few days as the lambing season creeps closer, but at the end of last week I managed to leave the farm on urgent family business, which had already been delayed by three weeks. The drive across northern England and down the M6 was haunting. I chose a route, as far as was possible, to avoid confirmed cases, but in some areas this has become almost impossible. The sight of the smoke from so many funeral pyres throughout Cumbria was horrific.

My worst moment so far came while I was away: Peter phoned me and said he was worried about some of our sheep. Two wouldn't get up and another wouldn't eat or walk. There were no signs of blisters. I suggested the thermometer, as a final check, and endured a dreadful two hours before he rang back. The three animals all had normal temperatures, so we decided not to hit the panic button. But the emotions we went through were awful.

On my return to Northumberland, we went first to the Hexham car wash in an attempt to clear the outside of the car of any virus. Peter sprayed the wheels and wheel arches with disinfectant when we reached home and we all bathed and washed our hair, and every item of clothing, just in case. It all takes so long, and we don't really know if it will make any difference.

We had more snow over the weekend and even more is forecast for this week. The sheep have had the hardest winter of their lives and their feed rations have been increased yet again; we have bought expensive glucose licks to give the pregnant ewes an instant energy boost. There is not a blade of grass to be seen anywhere, and this is not helping.

Farmers in this area are beginning to suspect that they too will lose their sheep within a three kilometre radius. The cases continue to creep across the countryside in the Heddon-on-the-Wall area and parts of County Durham are becoming hot spots.

Tow Law is the County Durham equivalent of Longtown. It is a long, grey town with the A68 running through the centre. There is little tourism, but it has an auction mart and lots of outlying farms. The climate is harsh and the people stoical, but as the disease tightens its grip the anxiety increases within the tightly knit community - the town is almost dead and there is no movement in the countryside. Since Friday the local valuer, Harry Vickers, has been living in the pub. He was classed as "a dirty contact" following a livestock valuation and unable to return to his farm and his sheep. But he is worried about his clients, some of whom are in a desperate state, both from an animal welfare and financial viewpoint.

I have received a faxed list of countries with confirmed cases of foot and mouth, and the dates of each known outbreak. Lord Plumb was correct: as a nation we have become complacent over imports. There is a rumour that the army barracks in Northumberland was supplied with beef from Uruguay: I can see from this list that that country's most recent outbreak was in January of this year.

One thing is clear to us all: the nearer your farm is to a confirmed case, the deeper the fear. Richard Gibb told me, when I rang him to offer our sympathy, that he thinks it is the uninfected farms that need the luck now. Our other friends, the Murrays, were eventually released from their confinement at the weekend, but they are now back in a self-imposed quarantine as they suspect the disease has almost reached their farm boundary. It is a form of torture.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will be back on Friday.

fields.headline: Relief evaporates fast as military's limited role becomes clear
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Robin Mott is struggling to hold it together. His face is pinched and drawn, not from the biting cold and sleet whipping around the end of his driveway, but from sheer frustration.
fields.body:
Robin Mott is struggling to hold it together. His face is pinched and drawn, not from the biting cold and sleet whipping around the end of his driveway, but from sheer frustration.

Five days ago, an outbreak of foot and mouth was detected a few hundred yards down the road from the farm near Bridestowe, Devon, where Mr Mott has been raising pedigree cattle for over 30 years.

Four days ago, he contacted the authorities in Exeter to inform them that sheep from the infectined farm were grazing within a few hundred yards of his livestock. Two days ago, a Maff vet contacted him to inform him about the outbreak. Yesterday, the last of the infected farm's stock were finally slaughtered.

"If you had driven past here at 9.30am yesterday, you could have pulled over to the side of the road and walked up and patted those sheep," said Mr Mott, 64. "If this disease is as infectious as they say, then it's beyond me why, five days later, those animals were still walking around so close to mine."

Throughout the cluster of tiny farming communities that make up the burgh of West Devon - the epicentre of the foot and mouth outbreak in the west country - horror stories like Mr Mott's have fuelled a growing sense of unease about Maff's response to the crisis.

Almost as much as the disease itself, that is what lies behind the anger, the lack of sleep, the fear that the next farm to succumb will be theirs.

"The most frustrating thing is that we feel we have more common sense down here than all the people in Whitehall put together," Mr Mott said. "What would Nick Brown have said if he had seen those sheep still alive?"

All that is supposed to change this morning when a team of 130 military police soldiers move into action to support the slaughter operation in Devon.

Under the command of Major Belinda Forsythe, the troops, normally based in Wiltshire supporting 1 Mechanised Brigade, will today begin coordinating the slaughter and disposal operation in a bid to free Maff vets to concentrate on implementing it.

A 30 strong central command unit will be set up at Maff's regional headquarters in Devon. It will assume responsibility for getting slaughter and disposal teams to where they are needed most and sourcing plant and materials such as coal and wood for funeral pyres.

The remaining soldiers will be split into 50 two man teams and deployed on infected farms where they will oversee the private contractors brought in by Maff to kill and burn diseased stock.

Speaking outside Wyvern barracks in Exeter, where the MPs will be based, Major Forsythe attempted to reassure farmers that the logistics teams could turn the situation around. "As I understand it, the biggest problem is that the vets are not being given the time to do what they need to do. We will be carrying out coordination tasks, and any administrative tasks required to allow veterinary officers to carry out their tasks."

When it was announced on Monday that the army had been called in, farmers in the area breathed a sigh of relief; yesterday, however, as details of what the soldiers would be doing emerged, relief was evaporating fast.

To farmers like Mr Mott, the army's intervention is barely adequate. "There are so many good things the army could be doing. They have the manpower and the equipment to take over the disposal work and get it back on track within a couple of days. In an international emergency, hundreds of our troops will be sent in practically overnight, so why can't that happen here? Because this is an emergency and it is getting worse."

webTitle: No end in sight to increasingly grim task

fields.headline: No end in sight to increasingly grim task
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The wind plays cruel tricks in Dumfries and Galloway. When it is still, the air smells of soil and silage, the ordinary, reassuring scents of agriculture. But when the wind blows it carries the sharp, disturbing whiff of smoke and disinfectant.
fields.body:
The wind plays cruel tricks in Dumfries and Galloway. When it is still, the air smells of soil and silage, the ordinary, reassuring scents of agriculture. But when the wind blows it carries the sharp, disturbing whiff of smoke and disinfectant.

Life and landscape have changed here. This is Scotland's agricultural heart and so far the only area of the country to be hit by the foot and mouth outbreak. There are now 54 confirmed cases and the region's rich pastureland is pockmarked with pyres and barriers and warning signs. Market towns are all but deserted and plastic tape crisscrosses farm tracks like so many crime scenes.

At Kirkwood Farm near Lockerbie, Anthony Steel is waiting for the slaughtermen to come and kill his flock of 1,900 healthy sheep. Kirkwood lies within 3km of an infected farm and the grim work will start at the end of the week. Mr Steel is still trying to rationalise the need for his animals to be culled.

"Things have gone haywire," he said. "I am really depressed. There is absolutely no doubt that it has spiralled out of control. If you talk to anyone now no one is saying it will be contained within a matter of weeks, most say it might be months, some say it might take years if it is controllable at all.

"I am being asked to make a sacrifice which I could understand if I had pure confidence it was going to work and work quickly but the more I see of it the more I fear it is a half-hearted gesture. There is too much indecision and there is distinct lack of confidence that they are going to get the disease finished. And my sheep will pay the ultimate sacrifice. It is just horrible."

In Lockerbie itself the high street is too quiet for a midweek morning. The newsagent's window is filled with notices of cancelled social events: a coffee morning at Dryfesdale Church, an old time dance with Sandy Legget's band, a pensioners' lunch.

At Fawcett's the butchers, Chilton Fawcett stands over half-empty display cases stocked with meat brought in from elsewhere. The family has had the business since 1938 and it survived the 1952 foot and mouth outbreak. Chilton Fawcett is not so sure about this one. Trade has already dropped by 60%.

"You can see yourself, there is no one around," he said. "The town is empty and business is seriously affected."

Andrew Campbell used to share that view. The convenor of Dumfries and Galloway council, and a farmer himself, he was sharply critical of politicians for their early response to the crisis. He thinks they have the message now.

"I said to them, you can push paper around in Edinburgh but if you don't come down and see for yourself and understand it you can't possibly lead in these matters. The whole economy of Dumfries and Galloway hangs from agriculture. It is 23% of our GDP and 43% of VAT registers."

It has already been estimated that in the first week of the outbreak north of the border, 118 people lost their jobs in Dumfrires and Galloway. And a survey by the federation of small businessses has predicted that as many as 90% of the region's small firms could be lost if the crisis drags on.

Back at Kirkwood Farm, Mr Steel say he does not know how much longer the community can live with the anxiety. "There's a strange situation where those farmers who have had their flocks destroyed actually feel sorry for us who are still waiting for it to happen," he said. "It's the worry that is the awful thing. You never see Tony Blair or the rest of the cabinet coming to help. Blair is ducking this altogether. Maybe he can't believe how bad it has become. Sometimes even I can't believe how bad it is."

fields.bodyText: The wind plays cruel tricks in Dumfries and Galloway. When it is still, the air smells of soil and silage, the ordinary, reassuring scents of agriculture. But when the wind blows it carries the sharp, disturbing whiff of smoke and disinfectant. Life and landscape have changed here. This is Scotland's agricultural heart and so far the only area of the country to be hit by the foot and mouth outbreak. There are now 54 confirmed cases and the region's rich pastureland is pockmarked with pyres and barriers and warning signs. Market towns are all but deserted and plastic tape crisscrosses farm tracks like so many crime scenes. At Kirkwood Farm near Lockerbie, Anthony Steel is waiting for the slaughtermen to come and kill his flock of 1,900 healthy sheep. Kirkwood lies within 3km of an infected farm and the grim work will start at the end of the week. Mr Steel is still trying to rationalise the need for his animals to be culled. "Things have gone haywire," he said. "I am really depressed. There is absolutely no doubt that it has spiralled out of control. If you talk to anyone now no one is saying it will be contained within a matter of weeks, most say it might be months, some say it might take years if it is controllable at all. "I am being asked to make a sacrifice which I could understand if I had pure confidence it was going to work and work quickly but the more I see of it the more I fear it is a half-hearted gesture. There is too much indecision and there is distinct lack of confidence that they are going to get the disease finished. And my sheep will pay the ultimate sacrifice. It is just horrible." In Lockerbie itself the high street is too quiet for a midweek morning. The newsagent's window is filled with notices of cancelled social events: a coffee morning at Dryfesdale Church, an old time dance with Sandy Legget's band, a pensioners' lunch. At Fawcett's the butchers, Chilton Fawcett stands over half-empty display cases stocked with meat brought in from elsewhere. The family has had the business since 1938 and it survived the 1952 foot and mouth outbreak. Chilton Fawcett is not so sure about this one. Trade has already dropped by 60%. "You can see yourself, there is no one around," he said. "The town is empty and business is seriously affected." Andrew Campbell used to share that view. The convenor of Dumfries and Galloway council, and a farmer himself, he was sharply critical of politicians for their early response to the crisis. He thinks they have the message now. "I said to them, you can push paper around in Edinburgh but if you don't come down and see for yourself and understand it you can't possibly lead in these matters. The whole economy of Dumfries and Galloway hangs from agriculture. It is 23% of our GDP and 43% of VAT registers." It has already been estimated that in the first week of the outbreak north of the border, 118 people lost their jobs in Dumfrires and Galloway. And a survey by the federation of small businessses has predicted that as many as 90% of the region's small firms could be lost if the crisis drags on. Back at Kirkwood Farm, Mr Steel say he does not know how much longer the community can live with the anxiety. "There's a strange situation where those farmers who have had their flocks destroyed actually feel sorry for us who are still waiting for it to happen," he said. "It's the worry that is the awful thing. You never see Tony Blair or the rest of the cabinet coming to help. Blair is ducking this altogether. Maybe he can't believe how bad it has become. Sometimes even I can't believe how bad it is." What's going on? webTitle: Troops move in, farmers' desperation mounts

fields.headline: View from the killing fields: as the troops move in, farmers' desperation mounts
fields.standfirst:
Call for the army to kill all healthy herds next to infected farms

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Down a lane, through the steam rising off Cumbria's rotting carcass mountains, rushed a Volvo estate car, stopping to hurl a pile of Laura Ashley fabric at a farm gate.
fields.body:
Down a lane, through the steam rising off Cumbria's rotting carcass mountains, rushed a Volvo estate car, stopping to hurl a pile of Laura Ashley fabric at a farm gate. This was a sign of Cumbria's rising desperation - the "carpet women" -a group of local women pooling old rugs and fabric to distribute to farmers who have run out of protective barriers for Wellington boot washing.

In village pubs, there were stories of farmers keeping cattle under nets and using acid as disenfectant. Most believed Maff was losing the battle against foot and mouth and the army had arrived too late.

Uniformed soldiers carrying flipcharts arrived on a Carlisle industrial estate yesterday to plan the overdue disposal of the foot and mouth carcass piles.

But the number of confirmed cases in Cumbria rose to 114 by last night and farmers admitted the disease was out of control. They said the army should immediately kill all healthy herds near infected farms, or every animal in Cumbria would be dead within a month, causing ecological disaster. Those who once questioned the precautionary cull are now desperate.

Peter Allen, of the National Farmers Union, said: "The priority is killing. Moving the dead sheep is secondary. We need to get on with the cull of high risk healthy animals near infected areas. The army has to do that at the same time as clearing carcasses. That does not seem to be the plan and I doubt there are enough soldiers up here to do it. The outbreak has clearly overtaken us. We are running behind it."

Cumbria, the worst hit county in Britain, now faces a shortage of tools to deal with the crisis. There is a lack of coal for pyres, winches to lift carcasses, a lack of vets and wagons. As Jim Scudamore, the chief vet, said, killing and clearing the animals is a logistical nightmare.

Vets dragged carcasses across fields, due to the lack of support. Putrid landfill sites were being considered as burial tips and money was being pumped into mental health care for farmers.

On isolated farms, women answered the phone, complaining the men were in tears. In the tourist spots, taxis were lined up idle. There was no business. This week, Cumbria tourism will lose £6m to £10m. Farming and agriculture will lose up to £5m.

Around 80 soldiers from the first battalion, Prince of Wales's Regiment in Chester begin working in pairs today to manage the removal of carcasses that have been festering for 10 days, enveloping whole villages in the smell of rot.

The task they face is grim. One of the farmers affected, Claire Scott, stood in her kitchen in Skelton and described the view from her sink of scattered carcasses, hooves up, and rotting. At the table a group of vets were filling out disposal forms. Mrs Scott was told the animals, already decomposing, were likely to have to stay for at least another three days.

Geoff Todhunter, a farmer from Little Bampton, had to buy his own winching equipment to remove dead cattle from his fields on to wagons for rendering because the ministry arrived on Thursday without any equipment. He began to winch carcasses on to wagons, but there were only four shuttling back and forth to a rendering plant. Mr Todhunter's herd alone needed 27. It took five days.

Colin Gillespie from Kirkhampton, near Carlisle, was yesterday still waiting for a digger to arrive to dig a pit to bury his cattle. Meanwhile crows and vermin were treading on the carcasses. He had been promised a site manager but no one arrived.

Eric Martlew, Labour MP for Carlisle, warned the government was clueless about the scale of chaos in Cumbria. He said the government should appoint a foot and mouth tsar for the county.

webTitle: Search for woman after court rules on abortion attempt

fields.headline: Search for woman after court rules on abortion attempt
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday named a woman who went missing after her former lover launched a legal fight to stop her from aborting their unborn child.
fields.body:
A judge yesterday named a woman who went missing after her former lover launched a legal fight to stop her from aborting their unborn child.

Claire Hansell, 31, disappeared after her ex-boyfriend, Stephen Hone, took his case to the courts. Mr Hone launched his legal action against the Calthorpe nursing home in Edgbaston, Birmingham, saying the proposed termination contravened the Abortion Act.

His lawyers argued it was unlawful because only one doctor was consulted, instead of two, and no questions were asked about Ms Hansell's physical and mental state and why she wanted a termination.

His initial court application was adjourned after Mr Justice Sumner, a family division judge, said the Solihull clinic which sanctioned the abortion should be notified before any further hearing.

His solicitor, Paul Conrathe, said the abortion was booked for today at another clinic in Edgbaston, Birmingham.

Mr Conrathe said the action was being taken to prevent the clinic committing a criminal offence.

But Mr Hone, 24, a sales consultant from Coventry, claimed a partial victory yesterday after the clinic agreed at the high court that it would not carry out the operation without further medical inquiries.

Mr Justice Sumner, sitting in London, said the clinic had given a "highly responsible and helpful" undertaking that, if Ms Hansell continued to seek an abortion at the clinic, it would not rely on the certificate signed by the doctor originally seen by her.

The clinic had also given a second undertaking that, in the event of an abortion eventually taking place after the correct procedures had been followed, they would not dispose of the foetus without first giving seven days' notice to Mr Hone.

He has already made it clear he would seek access to the unborn baby's remains so that he could arrange a burial.

Mr Hone said he was pleased with the agreement, but was"saddened" that the abortion could still go ahead. He said he was now "desperate" to find his former girlfriend in the hope of saving the unborn child.

The agreement does not prevent Ms Hansell from seeking to terminate her pregnancy at another clinic, provided the correct legal procedures are followed.

Mr Hone, who has a four-year-old son and a daughter of two from a previous relationship, has said he is against abortion and is prepared to take responsibility for the new baby and bring it up.

He said last night: "It is a victory in one sense but a loss in the sense that it has still not prevented the abortion of my child. Also, I would desperately like to hear from her just to know that she is all right."

fields.headline: Alligators swamp suburbs
fields.trailText: The record drought has forced hundreds of amorous and thirsty alligators out of the swamps and into the canals and ponds of suburban south-east Florida.
fields.body:
The record drought has forced hundreds of amorous and thirsty alligators out of the swamps and into the canals and ponds of suburban south-east Florida.

So many have fled the swamps that the Seminole tribe - traditional protectors of the Everglades and its wildlife - set up a hotline at the weekend to find the roaming reptiles.

The service has logged 175 reports of alligators in the suburbs.

"Alligators have found themselves in need of water and therefore have left their habi tat," the tribe's spokesman, Chuck Malkus, said. "It is now spring and it's the mating season for alligators. Typically they will mate on the waterline."

The students on the hotline call trappers licensed to remove the "nuisance" creatures. and release them deep into the Everglades. And they warn callers not to try feeding the strays. "Animals will not know the difference between the food and the hand that is feeding it," Mr Malkus said.

South-east Florida has 5m people and 500 miles of waterways, canals and lakes in dense suburbs covering what was once part of the Everglades. Reuters

fields.headline: Blackouts continue to plague California
fields.trailText: California is experiencing its first state-wide blackouts since the second world war
fields.body:
California is experiencing its first state-wide blackouts since the second world war, and the indications are that, with the early arrival of the hot weather, the problems may be only beginning.

The state's smaller electricity suppliers - generators of solar and wind power which have not been paid by the utility companies since last year - added to the crisis by cutting their supplies, it emerged yesterday.

As hair-dryers failed in Santa Monica and blank traffic lights caused delays in Oxnard, the governor, Gray Davis, said the state was "working night and day" to stabilise the electricity supply.

His administration has so far asked for $4.7bn (£3.3bn) state money to try to buy out-of-state electricity. But with the rolling blackouts entering their second day yesterday, the indications are that the cuts will continue until at least September, causing enormous economic damage to the state.

The blackouts have prompted apocalyptic predictions.

The energy secretary, Spencer Abraham, told a US chamber of commerce conference on energy: "The failure to meet this challenge will threaten our nation's economic prosperity, compromise our national security and literally alter the way we live our lives."

webTitle: Taped secrets of day Reagan was shot

fields.headline: Taped secrets of day Reagan was shot
fields.trailText: On the day that President Ronald Reagan was shot almost 20 years ago, his top advisers shut themselves in the White House situation room and nervously debated who was in command, while keeping a wary eye on Soviet military positions, according to tape recordings of the event.
fields.body:
On the day that President Ronald Reagan was shot almost 20 years ago, his top advisers shut themselves in the White House situation room and nervously debated who was in command, while keeping a wary eye on Soviet military positions, according to tape recordings of the event.

The tapes, to be discussed next month by their maker, Richard Allen, Mr Reagan's national security adviser at the time, reveal that the famous remark to reporters by the secretary of state Alexander Haig, that he was "now in charge" was preceded by similar comments in the situation room.

After being told that Mr Reagan was on the operating table, Mr Haig said: "The helm is right here. And that means right in this chair for now, constitutionally, until the vice-president gets here," according to the transcript.

The vice-president on March 30 1981, George Bush Sr, was on an Air Force jet, returning to Washington.

Mr Allen will tell next month's issue of Atlantic Monthly magazine that no one felt like provoking a fight that day by pointing out that the secretary of state was not the next in line for the presidency after the vice-president. He is behind the speaker of the House and the president pro tempore of the Senate.

The tapes also portray aides, somewhat confusedly, making sure they knew the location of "the football" - the briefcase that travels with the president and which contains codes to launch nuclear missiles.

The defence secretary at the time, Caspar Weinberger, informed the others that crews at strategic air command had moved to their planes, a step that could have saved a few minutes had there been a Soviet threat.

Taping of discussions in the situation room are generally not allowed. But Mr Allen said that he thought this event merited an exception.

"On this occasion, however, I considered a recording to be absolutely essential in order to preserve an indisputable record," he said.

webTitle: US hacker 'duped the rich and famous'

fields.headline: US hacker 'duped the rich and famous'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A restaurant worker is suspected of using the identities of some of America's richest celebrities and executives in a scam which the local authorities describe as the biggest identity theft in internet history.
fields.body:
A restaurant worker is suspected of using the identities of some of America's richest celebrities and executives in a scam which the local authorities describe as the biggest identity theft in internet history.

Abraham Abdallah, 32, a convicted fraudster, has been arrested, accused of infiltrating the financial accounts of more than 200 people on Forbes magazine's annual list of richest people in the US.

His alleged victims include Steven Spielberg and Oprah Winfrey from the world of entertainment, and Ted Turner, Warren Buffett, George Soros, Michael Bloomberg and Larry Ellison from the financial world.

Mr Abdallah is accused of using the web and his local Brooklyn library to track down confidential information and access bank, brokerage and credit card accounts.

One piece of evidence found by the police was a well-worn copy of Forbes magazine with home addresses, telephone numbers, bank accounts and mothers' maiden names scrawled beside the billionaires' biographies. In several cases their all-important US social security numbers had also been written down.

Mr Abdallah allegedly used web-enabled mobile phones and virtual voicemail services to track packages ordered in his victims' names and pick up messages from anywhere in the US.

Detective Michael Fabozzi of the New York police department told the New York Post: "There were so many packages going to so many places at one time, it's impossible to figure out how he kept track of it all ... but he did."

The department believes Mr Abdallah cloned the identities of his victims, setting up hundreds of bogus New York addresses for postal deliveries, before raiding their personal accounts.

The police, who arrested their suspect as he picked up a delivery a month ago, are still trying to discover the extent of the fraud, which they believe lasted more than six months.

Mr Abdallah has been charged with criminal possession of forged devices and stolen property and criminal impersonation. He denies the accusations.

The case began in December when the NYPD was alerted to a suspicious request to transfer $10m (£7m) from an account belonging to Thomas Siebel, founder of Siebel Systems, an electronics firm.

Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm, had contacted Mr Siebel about the request because it conflicted with the requirements of the account. He said he knew nothing about it.

The fraud squad traced the request to two Yahoo! email addresses. Merrill Lynch then found the same email used for five more billionaire clients.

Requests to other Wall Street firms, which handle the personal accounts of America's wealthiest people, uncovered similar coincidences.

The police found that many of the business addresses given to set up the accounts either did not exist or were shared by two billionaires at a time.

One piece of evidence found by the police was a well-worn copy of Forbes magazine with home addresses, telephone numbers, bank accounts and mothers' maiden names scrawled beside the billionaires' biographies. In several cases their all-important US social security numbers had also been written down. Mr Abdallah allegedly used web-enabled mobile phones and virtual voicemail services to track packages ordered in his victims' names and pick up messages from anywhere in the US. Detective Michael Fabozzi of the New York police department told the New York Post: "There were so many packages going to so many places at one time, it's impossible to figure out how he kept track of it all ... but he did." The department believes Mr Abdallah cloned the identities of his victims, setting up hundreds of bogus New York addresses for postal deliveries, before raiding their personal accounts. The police, who arrested their suspect as he picked up a delivery a month ago, are still trying to discover the extent of the fraud, which they believe lasted more than six months. Mr Abdallah has been charged with criminal possession of forged devices and stolen property and criminal impersonation. He denies the accusations. The case began in December when the NYPD was alerted to a suspicious request to transfer $10m (£7m) from an account belonging to Thomas Siebel, founder of Siebel Systems, an electronics firm. Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm, had contacted Mr Siebel about the request because it conflicted with the requirements of the account. He said he knew nothing about it. The fraud squad traced the request to two Yahoo! email addresses. Merrill Lynch then found the same email used for five more billionaire clients. Requests to other Wall Street firms, which handle the personal accounts of America's wealthiest people, uncovered similar coincidences. The police found that many of the business addresses given to set up the accounts either did not exist or were shared by two billionaires at a time.

webTitle: Freed British hostage tells of terror in Bangladeshi jungle

fields.headline: Freed British hostage tells of terror in Bangladeshi jungle
fields.trailText: A British engineer held hostage for four weeks in the Bangladeshi jungle yesterday told how he feared for his life.
fields.body:
A British engineer held hostage for four weeks in the Bangladeshi jungle yesterday told how he feared for his life.

Tim Selby, 28, was snatched at gunpoint by rebels on February 16 in the south-east of Bangladesh, while working on a road surveying project for a Danish firm.

He was freed on Saturday and yesterday flew back to Britain for an emotional reunion with his girlfriend, Brigid Thorns, 25, father Alfred, 60, and his mother Margaret, 61.

Mr Selby, who was held with two Danes, was marched through the jungle as his kidnappers tried to keep ahead of the army.

When asked if he feared never seeing his family again, he said: "On a daily basis. There were a number of times I said I've had enough of this, but I couldn't get out. There was at times absolute sheer terror."

The rebels demanded a £1m ransom for the release of the three hostages. Sources say they were released after a deal between the Bangladeshi government and rebels. The Foreign Office dismissed claims that the guerrillas' jungle hideout had been stormed by the army and the hostages released after a shoot-out.

Mr Selby said he knew little of how his ordeal came to an end. The first they knew was when their guards told them they would be released.

Mr Selby said he was delighted to be back on British soil: "It might be cold outside, it may be snowing, it may be raining, I couldn't care less, it's home."

His first taste of home was a 30-minute delay in landing at Heathrow because of ice on a runway.

fields.headline: Tony Denton
fields.standfirst: Engineer at the cutting edge of oil exploration
fields.trailText: Engineer at the cutting edge of oil exploration
fields.body:
An outstanding offshore engineer, Tony Denton, who has died aged 63, had a part in some of the 20th century's most exciting and significant work in his field. He was on board the first drilling platform in the hostile conditions of the North Sea. On the Statfjord-B project, he was responsible for the lift of the 40,000-tonne integrated dock and the tow of an 825,000-tonne concrete platform.

It was in 1963 that Denton met Captain David Noble, a master mariner and marine consultant, who asked him to look at the strength and stability problems of marine industrial equipment, such as oil and gas barges, floating docks, cranes and dredgers. It was the beginning of a fruitful partnership; Noble had vast sea-going experience, Denton had technical ability. Initially, he continued with his academic career at Imperial College, London, but, in 1966, he joined WD Noble & Co on a fulltime basis. In 1971, the firm became Noble Denton & Associates.

The next 30 years were to see their growth into global operations, with particular emphasis on advising underwriters on the risks of locating and moving large structures at sea. Denton's design studies, assessments, and recommendations for drilling rigs and production platforms, and his experience of the towage of very large platforms, won him worldwide recognition.

Engineering was in Denton's family blood - both his father and grandfather were senior colliery engineers. Born in Barnsley, and educated at Queen Elizabeth grammar school, Wakefield, where he was inspired by his mathematics teacher, he took the mechanical science tripos at Downing College, Cambridge, in 1958.

He then accepted a graduate apprenticeship with Quasi-Arc, and published his first technical paper. In 1960, he moved to British Oxygen and was seconded to Imperial College, where his research into the weldless closing of tubes formed from strip lead led to a doctorate. He remained at the college, lecturing in mechanical engineering while his working relationship with Noble developed.

He was managing director of Noble Denton International from 1977-86, and its chairman from 1981 until his retirement in 1997. From 1995 to 1999, Denton chaired the British national committee for the United Nations International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction.

He was vice-president of the Royal Academy of Engineering, chaired its international committee from 1992-95, and was president of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers in 1993. At the time of his death, he was president of the Institution of Incorporated Engineers. His honours included a CBE in 1997, a fellowship in engineering (1983) and an honorary doctorate from the City University.

Hugely generous, private and modest, Denton had a competitive spirit - and a passion for cars. In his youth, he owned Mini-Coopers, Triumphs and Morgans, culminating in the Formula 3 Cooper with which Jackie Stewart had won the European championship - and which Denton raced until a serious crash. A lover of fine wines, he was also a keen rugby player, and never happier than when entertaining friends at Twickenham.

Denton was married twice, first to Jean Moss, later Baroness Denton of Wakefield (Obituary, February 7 2001). He was especially proud of the work of his second wife, Anthea, whom he married in 1974, and whose sculpted bust of the engineer and businessman Sir William Barlow was presented to the Royal Academy of Engineering. She survives him.

Anthony Albert Denton, eng-ineer, born March 14 1937; died March 3 2001
