fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: Some things are best left unsaid
fields.trailText: Some things are best left unsaid
fields.body:
A question for you. Is five to nine in the morning a bit early in the day for mutual masturbation? And what about "tit-beating"? Do you even know what it is?

I ask, because Will Self's essay for last Saturday's Today programme embraced both of those terms, and we weren't sure what to do about it. Quite apart from offending some of our adult audience, there are also children listening, which can lead to embarrassing moments in the kitchen:

"Mummy, what's mutual masturbation?"

"I've no idea, Portia. Why don't you ask Skinner and Baddiel?"

There are BBC guidelines, of course, and they're quite specific; but not Will Self-level specific.

So we talked about it, the Today duty editor and me. In fact we talked about it for so long and in such depth that I took a quick shower afterwards. And we decided that it was pushing things a bit and that we would make a copy with the offending words removed and play that instead.

And then, with crushing inevitability, we accidentally ran the naughty version. There are dark forces at work in radio studios, believe me. If Will had made a simple mistake, a stumble over a word or a repeated sentence, we'd have had no trouble in playing out the corrected version. Our gremlins are selective and suffused with evil.

People will tell you that mistakes like this occur because of the new, rather ghostly electronic system for playing in pre-recorded interviews. It didn't happen when we had solid, quarter-inch tape, they say, misty-eyed. Oh yes it did. It happened a lot, especially when it was me charged with the task of labelling the tapes.

Of course, the most fun occurs when the guests are live. A few years ago John Humphrys had the pleasure of interviewing the American feminist Andrea Dworkin. The subject matter was pornography and suddenly, when John was in mid-sentence, she broke in: "Jaaarn...you gotta understand," she said, her voice rising with every syllable, "we're talking about splayed labia." Now they'd never been on the programme before. Or since. And imagine how I felt, then a junior member of staff, listening to this in my bed, aware of the BBC producer guidelines on such matters, knowing that the switchboard would be lighting up with complaints, knowing that a colleague - a close friend - was there in the studio anticipating the wrath of his editor, of the controller, of the general public. Yes, you're right. It was a reaction of untrammelled glee.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Family Soap | Night Waves | Kirsty MacColl's Cuba
fields.body:
For reasons no one seems able to explain, stress among British workers has reached unprecedented levels, bringing falling productivity, increased absenteeism, and high staff turnover. But one firm has developed an apparently effective answer. In Family Soap (11.0am, Radio 4) Sue Holt, a former health visitor, explains her work as a child-care coordinator at a Lancashire factory. She finds herself immersed in all varieties of family issues and her boss thinks her efforts have made his 1,000 employees far happier.

In 1938 Abel Meeropol, a Jewish teacher in New York, wrote a short song for his wife Anne. It eventually appeared under his usual pen name of Lewis Allen but he might as well have signed it Anon. Even now, few people have ever heard of the man responsible for one of the 20th century's most haunting protest songs. Strange Fruit grabbed the public's imagination when Billie Holiday sang it rather apprehensively to a night club audience. In Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) Philip Dodd tracks its subsequent chequered history.

The final instalment of Kirsty MacColl's Cuba (10.0pm, Radio 2), was compiled after the singer's death in a Caribbean swimming accident and is presented by the musicologist Jan Fairly. Using material MacColl had already taped, he considers the potential tourist attractions of the island and speculates about the effect that mass tourism might have after 40 years' near-isolation.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Herd instinct
fields.trailText: Herd instinct
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Snow, sleet, rain, sunshine: this is big weather and all happening in the space of a couple of hours. We seem to be the meeting place of two weather systems, one from the north and one from the south. Their collision spits out ripping winds laden with everything from snow to rain. Then the thrashing subsides into a sparkling stillness where huge, lumpily pregnant clouds build above white hills. The lanes under the Edge trickle with water. Across the entrance to farms are strewn the unwelcome mats of straw soaked in disinfectant. Notices on footpath fingerposts spell out the reason they are closed; some begin with the word DANGER, in red. It is not that Spring has laid a minefield through the woods, it's about us, we are the danger, the agents of infection, the threat.

More and more I'm beginning to feel that the deadly mix of fear and bureaucracy which has closed down the countryside has little to do with containing foot-and-mouth and more to do with containing a potentially explosive dissent. Walking past a field, where the gate has been lashed shut with twine, the bleating of soggy sheep has an urgent, accusative ring to it. Lambs totter about but the ewes stand facing the road and call loudly. It's pathetic. How long will it be before these animals are snatched by the nightmare of official regulations and zones, ending hooves-up in a burning heap? The exclusion zones are really about depersonalising the problem. It is this lamb in this field of this farm that will bear the brunt of our incompetence to treat creatures we will eventually kill to eat with the respect and consideration they deserve.

webTitle: Interview: Katharine Dor&eacute, West End producer

fields.headline: Last year it was men in tutus.
fields.standfirst: Now it's Dawn French's Bottom Katharine Doré, the woman behind Adventures in Motion Pictures, tells Lyn Gardner about her latest project
fields.trailText: Now it's Dawn French's Bottom Katharine Doré, the woman behind Adventures in Motion Pictures, tells Lyn Gardner about her latest project.
fields.body:
When Katharine Doré was eight her parents took her to see her first Shakespeare play: Trevor Nunn's production of The Merchant of Venice. The deal was that, as long as she sat quietly, she would get an ice cream in the interval. The interval came and the ice cream was offered, but Doré refused to get up. It turned out she was so entranced by the play that she didn't want to leave her seat in case someone stole it. Doré hopes ice cream sales at the Albery Theatre will be plummeting this week with the opening of A Midsummer Night's Dream.

This is her first venture as an independent West End producer after 13 years of guiding Adventures in Motion Pictures from fledgling dance company to international success. "I want people to feel the same thrill I felt all those years ago. I want them to hang onto their seats," says Doré, whose partnership with Matthew Bourne and AMP is on hold until the company takes up residence at the Old Vic in 2002. Bourne has been choreographing My Fair Lady at the National Theatre, while Doré has set up her own production company and is juggling several theatre and TV projects.

But first off is A Midsummer Night's Dream. Several established West End producers have already suggested that Doré is completely mad, and she accepts that the received wisdom is that doing Shakespeare in the West End is tantamount to putting everything you own on a three-legged horse. But she has good reason to believe she can keep her shirt where others have lost theirs. For a start, there are few West End producers, however seasoned, with Dore's experience of the large scale. There is a world of difference between putting on a three-hander such as Art and AMP's Swan Lake, with its full corps de ballet and orchestra.

The bottom line is that when Swan Lake was at the Dominion a couple of years ago it had to take £160,000 a week just to break even, so Doré reckons that the £120,000 a week needed for Dream to pay its way over an eight-week season is more than achievable. "There are two ways to approach the West End. You can say, 'This is a great property and it will put bums on seats', or you can say, 'I really believe in this and I want to do it'. That's my way," says Doré of the latter, cheerily pointing out that the years with AMP have given her a good nose for what an audience wants. "They want something superbly, beautifully produced, they want it to look great and they want to be entertained," she says. "Stunning to the eye and stimulating to the heart and mind. Those qualities are the Katharine Doré brand . . . oops, I can't use that word."

When, some years ago, Bourne proposed an all-male Swan Lake, Doré knew instantly it would work and wanted to be part of it. She had exactly the same feeling when director Matthew Francis and designer Lez Brotherston suggested that she stage a production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, set in a large English country house during the second world war. The text is still all Shakespeare's, but Theseus and Hippolyta are part of an exiled court, Demetrius is in the army, Lysander is in the RAF, and Shakespeare's rude mechanicals are now members of the local Women's Institute, eager to put on a play to celebrate the royal wedding. Doré's final trump card in terms of selling tickets is that Bottom is played by Dawn French.

But Doré is at pains to point out that she is putting on real Shakespeare, "not Vicar of Dibley Shakespeare", and that this is a company show, not a star vehicle. After some initial confusion, when some of the team thought they were being offered parts in a ballet, Doré has assembled a strong cast, including Jemma Redgrave as Titania, Michael Silberry as Oberon and Tilly Blackwood as Helena. Doré is also firmly of the opinion that if you update or transpose classics, you have to have a strong rationale. "There were a lot of doubters about Matthew's male swans in Swan Lake. But I could see the point of these masculine creatures, whose underlying violence and aggression comes through their lyrical movements. It was the same when Matthew and Lez put forward their idea for Dream. You can tell when a director is telling you about something from the heart and when they are just putting spin on a good idea."

A few years ago Doré and AMP took Swan Lake to Broadway. The show was a triumph, winning the company 15 awards, but the experience reminded her that, although we may grumble about our West End theatre, we have a lot to be grateful for. "I thought that taking a show to Broadway would be the ultimate, but it turned out to be the most desolate place on earth to work. There is no creativity and no community there. The only thing that counts is the bottom line. Thank goodness it is not like that here, that producers and audiences will still take risks. I really do believe that if the work is good enough, you'll get an audience for it."

 A Midsummer Night's Dream is at the Albery Theatre, London WC2 (020-7369 1740), from Friday until May 12.

fields.headline: All together now
fields.standfirst: What happens when 16 London choirs join forces? Brian Logan finds out
fields.trailText: What happens when 16 London choirs join forces? Brian Logan finds out.
fields.body:
It's a wintry Tuesday night in darkest north London, and the sound of singing is spilling out from a church. A Belgian choreographer and a British composer creep in. At the altar, amid a cluster of unused amps, a huddle of young men and women are filling the space with one of the most uplifting vocal symphonies their visiting audience has heard. This is the Congolese Christian Choir. They sing in French, or in the Kikongo dialect; not all of them speak English. The excited man in charge wants to show the choreographer, Alain Platel, and the composer, Orlando Gough, what his group can do. After half an hour of soaring African spirituals, the guests are reluctant to leave. "I could stay for ever," says Platel, dewy-eyed. "I found that very, very moving," says Gough.

The reason for their visit is a project called Because I Sing, directed by the pair and produced by Artangel. Fascinated by communal singing - from football matches to the last night of the Proms - Artangel chief Michael Morris and Platel, acclaimed choreographer of Les Ballets C de la B, came up with the idea of uniting amateur choirs from across London in a one-off "choral portrait" of the city. The event - which takes place later this month at Camden's Roundhouse, and is being filmed for Channel 4 - has involved a year's work. "I've lived in London all my life, and I've discovered parts I never knew existed," says Morris.

According to Gough, who runs the professional choral ensemble The Shout, the only directory of London choirs is written by and for a middle-aged white constituency. By "putting the word out and following our noses", the team excavated an astonishingly diverse subculture. The final bill of participants - which includes the Armenian church, the Gwalia Welsh choir and the Ngati Ranana Maori choir - represents their richest pickings. "At first," recalls Gough, "we got distracted by the idea of full ethnic coverage - it was becoming a PC exercise in getting one of everything, which was ridiculous because they just don't exist." There is, for example, no Asian choral tradition. So Gough and Platel broadened the terms of their search. In the final production, a choir from Lloyds Bank will sing with the South Hampstead School for Girls, and the London Gay Men's Chorus with the Kingdom Gospel choir of Tooting. Time constraints scuppered the Metropolitan police's plans to participate; their rendition of Bohemian Rhapsody had much impressed Gough and Platel.

The latter is a small-town boy - he was an academic in Ghent before shooting to unlikely stardom in the early 1990s - and is bamboozled by London's vastness. "This is hell," he remarks, emerging from Shepherd's Bush tube station. The choirs that comprise Because I Sing are the flipside: London's heaven, representing both the city's multiculturalism and the desire of communities to retain their identities within it. Platel is fascinated too by the nooks and draughty cellars the choirs have found to rehearse in. It's essential to him that Because I Sing "retains an element of the spaces in which the choirs perform. I'm worried that, by taking them to the Roundhouse, we might harm them." Gough agrees: "It's up to us to try and preserve the magic."

In Shepherd's Bush, Platel and Gough visited St Saviour's Church, for the London Diocese Deaf Choir's Christmas service. The appeal of the deaf choir couldn't be more different from that of their Congolese counterparts: they sing, not vocally, but with their hands, in synchronised swoops and flutters of sign language. Choir leader Dorothy had her work cut out keeping singers and organist, who's high-tone deaf, in time. There were disagreements over how each carol should be signed - partly because the British Sign Language word for "Christmas" doesn't incorporate the word for "Christ".

And yet the performance was extremely expressive - like a dance, in miniature. Gough left St Saviour's delighted by what he had seen, and "terribly excited about the event" - even though neither he nor Platel have a keen idea what form it will take or who'll sing what. The 16 groups come together only three days before their performance - an occasion on which, says Gough, "I think the shit is going to seriously hit the fan."

Very few of the choirs have experience of singing in any group larger than their own. "Trying to get 500 people or ganised and galvanised is going to be very hard. The choirs are very anxious about the practicalities," he explains. In the face of such anxieties, Gough has abandoned his plan of having the scenery changes powered by horses - as a tribute to the Roundhouse's railway origins. Jeremy Haneman, of the London Gay Men's Chorus, agrees that the project is bewilderingly ambitious. "If a lesser organisation than Artangel had come up with it, we would have said, 'Dream on.' Even now, it's a bit of a mystery what's going to happen. That's part of the attraction."

Gough is expecting something "like a political summit, with that chaos and that many misunderstandings. But I don't want it to be precious and beautiful. A lot of the amateur choirs are at their best when they're at their rawest." It's not until a few months after seeing the Congolese and deaf choirs that Gough formulates a clearer picture of the final production. After delicate negotiation, songs have been selected for each choir to perform, and a structure for the event - "from rarefied and exotic", says Gough, "to familiar and poppy" - settled upon.

he Armenian group is to kick off the show, the Gay Men's Chorus will croon Kylie Minogue, and the finale will involve "all the choirs singing a different popular song simultaneously. We have three enormous banks of steps forming a great Busby Berkeley staircase at the end. We want to get all the choirs singing but not in a kind of cheesy Hollywood romp. So we're going for this stranger idea - which might be really beautiful, might be chaotic and might be quite funny." While the production "could easily spiral out of control", says Gough, he and Platel hope it will remind audiences of music's messy, informal grassroots "There isn't a culture of respect for amateurism any more," Gough adds. "It's so easy to see and buy highly professional music these days that people always expect perfection. Whereas part of what's special about these groups is that they're not perfect." Haneman, of the London Gay Men's Chorus, points out that - as the event's title obliquely indicates - singing isn't a means to an end, but the end itself. "There's no logical reason to do it. It's not particularly good for your health. But there is nothing like it."

 Because I Sing is at the Roundhouse, London NW1 (020-7771 2000), on March 31 and April 1.

fields.headline: Reforms leave Kurds cold
fields.trailText: Kurdish leaders in Turkey are disappointed at the government's programme of reforms for membership of the European Union
fields.body:
Kurdish leaders in Turkey expressed disappointment yesterday at a programme of reforms announced by the government to prepare the country for possible membership of the European Union.

The programme was described by the government as a "a fundamental revision of Turkey's political, economic, social and administrative structures".

As part of the process leading to eventual EU membership for Turkey, Brussels had asked Ankara to loosen restrictions on the use of languages other than Turkish - though the request carefully avoiding a direct reference to Kurdish.

The reform programme appeared to give some ground on language but fell well short of meeting Kurdish demands for greater cultural rights in education and broadcasting. "This is much less than people expect," said Hasan Kaya, of the Kurdish Institute in Istanbul. "We believe this programme will be insufficient."

The document produced by the government is circumspect. It states that Turkish is the country's official language which should be used in education, but it also recognises the right of people to use other languages and dialects.

There is a division in the government about the extent of reforms. The far-right Nationalist Action Party and the military argue that allowing Kurds to broadcast or teach in their language would encourage Kurdish nationalism.

Leading Kurdish activists disagree. The mayor of the mainly Kurdish city of Diyarbakir, Feridun Celik, said he believed only about 10% of Kurds now support independence - but the majority want greater cultural rights.

European officials have reacted cautiously to the reform programme. "We need time to examine the document in detail", a European commission spokesman said yesterday.

It contains plenty that will please the EU if carried out. The programme requires the implementation of 89 new laws and sets as a priority the development of freedom of speech in accordance with EU norms. The programme also promises to review the death penalty.Turkey became a formal candidate for EU membership in 1999.

fields.headline: Galen causes ferment
fields.trailText: The rumour mill has gone into overdrive where Galen, the Northern Irish pharmaceuticals company, is concerned.
fields.body:
The rumour mill has gone into overdrive where Galen, the Northern Irish pharmaceuticals company, is concerned.

In the past week its shares have fallen sharply on speculation about possible financial problems at Warner Chilcott, the women's healthcare company it acquired in September. This followed the resignation of Warner boss Paul Herendeen.

But analysts point out Mr Herendeen's resignation had more to do with his desire to find a chief executive role and that the company is confident of achieving its analysts' forecasts for the year to September 30, 2001.

Positive announcements are also expected from the company in coming weeks. Approval for Galen's estradiol-based IVR formulation is anticipated soon. Approval could lead to product launch ahead of the anticipated mid-year timetable. Galen shares closed 2.5p weaker at 825p.

fields.headline: Analysts' chemical reaction
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown may think the domestic economy is set for sturdy growth this year despite the slowdown in the US economy but not everyone in the Square Mile agrees.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown may think the domestic economy is set for sturdy growth this year despite the slowdown in the US economy but not everyone in the Square Mile agrees.

The stock market, after all, is the City's prediction of where corporate profits will be in future and even after yesterday's strong showing is languishing at levels last seen two years ago. Moreover, some analysts think certain areas of the economy are already mired in a recession.

Take the chemicals industry. Yesterday Credit Lyonnais Securities significantly reduced its profits forecasts for the sector across Europe on the grounds that it is already in a cyclical recession.

Because of the US slowdown, Credit Lyonnais analyst Martin Evans believes demand is weakening and the order books of European chemicals firms are low. "Chemicals activity in Europe is likely to be significantly diminished in 2001, with 2002 not much better," he predicts.

As a precaution he has lowered his rating on ICI , down 8p to 450p, to "hold", cut his forecasts for BOC , off 13p to 995p, and slapped a "reduce" recommendation on sector favourite Johnson Matthey , a penny higher at £10.55.

"We don't think the fuel cell hype around Johnson Matthey is enough to offset the difficult trading conditions in the US automotive market," he said.

Another stock caught up in the US-related malaise yesterday was glass maker Pilkington which slipped 8.75p to 118.5p as analysts reacted negatively to a trading update. Much like the chancellor, Pilkington thinks it is well placed to face the economic uncertainties of the coming year, but analysts are not so sure.

Merrill Lynch thinks the slowdown in the US automotive market and rising raw material costs will start to bite soon. After cutting its profits forecasts for the next two years, Merrill was yesterday advising its clients to hold off buying for the moment.

As it happens, leading shares finshed the day sharply higher as the ever-volatile telecoms sector swung back into favour after solid gains in New York overnight.

The FTSE 100 finished up 95.2 points at 5,646.8, with Marconi (25p stronger at 389p), Vodafone (6.25p better at 207p) and BT (up 22.5p to 522.5p on speculation that its chief executive, Peter Bonfield, had quit), delivering most of the upside.

Elsewhere, the FTSE TechMark 100 rose 30.85 points to 2,049.30, as the likes of Sage (7.25p higher at 257.25p), and Misys (29p stronger at 550p) bounced back from recent weakness.

Dealers were not reading too much into the performance. With market turnover low they attributed the strong showing to the squaring of positions ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. "No one wants to go into the Fed meeting long or short of stock," said one senior market man.

Lower down, the FTSE mid 250 finished 0.5 points lower at 6,218.9, undermined by dreadful display from Capital Radio after UBS Warburg turned an outright seller of the stock. Analyst Simon Mays-Smith thinks Capital Radio deserves to trade at a discount to its peers - about 900p - because of its "maturing growth profile". Capital shares ended 105p lower at 910p.

Elsewhere, Bright Station , the software and e-commerce company run by colourful entrepreneur Dan Wagner, ended 1.75p higher at 24.5p, despite dark rumours that the company will miss its revenue forecasts.

One broker, rumoured to be Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, is said to have hacked tens of millions off its revenue estimates for the next two years. According to the gossips Bright Station has been hit by the downturn in the technology market.

It has £16m cash on the balance sheet - enough to live off for a couple more quarters - but analysts think some cash injection will be needed if the company is to flourish.

fields.headline: At this price
fields.standfirst: DCS
fields.trailText: DCS
fields.body:
Software company DCS Group has been having a tough time after making the error of getting set to expand just before a downturn.

It is paying the price. The stock, which traded at £21 last May, dropped 7p yesterday to 32.5p. Punters will not be pleased to learn that the last time the shares were this low was in 1993.

Some analysts are describing the company's moves as a catalogue of errors but it is not clear whether DCS's situation is terminal or just deeply depressing.

"The broad facts are that we geared up for growth in 2000 but unfortunately it did not come through as we expected," DCS's chief executive, Tim Robinson, said.

The company, which issued a profits warning in December, posted results yesterday in line with revised expectations and finance director Jonathan Lees is leaving. "Change is appealing for both him and the company," Mr Robinson said.

The figures did little to lift City spirits. Turnover fell 15% to £140m and the group said it would not be paying a final dividend. DCS reported a pretax and goodwill loss of £11.8m for the year to the end of December compared with a profit of £10m in 1999.

The company said its financial performance was affected by a lack of demand for its core applications systems and services, and demand for its newer web-based solutions not growing as quickly as expected.

Although the results are in line with revised figures, the company's immediate future looks bleak. DCS is heavily indebted and, although the company hopes to break even at the end of the year, that is the best-case scenario, according to analysts.

The company, which cut 10% of jobs in the fourth quarter and said it would continue to review its cost base, admitted the economic climate and its impact on IT spending was causing continuing uncertainty. If you have stock, hold and hope for better times; if you do not, now is hardly the time to rush in.

fields.headline: Debt-laden Xerox defies predators
fields.trailText: Xerox, the copier company that was one of the biggest victims of the technology shakeout, announced recovery plans yesterday and said it wanted to remain independent.
fields.body:
Xerox, the copier company that was one of the biggest victims of the technology shakeout, announced recovery plans yesterday and said it wanted to remain independent.

Chairman and chief executive Paul Allaire, who returned from semi-retirement last year to take over the struggling business, said yesterday: "We are confident about our turnover plan. We are not up for sale." But he admitted the company was talking to several leveraged buyout firms interested in taking a stake.

Xerox has $16.4bn in debts. It announced a $1bn cost-cutting plan last year, which is expected to lead to up to 10,000 job cuts around the world.

Mr Allaire said the company was making good progress on an asset disposal programme set to raise between $2bn and $4bn. Sale of a stake in two businesses has raised $1.9bn. It was now looking to sell stakes in its ink jet business, European paper business and Xerox Parc research lab.

Leases and sales make up between $11bn and $12bn of debt, a burden that has proved increasingly expensive as credit ratings have been slashed. The company is in discussions with several others around the world in an effort to outsource its equipment financing business. Mr Allaire said Xerox hoped to complete a deal later this year. "It's a good business, it's just not good for us any more. A lot of people are interested."

GE Capital is widely rumoured to be a leading contender to take over the business in Europe and the US.

David Giroux, a fund manger at T Rowe Price, said yesterday: "The key to the whole [restructuring] is to get rid of the financing business." Yesterday, Anne Mulcahy, chief operating officer, announced a new digital colour copier in an effort to improve revenues this year.

The SEC is still investigating the company for accounting irregularities but Mr Allaire said yesterday he was confident that the company had carried out a proper internal review.

He also offered an upbeat assessment for the rest of this year in spite of a raft of shareholder and employee lawsuits. "The business climate in the US is clearly more adverse but, since most of the issues were internal, by fixing them our turnaround will be forthcoming."

David Giroux, a fund manger at T Rowe Price, said yesterday: "The key to the whole [restructuring] is to get rid of the financing business." Yesterday, Anne Mulcahy, chief operating officer, announced a new digital colour copier in an effort to improve revenues this year. The SEC is still investigating the company for accounting irregularities but Mr Allaire said yesterday he was confident that the company had carried out a proper internal review. He also offered an upbeat assessment for the rest of this year in spite of a raft of shareholder and employee lawsuits. "The business climate in the US is clearly more adverse but, since most of the issues were internal, by fixing them our turnaround will be forthcoming."

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Hats off to BBC2's Working Lunch programme and its campaign to get banks and building societies to stump up for the miserly earnings on Tessas
fields.body:
 Hats off to BBC2's Working Lunch programme and its campaign to get banks and building societies to stump up for the miserly earnings on Tessas (the tax-exempt special savings accounts invented by John Major during the five minutes he was chancellor in 1990). Savers started grumbling about the interest they were receiving on their old Tessas after they noticed that the new individual savings accounts were being offered with much more attractive rates. The programme urged viewers to protest, after a ruling by the financial services ombudsman, and so far compensation worth more than £50,000 has been paid out. A pat on the back to the plucky little Melton Mowbray building society, which automatically compensated all of its account holders. Boo, hiss to Halifax, which resisted paying out compensation. A special boo to Northern Rock, which only compensated customers who wrote more than one letter complaining. One Northern Rocker got a compensation cheque for a grudging £2.96.

 According to the Winnipeg Sun, the Canadian city is the dandruff capital of the world. The city is used at least two or three times a year for research by anti-dandruff shampoo manufacturers. Says Wendy Lazer of Hill Top Research: "We are the premier dandruff testing site in the world. It's one of the things we are famous for." (One of the things?) She is now looking for 350 volunteers for the biggest research study yet undertaken. And you thought all that white stuff in Canada was snow.

 Innumerate Banks Update: we recently carried an item about Lloyds' brave decision to recognise February 30 as a working day. Spurred by this, Dr Carl Darby from Huntingdon (we're attracting a better class of reader these days) writes to highlight Barclays' "Annual Review and Summary Financial Statement 2000" sent by the bank to shareholders. According to pages 16 and 17, the total income from Barclaycard for the year was a mere £1m, the total income of corporate banking was a pitiful £2m and Barclays Global Investors contributed less than £500,000. "Either they are mistaken about what constitutes a big bank or the column headings are wrong," writes Dr Carl.

fields.headline: Last orders for Whitbread pubs
fields.standfirst: In the early hours of yesterday morning it all ended in a £1.6bn sale to Morgan Grenfell
fields.trailText: In the early hours of yesterday morning it all ended in a £1.6bn sale to Morgan Grenfell
fields.body:
At 3.30 yesterday morning, the lights were still blazing at the offices of law firm Slaughter & May, just off Moorgate in the City. The chief executive of Whitbread, David Thomas, was signing a £1.625bn deal to sell the company's chain of 2,998 pubs to the venture capital firm, Morgan Grenfell Private Equity.

"It turned into a bit of an endurance contest," he said. "There seems to be a rule against signing any deal in the City outside the hours of midnight to 7am."

The long-awaited transaction is the latest in a series of sales to put thousands of Britain's pubs in the hands of foreign banks. Morgan Grenfell, which is owned by Deutsche Bank, joins the Japanese finance house Nomura among the country's top four landlords.

It marked the apparent end of a five-month tussle between several of Britain's leading leisure entrepreneurs - including a public row between former PizzaExpress colleagues Luke Johnson and Hugh Osmond.

The saga began in October, when Whitbread announced that, having sold its brewing division, it no longer wanted its pubs and bars, which include the nationwide chains Hogshead and Dme.

Mr Thomas said: "We have to provide what our shareholders want - returns and growth. Things like off-licences, brewing and pubs weren't capable of providing improving returns."

About 25 buyers expressed interest, including the established pub chains such as Enterprise Inns. By the final stages, however, four bidders were left in the ring - Morgan Grenfell, Punch Taverns, Pubmaster and Nomura.

A sudden spat broke out last month, when Punch Taverns' chairman, Hugh Osmond, discovered that Morgan Grenfell had recruited Belgo restaurant supremo Luke Johnson as a potential boss of the pub chain.

Mr Osmond had previously been a close associate of Mr Johnson - the pair turned PizzaExpress into one of the success stories of the 1990s.

Mr Osmond was furious to find himself pitted against his old colleague - he cited a "no competition" clause signed by Johnson as a shareholder in Punch two years ago. Lawyers' letters were exchanged and the outcome was that a mightily peeved Mr Johnson had to withdraw from Morgan Grenfell's bid. Mr Osmond admitted: "I don't imagine I'll be top of his Christmas card list any more."

Meanwhile, a parallel controversy developed as a cluster of disgruntled landlords demanded the right to buy their own pubs. Whitbread refused, maintaining that such a process would be expensive and time-consuming, but the tenants persisted, with support from former chairman Sir Charles Tidbury, a distinguished brewery chief who once survived an IRA assassination attempt.

That debate culminated in an angry confrontation at an extraordinary general meeting of Whitbread in January, at which tenants claimed they had been treated like "lepers" and Sir Charles bemoaned the board's lack of moral fibre

Mr Thomas was unrepentant yesterday: "Sir Charles is a colourful character with strong views. I admire his determination, but I totally disagree with him on this occasion."

As Morgan Grenfell edged ahead of the pack, becoming the only bidder to offer more than £1.6bn, there was a final twist. Mr Osmond pulled a second "no-competition" clause from his sleeve, this time signed by Bankers Trust Capital, which sits alongside Morgan Grenfell in the Deutsche Bank group.

Mr Osmond was scathing about the amount the German bank was willing to pay for Whitbread's pubs: "They're paying more than Whitbread ever expected.

"I don't think they're working on the right run rate - they've never run pubs before and they've got to take into account the cost of things like the minimum wage and Sky television."

He threatened to block the deal, claiming that Deutsche has inside knowledge of Punch which could give the German bank an unfair advantage in high street competition: "They know a great deal about Punch Taverns. Whether the Chinese walls within Deutsche Bank will hold water is far from legally certain.

"We paid good money for them to sign a no-competition clause. If they want to compete now, they need to come and talk to us."

The deal might be scuppered by several different legal challenges - including a hearing in Luxembourg next month at which tenants will claim that the terms of their leases should be declared contrary to European law. Morgan Grenfell, al though unwilling to discuss the transaction yesterday, is adamant that its legal position is sound.

Although it has no experience in running pubs, the venture capital firm has sealed a number of other high-profile purchases, including that of the Italian scooter firm Piaggio and a deal to acquire 12.5% of Bernie Ecclestone's formula one motor racing operation.

Morgan Grenfell's intention is to follow the example of Nomura by running the pubs on an arm's length basis - collecting rent from landlords but allowing them to keep any profits. The rental income will be securitised in bonds sold to investors to generate more capital for Morgan Grenfell to make acquisitions.

The popularity of pubs with banks is down to the slow decline of the neighbourhood "local". Smaller outlets are gradually losing the battle to compete with big, city centre chains such as All Bar One and Slug & Lettuce.

Banks, which want steady, long-term income rather than a quick return, are more willing to cope with low growth. Leisure companies such as Bass and Whitbread, which have both quit the brewing sector, no longer need outlets for their beer.

Of the 2,998 pubs sold by Whitbread, just 193 are high street brands. The rest, in the long term, have little scope for growth unless the new owners can come up with some imaginative techniques to revive interest.

Mr Thomas said: "There's going to be a lot of pressure on neighbourhood pubs. The epitome of the British pub will have to widen its range of offerings in order to maintain its viability."

He suggested that rural pubs could become collection points for supermarket groceries and even offer post office facilities. The decline of such outlets could be hastened by licensing reform - pubs in residential areas are much less likely to be able to open late than are high street chains, which will soon be allowed to open until the early hours.

Whitbread has already been trying out "bartailing" - selling goods such as scooters, Calvin Klein underwear and last-minute Valentine's gifts in pubs. CDs might soon be on sale and on trial are web cameras offering customers a preview of whether pubs are busy before they set out from home.

Nomura, Punch Taverns and Morgan Grenfell face a challenge. Either they explore these routes to revitalise their pubs which could persuade drinkers to remain loyal, or they settle back and watch their beer pumps slowing to a trickle.

webTitle: Bremen's beer is given a chilly reception by angry landlords

fields.headline: Bremen's beer is given a chilly reception by angry landlords
fields.trailText: Drinkers at the Old King's Head in Broughton-in-Furness, Cumbria, will no longer be able to buy bottles of Beck's following the sale of the pub, along with 2,997 others, to the German private equity firm Morgan Grenfell, writes Andrew Clark .
fields.body:
Drinkers at the Old King's Head in Broughton-in-Furness, Cumbria, will no longer be able to buy bottles of Beck's following the sale of the pub, along with 2,997 others, to the German private equity firm Morgan Grenfell, writes Andrew Clark .

Landlord Gary McClure is cancelling his supply of the beer, which originates from Bremen, in protest at the deal: "We will not be having a German night in this pub. This bank will take all the proceeds from their investment out of Britain and back to Germany."

Mr McClure is leader of a vocal group of landlords demanding the right to buy their pubs. They point out that Whitbread describes them as "partners" - a term which they claim gives them a moral and a legal right to first refusal. "We will be taking this to court," Mr McClure says.

He claims to have close to 1,000 publicans behind him, although Whitbread says the number is more like 140. They have recruited a solicitor and are on the point of instructing a barrister.

Michelle Kingley, of the Old Crown in Stroud, Gloucestershire, says: "We feel we've been sold down the river. This is a big, bureaucratic company, and they seem to think they can play with people's lives."

Mrs Kingley, like many other tenants, signed a 20-year lease nearly 10 years ago: "What happens when the lease runs out? They could split the company up, they could sell it on. We've got no idea. They're a German bank - all they're interested in is rent and money."

Under the transaction, Morgan Grenfell inherits a beer supply agreement with the Belgian firm Interbrew which determines the price and range of drinks available in the pubs. Landlords say the new owner could negotiate an exit from this arrangement and go elsewhere for a narrower range of beers at less favourable prices to tenants.

They question whether they will get the same support from the new owner, in promotional material, special offers and cellar services.

The publicans have the support of some industry heavyweights: JD Wetherspoon boss Tim Martin has expressed sympathy, as has former Whitbread chairman, Sir Charles Tidbury.

Sir Charles, who ran Whitbread from 1979 to 1984, be came involved after chatting to the landlord of his local, the Jolly Farmer in Warsash, Hampshire. Sir Charles said: "I'm not a person who opposes change - it's a question of how that change is achieved. It wouldn't have cost Whitbread anything to let these long-serving people choose new partners themselves."

The landlords allege that Whitbread misled them on the level of discounts they would receive for beer in comparison to free houses. They intend to sue for breach of contract and misrepresentation.

Gerald Swinbank of the George & Dragon pub in Bradford, West Yorkshire, says: "We've been kept in the dark about this whole process. What does a bank know about running pubs? A few years ago, we knew where we were with Whitbread."

fields.headline: Bank extends farm loan aid
fields.standfirst:
Tourist industry helped with foot and mouth losses

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tourist industry helped with foot and mouth losses
fields.body:
Barclays Bank yesterday extended its loan break to farmers affected by the foot and mouth outbreak to all businesses - ranging from chip shops to hotels - in the worst-hit areas of the country.

One in four of its farming customers in communities hurt by the rapidly spreading disease have already taken up its three-month break from loan payments since it was introduced on March 3.

With the deepening of the crisis, the bank said its managers would be contacting other businesses which faced financial difficulties.

"As the outbreak continues, it is becoming clear that many other businesses - particularly those operating in the tourist sector - are also being hit hard," said Alastair Camp, a Barclays director.

The bank said it was impossible to indicate how many businesses might now be in need of financial help or what the impact could be on its overall profitability.

Barclays' attempt to show a sympathetic face to troubled rural communities comes after Royal Bank of Scotland donated £1m to charities helping farmers. Royal Bank was also at pains yesterday to demon strate that it would not take a tough stance on farmers who were already operating in a bleak economic environment before this latest crisis broke.

The announcements from the banks come as fallout from the epidemic continues to spread into the wider economy, with profit warnings yesterday from Express Dairies and pylon repair company Peterhouse Group, along with a price rise on some of Unilever's meat snack products.

While dairy herds have so far remained largely unaffected by the outbreak, Express Dairies still issued a trading statement in which it said that continuing uncertainty over the rural economy could add to the company's woes.

Peterhouse, the engineering company, warned that work on pylons had been affected in restricted areas in the south-west and Cumbria.

"The outbreak is bound to have a short-term effect on the group's performance in 2001," it said in a statement. It added that a sharp upturn in business was anticipated as soon as access to agricultural land was once again permitted. The effects of the outbreak were also being felt by companies throughout the rest of Europe yesterday, with Unilever's IgloMora brand - Belgium and the Netherlands' equivalent of Birds Eye - claiming that foot and mouth disease had in part forced it to increase the price of its meat snack products.

The company said it was passing on some of a 35%-40% increase in poultry prices, and a rise of up to 70% on pork.

Blaming BSE and foot and mouth disease for the rising cost, Unilever insisted there were no plans to introduce similar price rises on its Birds Eye range. "We are swallowing the rising costs ourselves," a spokesman said.

In Germany, the farm machinery manufacturers' association, AGL, has warned that its members' sales could fall as anxious farmers in Britain and throughout Europe put off new investments.

"Farmers are uncertain - they don't know how their markets will develop, what politics will do, and some of them suffered outright losses because of the mad cow crisis," an AGL spokesman told Reuters. He said spring was usually high season for buying such equipment but this year purchases were being pushed back.

fields.bodyText: Barclays Bank yesterday extended its loan break to farmers affected by the foot and mouth outbreak to all businesses - ranging from chip shops to hotels - in the worst-hit areas of the country. One in four of its farming customers in communities hurt by the rapidly spreading disease have already taken up its three-month break from loan payments since it was introduced on March 3. With the deepening of the crisis, the bank said its managers would be contacting other businesses which faced financial difficulties. "As the outbreak continues, it is becoming clear that many other businesses - particularly those operating in the tourist sector - are also being hit hard," said Alastair Camp, a Barclays director. The bank said it was impossible to indicate how many businesses might now be in need of financial help or what the impact could be on its overall profitability. Barclays' attempt to show a sympathetic face to troubled rural communities comes after Royal Bank of Scotland donated £1m to charities helping farmers. Royal Bank was also at pains yesterday to demon strate that it would not take a tough stance on farmers who were already operating in a bleak economic environment before this latest crisis broke. The announcements from the banks come as fallout from the epidemic continues to spread into the wider economy, with profit warnings yesterday from Express Dairies and pylon repair company Peterhouse Group, along with a price rise on some of Unilever's meat snack products. While dairy herds have so far remained largely unaffected by the outbreak, Express Dairies still issued a trading statement in which it said that continuing uncertainty over the rural economy could add to the company's woes. Peterhouse, the engineering company, warned that work on pylons had been affected in restricted areas in the south-west and Cumbria. "The outbreak is bound to have a short-term effect on the group's performance in 2001," it said in a statement. It added that a sharp upturn in business was anticipated as soon as access to agricultural land was once again permitted. The effects of the outbreak were also being felt by companies throughout the rest of Europe yesterday, with Unilever's IgloMora brand - Belgium and the Netherlands' equivalent of Birds Eye - claiming that foot and mouth disease had in part forced it to increase the price of its meat snack products. The company said it was passing on some of a 35%-40% increase in poultry prices, and a rise of up to 70% on pork. Blaming BSE and foot and mouth disease for the rising cost, Unilever insisted there were no plans to introduce similar price rises on its Birds Eye range. "We are swallowing the rising costs ourselves," a spokesman said. In Germany, the farm machinery manufacturers' association, AGL, has warned that its members' sales could fall as anxious farmers in Britain and throughout Europe put off new investments. "Farmers are uncertain - they don't know how their markets will develop, what politics will do, and some of them suffered outright losses because of the mad cow crisis," an AGL spokesman told Reuters. He said spring was usually high season for buying such equipment but this year purchases were being pushed back. What's going on? webTitle: Philips' warning adds to hi-tech gloom

fields.headline: Philips' warning adds to hi-tech gloom
fields.trailText: Europe's biggest electronics company, Philips, added its voice yesterday to the growing chorus of profits warnings from the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
Europe's biggest electronics company, Philips, added its voice yesterday to the growing chorus of profits warnings from the hi-tech sector.

The Dutch group said that, although sales revenues from the semiconductor division in the first three months of the year would be some 7% ahead of the same period last time, income from operations would be 10% down on the €241m (£160m) in the first quarter of 2000.

Philips shares closed down 1.8% at €31.95 after hitting an intra-day low of €30.70.

Other technology stocks moved ahead, however. The DJ Stoxx European technology sector index surged 4.56%. Marconi shares were up 25p at 377p, ARM Holdings added 15p to 315p while chip maker Infineon was up €1.63 at €40.5.

Philips blamed the weakness in the US economy and the slowdown in sales of telecommunications equipment and personal computers for the weaker performance. "There is a squeeze on margins and we are also feeling the effect of lower than expected volumes," a spokesman said.

The company warned that it expected its components and consumer electronics divisions would be in the red in the first quarter. It added that its joint venture in Korea, which makes liquid crystal displays, and in Taiwan, the world's largest chip foundry, had also been hit by the slowdown in demand.

The performance of lighting, domestic appliance, personal care and medical systems divisions would be "at least equal to or better than last year".

The warning comes just a month before chief executive Cor Boonstra who, over the past five years, has reshaped the Philips business, hands over to his successor, Gerard Kleisterlee.

Analysts said the warning from Philips had been foreshadowed in the annual report earlier this year and followed warnings from mobile phone makers Ericsson and Nokia and fellow chipmaker STM Microelectronics. Philips said yesterday that it had taken measures to cut costs but there were "no concrete plans" to reduce the workforce.

Theo Kitz, an analyst at German bank Merck Fink, said: "The market was expecting some sort of warning from Philips after several profits warnings by rivals, but we are surprised that the components division is also hit." The bank has reduced its earnings forecast for Philips this year from €2.24 a share to €1.91 a share.

webTitle: Do you suffer from a bad attitude in the workplace?

fields.headline: Do you suffer from a bad attitude in the workplace?
fields.standfirst: Judi James turns her nose up at a Friday afternoon assignment
fields.trailText: Judi James turns her nose up at a Friday afternoon assignment.
fields.body:
Is faux-positivity syndrome rife in your office? Ever find yourself muttering "No problem" between clenched teeth or smiling through meetings when you really feel like weeping with despair?

The happy-clappy Can-do culture swept through business in recent years as swiftly as a kilo of prunes works its way through your digestive system, and with much the same end result.

We joined in with gusto, but now that nod-and-smile routine may no longer be enough. Thinking positively is one thing but papering over serious problems is quite obviously dumb. If something in the company stinks and the workforce are too polite to mention the smell then things can only get worse. Pretence is stressful. We have spent the past few of years enthusing about everything and now the cracks are starting to show.

Paranoid bosses have begun to get picky. More and more staff are seeing the words "attitude problem" on their annual review. But how so? You have stopped moaning; you agreed all that unpaid overtime; you take on more work than you should in an effort to appear compliant, so how did this Eminem-style bad attitude come across?

Well unless the loos are bugged and that stream of projectile invective you would bottle up till coffee break found its way into a microphone on the CEO's desk, I would suggest it was the smaller details that gave you away. In other words, it is not what you said when the boss asked you to start that complex spreadsheet at 5pm on a Friday, it was the way you agreed that got him/her seething.

According to a recent straw poll of mistrustful managers, these are the ways they can tell you don't really love them when they put you under pressure.

The smile: Of course you held it in place, it is just that it became that little bit too rigid. This was because you were trying to smile and gnash your molars at the same time when it was suggested you refill the photocopier for the fifth time that day. You offered a Bob Monkhouse or Tony Blackburn when your boss wanted a Carole Smilie. Go away and practise.

The eyes: Mirrors of stress, despair and utter exhaustion. You say "No problem!" but your eyes yell "Go away and dig a hole and die in it." Plead eyestrain and pop a pair of designer shades on when the effort of acting becomes too much.

The pause: Your boss asks you to do a job. You pause a few seconds longer than necessary before agreeing to do it. This sets managers into a tizz. You should have ripped the work out of their hand immediately and skipped around the office punching the air with undisguised glee.

The vocal tone: Your boss wanted keenness. You responded in a monotone. Or you sounded cynical or sarcastic. Or you may have even appeared patronising. Rehearse the key classic responses like "Right away" or "Consider it done" and weave some sincerity into your tone.

The mouth pucker: One of the best-loved micro that register dissent. Pursing, sucking in or even doing a lip shrug will all let your boss know he/she is taking a liberty. Ditto looking away, tapping the fingers or raising one eyebrow.

The nose sigh: A mouth sigh would be too blatantly negative following a key request, but we will happily indulge in the less obvious but equally destructive silent snort. A short burst of air through the nostrils will send most bosses into a panic attack. It is seen as an act of mutiny. Keep your lungfulls to yourself in future, even if it means holding your breath and grinning until the boss is out of range.

webTitle: What is my legal entitlement to sick pay?

fields.headline: What is my legal entitlement to sick pay?
fields.trailText: 21 March: My employer will deduct holiday and pay unless I have 12 month's service.
fields.body:
The problem

My company, a recruitment firm in the City, has a probation period of 6 month. Following a recent illness where I was hospitalised for 5 days, I have returned to work to find out that, according to my employer, I am not entitled to any sick pay until I have been with the company for 12 months.

They are going to deduct my time off from holiday owed. I currently have only 4 days of holiday left so they will also deduct one day's pay.

The solution

There are two schemes with regards to absence through sickness. The first is Statutory Sick pay and I understand that this is payable by the employer from the fourth qualifying day that you are off - for your fourth and fifth day off work. There is no qualifying period and you do not need a doctor's certificate for less than seven days off. Many employers also have an occupational sick pay scheme which they operate themselves and determine their own qualifying periods. The details should be clearly set out in your company handbook.

The bottom line is that I believe that your employer is referring to occupational sick pay when they say you are not entitled due to your not having been there twelve months. I believe you are still entitled to statutory sick pay - at least for two of the days you were off. This probably won't be full pay for those two days.

You need to check the company handbook and seek advice (from your union or ACAS or even Citizen's Advice).


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: US interest rates
fields.standfirst: Alan Greenspan,   head of the US central bank, the Federal Reserve, has announced a cut in interest rates, for the third time in as many months, to 5%. However, many in the financial markets see it as 'too little, too late'. Derek   Brown explains
fields.trailText: Alan Greenspan, head of the US central bank, the Federal Reserve, has announced a cut in interest rates, for the third time in as many months, to 5%. However, many in the financial markets see it as 'too little, too late'. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
What did Greenspan do?
He cut the Fed's key rate, to make borrowing cheaper and stimulate the flagging US economy through increased business investment and consumer spending.

How big was the cut?
As most market observers expected, Greenspan cut the rate by 50 basis points - or 0.5%. That brought the key rate down to just 5%.

Who is Greenspan, exactly?
The most powerful single person in the world, many say. Every word he utters is carefully examined for nuance; every decision he makes is fraught with implications for the US and world economies.

Is the US economy really on the skids?
Far from it. Unemployment and inflation are both low; consumer spending is high, and the federal budget, after years of soaring growth, is now in balance. But there are other, less tangible, factors in play. Business confidence is sagging, and there is a growing clamour of alarm about President George Bush's plans for swinging tax cuts.

Will the interest rate decision have an effect on the world outside the USA?
You bet your life. Global stock markets are in a state of disarray verging on meltdown. It's worst in Japan: the Nikkei index stands at less than a third of its all-time high, and general deflation is leading the world's second biggest economy close to a full-scale depression. Tokyo has signalled its desperation by cutting interest rates to zero, to stimulate stagnant consumption.

What about Britain?
Business leaders are clamouring for a urgent cut in the Bank of England base rate, to shore up the economy and prevent us sliding into recession in America's wake. Earlier this month, the Bank's monetary policy committee voted to keep the rate on hold at 5.5%.

How is the stock market reacting?
There's doom and gloom on the stock exchange this morning. The key FTSE-100 index is dropping like a stone, having shed some 500 points in recent days to stand at just over 5500. That's more than 1400 points down on the historic peak achieved more than two years ago. As ever, British share traders are slavishly following the trend on Wall Street, which took a pasting in the wake of the Greenspan announcement.

Does it not serve them right?
To an extent, they are the victims of their own greed, especially those who piled into high-tech shares in 1999-2000, only to see their investments evaporate last March in the dot.com meltdown.

But the stock market's gyrations are not confined to tech shares: after a remarkable "bull" run which lasted most of the 1990's, during which the value of shares rose by more than 12% every year, the market has now entered a pronounced "bear" phase, in which prices are under remorseless pressure.

What does it mean for non-shareholders?
Basically, just the same as for shareholders. If you have savings, a pension, or an insurance policy, you have a direct stake in the market. And even if you don't have any of these, you are still liable to be affected by macroeconomic conditions. Your life may not be on the line, but your livelihood almost certainly is.

webTitle: What should I do with my money?

fields.headline: What should I do with my money?
fields.standfirst: Patrick Collinson, deputy editor of Jobs and Money, offers advice to savers concerned about the recent stock market meltdown
fields.trailText: Patrick Collinson, deputy editor of Jobs and Money, offers advice to savers concerned about the recent stock market meltdown.
fields.body:
The London stock market plunged again this morning, with markets taking their lead from a dive in high-tech shares on Wall Street last night. By lunchtime the FTSE100 was down by around 120 points to hover just above the 5,500 level, or more than 20% off its peak early last year.

The market meltdown on both sides of the Atlantic is now beginning to seriously affect the investments and pensions of millions of small savers, placing the small army of individual savings account buyers in a deep quandary. Adverts plastered on billboards across Britain are currently telling small investors to buy an Isa before the end of the tax year, but the market turmoil is, understandably, making investors highly cautious.

Many are still suffering the fallout from the bursting of the dot.com bubble. Last year's favourite Isa choice - technology funds - turned out to be disastrous, turning a £7,000 Isa investment in March last year to £3,500 or less this year.

"WWWin with Jupiter's new global technology fund" gushed one advert last March. The fund has since fallen by 56%.

"Get plugged in. Plus 106% in nine months," proclaimed Framlington for its NetNet fund. It's down by a whopping 75%, cutting a £7,000 investment to less than £1,700 in just 12 months.

"We believe pessimism is overdone and frankly the best thing to do is just hang on," said a Framlington spokesman.

Former technology analyst Brian Ashford Russell said this week: "Sentiment in the market is appalling out there. Just as this time last year the news was about as good as it could possibly get, now the news is about as bad as it can get. We're sorry we haven't protected investors better from this downturn."

Mr Ashford Russell thinks that the plummeting Nasdaq technology index is unlikely to go lower than 1700. With another 100-point fall in the index last night the Nasdaq currently stands at 1850, only a shade above where Mr Ashford Russell sees buyers coming back.

Investment advisers are pleading with the public not to put off buying an Isa ahead of the April 5 deadline, warning that they will lose forever the tax-free £7,000 allowance offered by an Isa. Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of Bestinvest, said: "It is quite clear that a great many investors are ignoring their 2000/1 Isa allowances... but Isas aren't one-year investments and history suggests that buying into weak markets with the indices at low levels is attractive. Investors should be bold and use their Isa allowances."

The Pep and Isa Managers Association recommends that nervous investors should take out a self-select Isa, in which the investor can hold £7,000 in cash for a couple of months before committing it to shares. Alternatively, investors can "drip-feed" their money through a monthly savings plan.

Many small shareholders may believe the steep falls in share prices represent a buying opportunity", allowing them to go "bottom-fishing" for cheap stocks.

But remember an alternative City saying: "Don't catch a falling knife." Just because stocks are cheap, it does not necessarily mean that they are not going to fall a lot further. Many dot.com stocks fell 50% in the three months after their peak valuations in March last year. They then levelled off, but have since plummeted again, falling in many cases to just 5% of their peak price.

One investment manager who believes the bear market has a lot further to go is Peter Webb, manager of Premier UK Smaller Companies unit trust. He says that share prices are finally coming back to realistic levels.

"We're really enjoying these markets. It would be great even if the market fell to 5000. The more markets fall, the more likely it is that good fundamental analysis will return - and the stocks that we are invested in will command a premium," he says.

"The technology stocks shakeout has still got a long way to go. The average price/earnings ratio on the market is somewhere around 19, but historically it has been around 12. I have no idea why people are still factoring in such high p/es," he says.

For investors who believe that the bear market has a lot further to go there is an alternative strategy - buy a hedge fund that can make money when markets fall as well as when they rise.

A number of fund management firms have introduced or are planning "hedge fund Isas" to attract investors after technology funds' fall from favour.

Last month Deutsche Bank introduced its Guernsey-registered Xavex HedgeFirst fund for investors with as little as £7,000, bringing it within Isa investment limits.

Jupiter plans to launch a product in the spring, while funds from Credit Suisse First Boston and Henderson will open this month.

Hedge funds are traditionally private partnerships used by wealthy individuals and banks to achieve very high returns, often by making use of complex financial tools such as derivatives and arbitrage to bet on market movements.

Some experts say hedge funds will become this year's top investment story. But financial watchdog the Financial Services Authority last week warned investors to "think twice" before putting money into " exotic " Isas.

"The FSA is concerned that the rush to take out Isas before the end of the tax year might blind consumers to the risks involved with certain complex products that offer the potential for a high return but often mean a higher risk to capital," a spokeswoman said.

Isas that invest in hedge funds or use derivatives linked to the performance of a complex hedge fund index "are often not suitable for your core investment for the year, particularly if this represents a high proportion of your total savings. They can be difficult to understand, and the costs and charges may not be clear."

She added that some of the funds are registered outside the UK and so individuals may not be covered by British complaints and compensation schemes if things go wrong.

Last year's favourite Isa choice - technology funds - turned out to be disastrous, turning a £7,000 Isa investment in March last year to £3,500 or less this year. "WWWin with Jupiter's new global technology fund" gushed one advert last March. The fund has since fallen by 56%. "Get plugged in. Plus 106% in nine months," proclaimed Framlington for its NetNet fund. It's down by a whopping 75%, cutting a £7,000 investment to less than £1,700 in just 12 months. "We believe pessimism is overdone and frankly the best thing to do is just hang on," said a Framlington spokesman. Former technology analyst Brian Ashford Russell said this week: "Sentiment in the market is appalling out there. Just as this time last year the news was about as good as it could possibly get, now the news is about as bad as it can get. We're sorry we haven't protected investors better from this downturn." Mr Ashford Russell thinks that the plummeting Nasdaq technology index is unlikely to go lower than 1700. With another 100-point fall in the index last night the Nasdaq currently stands at 1850, only a shade above where Mr Ashford Russell sees buyers coming back. Investment advisers are pleading with the public not to put off buying an Isa ahead of the April 5 deadline, warning that they will lose forever the tax-free £7,000 allowance offered by an Isa. Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of Bestinvest, said: "It is quite clear that a great many investors are ignoring their 2000/1 Isa allowances... but Isas aren't one-year investments and history suggests that buying into weak markets with the indices at low levels is attractive. Investors should be bold and use their Isa allowances." The Pep and Isa Managers Association recommends that nervous investors should take out a self-select Isa, in which the investor can hold £7,000 in cash for a couple of months before committing it to shares. Alternatively, investors can "drip-feed" their money through a monthly savings plan. Many small shareholders may believe the steep falls in share prices represent a buying opportunity", allowing them to go "bottom-fishing" for cheap stocks. But remember an alternative City saying: "Don't catch a falling knife." Just because stocks are cheap, it does not necessarily mean that they are not going to fall a lot further. Many dot.com stocks fell 50% in the three months after their peak valuations in March last year. They then levelled off, but have since plummeted again, falling in many cases to just 5% of their peak price. One investment manager who believes the bear market has a lot further to go is Peter Webb, manager of Premier UK Smaller Companies unit trust. He says that share prices are finally coming back to realistic levels. "We're really enjoying these markets. It would be great even if the market fell to 5000. The more markets fall, the more likely it is that good fundamental analysis will return - and the stocks that we are invested in will command a premium," he says. "The technology stocks shakeout has still got a long way to go. The average price/earnings ratio on the market is somewhere around 19, but historically it has been around 12. I have no idea why people are still factoring in such high p/es," he says. For investors who believe that the bear market has a lot further to go there is an alternative strategy - buy a hedge fund that can make money when markets fall as well as when they rise. A number of fund management firms have introduced or are planning "hedge fund Isas" to attract investors after technology funds' fall from favour. Last month Deutsche Bank introduced its Guernsey-registered Xavex HedgeFirst fund for investors with as little as £7,000, bringing it within Isa investment limits. Jupiter plans to launch a product in the spring, while funds from Credit Suisse First Boston and Henderson will open this month. Hedge funds are traditionally private partnerships used by wealthy individuals and banks to achieve very high returns, often by making use of complex financial tools such as derivatives and arbitrage to bet on market movements. Some experts say hedge funds will become this year's top investment story. But financial watchdog the Financial Services Authority last week warned investors to "think twice" before putting money into " exotic " Isas. "The FSA is concerned that the rush to take out Isas before the end of the tax year might blind consumers to the risks involved with certain complex products that offer the potential for a high return but often mean a higher risk to capital," a spokeswoman said. Isas that invest in hedge funds or use derivatives linked to the performance of a complex hedge fund index "are often not suitable for your core investment for the year, particularly if this represents a high proportion of your total savings. They can be difficult to understand, and the costs and charges may not be clear." She added that some of the funds are registered outside the UK and so individuals may not be covered by British complaints and compensation schemes if things go wrong. fields.headline: US interest rates cut to 5%
fields.trailText: The US central bank cut the cost of borrowing for the third time in as many months yesterday warning that the world's biggest economy faced "economic weakness in the foreseeable future".
fields.body:
The US central bank cut the cost of borrowing for the third time in as many months yesterday warning that the world's biggest economy faced "economic weakness in the foreseeable future".

The Federal Reserve Board said that the sudden collapse in the US stock markets had stymied consumer spending and that big business was under pressure.

President George W Bush, in an attempt to clarify his earlier contradictory statements, said he was upbeat about American growth over the long term despite "short-term problems".

But for the many in the financial markets, the move to 5% was seen as "too little, too late".

Within 10 minutes of the announcement, the Dow Jones had fallen more than 10 points, erasing a 46-point gain earlier in the day which had taken it above the psychologically-important 10,000 level.

The US move comes just 24 hours after central bankers in Japan returned to zero interest rates to steady the country's precarious finances.

The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee will meet on April 5 with some economists predicting another quarter per cent cut in rates bringing them down to 5.5%.

fields.headline: Anne Enright's top 10 slim volumes
fields.trailText:
Anne Enright's latest novel, What Are You Like?, tells the tale of twins who are separated at birth and lead dislocated lives until finally they meet at the age of 25.
Anne Enright is also the author of The Wig My Father Wore, and a collection of short stories, The Portable Virgin
fields.body:
Anne Enright's latest novel, What Are You Like?, tells the tale of twins who are separated at birth and lead dislocated lives until finally they meet at the age of 25.
Anne Enright is also the author of The Wig My Father Wore, and a collection of short stories, The Portable Virgin.
Buy What Are You Like? at Amazon.co.uk

1. Chronicle of a Death Foretold by Gabriel Garcia Marquez
This is a perfect book.

2. Heart of Darkness by Joseph Conrad
Unfashionable and troubled, this small novel is written with intense clarity - sentence for sentence it is still more unsettling than many unpleasant books that have been written since.

3. The Newton Letter by John Banville
A reclusive academic becomes entangled in the lives of two women who live in a decaying big house. An exquisitely written, classic threesome: wanting both he gets neither, or half gets them? Or something.

4. Coup de Grace by Marguerite Yourcenar
Another threesome, this time involving two men and a woman on the run from the Russian revolution. The wrong people fall in love and, in a wonderful denoument, the wrong people get killed.

5. Afternoon Raag by Amit Chaudhari
Chaudhari's other books may be even better, but I am saving them for a rainy day. This is the story of a student who comes from Bombay to Oxford. Again there are two women, but in this version nothing at all seems to happen, in the most beautifully modulated way.

6. Eugene Onegin by Alexander Pushkin
For the young girl in all of us. Onegin rejects Tatiana, then falls in love with her when it is too late. An incredibly graceful tale about the elusiveness of love.

7. The Death of Napoleon by Simon Leys
An elegantly sustained historical whimsy. Napoleon escapes St Helena, leaving a proxy to die in his place. When he returns to France, he finds that his great moment has passed.

8. Good Morning Midnight by Jean Rhys
Drink, desperation and the search for a good hat. Jean Rhys is a terrifying writer and here she is on familiar ground as she charts the nervy, banal disaster that is a woman on her way down.

9. The Crying of Lot 49 by Thomas Pynchon
This was the most exciting book of my adolescence: all the big questions packed into a small, highly ironic space. It was the first and neatest treatment of a very modern theme - too much information and the paranoia it provokes.

10. A Kid for Two Farthings by Wolf Mankovitz
One of my favourite books as a child, this tale needs an adult reading to get the full poignancy. It tells the story of a boy in London's east end who buys a crippled goat that he thinks is a baby unicorn.
