fields.headline: Bank extends farm loan aid
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank yesterday extended its loan break to farmers affected by the foot and mouth outbreak to all businesses - ranging from chip shops to hotels - in the worst-hit areas of the country.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank yesterday extended its loan break to farmers affected by the foot and mouth outbreak to all businesses - ranging from chip shops to hotels - in the worst-hit areas of the country.

One in four of its farming customers in communities hurt by the rapidly spreading disease have already taken up its three-month break from loan payments since it was introduced on March 3.

With the deepening of the crisis, the bank said its managers would be contacting other businesses which faced financial difficulties.

"As the outbreak continues, it is becoming clear that many other businesses - particularly those operating in the tourist sector - are also being hit hard," said Alastair Camp, a Barclays director.

The bank said it was impossible to indicate how many businesses might now be in need of financial help or what the impact could be on its overall profitability.

Barclays' attempt to show a sympathetic face to troubled rural communities comes after Royal Bank of Scotland donated £1m to charities helping farmers. Royal Bank was also at pains yesterday to demon strate that it would not take a tough stance on farmers who were already operating in a bleak economic environment before this latest crisis broke.

The announcements from the banks come as fallout from the epidemic continues to spread into the wider economy, with profit warnings yesterday from Express Dairies and pylon repair company Peterhouse Group, along with a price rise on some of Unilever's meat snack products.

While dairy herds have so far remained largely unaffected by the outbreak, Express Dairies still issued a trading statement in which it said that continuing uncertainty over the rural economy could add to the company's woes.

Peterhouse, the engineering company, warned that work on pylons had been affected in restricted areas in the south-west and Cumbria.

"The outbreak is bound to have a short-term effect on the group's performance in 2001," it said in a statement. It added that a sharp upturn in business was anticipated as soon as access to agricultural land was once again permitted. The effects of the outbreak were also being felt by companies throughout the rest of Europe yesterday, with Unilever's IgloMora brand - Belgium and the Netherlands' equivalent of Birds Eye - claiming that foot and mouth disease had in part forced it to increase the price of its meat snack products.

The company said it was passing on some of a 35%-40% increase in poultry prices, and a rise of up to 70% on pork.

Blaming BSE and foot and mouth disease for the rising cost, Unilever insisted there were no plans to introduce similar price rises on its Birds Eye range. "We are swallowing the rising costs ourselves," a spokesman said.

In Germany, the farm machinery manufacturers' association, AGL, has warned that its members' sales could fall as anxious farmers in Britain and throughout Europe put off new investments.

"Farmers are uncertain - they don't know how their markets will develop, what politics will do, and some of them suffered outright losses because of the mad cow crisis," an AGL spokesman told Reuters. He said spring was usually high season for buying such equipment but this year purchases were being pushed back.

webTitle: European stocks fall while Japan rallies

fields.headline: European stocks fall while Japan rallies
fields.standfirst: Europe's markets followed Wall Street's downward turn, but action by the Bank of Japan caused Japanese stocks to surge ahead, writes the Guardian's economic correspondent Mark Atkinson
fields.trailText: European stock markets followed Wall Street's downward turn, but action by the Bank of Japan caused Japanese stocks to surge ahead, writes the Guardian's economic correspondent Mark Atkinson.
fields.body:
European stock markets tracked Wall Street lower today amid deep disappointment at the size of last night's cut in interest rates by the US Federal Reserve.

However, Japanese stocks surged ahead on hopes that Monday's easing of monetary policy by the Bank of Japan would revive the moribund economy.

Following the heavy sell-off last week, which was sparked by a wave of profit warnings, dealers had pinned their hopes on the Fed cutting rates by 0.75% in order to revive their fortunes.

In the event, the central bank opted for another 0.5% reduction, the third in as many months, which took the key federal funds lending rate to 5%.

While expressing concern about the impact of falling stock markets on confidence, the Fed in effect signalled that the real economy was not weak enough to justify a bigger move.

Wall Street fell sharply in the wake of the announcement, and when London opened this morning, there was a knock-on effect on UK stock prices. By mid-morning, the FTSE index had fallen 130.9 to 5515.9.

The UK market may also have been influenced by the release of the minutes of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) for March, which showed a 7-2 majority in favour of leaving rates on hold earlier this month.

With most of the data available since then showing the economy standing up well to the US slowdown, this dampened hopes of a UK rate cut at the MPC's next meeting in April.

Continental European markets were depressed by a weak reading from Germany's Ifo business climate index, which fell to its lowest level since July 1999.

"The data clearly suggests that there is potential for a sharp slowdown in Germany around the corner," said Rainer Guntermann at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein.

The mood in Japan, however, was much more upbeat. Dealers brushed aside the tumble in Wall Street and focused on the benefits of the central bank's dramatic u-turn on Monday, when it effectively revived its zero interest rate policy by deciding to flood the banking system with cash.

Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei average jumped 7.49%, or 912.97 points, to 13,103.94, its biggest one-day percentage gain since November 17 1997, and the seventh biggest jump on record.

The rise was broad-based, led by debt-plagued banks and other interest rate sensitive sectors such as retailers, on the hopes that cheaper credit from the central bank will spur banks to make painful disposals of bad loans while reviving consumer spending.

"The market is applauding the Bank of Japan for its radical steps and hopes the economy can begin to rebound off this," said Nobuaki Kurisu, chief fund manager at Sumisei Global Management.

The broader Topix index jumped 75.80 points to 1,275.41, a 6.32% rise - its largest one-day percentage increase since April 16 1953.

Although the Japanese stock market gains could add much-needed optimism to an economy still wrestling with its worst postwar downturn, economists remain cautious, saying the outlook is uncertain.

webTitle: Thomas steams into rival Bob the Builder

fields.headline: Thomas steams into rival Bob the Builder
fields.standfirst: Tank engine group dubs handyman here-today, gone-tomorrow fad
fields.trailText: Tank engine group dubs handyman here-today, gone-tomorrow fad
fields.body:
William Harris, chairman of Gullane, the children's entertainment group that makes Thomas the Tank engine programmes and merchandise, launched an attack yesterday on Thomas's arch-rival, Bob the Builder.

Mr Harris said: "Thomas has proved he has earning power over a long period of time - that is not the case for Bob the Builder. Bob has a lot to prove in terms of staying power and has a long way to go to become a classic at Thomas's level." He said Bob the Builder could end up a "here-today, gone-tomorrow" fad.

The 56-year-old tank engine, which accounts for two-thirds of Gullane's revenue, saw a leap in its profile last year when Thomas, the feature film, hit cinemas in the important US market. While profits from the film have been modest, a generation of American toddlers now recognise Thomas's face.

Hit Entertainment, which produces Bob the Builder, also hopes to raise its handyman's American profile after making his debut on the US children's network Nickelodeon this year. Speaking after Gullane is sued its results for the six months to January, Mr Harris said he was confident of the enduring appeal of the Thomas brand. "Little boys will always love machinery and want to play with trains," he said. "Producing products for children above pre-school age and into their teens is much more difficult. They can be extremely hard to predict."

He added that Gullane's other well established products - which include television's Sooty and Captain Pugwash - were strongly in demand. Meanwhile, a part- nership deal has been secured with Disney for Gullane's Art Attack television show.

Mr Harris said the company was developing a book publishing arm with with titles including Harry and a Bucket Full of Dinosaurs. Gullane is also thought to be looking at a number of acquisitions, also in the pre-school entertainment sector.

The company posted pretax profits for the six months to January of £4.28m, an increase of 80% on the same period last year on turnover up 78% at £13.26m - excluding direct revenues from the Thomas feature film.

fields.headline: Genus joins casualty list
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Among firms to warn that they could be hit by the foot and mouth outbreak are Genus, which supplies on-farm artificial insemination for cattle, and animal feed and fertiliser supplier Carr's Milling .
fields.body:
Among firms to warn that they could be hit by the foot and mouth outbreak are Genus, which supplies on-farm artificial insemination for cattle, and animal feed and fertiliser supplier Carr's Milling .

Genus has seen its turnover halve after banning staff from making farm visits, while Carr's issued a profits warning on Monday, claiming disheartened farmers were cancelling orders for fertiliser.

Last week GKN, Britain's biggest engineering group, said it had seen a downturn in orders for tractor parts which it said was due to BSE and foot and mouth crises.

Food processors have also warned that rising meat costs were likely to have an impact on business. Devro, which makes sausage skins, said its profits had been hit by BSE and anticipated further problems with the foot and mouth crisis. Northern Foods and leather goods manufacturer Pittards have voiced similar concerns.

Paul Crawford, a senior economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research, said the cost to farming and related industries was estimated at £3.7bn.

However, the worst hit businesses were likely to be in the tourism sector - Mr Crawford forecasts a cost of £5.5bn in 2001.

Genus has seen its turnover halve after banning staff from making farm visits, while Carr's issued a profits warning on Monday, claiming disheartened farmers were cancelling orders for fertiliser. Last week GKN, Britain's biggest engineering group, said it had seen a downturn in orders for tractor parts which it said was due to BSE and foot and mouth crises. Food processors have also warned that rising meat costs were likely to have an impact on business. Northern Foods and leather goods manufacturer Pittards have voiced similar concerns. Paul Crawford, a senior economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research, said the cost to farming and related industries was estimated at £3.7bn.
